HEADLINE: DataBank; 
Dow Breaks Through Pre-Attack Level

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK

 BODY:
Stocks posted big gains this past week, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to its highest close since the Sept. 11 attacks.
 The Federal Reserve's half-point reduction of short-term interest rates on Tuesday, to 2 percent -- the 10th cut this year -- was a big reason for the advance. 
Investors bought stocks on optimism that the latest cut would finally help stimulate the economy. 
 Equities got a further lift when reports emerged on Friday that seemed to run counter to the Fed's prediction that the economy would worsen, suggesting an economic turnaround had already started. The University of Michigan's monthly index of consumer sentiment, a widely followed barometer, showed a November improvement in attitudes about finances and the economy.
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrials rose 284.46, or 3.05 percent, to 9,608.00, the first time since the Sept. 11 attacks that the average had closed above its Sept. 10 finish of 9,605.51. The Nasdaq composite index rose 82.75, or 4.74 percent, to 1,828.48. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 36.21, or 3.34 percent, to 1,120.31. Both the Nasdaq and S.& P. indexes regained their pre-attack levels in October. MICHAEL BRICK

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Consumers Look At Corporate Conduct

BYLINE:  By Reed Abelson 

 BODY:
In the wake of the terrorist attacks, consumers are paying much closer attention to whether they think a company is socially responsible, a new poll suggests.
 About three-quarters of 1,000 people surveyed last month agreed that companies have a responsibility to support worthy causes, a significant increase from the two-thirds who felt that way in a similar poll taken in March. 
And 85 percent of them said the events of Sept. 11 made it "more important than ever" for companies to support their communities. 
 "Expectations of corporations have dramatically shifted," said Carol Cone, chief executive of Cone Inc., a marketing company in Boston. The telephone poll was conducted for Cone by RoperASW, which had also done the earlier survey that polled 2,000 consumers. 
A much larger number of Americans also said that a company's commitment to social issues affected the way they shopped. Slightly more than three-quarters said that commitment was important in deciding what to buy, compared with about half of those asked in March. More than three-quarters of those polled also said they would be likely to switch brands, assuming the price and quality were the same, to help support a cause, compared with about half in March. Reed Abelson

HEADLINE: BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Little Skimping on the Arts

BYLINE:  By Rick Gladstone 

 BODY:
Despite the layoffs, losses and austerity rolling through corporate America, many companies are not pulling back on their financial support for the arts.
 A survey of 100 major corporations conducted by the Business Committee for the Arts, a nonprofit group based in New York, indicates that support for the arts will remain stable in 2002. 
Sixty-four percent of the companies said they would maintain their level of support, 5 percent said they would increase it, 12 percent planned to decrease it and the rest were undecided. The respondents were queried during the week of Oct. 22, and the results of the survey were released today. 
 A separate poll that was conducted by the committee in July and August showed that the record $1.56 billion in business support for the arts that was reached in 2000 was likely to rise by about 3 percent this year. Rick Gladstone

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE LAWSUITS; 
Lawyers' Math in Sept. 11 Deaths Shows Varying Values for Life

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
The salesman was running late that morning. He called his wife to say he was probably going to miss his meeting at Windows on the World. But at the last minute, at 8:47, he called his office to say he had made it to the restaurant.
 One minute later, American Airlines Flight 11 hit the building, the north tower of the World Trade Center. It was 100 minutes before the tower collapsed. He was 29. 
 The other day, a lawyer for the salesman's 27-year-old widow pushed back in his chair at a Park Avenue law firm and estimated how much the dead man's final suffering high over Manhattan might be worth one day in court. In another case a few years ago, he said, a jury awarded $365,000 to the survivors of a passenger who experienced five minutes of terror as a damaged plane careened to earth. 
"You're talking about many minutes," the lawyer, James P. Kreindler, said matter-of-factly. "It should be a large award." Maybe $1 million, he said, for the salesman's final anguish. 
Such calculations are being considered by hundreds of lawyers as they measure the potential value of cases of those who lost loved ones at the World Trade Center, the Pentagon and in the four hijacked planes. 
The lawyers are asking uncomfortable questions. How much did the dead man make? Was the death fast or slow? Were the passengers terrorized by seeing flight attendants stabbed? How hot was the fire?
For centuries, civil lawsuits have tried to answer such questions in dispassionate economic terms. The main goal of a wrongful death suit is to replace financial support to the dependents of a person whose death was the result of an intentional act or negligence.
In measuring the value of a lost life, lawyers often say that dollars are inadequate, but that they are all there is. In addition to damages for economic losses, intangible things, like the suffering before an inescapable death, are given a price tag. Lawyers say they are struggling to analyze how such intangibles should be computed in the Sept. 11 attacks. 
Mr. Kreindler described the calculations in the salesman's case on the condition that the dead man, newly married and expecting his first child, not be identified. 
Some of the victims are likely to file suits against the airlines and others. Most are expected to file claims for compensation under the fund set up by Congress. 
Either way, lawyers say their calculations based on similar cases in the past are likely to be influential. Mr. Kreindler and an associate, Justin T. Green, said they might try to hire engineers and other experts to reconstruct what those minutes in Windows on the World must have been like.
They might analyze how quickly the fire might have climbed. They might use investigators to track down witnesses who saw people jumping from the building to show the desperation of the trapped people. 
"We want to know exactly what happened in the restaurant," Mr. Green said.
Proving pain and suffering is always a delicate task, Mr. Kreindler said. Jurors or other decision makers must be told enough, but not so much as to feel manipulated. "You want to leave something to their imagination," Mr. Kreindler said.
Other lawyers said the pain and suffering claims based on Sept. 11 present unusual challenges, particularly for applications under the government fund. Many questions about the fund remain unanswered, including what evidence might be accepted.
Some lawyers say the chaos and the vast range of terror experienced by so many people at the trade center make it difficult to assemble the details of many people's final minutes. Jeffrey A. Lichtman, a lawyer who is handling cases involving deaths there, said people on some floors, like those where the planes hit, are presumed to have died instantly, which would mean the law would not recognize any suffering to compensate. 
But people on other floors lived for differing amounts of time and in a range of conditions. Rather than force claimants to prove each pain and suffering case, Mr. Lichtman said, "I will be making the argument that there should be a presumption based upon where you were." 
But some cases, lawyers say, will include detailed accounts. Michel F. Baumeister, a lawyer who is representing clients who lost family members at the trade center and on several of the planes, said cellphone calls will help prove the psychological suffering of those who knew that death was coming.
In one case, Mr. Baumeister said, a co-worker will testify to seeing the man trapped in the trade center as others were escaping. The man also called his wife and said he understood his fate.
It is unclear whether there will be opposing lawyers in the cases filed for compensation under the fund. But some lawyers say hearing officers may be as skeptical of pain and suffering claims as defense lawyers. 
In an air crash case a few years ago a lawyer representing the airline took issue with a claim seeking damages for the suffering of two passengers. The families of the dead men argued that their loved ones must have suffered in the short time after an explosion. But a transcript shows that the airline lawyer, Howard Barwick, suggested that the explosion had killed the men instantly, and argued there there was no suffering to compensate. The tactic worked, Mr. Kreindler said. The award for pain and suffering was zero.
In the salesman's case, Mr. Kreindler said, even a $1 million award for pain and suffering would probably be a tiny fraction of the award because death cases focus mostly on compensating survivors for lost support, the amount the victim would otherwise have provided. 
The salesman was a star at work. At 28, he had been made United States sales director for one company and then had been hired away by another. Early this year, the new company gave him an ownership stake, the title of executive vice president and a salary of about $500,000. 
In court, a lifetime of lost support is typically estimated through the testimony of economists. By analyzing age, salary and other benefits, they project how much a person might be expected to earn over a lifetime.
From that sum is subtracted the amount the person might have spent on things like subway fare or country club dues. 
An economist might persuade a jury, Mr. Kreindler argued, that a hard-driving person like the salesman might work well past 70. It was plausible, he said, to assert that the salesman would have had 40 years ahead of him and that he would have earned more than $500,000 in each of those years. In all, the lawyers concluded, the economic losses might be as much as $25 million. 
Some states award families compensation for their own noneconomic losses, like lost companionship. In its September legislation, Congress said the fund should compensate for such losses, too.
The salesman's case "is a very sympathetic case for noneconomic damages because he never knew his son," said Mr. Green, Mr. Kreindler's associate. Possible noneconomic damages in a court case, the lawyers said: $5 million. The $30 million total they hope for would be among the largest ever in a wrongful death case. It is impossible to say whether any such sum could be recovered.
A few days after the lawyers computed what the salesman's case might bring, another lawyer, Alan L. Fuchsberg, was estimating the value of a case involving another man who died on Sept. 11.
He was 42 and earned $54,000 as a clerk in a financial firm in the World Trade Center.
Mr. Fuchsberg said the clerk's case might bring a substantial award for pain and suffering. The office he worked for was on the 90th floor of the second tower to be hit, where there were announcements encouraging people to return to their desks while the first tower burned.
The clerk, Mr. Fuchsberg said, would have had plenty of time to understand his circumstances. "Obviously," the lawyer said, "it got very smoky and hot and unbearable."
But Mr. Fuchsberg said he told the clerk's father to expect a comparatively small award for economic damages, especially if it was difficult to prove that the clerk, who was single, provided substantial support to his aging parents. Mr. Fuchsberg said some claims for single people with no dependents could be worth as little as $100,000. 
The clerk's father, who asked not to be named, said he was stunned to learn the role a person's income played in lawyers' math. "The value of a life is certainly not determined based on earnings," he said, his voice breaking. "We're talking about my son."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A Lawyer's Worksheet"How lawyers estimate the value of a wrongful death claim for a breadwinner. Projected annual earnings+ Expected number of years remaining of working life. + The value of other expected income from the deceased person's labors.- The amount that would have been consumed by the person who died, like expenditures for food, clothing and personal hobbies.+ The economic value of the deceased person's contribution to the household, like gardening work and driving children to school.+ Compensation for nonfinancial losses suffered by the person who died, like the pain and suffering endured by the person because of the injury that caused death.+ In some states, the value of the nonfinancial losses suffered by family members, like the loss of love and companionship for a spouse or the loss of parental care by a child. Total:(pg. B10)

HEADLINE: As Crowds Dwindle, San Franciscans Become Nostalgic for the Missing Tourists 

BYLINE:  By EVELYN NIEVES 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10 

 BODY:
The seals were barking up a riot on their favorite pier this afternoon, barking and clapping and all but doing cartwheels as they waited and waited for the tourists and their famous Boudin Bakery sourdough bread. 
 Durson Senel, a salesman at Web Camera, waited and waited for the tourists, too. So did Nir Riesman, next door to Web at King's Fine Art and Antiques. And Maria Elena Palma, next door to King's at Quality Sports souvenirs. And the bakery workers across the road, starring glumly at the too-crowded rows of loaves at Boudin. 
 Everyone at Fisherman's Wharf was waiting, on a day the sun was warm and sweet and the shops should have been crazy busy. "They used to line up and pack the store for these," Mr. Senel said, pointing to the disposable point-and-shoot cameras, $2.99 and up, in a bin outside the front door. "Sometimes," he said with a chuckle, "it was almost a nuisance." 
The throngs of tourists, San Francisco's lifeblood, are gone. Gone from the cable cars and department stores in Union Square, gone from the trendy bars and restaurants in North Beach, gone, like a summer storm, from the city's hilly streets. The decline in tourism began with a softening economy, hit hard after Sept. 11, and dipped even lower last weekend, after Gov. Gray Davis issued a warning of a "credible threat" of terrorists who might try to "destroy" the Golden Gate and Bay Bridges, among others in California.
Governor Davis's warning, say city officials, cause a flurry of canceled reservations at the hotels and restaurants last weekend and turned tourist-dependent sites like Fisherman's Wharf into ghost towns.
"It was the lousiest announcement he ever made," said Mr. Senel, speaking of the governor's warning, which the F.B.I. immediately played down as uncorroborated and this week called "not credible." 
"It was selfish," Mr. Senel went on. "We were over here thinking" -- he glanced at the Golden Gate Bridge in the near horizon -- " 'O.K., is it going to blow now?' "
Though the threat Governor Davis announced -- that terrorists might attack major bridges at rush hour from Nov. 2 to Nov. 7 -- would have been over by now even if it had been credible, it doesn't feel like it's over on or near the Golden Gate Bridge, the city's most visited landmark. The presence of National Guard troops on the bridges, and California Highway Patrolmen riding back and forth across the span, no doubt reassures commuters. But some city officials say that the publicity on all the security, which has been present except for the National Guard since Sept. 11, sends a message to tourists that the bridges are still not safe.
While 82 percent of San Francisco's tourists usually fly here, the city, like others across the country, has been focusing since Sept. 11 on attracting drive-in travelers. "I don't think people are necessarily afraid to fly," said Laurie Armstrong, vice president of the city's convention and visitors bureau. "But people want to stick close to home in case something does happen." City officials were buoyed when Governor Davis came to Fisherman's Wharf early last month to announce a $5 million statewide advertising campaign to induce California residents to travel within the state.
"And then the governor comes out and says the bridges are threatened," Ms. Armstrong said, "and we're looking at each other thinking, 'What's next?' "
She said they hoped that visitors would come back this weekend.
In fact, visitors are straggling in, if not in big numbers or with deep pockets. But San Francisco, which has long relied on its beauty to get by, is having a harder time these days than many cities less dependent on dazzled guests. Tourism, the city's largest revenue-generating industry by far, bringing in $474 million in taxes and fees, is such a large part of the city's $5.2 billion budget, that its drop in just these last two months, coupled with the dot-com crash, may mean close a $100 million shortfall by the end of the fiscal year.
Hotel occupancy in September, the latest month for which figures are available, shows a drop from the same month last year, to 59.4 percent from 88.5 percent. (In the two weeks after Sept. 11, many hotels had occupancy rates in the teens, the worst decline in the nation.) Nearly 3,000 hotel workers have lost their jobs or had their hours cut. It has reached the point where the mayor has created a tourism outreach plan that includes urging people in the state to come to San Francisco by calling them up and inviting them. 
San Franciscans, slightly disdainful of tourists the way residents everywhere are of the camera-toting, souvenir T-shirt-wearing guests who trample their landmarks, are becoming nostalgic for the crowds. "Just two months ago, the lines for the cable cars would be as long as the block," said Michael Dunn, a 56-year-old writer, as he watched people pop into the Powell Street cable car with no wait at all. "It's a little scary," he said. "First, the dot-comers left, and now the tourists."
Ms. Palma of Quality Sports at Fisherman's Wharf, was sitting behind the register with her head in her hands, thinking of the right slogan to bring the tourists back. "The bridges," she said finally, "are not falling down."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fish and crab stands, ordinarily swamped at noon on Fisherman's Wharf in San Francisco, stood empty on Friday. Store owners say business has been off since the terrorist attacks on New York and the Pentagon. (Susan Ragan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Gambling Law May Mean Salvation for Yonkers Track 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT WORTH 

DATELINE: YONKERS, Nov. 10 

 BODY:
Just two months ago, it seemed that nothing could save Yonkers Raceway. The dilapidated harness racing track, once a gambler's Mecca, had been losing money for years, and the 100-acre property just off the Major Deegan Expressway was for sale.
 Now, in a twist that no handicapper could have foreseen, the track may have been granted a reprieve -- by the Sept. 11 terror attack. 
 Last month, the disaster pushed the New York State Legislature to approve the largest expansion of state-run gambling in decades, to help restore its shrinking revenues. If the law survives the expected legal challenges, it will mean video slot machines at Yonkers, which could draw floods of new gamblers and restore the track's bottom line. 
"It's like God intervened for the gamblers," said Ivan Vass, 70, as he sprawled on one of the couches on the second floor of the Yonkers clubhouse, watching a race on television. 
For Mr. Vass and the other retirees who spend their days laying odds and reminiscing in the track's vast, decaying clubhouse 20 minutes north of New York City, the new law could mean better horses, new blood and the kinds of crowds that have not been seen here since the 1960's, when the track drew 40,000 people on weekends, and 25,000 on weeknights. 
"It's like a morgue here sometimes, like a public library," Mr. Vass said, gesturing around at the other customers, nearly all of them gray-haired men like him. "Now they'll finally have the money to fix this place up."
Other customers agreed. "It's going to keep this place open, that's for sure," said Vincent Casucci, 80, as he sat by himself nursing a cup of coffee in the track's cavernous main gallery. "If they get the one-armed bandits in here they can't lose."
In fact, the track's owner, Tim Rooney, said he planned to start renovating the place as soon as possible. He had been trying to sell it, after years of losses and shrinking attendance. The track's grandstand, which once held 15,000 people, was torn down five years ago, and the clubhouse's third and fourth floors are closed. 
In an interview in his office just after the new law was signed, he was all ebullience. "The potential is just spectacular, not just for us, but for the horsemen, the customers, the whole community," he said. 
It is true that the track's sudden good luck appears to owe something to the Sept. 11 attack, he added, a little uncomfortably. But the gambling bill might have passed anyway, he said, given the slumping economy and heavy lobbying by gambling supporters. 
And the good luck may not last. The State Constitution includes stiff restrictions on gambling, and there are sure to be legal challenges from gambling opponents and competitors like Donald J. Trump, who owns casinos in Atlantic City and has long fought an expansion of gambling in New York State. 
But the gamblers here say they have politics on their side for a change: the state needs the money.
The people who would come to Yonkers to play the slot machines might not bet on horses, but tracks would receive 12 to 25 percent of the take from the machines, with the rest going to the state's education fund. The law also requires that 45 percent of the track's profits from the machines go into purses -- the money that goes to the horse breeders, trainers and drivers. 
Mr. Rooney said he expected purses to double soon after he installs the initial round of 2,500 video slot machines.
Mr. Rooney and his son-in-law Robert Galterio, the track's general manager, talked excitedly about plans for a whole new $150 million building to house the machines. "I'd be very upset if we didn't have the machines in by this summer," Mr. Galterio said.
The new law would bring video slot machines to other tracks, including Aqueduct, a thoroughbred raceway in Queens, and it sanctions new Indian-run casinos in the Catskills and western New York. 
But its effects are likely to be most striking at Yonkers. Once the region's biggest gambling venue, the track is now virtually empty on some weeknights, having lost out to television, off-track betting and harness racing's failure to attract a new generation of fans.
Slot machines have already helped to revive dying harness tracks elsewhere in the country. At Dover Downs in Dover, Del., daily purses were about $7,500 six years ago, and after slots were legalized they shot up, reaching about $130,000 today.
If Yonkers has anything like that kind of success, the breeders, trainers and drivers will profit, too. 
"The entire industry will spiral upward instead of downward," said Joe Faraldo, the president of the group that represents the horsemen at Yonkers, who often drives and trains horses here himself. "The horsemen are overjoyed."
The city of Yonkers could benefit as well, said Mayor John Spencer. The track was once the city's second-largest employer and taxpayer, with more than 2,500 employees (not including horsemen and trainers), but it now has only 500. 
One thing is certain: the prospect has warmed the hearts of some aging gamblers.
"It'll bring a lot of new life, and we could certainly use it," said Michael Morgan, a retired tugboat deck hand from the Bronx who has been coming here since the 1950's, as he sat with a friend in the vast gallery, gazing out at the empty track. 
"We may end up broke," he added. "But we'll be happy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The owner of the Yonkers Raceway, which had been for sale, hopes that a new law will bring a cash infusion. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: World Trade Organization Admits China, Amid Doubts 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: DOHA, Qatar, Nov. 10 

 BODY:
China joined the World Trade Organization this evening, completing a quest that required 15 years of haggling over whether the nation's fitful embrace of a market economy entitled it to the full trading rights of capitalist countries.
 Trade ministers from the United States, Europe and India referred to the marathon negotiations over China's admission as difficult, acrimonious and politically charged, but the admission ceremony was brief and cordial. Michael Moore, the organization's director general, hugged Shi Guangsheng, China's trade minister, as a moderator itemized articles of membership and declared, "The ministerial conference so agrees." 
 Chinese officials have presented the nation's membership as one of their most significant diplomatic achievements since China displaced Taiwan and took a seat on the United Nations Security Council in 1971. 
That step decades ago gave China the political rank of the United States and the former Soviet Union. Today's step ensures China equal status for its fast-growing economy, though in return it will have to grant foreign companies access to its 1.3 billion consumers.
World trade ministers have gathered in this Persian Gulf emirate to hammer out an agenda for trade liberalization globally, and China's admission ceremony came on the second of five days of these talks.
Qatari troops in purple camouflage and security guards wearing flowing white robes and kaffiyehs surrounded a complex on the shores of the gulf to protect delegates, who had been warned of potential terrorist action. There were no disruptions.
The discussions are at an early stage, and few were predicting breakthroughs before Tuesday. The goal is to begin a three-year round of negotiations on virtually all aspects of trade, but there is no guarantee that the effort will not fail as it did in Seattle two years ago.
American and European negotiators who strongly advocate trade liberalization showed few signs of having quelled a rebellion by some developing countries. Poorer nations are demanding concessions on trade issues they care about most before agreeing to discuss the demands of their industrial counterparts.
The most divisive issues include an attempt by India and Brazil to allow nations to violate medical patents when public health is at stake, an issue that pits a broad swath of the developing world against the United States. Europe and Japan are under heavy pressure to remove some protections for farmers, a longtime goal of the United States and many poor nations that want to export more farm products.
Murasoli Maran, India's trade minister, said his nation would stand firm against any new round of trade liberalization if its demands are not met. "We will withstand all pressures," he said.
China's accession was greeted by delegates here as an important moment. But many officials say privately that the long-term implications are uncertain. "I believe that as this century unfolds and people look back on this day, they will conclude that in admitting China to the W.T.O. we took a decisive step in shaping a global economic and commercial system," said the American trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick.
He added, however, that the changes China would have to make to comply with international trade rules remain a "daunting challenge." American officials have argued for years that trade commitments will force China to open areas of business that have been closed or restricted, like banking services, agriculture and retail chains. Beijing, they say, will ultimately have to improve its legal system and remove government from day-to-day interference in business affairs.
Whether membership marks a more profound transformation is another question. Some Western experts predict that open trade and freer investment will act as sea water on a wooden pier, weakening the pillars of the Communist Party's power. For its part, China expects to expand the market for its own export industries while maintaining the dichotomy between an open economy and a closed political system.
Anne M. Veneman, the secretary of agriculture, who is here to focus on farm trade, predicted that China's entry could increase American exports by $2 billion annually.
And though Mr. Shi, the trade minister, echoed the trade-wary sentiments of India and other nations, American officials foresee that China's passion for development will make it a solid ally in pushing for trade liberalization in coming years.

HEADLINE: Terror, Not Election Losses, Worries a Governors Group 

BYLINE:  By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr.

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 10 

 BODY:
When the nation's Republican governors gathered here this weekend for their annual meeting, they put the best face they could on last Tuesday's elections in which Democrats reclaimed the governor's offices in Virginia and New Jersey. And they mostly glossed over the possibility that Democrats might lengthen their victory string next year when 36 more governor's races are held, races in which more Republican than Democratic seats will be at risk.
 But there was no glossing over when the 16 governors who showed up -- there are 29 Republican governors in all -- took up the first two issues on their agenda: terrorism on the rise and an economy in decline. 
 They spoke of unemployment rates that have increased by a third or more in recent months, especially since Sept. 11, with the outlook for things to get worse before getting better. They told of state budgets that have slipped close to or into the red, requiring special legislative sessions to make painful adjustments. 
The governors recounted how they had been struggling to come up with plans to thwart terrorism attacks or to respond to attacks they might fail to thwart -- "not plans to handle things like fires or floods or stuff we already know how to handle, and handle well," said Gov. Frank Keating of Oklahoma, "but things we've never, ever had to handle, and nobody else either, like anthrax and smallpox."
They asked the federal authorities to share more intelligence about terrorist threats with them to help them improve antiterror planning. They called for better coordination of federal, state and local public safety efforts, arguing that ultimately state and local defense was not up to the federal government or the Pentagon but was the responsibility of state and local authorities.
And sometimes they vented frustration. Gov. William J. Janklow of South Dakota, having heard talk about the rounding up, jailing and trial of terrorists, grabbed a microphone and blurted:
"We're in a war, with people who want to kill us. And somehow we're still taking about 'arresting' them and 'bringing them to justice.' I don't get it. We need to kill them until the rest surrender. No lawyers and no courts. Then we need to capture their leaders. We can try them -- and then kill them."
Governors applauded.
The governors mostly chose to see the Democratic wins in Virginia and New Jersey as aberrations -- victories over struggling, lesser-known, out-spent Republican candidates by Democrats who often sounded like Republicans as they ran.
"I'm not sure there is anything more to it than that, no great themes," said Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut.
As for next year's races, the governors insisted, by and large, that there was no need to worry so long as President Bush's approval rating stayed up and the economy did not collapse and as long as progress was made in the war.
But several Republican consultants and pollsters who briefed the governors warned against relying on President Bush's popularity.
"His big numbers don't necessarily mean that you're safe, don't necessarily provide a protective umbrella," said Bill McInturff of Public Opinion Strategies group.
Mike Murphy of Murphy, Pintak, Gautier and Hudrome, recalled that in the 1942 elections after the Pearl Harbor attacks, Democrats lost many seats in Congress despite President Franklin D. Roosevelt's huge personal popularity.
"It's one thing to rally around the president and something else to rally around a party," Mr. Murphy said. "We've got to work on our own message."
Despite such warnings, the governors remained upbeat about 2002.
"We think we are in quite good shape," said Gov. James S. Gilmore 3rd of Virginia.
Mr. Gilmore also is Republican national chairman, a job he may lose given Tuesday's losses. But little criticism of him was voiced here, and some colleagues went out of their way to defend him.
"He's our best fund-raiser, none better," said Gov. John Hoeven of North Dakota. "We need to keep him around."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. William J. Janklow of South Dakota was among 16 Republican governors who attended a gathering in Las Vegas this weekend. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Perspective; 
Reader Responses Continue to Pour Through the Yankee Floodgate

BYLINE:  By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
We have surely moved on. Or have we? The First Fan, by staging a late-inning rally in the New York mayor's race, managed to keep a hated opponent from winning the championship. Yankee management, avoiding the sentimentality it demands only of fans, began the human pruning, weeding and replanting process that will transform the greatest team of our time into the greatest team of some other time. Baseball itself will abandon its traditional premise of being a pastime with a civic subtext by closing down money-losing teams. 
 Yet, traffic to thelipsite@aol.com shows no signs of slowing down. Not wanting to strand e-mailers on the cyber paths, this is not only a sequel to last Wednesday's roundup of responses to last Sunday's "Hate the Yankees? This Harangue Is for You," but a further exploration of a remarkably passionate and thoughtful fandom around the country. 
 One measure of the impact of the Yankees-Arizona World Series is that the jokes have started circulating.
Bob Nathan of Colorado sends the one about the New York first-grade teacher who asks her class to raise their hands if they, too, are Yankees fans. All do except for one little girl who explains that she is a Diamondbacks fan, as are her mom and dad. 
The teacher says: "That's no reason. What if your mom and dad were morons, what would you be then?"
"Then," replied the little girl, "we'd be Yankee fans."
These are, of course, recycled jokes from other teams in other times, but jokes directed at the Yankees have been few and far between. As respondents have pointed out, making jokes about a team with the soul of a General Electric or Citibank is like kicking a steel vault with Jell-O boots. Could attitudes be changing? 
A local Mets e-mail cell has been crackling with missives from Greg Prince, known as the Bard of the Yard, whose post-Series effort was an Onion-like news story in which a somewhat cranky God wondered why Paul O'Neill had to break so many sporting goods and why Joe Torre's sister, the nun, didn't pray for more important things than baseball games. He also declared that despite years of earthly hype, there were no Yankees up where He lived.
The Big Manager added: "You know, I haven't always had the best of luck with serpents and the like. But in this case, I think the snakes worked out just fine."
But the laughter becomes hollow when the truth sinks in. Perhaps in the same pragmatic spirit in which Mayor Rudy Giuliani, a longtime Yankee fan, singled home Michael Bloomberg, who had spent more than $50 million on his election campaign, George Steinbrenner, General Manager Brian Cashman and Manager Joe Torre will discard old players and buy new ones in the best use of a $120 million payroll.
Andrew Sollinger nailed it when he wrote: "The Bomber Bullies were miscast as heroic underdogs, an uncomfortable role for a club designed and continually redesigned like some scientific free-agent experiment run amok -- Steinbrenner does Frankenstein. When it comes to World Series Game 7's, professionalism, poise and pride take a backseat to heart, which makes believers out of both players and fans."
As seems often the case, some of the most pointed messages come from Boston. It is not clear if this is because Boston is America's Athens or because Red Sox fans have been fine-tuned by suffering.
Bob Dame, who says he has been a Red Sox fan since he was 3 years old, writes: "When the Red Sox lost Game 7 in '67, '75, and '86, it was a CHOKE, pure pain, second-guessing and hand-wringing. But the Yankees and their fans are not at all humbled: 'We will sign Jason Giambi, and all is well.' "
Giambi, Oakland's power-hitting first baseman, is expected to be courted by the Yankees (Bye-bye and thanks, Tino Martinez). 
Dr. Richard D. Ginsburg of Boston writes: "I am confused by your harangue because you do such a great job of explaining what is so detestable about the mindless sport fanatic and yet miss the reason why the Yankees are resented. Fans yearn for a return to purity in sports. While the Yankees have a great team, their image also reflects what has gone wrong in sports. What the Yankees have done in this World Series is outstanding, and our country recovered a bit from the character they showed right 'til the very end. But, as long as Steinbrenner and the rest of the team owners continue to play the money game, teams like the Yankees will always be resented."
The "money game" has just begun. Deeming certain cities unworthy of having a major league franchise because of their revenue stream is an economic, moral and symbolic action that will be debated on many levels for some time to come.
On the human level of a fan, please listen to Randy Henrick, who writes: "My team, the Expos, are going to be folded today. That's a tragedy. It would make a better statement to our society and the world to fold the Yankees and save the Expos. I also don't buy into the nonsense about the Yankees being America's team after Sept. 11. Better for the world to see the worst of America, as represented by the Yankees and their hooligan fans, fail in the end. That shows there is hope for us all and, in the end, that good can sometimes triumph over evil, at least metaphorically speaking.
"I had honestly hoped they," Henrick continues, referring to his Expos, "would relocate to Washington so I could continue my passion in a not-too-distant venue. I feel like I have lost a close family member and a part of myself. There is a great void in my life. Major league baseball enticed and teased my passion, energies and life milestones for 33 years and now casts me (and my fellow Expos fans) aside without even so much as an apology or a chance to even say goodbye. Someone should sue."

HEADLINE: Global Warming Impasse Is Broken 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
After four grinding years of negotiations, the final details of a pioneering treaty aimed at fighting global warming emerged from talks in Morocco yesterday, and many large industrial countries, excepting the United States, said they were likely to ratify the agreement.
 If enacted, and significant hurdles still must be crossed for that to happen, the treaty, called the Kyoto Protocol, would set the first binding restrictions on releases of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping greenhouse gases by industrial countries. 
 President Bush rejected the treaty in March, limiting its reach by putting the United States, the largest source of such gases, on the sidelines. At the time, the decision caused some other countries, most notably Japan, Canada, Russia and Australia, to hesitate. 
But after two weeks of discussions in Marrakesh among this group, along with developing countries and the European Union, the treaty's strongest proponent, agreement was reached on a set of compromises. 
"The Kyoto Protocol is saved," Olivier DeLeuze, head of the delegation from the European Union, said after the deal was announced. 
Negotiations were far tougher than those producing every other past international environmental treaty, officials of many governments said, because cuts in these emissions will come mainly from restricting the burning of coal, oil and other fossil fuels, the underpinning of industrial economies.
The industrial countries that sign on will be required, as a group, to cut emissions by 2012 to levels about 5 percent below emissions levels in 1990. That shared target will be easier to achieve, in part, because Russia and some other countries, after the collapse of Communism, saw emissions drop far below 1990 levels. 
As happens to most international agreements, the treaty lost some of its initial vision over years of negotiation between blocs of countries that would be affected differently by its terms. For example, Russia, Canada and Japan sought and gained substantial credit toward their gas targets for the ability of their forests to absorb carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas. 
In telephone interviews yesterday, American officials at the meeting gave no sign that the Bush administration would reconsider joining the effort. "Other countries have chosen their path, and our answer is still no," said a senior member of the American delegation.
Some of Mr. Bush's critics in the Senate, most notably James M. Jeffords of Vermont, chairman of the Environment and Public Works Committee, criticized the administration's lack of an alternative to the treaty. He said that Washington "refuses to take responsibility for its share of the problem."
Most climate scientists say that a buildup of greenhouse gases has caused at least part of the world's warming trend that could lead to droughts, floods and agricultural disruption.
Mr. Bush has said that the Kyoto pact could harm the American economy and was unfair because developing countries like China and India were excused from any obligations to make emissions cuts.
In a statement delivered at the closing ceremonies, Paula J. Dobriansky, the under secretary of state for global affairs, said the Bush administration was still committed to solving the problem, but in its own way and at its own pace. "Climate change is a serious issue that requires real action," she said. 
Nonetheless, the completion of the treaty -- even without the United States and with various compromises -- still represented an important moment in industrial history, environment experts said. 
After a century of growing use of fossil fuels with little regard for the impacts of a steady buildup of greenhouse gases, many experts said, this is the first global mechanism for limiting such environmental harm. 
"It's by far the strongest environmental treaty that's ever been drafted, from the beginning to the end, from the soup of measuring emissions to the nuts of the compliance regime," said David D. Doniger, the director of climate programs for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a private environmental group. 
"The parties have reached complete agreement on what's an infraction, how you decide a case and what are the penalties," said Mr. Doniger, who attended the meeting. "That's as good as it gets in international relations."
Another innovation in the treaty is its unfettered trading mechanism for greenhouse-gas emissions. Until last summer, the European Union, driven by strong public sentiment, had staunchly opposed allowing a country to get credit towards its emissions targets by investing in cheaper pollution cleanup projects overseas. 
But under pressure from Japan, Canada and Russia, that opposition faded in Marrakesh, negotiators said. The goal of such trading is to foster international markets for energy-efficient technologies, treaty supporters said. 
"The Marrakesh results send a clear signal to business, local governments and the general public that climate-friendly products, services and activities will be rewarded," said Michael Zammit-Cutajar, a United Nations official.
To gain legal force, the treaty must be ratified by at least 55 countries, including a group responsible for at least 55 percent of the heat-trapping emissions from industrial countries in 1990. With the United States out, that threshold can be achieved only with the support of both Japan and Russia. 
Russia gave strong signals yesterday that it was satisfied. In a statement made before the meeting closed, Aleksandr I. Bedritsky, the lead negotiator from Russia, said the agreement "opens the path for the ratification by all countries, including the Russian Federation."
Representatives of Japan, where industries are fighting the pact, were more circumspect. That hesitation is natural because Japan -- under the arithmetic of the treaty -- will have to make significant cuts in emissions domestically to reach its target, said Dr. Richard L. Schmalensee, dean of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. 
Europe is in a better position to meet its targets because it benefits from the large cuts in emissions that already occurred in Britain and Germany for economic, not environmental, reasons. The Europeans took credit in Marrakesh for leading on the issue. 
Many officials at the meeting said that Mr. Bush, who is dedicated to building and maintaining an alliance against terrorism, was missing an opportunity to seek an international approach to the environment. 
Dr. Schmalensee said the main benefit of the treaty was not the modest cuts in emissions it set, but the mechanisms and institutions it would create. "It'll build some engagement and the habit of compliance," he said. "This is a first step."

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
Hard Times at Yale, Where the Peace Corps Has a Waiting List

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN 

 BODY:
YALE students are the best and brightest, they go full throttle at whatever they do, and lately, seniors have excelled at worrying. "Everyone's gossiping in the dining halls," says Bethany Lacina. "You hear stuff like Salomon Smith Barney hired hundreds last year, but they're only taking 40 in the whole country this time. Who knows if it's true. But it's preying on everyone's mind."
 "Even getting an interview was hard this year," said Andrew Whealy. Two summers ago, as a sophomore, he had an investment banking internship, and last summer, with the flush economy, figured he could take a break, working odd jobs at Yellowstone park. "Now," he says, "People who took internships last summer are first in line ahead of me." Worried? "Not totally, not yet." He had put on a suit and was browsing the booths at the Yale job fair on Friday. "I notice students are looking for financial stability and safety, like the Peace Corps and C.I.A." 
 Indeed, federal recruiters -- Faith Tagg of the Peace Corps, Amy Mechur of the Federal Reserve Board and Bryan ("no last name please") of the C.I.A. -- were swamped. "I've got something for you; you'll love this," Agent Bryan cheerfully told visitors, handing out free C.I.A. mugs, C.I.A. pens and C.I.A. paperweights. Jittery seniors carried around stacks of employment brochures in their handsome C.I.A. shopping bags. Agent Bryan assured students they didn't have to be language experts to have a bright future at the C.I.A. "Liberal arts majors are a perfect fit," he said. "We need people doing background checks on new employees. We're looking for self-starters, good writers, people with common sense."
A year ago Ms. Tagg would have been delighted to find a couple of Peace Corps candidates here. Thursday she did 13 interviews and had to put four on a waiting list. Students like Rebecca Jaffe are as intense about the Peace Corps as they would be about Goldman Sachs. Ms. Jaffe dressed formally. "You want to make a good impression," she said. "I was the first interview. I'm willing to leave whenever. I'll take any post. I've traveled to Africa, done Outward Bound, slept on rocks. I think with my experience I stand a decent chance."
These seniors were 12 during America's last recession, but are fast learners and were adapting to a rotten job market. Nearly twice as many attended Yale's two job fairs this fall as last year. Erin Johanson had waited too long and spots for a C.I.A. campus interview were filled. So he went to the fair in a suit ("always better to be a little overdressed") and met Agent Bryan. "He was very friendly," said the senior.
MS. MECHUR, 23, an economics major who graduated in June and returned Friday as a job recruiter, felt like Yale Van Winkle. "It's amazing how everything's changed for these seniors," she said. In September 2000, at the start of her senior year, "I already had offers exploding. That fall I had six offers. No, 10. Actually, might have been 12." Investment banking firms offered $55,000 base pay and a signing bonus of $10,000, and said her year-end bonus could be 115 percent of base pay, a $128,250 total. Not surprisingly, 150 of 1,300 seniors last year took Wall Street jobs. Ms. Mechur was that rare business major to turn down big bucks and choose a Federal Reserve Board job for the policy experience. Friday, seniors visited her booth nonstop. "The pay's not bad," she said. "Almost $40,000 a year." Recruiters sounded giddy. "We're enthralled by the talent here," said Agent Bryan, handing out another C.I.A. mug and shopping bag.
Marie Sorensen, an anthropology and art major, took advantage of the boom economy's fluidity when she graduated in June 2000, working a summer job in photography, traveling to Europe, getting work with a temp agency for $21 an hour and returning to Europe. It was like playing musical chairs, and every time she won. Then, just as she was ready for a permanent job, came Sept. 11. For the first time in her life, there was no chair when the music stopped. She moved back with her parents and went to a headhunting firm, but found she wasn't treated like a Yalie. "The guy asked if I'd take a position as an admin -- a secretary! I said you wouldn't offer that to a 23-year-old Yale man. I've been reading this book for women, about how to get treated with respect in the workplace. They talk about doing down your makeup, dressing conservative so you don't get stereotyped. They think I'm some attractive little Yale arts girl, but they'll see. I'm learning, I'm going to baffle the hell out of them."

HEADLINE: Recalling the 70's, Warily 

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
The words have an eerily familiar ring to them. Deficits. Budget gaps. Hiring freezes. Cuts. Early retirement. Attrition. Sacrifice.
 They made up the language of the fiscal crisis, those words, and they are echoing again around New York, recalling that tough time in the mid-1970's when, after years of free spending and fiscal irresponsibility, New York City approached bankruptcy. It stayed afloat, with help from banks, the state, fiscal monitors, municipal unions and a kicking-and-screaming Washington. But though the crisis transformed the city's politics and financial practices, its people felt its ill effects for at least a generation. 
 Nobody is worried about bankruptcy today, but the slowing economy, the collapse of the dot-com bubble and the impact of Sept. 11 have raised the specter of the city's enduring another period of austerity, a return to the days of dirtier streets, legions of the homeless, an increase in the welfare population, a rise in crime, a plummet in the quality of life so sharp that people fled town. 
Those days seem so distant. Could they come back? Are there legitimate parallels to be drawn?
Comparisons are elusive. The experts say that New York City is in for a difficult time because of the ripple effect of a troubled economy and the terrorist attack. Tourism is down, businesses that were forced out of town may not want to return and unemployment is growing, with economists predicting a loss of about 100,000 jobs in the next fiscal year. For a comparison, the city lost more than 600,000 jobs from 1969 to 1975.
If the trend does not reverse itself, the numbers could represent serious trouble. There is another kind of trouble, more psychological in nature. Fear of crime and impatience with bad services drove people away in the 1970's. Today the city is coping with a broader fear, of being a target of international terrorism. How does it even begin to address that, other than with bravado and clever television commercials starring pretend ice skater Woody Allen? 
All that means less economic activity, lower tax revenues, less money in the city and state coffers. Combined with the recession, the picture worries some experts, even factoring in federal help to rebuild the attack site. "I think the financial and economic problems the city has are potentially as severe as in the mid- 1970's," warned Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller.
Felix G. Rohatyn, the financier who led the fiscal rescue effort in the 1970's, agrees and then some, because of the national recession. "I think the financial problems are going to be much greater than in the 1970's," he said.
The consensus: as bad or worse economically. But -- and this is a big but -- against a very different backdrop. The city's underlying fiscal health is good. It could be better. It still has a lot of debt because of borrowing -- legitimate borrowing, not 1970's style -- but too much of it, Mr. Hevesi has warned repeatedly. Nearly 19 cents of every tax dollar goes to debt service. And the city would be in a better position if Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had not spent surpluses generated by the flush years, but instead saved them for a rainy day. 
The city still has one of the most sophisticated and respected budget processes in the country. There is almost no parallel to the mess of the fiscal crisis, when critics who compared City Hall to a candy store could not be accused of exaggerating. For a long time, nobody, including Mayor Abraham D. Beame, even knew how big the city's work force was. Today, updated "head counts" are published in reports and on several official city Web sites.
Then, whenever anyone cried poverty, money would inevitably appear as if by magic; the magic turned out to be borrowing against next year's revenues to pay off this year's debts, again and again and again until the city was barred from the financial markets. Today its bonds and notes are considered good investments. Then the city was able to dig out only with the help of the governor, bankers, fiscal monitors, Washington and its own unions. 
Mr. Beame became a ceremonial mayor -- inconceivable today. Mayors of New York are now international celebrities, as they were even before Sept. 11. "The federal government used to view New York City's problems as a result of its own mismanagement and was unsympathetic," said Abraham Biderman, a city finance commissioner in the 1980's. "Now everyone understands its problems are not of its own making." 
Washington, the city's harshest critic then, is sympathetic now. That stands to help.
But the city will still have to cut services deeply and quickly. Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg has ruled out raising taxes, which he argues would be counterproductive, and the city faces a budget gap of at least $4 billion in the fiscal year that starts July 1. That represents about 12 percent of the city dollars in the budget, compared with a gap of 18 percent in the height of the fiscal crisis, according to the Citizens Budget Commission.
Under the law, the city is supposed to balance its budget within each fiscal year, though given the emergency, the state gave the city a little flexibility: immediately after the attack, the state authorized the city to sell up to $2.5 billion in short-term bonds, to help it recover from the disaster as it awaited federal help. So far, $1 billion worth of those bonds have been sold, and they do not have to be repaid until next October. 
The Giuliani administration is already cutting spending and Mr. Bloomberg will have to go further, making significant cuts, and in very few services since it is probably politically impossible to reduce the number of firefighters, police officers or teachers. That argues for a broad strategy, Mr. Bloomberg said on Friday, involving all of the city's unions, whose 250,325 members -- 14,500 more than when Mr. Giuliani took office -- account for half of the $40 billion budget. 
"Nobody is going to solve the city's fiscal problems without the municipal workers, through their unions and pension funds being part of that process," Mr. Bloomberg said.
He was not specific, but the possibilities are neither new nor complicated: reducing the work force through hiring freezes, and through early retirements and severance packages that would be partially financed with pension fund money. That would take the cooperation of the union leaders, who would have to be convinced that a cooperative deal was in the interest of their members. The unions and their pension funds played a central role during the fiscal crisis, but then the alternative was bankruptcy. 
Making workers more productive could save money, too, an elusive goal for decades. Other possibilities are limited, as Mr. Bloomberg noted at a news conference Friday. "In the 1970's, we had an expense problem; expenses were out of control. Right now we have a revenue problem," he said. "Both lead to deficits. The option of cutting things is less today maybe than then, or maybe it will be more painful."
Options are few in part because the city learned from its mistakes and cannot, New Yorkers may fervently hope, repeat them. For instance, it deferred maintenance of its bridges, let them rust and rot so badly that some, the Williamsburg Bridge in particular, became a health hazard and cost the city a fortune over the years. 
In a way, as victim of its own success, the more disciplined city has less bloat to cut today. In the 1970's it relied on strategies it cannot use again, like having the state take over some city responsibilities.
That is very unlikely to happen again. Nor is anyone anticipating the kind of broad mobilization that saved the city during the fiscal crisis. Mr. Rohatyn strongly advises short-term federal assistance to cities and states. He argues that the city, hit by both the recession and terrorists, cannot can go it alone.
The numbers strongly suggest that he is right, that while this is not 1975, it is not the healthiest of times, either. But though Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Bloomberg and Gov. George E. Pataki want substantial federal aid to rebuild, so far they see budget balancing as a local job.
That lack of a crisis atmosphere is the most dramatic contrast with the 1970's, but the city's leaders are hardly in denial.
"I think we have to be realistic and face the facts that it's going to be tough times for a year or two," Mr. Bloomberg said. "We are going to have to make some tough choices."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Call It What It Is: Subtraction

BYLINE:  By DAVE ANDERSON 

 BODY:
THE new buzzword in baseball is contraction, as in the folding of two franchises. But what the owners want to do is really subtraction. In any math class, 2 from 30 has always been subtraction, not contraction.
 Then again, baseball owners have never had high marks in math or finance. Or judgment. 
 Until free agency was thrust upon them a quarter of a century ago, the owners thought that they, not the players, were entitled to most of the money. And by then it was too late.
Until the players' contracts soared into the millions, the owners never thought about a salary cap. And by then it was too late.
Until some clubs were struggling to survive financially while some clubs, notably the Yankees, were collecting multimultimillions from cable television, the owners never thought about revenue-sharing. And by then it was too late.
Baseball's owners, who expect taxpayers to vote to fund their new stadiums, also have never had high marks in fan-friendliness.
Less than 48 hours after an unforgettable Game 7 in an unforgettable World Series that, according to the television ratings, charmed not just Arizona and New York but the entire nation, Commissioner Bud Selig dropped "contraction" into baseball's vocabulary. With a thud.
Just when baseball at its best was fun again, just when even the most bitter fans had seemed to forget the 1994 lockout that canceled that year's World Series, the owners' vote to subtract two franchises, probably Montreal and Minnesota, took all the fun out of it. Again.
The owners don't seem to understand that their management system is what needs to be eliminated, not two franchises.
The owners' arrogance also needs to be eliminated. Selig talked about lopping off two franchises without ever talking to the players' union about it just when the already difficult negotiations for a new collective-bargaining agreement are about to begin.
You would think that instead of alienating the union on the eve of negotiations, Selig and the owners would try to create at least a cordial relationship by informing the union about the plans for subtraction.
The union's role would involve the method of dispersement of most of the 50 players on the two teams to the other clubs, presumably in a draft in the inverted order of the standings in the recent season. The two teams' minor league players would also be affected.
In their arrogance, the owners have yet to realize, with some utility infielders making millions, that baseball's players union is the most powerful in sports.
The owners have only themselves to blame for the union's muscle. With two or three owners always willing to ante up more and more millions for Alex Rodriguez last year or for Barry Bonds and Jason Giambi this year, salaries keep soaring higher and higher. Maybe the current economy will subdue this year's free-agent auctions somewhat, but probably not much.
For all practical purposes, baseball's management system is really baseball's management chaos.
In pro football and pro basketball, a salary cap has maintained some sense of order among the multimillion contracts. But baseball's union is too strong to allow the owners any semblance of order. The owners' only solution is revenue-sharing. Without it, more subtraction is inevitable. Two more franchises in a year or two, two more franchises in four or five years.
Revenue-sharing is why the N.F.L. is so healthy even with a salary cap. Without each team sharing equally for four decades from what is now a billion-dollar television contract, the Green Bay Packers franchise would be somewhere else or nowhere else. Several other franchises would be gone, too. Instead, the Packers not only live, they thrive.
But until the Yankees and baseball's other big-market franchises agree to share at least some of the wealth with the small-market franchises, the small-market franchises will suffer. And more will die.
The Expos have had several blue-chip players, like Pedro Martinez and Moises Alou, but let them depart as free agents because the club couldn't afford to pay them anywhere near market value. Year by year, the Expos, who were leading the National League East before the 1994 lockout, got worse and worse, eventually disillusioning whatever baseball fans Montreal had.
Even so, the Expos franchise could be moved to, say, northern Virginia rather than subtracted.
Minnesota is different. Unlike the Expos, the Twins franchise, which originated in Washington a century ago, has a rich history. It won the World Series as recently as 1991. It has Hall of Fame names: Walter Johnson, Harmon Killebrew, Rod Carew, Kirby Puckett. With revenue-sharing, it would be able to endure the way the Packers have in pro football.
Instead, the owners plan to subtract both the Twins and the Expos. In a year or two, they'll subtract, say, Florida and Tampa Bay. That's baseball's idea of progress.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL; 
Bitter Rivalry Endures in Cozy Setting

BYLINE:  By JOE DRAPE 

 BODY:
The conversation was silenced now that the 116th meeting of Williams and Amherst was in overtime with the Ephs and the Lord Jeffs knotted, 17-17. They were deadly serious in the corner of this East Side bar. Kevin Kelly, a psychiatrist and 1972 Williams graduate, studied the big screen with practiced concentration.
 Wedged against the wall, John Marion, Amherst class of '55 and a manufacturing executive, straightened his purple Lord Jeffs' sweatshirt and tugged the bill of his matching cap. One bar stool down, Robin Paul, who graduated from Williams in 1999 with majors in economics and philosophy but now plays a cheerleader on the television series "Ed," banged her hand on the mahogany, imploring the Ephs defense. 
 Forget Texas-Oklahoma, Alabama-Auburn or Michigan-Ohio State, The Biggest Little Game in America was about to turn the aptly named barroom Ship of Fools into a room full of either heartbroken or ecstatic football fools.
Kevin Drakeford worried about what he called the script, which he first experienced as an Amherst running back in the early 90's and now seems to roll in a continuous loop: the Lord Jeffs grab a halftime lead, only to relinquish it in the second half.
"I've been heartbroken so many times that I know I can't count on us holding on," confided Drakeford, a financial consultant. He said this despite Amherst's 17-7 halftime lead, which had the hundred or so Lord Jeff fans slinging their beers in a barroom crowded with another 50 or so Ephs fans. "You got to go back to Yogi Berra: 'It ain't over till it's over.' "
It is complicated to explain how a couple of New England Division III teams with nonscholarship players can turn out a couple of hundred "Deeee-fense" chanting alumni for a civilized barroom brawl, not only in Manhattan but in more than 50 sites ranging from Atlanta to Hong Kong.
But a couple of fun facts might help. 
Williams College, which played host to yesterday's game at Weston Field in Williamstown, Mass., was founded in 1793 and named for Colonel Ephraim Williams (thus the nickname Ephs, pronounced EE-fs). Amherst was born when Zephaniah Swift Moore, Williams's second president, left and created the college on the other side of the Berkshires. The first building at Amherst is a direct copy of the first building at Williams, earning forever the enmity of the Williamstown faithful that still call them The Defectors.
Each school boasts famous alumni from on and off the gridiron. Williams sent Jack Maitland to the Baltimore Colts; Amherst sent Doug Swift to the Miami Dolphins. Each counts a United States president among its graduates, James Garfield for Williams and Calvin Coolidge for Amherst.
During yesterday's telecast at the bar, partisans for both schools were reminded of a recent product of the rivalry: George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees. In 1951, Steinbrenner, then the sports editor for the Williams student newspaper, predicted an Ephs rout of the Lord Jeffs. He was right as Williams won, 40-7.
"You are indoctrinated into a hatred for Williams," said Cam Hicks, a 1995 Amherst graduate now working on Wall Street.
This bitterness cuts both ways, especially for the current and the former football players. Mike Osnato was a wide receiver for the Ephs until his graduation in 1994. He arrived at the Ship of Fools early for prime seating and explained some of the traditions. One of them is the address given during the week of the big game by the longtime Williams assistant coach and administrator Renzie Lamb.
The preamble may vary year to year, but Lamb's crescendo is virtually the same. It goes something like this: "If you wish to be happy for an hour, get intoxicated. If you wish to be happy for three days, get married. If you wish to be happy for eight days, kill your pig and eat it. If you wish to be happy forever, beat Amherst."
The one tradition Osnato wanted desperately repeated as Williams tried to finish off the Lord Jeffs in overtime was The Walk. It occurs only after Williams defeats Amherst and entails the Ephs marching up Williamstown's Spring Street, in full pads, helmets on, to a local barbershop. Once there, the shades are pulled as members of the team light cigars, pop beers, sing fight songs and, well, watch a teammate or two get their head shaved. "Especially for seniors, it's the best way to end your career" said Osnato, a Manhattan attorney.
Fortunately for Osnato, Williams running back Tyler Shea made The Walk possible when he bowled over the goal line to give the Ephs a 23-20 overtime victory. It left Drakeford muttering once more about The Script. It turned Paul into the cheerleader she plays on television. It sent Marion out the door onto Second Avenue.
"Congratulations," he said to his bar mates. "See you next year."

GRAPHIC: Photos: John Marion, a graduate of Amherst, saw his team take Williams to overtime, only to lose and fall to 7-1.; Williams fans had reason to cheer yesterday at the bar Ship of Fools, on Second Avenue between 82nd and 83rd Streets. (Photographs by Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
Forget the World; Fight Contraction

BYLINE:  By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
THE United States is at war and Major League Baseball says it will eliminate two sickly teams and politicians around the country have begun to cry out against the owners' proposed euthanasia. It is so heartening to know that our nation has grasped the lessons of Sept. 11 and has all its priorities in working order.
 Just two months ago, we were in heated debate about baseball's mere place in our sudden crisis culture, grappling with our guilt for even caring about when the season should resume and El Duque's condition and the long nights of the postseason to come. Are there any fewer people missing or dead? Is the country less jittery after the anthrax attacks? Are the increasing odds of a ground-troops buildup in Afghanistan bringing more comfort for the coming cold winter? 
 Forget all that. Forget whether airport security workers should become federal workers with standardized training and decent pay. Forget how and if the economy can be invigorated. Forget rising unemployment and shelved issues like education, Social Security and health care. Let's have a sit-in and chant defiantly in support of the Montreal Expos and the Minnesota Twins.
"This unprecedented decision is bad for the fans, bad for the players on the field and the workers and businesses at and around the stadium, bad for the minor league teams that will also be cut loose, and bad for the cities that will be forced into new and more costly bidding wars to avoid being dumped by baseball," complained John Conyers, a Michigan congressman and the highest-ranking Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee. "This is like a game of musical chairs -- two teams will be left standing and fans will be left out in the cold."
Actually, baseball's move to contract is more about the folding of broken chairs and a conceptual admission that professional sports is subject to the same economic cycles as the rest of the country and that its long era of unrestrained growth is over.
Unlike major league players, most fans are not holding guaranteed contracts worth millions of dollars. Most fans work for companies shredding jobs at a rate that makes the baseball owners look like labor leaders for trying to contract by only two. Where are these politicians who now threaten baseball's antitrust exemption when one of our humanist corporations lays off 10,000 "fans" to protect itself on the stock exchange?
On whose side have they generally been during the era of expansion when public money that could have been used to rebuild schools went for new stadiums whether or not the fans voted to use public tax dollars? The sad truth is that when government mixes with professional sports, "fans" are seldom a consideration. Self-interest prevails. 
As Senator Byron Dorgan, a North Dakota Democrat, claims to have recently told Commissioner Bud Selig, "I don't much care what you do, but don't you try to shut down the baseball team in Minnesota or you're going to have a huge problem with me." Be his guest, in other words. Dump the Florida Marlins. Their fans will never cost him an election.
It is, of course, a myth that politicians are held accountable for the disappearance of a sports franchise. New Yorkers couldn't tell you who the mayor was when the Dodgers and Giants left town. Had the Yankees bolted for New Jersey on Rudy Giuliani's watch, believe me, we would have had no problem fingering the culprit. 
Politicians typically use their local teams to promote themselves for the same reason celebrities pull strings to get those camera-friendly courtside seats at Madison Square Garden. Sports have become a cheap cliche, a device to cast oneself as part of the crowd, as the average guy on the street. Once again, where were the politicians all these years while Joe Fan was being squeezed out of the ballparks and arenas, or up to the nose-bleed sections, to make room for the shrimp-eaters in the luxury suites? Where is the alarm when the games disappear from free television, or when the owner becomes the broadcaster, and the earning synergy grossly inflates your monthly cable bill?
Understandably, Senator Paul Wellstone, a Minnesota Democrat, has to express outrage over the potential folding of the Twins. But when he tells the owners, "You might get people angry enough and lose the exemption," which people is he talking about? The few thousand in French-speaking Quebec who still remember the difference between hits, runs and errors? For every fan in Montreal and Minnesota who may have to mourn the loss of major-league baseball, there are at least tens of thousands in every remaining city who will rejoice at not having to pay wallet-emptying prices to watch minor-league pushovers pose as major-league teams.
Contracting by two won't solve baseball's competition and credibility gap and it surely won't expedite a collective bargaining agreement with the intractable players' union. But it's about time someone stood up and admitted that as an industry, sports has become a bloated festival of greed, all principals included, at the expense of the fan.
From baseball to bowl games, sports have become overdone and overindulged. Contraction was bound to begin somewhere. My advice to the politicians is to not get too bothered by the economics of our relatively sound industry of escapism. Go figure out a way to save the airline industry and the Postal Service.

Negotiators Finish Details Of Pioneering Climate Pact
The final details of the Kyoto Protocol, a treaty aimed at fighting global warming by restricting releases by industrialized countries of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping greenhouse gases, emerged from talks in Morocco. Many large industrial countries said they were likely to ratify the agreement, including Japan, Canada, Russia, and Australia, which had hesitated after President Bush rejected the treaty last March. Prime Minister John Howard, who took a hard-line stance against illegal immigration and emphasized his support for the American-led war against terrorism, won a third term in national elections that focused on security and immigration issues. His Liberal Party won 67 seats of 150 seats in Parliament; the rival Labor Party won 65 seats. A15

Somalia Faces Terror Charges
Somalia's weak government has vowed to root out terrorism and says it takes seriously American allegations that fundamentalists inside Somalia have aided Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network. Still, the country is not persuaded that its struggling citizens are secretly planning attacks against the United States. A3

Montesinos, after President Alejandro Toledo requested their release. Mr. Montesinos remains a threat to Peru's fledgling democracy, Mr. Toledo said in an interview. A4

Some Animal Rights Groups Are Stepping Up Protests

Shadow of 70's Crisis Hangs Over City Again
A combination of the slowing economy, the collapse of the dot-com bubble and the impact of the attacks on the World Trade Center has raised the specter of New York City enduring another period of austerity much like that of the 1970's, though comparisons are elusive. A1

City Will Drop Charges
Charges against all but one of the firefighters arrested during a raucous demonstration at ground zero on Nov. 2 will be dropped, city officials said, in a gesture to help restore the close relationship forged between police officers and firefighters in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. The move comes in the midst of a continuing struggle between firefighters and the city over how many firefighters should be permitted at the World Trade Center site to help search for the remains of their colleagues, 343 of whom died in the disaster.
