HEADLINE: Word for Word/Weights and Measures; 
In the Aftermath of Terror, Grab a Calculator and Tally Forth

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
MEASURING the impact of the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon has become a relentless exercise among economists, politicians, journalists, historians and everyday people. In its simplest terms, taking numeric stock of damages and changes is the necessary stuff of recovery --the basis for making decisions on the allocation of funds, the adjustment of interest rates, or at a more mundane level, whether to take that holiday trip to the Big Apple. But the counting ritual is also therapeutic -- a means for getting a handle on events that may still feel wildly out of control. 
 It wasn't until I saw the second jetliner smash into the second tower that it really dawned on me: Terrorists were intent on destroying our society and our economy, wrote Richard Berner, the chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley, in an essay for the National Association of Business Economics. 
 Would they succeed? he asked. 
 Not likely, but there's no doubt the attacks --which arrived in the midst of an already slowing economy --have had an impact on everything from the unemployment rate to what we eat and where we eat it. Following is a motley collection of readings taken from all levels of society since Sept. 11.
 JAYSON BLAIR

REBUILDING -- In New York, three weeks after Sept. 11, the city comptroller's office released a report estimating the local economic cost of the attack at $90 billion to $105 billion over the next three years. The numbers included, among other things, $42 billion for cleanup and security, $4 billion in lost rent and wages from jobs relocating out of the city and $82 million in lost parking violation fees because of street closures.

RECOVERING -- The United States Navy reports that the hospital ship Comfort, which spent three weeks following the attacks docked at a pier on the Hudson River, provided 17,000 meals; washed 4,400 pounds of laundry for New Yorkers, rescue workers and other guests; gave 13,058 massages; and issued 227 haircuts.

MISBEHAVIOR -- Crime in New York City in the month of October dropped 13 percent compared with the same time period last year, officials said. In the precinct around the World Trade Center, crime is down 23 percent.

GETTING INVOLVED -- Job applications at federal intelligence agencies are way up. The Central Intelligence Agency received 26,000 applications since the attack -- about seven times more than it did during the same period last year. The National Security Agency, another arm of the intelligence community, has received 19,000 resumes --about three times as many as during the same time period last year.

THE SHOW MUST GO ON -- Broadway theaters lost $3 million to $5 million the week after the attack, but have bounced back to about 90 percent of projections made earlier this year by the League of American Theaters.

THE SMALL SCREEN -- Movie ticket sales are down and video rentals are up --with comedies topping most lists. Some stores in Manhattan have reported that rentals have increased by as much as 40 percent since the attacks.

COUCH POTATOES -- Officials at The Wiz, a chain of electronics stores in the New York region, report that sales of televisions are off the charts.

BAILOUTS -- In 2000, one of the largest government bailouts was of the apple industry, which received a total of $136 million. Since Sept. 11, the government has approved a $15 billion airline industry bailout, and is considering billions more for Postal Service and insurance industry bailouts.

STOCKS -- The best and worst performing industries since the month before the attacks:

I.P.O.'s -- Initial public offerings of stock are considered a crucial indicator of the health of the financial markets. According to IPO.com, there were 28 initial public offerings of stock by companies in September 2000, compared with zero in September 2001. In October, the numbers improved slightly. There were 26 initial offerings in October 2000, compared with 7 in October 2001.

LAYOFFS -- The airline industry alone has laid off more than 100,000 people since Sept. 11 and economists estimate that in total, more than 360,000 people have lost their jobs thus far.

LEARNING CURVES -- Since the attacks, Penguin Classics has printed more paperback copies of its English translation of the Koran --about 20,000 --than it sold all of last year.

FOOD FALLOUT -- Many people, particularly in those areas most affected by the attacks, are staying home for diner. The Restaurant Trade Association of New York reports business is down about 40 percent in Manhattan since the attacks. Meanwhile, officials at the fast food chain White Castle report that sales of its Cave Case -- a take-home pack of 30 mini-hamburgers in a box --are 14 percent above their projections since the attack.

JUST DESSERTS -- Tentation, a French catering company with offices in New York, has produced 500 chocolate I Love New Yorkcookies.

OUT OF LUCK -- In the months before the attacks, gambling revenue in Atlantic City was down only 1 percent compared with last year. But after the attacks, casinos there suffered a 6 percent drop in revenue. They brought home $354.2 million in September, compared with $377.9 million during the same month last year.

AIRPORT CONFISCATIONS -- With tighter carry-on restrictions in place, security officials at Los Angeles International Airport have confiscated an average 5,000 offending items a day, including straight razors, ice picks, cigarette cutters and tweezers. That's more than double the levels for the same period last year.

BUYER'S MARKET -- In Battery Park City, the neighborhood just west of ground zero, apartments are now discounted up to 30 percent.

BARRIERS -- A Maryland company that makes 5,000-pound steel-reinforced concrete barriers, which are commonly used to protect public buildings, reports that sales have tripled.

MAKE MY DAY -- Gun sales in California, which has some of the most restrictive weapons laws in the country, have surged 30 percent in the wake of the attacks. The state attorney general's office reports that sales of handguns, rifles and shotguns combined have steadily averaged about 9,000 per week.

DEEP BREATHING -- Military Outdoor, a large supplier of military surplus items based in Greenville, Tex., reported sales of 39,000 gas masks to retail stores from Sept. 11 to the end of the month. The company reported just 250 sales in the same period last year.

MENTAL HEALTH MONEY -- Federal money given to the states affected by the attacks for mental health and substance abuse counseling: $28 million.

TAKING THE EDGE OFF, BOTH ILLEGALLY -- Marijuana seizures along the United States-Mexico border in Arizona were up 36 percent to more than 2,500 pounds from Sept. 11 to Oct. 1, law enforcement officials reported.

AND LEGALLY -- Prescriptions for Zoloft, Prozac and other antidepressant and antianxiety drugs have soared since the attacks, according to NDCHealth, a health care company. In Washington, prescriptions for antianxiety and antidepressant drugs were up 13 percent, while prescriptions for sleep aids were up 13 percent. In Manhattan, visits to mental health clinics were up 50 percent.

RUBBED THE RIGHT WAY -- At the five Spa Sydell locations in the Atlanta area, massages are up 8 percent.

HEADLINE: Back Issues 

BYLINE:  By Loren Graham; Loren Graham's most recent book is "What Have We Learned About Science and Technology From the Russian Experience?"

 BODY:
 THE AGE OF SCIENCE
What Scientists Learned in the 20th Century.
By Gerard Piel.
Illustrated by Peter Bradford.
460 pp. New York:
A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book/
Basic Books. $40.
 In May 1948 Gerard Piel, a former science editor for Life, started a new science magazine bearing the purchased title of a moribund periodical, Scientific American. Within a few years he and several associates created a model for science journalism that has had worldwide influence. By 1986 Scientific American had a circulation of over a million and was printed in English and nine other languages.
The distinguishing characteristics of Piel's science journalism were a conviction that science is both objective and a social good, a refusal to talk down to his audience and careful, even lavish illustrations and photographs. His ideal reader was a scientist seeking knowledge outside his or her own field. He often enlisted scientists as authors, coaxing them with meticulous editing to find ways of explaining their recent work to intelligent people with other backgrounds. A nonscientist (he was an undergraduate in history at Harvard), Piel educated himself in science at the same time he promoted and edited informative overviews of recent scientific developments, which the editors of journals serving the individual scientific disciplines did not do. 
Piel, who retired as the publisher of Scientific American 15 years ago, now presents us with a synthesis of scientific knowledge drawing on issues of the magazine during the last 53 years. He describes his new book as "what I have learned about what scientists learned in the 20th century." The main sections are "Light and Matter," "Space and Time," "The Living Cell," "Earth History and the Evolution of Life" and "Tools and Human Evolution." The resulting book is somewhat similar to a text for general science at the advanced high school or elementary college level, but infinitely more interesting. As Piel observes, such texts usually have an author named "Dull." Piel is anything but dull.
Impressive as this work is, however, it bears the stamp of the times in which Scientific American was born. Immediately after World War II, most educated American readers agreed wholeheartedly with Piel that science was truth and "offers the example of reason, tolerance and individual autonomy." He still subscribes to this view, and gives us an optimistic vision of the fate of the world if we can all only learn to think and act like natural scientists.
In his discussion of the future, Piel strongly emphasizes "the demographic transition," the coming stabilization of the world's population as a result of increasing education and development. He correctly notes that in most industrialized and highly educated societies, fertility has fallen to, or below, the replacement rate of two children per childbearing female lifetime, and he cheerfully predicts that all countries will be in the same situation before the end of this century. 
He endorses Jacob Bronowski's rebuke of foreign-policy makers for not letting "the tolerance or the empiricism of science enter the parochial rules by which we still try to prescribe the behavior of nations." Does he actually believe that natural scientists have better insights into the religious, ethnic and economic passions of the world than people who have spent their lives studying them?
In the years since Piel began writing about science in 1938, his readers have become much more sophisticated. At that time many Americans thought that science was an unproblematic positive force; the most difficult questions connected with it were the technical issues themselves. If we could just get the technical details straight, other problems would solve themselves.
Recent public opinion polls show that Americans are still usually enthusiasts for science, but they no longer believe that the most difficult problems concerning science are in the body of science itself; those problems are in the ways in which science interacts with society. In a time
of discussions of cloning, bioterrorism, global warming, stem cell research, nuclear energy, genetically modified crops and euthanasia, educated citizens have learned that knowledge of the basic science involved is only a necessary, not a sufficient, condition for intelligent decisions. Furthermore, Americans have learned that in such controversies scientists often disagree with one another. While they have not turned against science or scientists, they now recognize that scientists, like all other people, are involved in rivalries and disputes in which reason and tolerance are not as obvious as they were to Piel when he began his magazine. Citizens in the new millennium feel a need for a new kind of science journalism that will neither praise nor condemn science, but instead help them sort their way through these extremely difficult issues. Asking scientists to explain recent developments in their fields, as Piel did so well, is no longer adequate.
AT the moment this new need is not being well served. One logical source of help would be historians and philosophers of science, as well as the specialists in our universities in programs called "Science, Technology and Society." With few exceptions, however, these scholars are interested only in talking to one another, not in communicating with the larger public. The sociologists of science, in particular, have developed an arcane jargon about the "sociology of scientific knowledge" (S.S.K.) that only the most avid veteran of academic disputes is willing to follow. (I should admit that I am a member of the editorial board of one of the main journals in the field, and therefore shoulder some of the blame.) And science journalists, by and large, have not adequately appreciated the new need and do not usually have appropriate backgrounds in science, ethics and politics to pursue these issues in a way that helps citizens develop more informed opinions.
When Piel and his colleagues created Scientific American over a half-century ago, he correctly saw the need for a magazine that would transcend the specialist science journals and offer overviews for educated lay people of developments in the individual scientific disciplines. He succeeded brilliantly. Let us hope that another such talented journalist of the sciences will emerge in the near future who will respond to the need of the new century and give us similarly informed descriptions and analyses of how science and technology are interacting with the society around us.

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 32

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks 

BYLINE:  By Scott Veale

 BODY:
 QUARREL & QUANDARY: Essays, by Cynthia Ozick. (Vintage International, $13.) In her latest collection of essays, which won a National Book Critics Circle Award, the author recalls her public school education in New York City in the 1930's and 40's and her formative encounters with New Criticism during its heyday in the 1950's. She also offers striking reflections on such topics as the Unabomber and the commodification of Anne Frank. Ozick is "the most accomplished and graceful literary stylist of our time," John Sutherland said here last year.

BETRAYAL OF TRUST: The Collapse of Global Public Health, by Laurie Garrett. (Hyperion, $16.95.) The author of "The Coming Plague" (1994) argues that the covenant between citizens and government in health care matters is broken; she outlines in chilling detail the threat of bioterrorism and the crumbling health systems in Russia, India, Africa and the United States. "These are lurid, disturbing and well-documented images that are not easily dismissed as alarmist," Fitzhugh Mullan wrote in these pages in 2000. "Her message . . . is a momentous one that is delivered persuasively."

ABYSSINIAN CHRONICLES, by Moses Isegawa. (Vintage International, $15.) This panoramic first novel about Uganda's turbulent postcolonial history uses the struggles of three generations of a single family to show how external forces -- religious, political and economic -- have blighted the nation and corrupted its traditions. Last year our reviewer, Richard Eder, said that even if the tale is disjointed and overwrought at times, "Isegawa makes his country a locus of life, tragedy and character that . . . stays with us."

A POSITIVELY FINAL APPEARANCE: A Journal, 1996-98, by Alec Guinness. (Penguin, $14.) Modest, refined and droll, Sir Alec Guinness, who died last year at the age of 86, holds forth on country living, the larger world, acting and the passage of time. "He is a repository of theatrical knowledge and a vessel of gratitude," Barbara Grizzuti Harrison wrote in the Book Review in 1999, "a man whose impeccable, fluid prose takes us from inner thought to outer action seamlessly, a man who in all his ways is buoyant, vivid and brave."

AFTERBURN, by Colin Harrison. (St. Martin's, $6.99.) Among the many balls tossed into the air in this thriller are an international tycoon (and former P.O.W. in Vietnam), his barren daughter, a mob boss and a young female mathematical genius jailed for hijacking trucks. It adds up to "an exciting ride," Stephen Dobyns said here last year. "Harrison writes extremely well, and sections of 'Afterburn' are as elegant as you'll hope to find in any novel."

EINSTEIN IN LOVE: A Scientific Romance, by Dennis Overbye. (Penguin, $15.) Plumbing the first 40 years of Albert Einstein's life, a science writer for The Times focuses on his subject's emotional, intimate side and how it affected his scientific discoveries. It turns out that while Einstein was a cad with women and a lousy father, he stayed faithful to his ideas about the universe. Last year in these pages, Jim Holt found "the scientific exposition in this book" to be "almost as racy as the biographical bits."

HOOKING UP, by Tom Wolfe. (Picador USA, $13.) The targets in this collection of essays include the death of the American novel, millennial self-absorption and -- in a vintage 1965 sendup -- the mummified New Yorker of William Shawn. Last year our reviewer, Maureen Dowd, found this a mixed bag, but allowed that "whenever some big bizarro thing happens . . . I want the man in the white suit to do his usual exhaustive reporting, turn the labels inside out and the hypocrites upside down" and "tell me what's what in one of those jittering, dazzling riffs of his."

THE REVISIONIST, by Helen Schulman. (Bloomsbury, $14.95.) A young neurologist, distracted and adrift, becomes obsessed with a Holocaust denier who changed his mind. He tracks down his doppelg* nger, believing he has found a kindred spirit whose example will inspire him to transform his own life. The result is "an original, bold and often moving" novel, Brian Morton said here in 1998.

ARTEMISIA, by Alexandra Lapierre. (Grove, $15.) Set in 17th-century Italy, this French novel tells of the twisting fortunes of two real-life artists -- Orazio Gentileschi and his daughter, Artemisia -- and the rapacious art collectors and wealthy patrons they dealt with. The tale "employs admirable artistry in depicting the turbulent life and times of two great painters," Peter Bricklebank wrote here in 2000. Scott Veale

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
LUDWIG, WILLIAM FRANK

 BODY:
 LUDWIG-William Frank. Died November 8, 2001 in Vero Beach, Florida from complications of lung cancer. Loving husband of Gaye, devoted father of Bill, Amelia, Jack and Julia, beloved grandfather of Stacey, Lydia, Anna and Zachary and brother of Judy and Donald. Friend and colleague to many as Vice President at JP Morgan and partner at Morgan Lewis G&A. Born February 2, 1930 in Sanford, Florida, Bill graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1951, and Columbia Law School in 1958, after military service as an officer in the US Naval Reserve. Bill began a 26-year career at JP Morgan & Co. in 1958, first as legal counsel, then as Vice President serving the banking needs of many of America's largest companies. Bill interrupted his career at Morgan in the mid 1960s, heeding the call of John F. Kennedy for public service. He led the Latin American Lending Division of the US Agency for International Development. Bill was the first head of the workout department of Morgan in the 1970s and was named a director of Penn Central when that company emerged from bankruptcy. In the mid-1980s he created and led the bank's leveraged buyout activities. Bill's vigorous independence of mind, pragmatic approach to business and ability to find humor in almost any situation impressed all with whom he came in contact. From long standing business relationships grew many fast friendships. At the suggestion of a bank colleague, Bill met his second wife, Gaye McIntosh, just over 20 years ago. 
In 1986, Bill left JP Morgan to become partner in the leveraged buyout firm of Morgan Lewis G&A. After 7 years of creative and successful deal making, Bill and his family moved to Vero Beach, Florida to be close to his Florida roots. A memorial service was held Saturday, November 10th at his home in Vero Beach. Contributions in Bill's memory can be sent to the University of Pennsylvania's Penn Fund.

HEADLINE: BLACKBOARD; 
E-Commerce Degrees: Fight or Flight?

BYLINE:  By DANIELLE SVETCOV 

 BODY:
IN the final hours of the 20th century, universities jumped on the online money wagon, and for some, not without regrets. Many master's programs in e-commerce are now facing an enrollment free fall, yet another side effect of the failed dot.com economy.
 At the Illinois Institute of Technology in Chicago, where 10 students enrolled in the e-commerce master's program this fall -- compared with 29 last year -- administrators have decided to suspend future admissions. Across town at DePaul University, which started its degree program this fall, no students enrolled. 
 Universities seem to be facing the situation with equanimity. "I'm a little disappointed it happened so soon, but I'm not surprised," says Martin Bariff, academic director of the year-old program at the Illinois Institute of Technology, whose problems may be compounded by its location in a competitive vortex of business schools. "My prediction was that we'd go four to six years," he says, acknowledging that enrollment relied on the dot.com boom. The program will last 18 more months, until current students matriculate. The institute will continue to offer an e-commerce certificate for students who wish to study the subject for a shorter period. 
Like Mr. Bariff, many administrators anticipated an economic bust and planned accordingly. "Our strategy was to start the degree program in fall 1999 with existing resources and monitor the demand for a couple of years," says Lorne Olfman, dean of the School of Information Science at Claremont Graduate University in California, which also reports a drop in enrollment. Similar strategies kept financial losses to a minimum at other institutions. But the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee committed $250,000 to its new program, including seven new courses; enrollment there has fallen 50 percent.
And then there are the concerns of students, who are spending one to two years taking courses in Web design, e-commerce marketing and law while juggernauts like Etoys and Webvan fall out of the race.
"Our current students are worried about two things," Mr. Bariff says. "One, can they get a job? And two, if their degree is not going to last a decade or more, what is the value of it?"
But a rosier forecast comes from the University of Wyoming, which spent nearly $500,000 on an e-commerce program and benefits from being in a region short on information-technology professionals. The program is full. Temple University in Philadelphia, ranked the 14th best technology-business school by ComputerWorld magazine, says it also has not seen a decline in interest in its two-year-old program. "As with any discipline, it will evolve and morph in various ways," says Raj Chandran, senior associate dean of Temple's business school, which spent $2 million on an e-commerce institute with some 20 new teachers. "We feel that there will be a continuing interest in e-commerce."
Forrester Research, which issues reports on the technology industry, supports Mr. Chandran's view. According to Forrester, consumers bought a not-insignificant $4 billion in online goods in August (about the same as last year).
Students -- paying from $15,000 to $40,000 in tuition -- have no choice but to look at the bright side. "In any technology-related industry you have to keep educating yourself on latest developments," says Adam Parikh, an e-commerce student at Wisconsin. He thinks e-commerce will prevail, especially as companies look for ways to cut costs. "E-commerce is the perfect way to automate processes and become more efficient," he says. "We have also been fortunate enough to learn from the mistakes and successes of others. We have been educated to avoid the pitfalls of e-commerce pioneers."
In most cases, these stand-alone degrees grew out of existing M.B.A. programs with the aim of graduating managers who understand both strategy and information systems. Compulsory courses have names like "Database Analysis and Design" and "Accounting Information Systems for E-Business." 
For his Web design course at the Illinois Institute of Technology, Jeff Correll has just completed a review of casino Web sites. And he's happy to announce: The casinos have not optimized their e-commerce potential. DANIELLE SVETCOV

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jeff Correll, right, and teacher in a Web design course. What now? (Peter Thompson for The New York Times)

SUBJECT: STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (90%); ELECTRONIC COMMERCE (90%); COLLEGES & UNIVERSITIES (90%); GRADUATE & PROFESSIONAL SCHOOLS (90%); INTERNET & WWW (90%); BUSINESS EDUCATION (89%); UNIVERSITY ADMINISTRATION (78%); COMPUTING & INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY (78%); INFORMATION SCIENCE (64%) COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES; COMPUTERS AND THE INTERNET; SPECIAL SECTIONS; GRADUATE SCHOOLS AND STUDENTS 

ORGANIZATION: DEPAUL UNIVERSITY (57%)

PERSON: SVETCOV, DANIELLE

HEADLINE: Half a Century of Student Protest 

BYLINE:  By Stephanie Gutmann; Stephanie Gutmann is the author of "The Kinder, Gentler Military: How Political Correctness Affects Our Ability to Win Wars" (Encounter Books).

 BODY:
 Organized labor and students come together.

1940-50
As interest in Communism and Socialism flourishes, the party forms many youth adjuncts on campuses. Labor unions also recruit heavily and openly, mobilizing labor-led student groups like the American Youth for Democracy, the American Student Union and the American Student Congress to fight, among other issues, low pay and racial discrimination in the workplace.

Antidiscrimination activists in the labor movement "discover" Jim Crow segregation policies that have been operating unchallenged in the South for decades. The civil rights movement is powered by professional activists and black church organizations. Eventually students, many from northern universities, become involved.

Feb. 1, 1960
Using the now-established tactic of the sit-in, four black North Carolina students are arrested when they refuse to leave a whites-only lunch counter at an F.W. Woolworth store in Greensboro, N.C.

May 1960
The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee is formed as a spinoff of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and the Congress of Racial Equality, two stalwarts in the civil rights movement. The youth group establishes headquarters in Atlanta and elects a chairman, Marion Barry, a Fisk University student and future mayor of Washington.

June 11-15, 1962
About 60 activists, including Tom Hayden, a student at the University of Michigan and future California state senator, hold a retreat at an autoworkers' union conference hall in Port Huron, Mich., near Detroit, a symbol of the American labor movement. The resulting Port Huron statement is declared the guiding manifesto of Students for a Democratic Society. The statement, calling for a new left, is sweeping in its concerns -- ending the Vietnam War, poverty, racial discrimination and the spread of atomic weapons.

1963
As Jim Crow policies fall away, the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee turns to helping Southern blacks register and cast their votes. Bloody confrontations are often the result.

PUB-DATE: March 7, 1965
Protesters for civil rights, including members and leaders of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee, are beaten as they march from Montgomery to Selma, Ala., a city particularly hostile to voting rights. In the Ghandian tradition of passive resistance, marchers do not fight back. Photographs of the beatings outrage the American public and help pass the Voting Rights Act of 1965, providing federal protection for black voters.
May 1966
Young black activists become impatient with civil disobedience and what they see as a white takeover of their movement. New leaders emerge from the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee calling for the use of violence in self-defense. Stokely Carmichael, a recent graduate of Howard University, is elected president of the group.

June 1966
At a news conference with Representative Adam Clayton Powell, Stokely Carmichael (above, seated) advocates black power, which alienates many of his group's moderate supporters. By early 1967, the committee is near bankruptcy and he has left to help found the Black Panther Party, a group that adopts the dress of the Cuban revolutionary Che Guevara and maintains caches of arms.

1968
Students for a Democratic Society has chapters in 44 cities, but ideological splits emerge among those who want to achieve change "by any means necessary" (the Black Panther slogan) and those who want to work within the system. One radical faction, largely students who have dropped out of school to "make revolution," name themselves the Weather Underground.

While racial discrimination continues as a student concern, the war and the draft become a larger focus as American involvement in Vietnam deepens.

PUB-DATE: April 30, 1968
Students take over five Columbia University buildings and sit in at the office of the president, Grayson L. Kirk, to protest the university's plan to build a gymnasium in a park abutting Harlem, and its affiliation with a consortium that does military research for the government. There are scuffles, and hundreds of students are arrested. Mr. Kirk (above, left) explains to the press his decision to call in the police. Widely criticized, he eventually resigns.

May 2-4, 1970
On the night of May 2, a violent demonstration erupts on the central campus of Kent State University in Ohio. The crowd sets fire to the Reserve Officer Training Center with Molotov cocktails and beats up a firefighter. The police in riot gear force students to disperse. On May 3, several thousand attend another antiwar rally that becomes a melee of surging protesters, rock throwing and tear gas. Members of a National Guard unit fire their rifles. Four students are killed and nine are wounded.

By the late 70's many S.D.S. and Weather Underground members have gone into hiding to avoid federal prosecution. With the end of the Vietnam War in 1975, student activists are without a pressing issue. Many would rather hit the books anyway. By the early 80's, with inflation and a stagnant economy, students are anxious about getting jobs after college. Activism is less chaotic and more polite.

April 1985
On April 4, Columbia students chain the doors of the administration building and demonstrate for four weeks to protest the university's investment in countries that do business with South Africa. On April 22, about 30 students at Cornell construct huts of cardboard, tin and garbage bags behind the administration building to represent South African shantytowns. Over five days about 1,000 are arrested at Cornell.

The late 90's and the present are marked, once again, by an alliance of students and organized labor. In an era when many students will go to work for huge conglomerates, activists take aim at the corporation. This dovetails with organized labor's distrust of globalization, which forces union workers to compete with low-paid workers in undeveloped countries.

PUB-DATE: June 1, 1996
To gain foot soldiers and reinvigorate itself, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. starts Union Summer, a four-week internship for students who want to learn organizing skills and work at the grass-roots level of the labor movement.

Summer 1998
Students from Union Summer start United Students Against Sweatshops to protest conditions at overseas factories that produce the logo-covered clothing sold on campus. The group sets up 100 chapters its first year, and dozens more such organizations emerge on campuses across the country. One target is the biggest manufacturer of athletic shoes, Nike. A number of universities adopt new policies.

December 1999
Student activists of varied stripes converge in Seattle, where the World Trade Organization is meeting to negotiate ending trade barriers among nations. The students are part of a demonstration of 30,000 to 50,000 people of all ages who find common cause protesting large corporations and the globalization of trade. Most marchers are peaceful, but small groups break windows and stone the police, who respond with tear gas and arrest nearly 600. The meeting ends with no new agreements and is considered a failure.

April 18-May 9, 2001
About 50 Harvard students refuse to leave an administration building until the university agrees to raise what it pays janitors to $10.25 an hour. After 20 days they roll up their sleeping bags and leave the hall, and the university agrees to form a commission to study the issue.

ORGANIZATION: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN (55%)

PERSON: GUTMANN, STEPHANIE 

GEOGRAPHIC: DETROIT, MI, USA (79%); GREENSBORO, NC, USA (79%) MICHIGAN, USA (93%); NORTH CAROLINA, USA (92%); ALABAMA, USA (79%); CALIFORNIA, USA (79%) UNITED STATES (94%)

SECTION: Section 2; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 3240 words

HEADLINE: Television/Radio; 
Public Radio's Private Guru

BYLINE:  By SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN 

 BODY:
DURING the final days of October, as the public radio station WAMU-FM in Washington launched an on-air fund drive, one particular group of former listeners began calling in to donate only their complaints. They were fans of a bluegrass show that had been dropped without warning four months earlier from its coveted slot during drive-time on weekday afternoons. Refusing to contribute money, demanding refunds of previous gifts, the protesters meant to deny WAMU its goal of raising $1 million. And this was only their latest piece of political theater.
 In the preceding weeks, bluegrass loyalists had picketed two fund-raising events, one man carrying a sign declaring "WAMU = Fraud, Stupidity and Heartache." "Save Bluegrass" Web sites and e-mail lists had sprung up. Back before the terror attacks of Sept. 11 had consumed Congressional attention, Representative Howard Coble of North Carolina had taken to the floor of the House to declare, "Perhaps the WAMU management team needs to be introduced to the woodshed." 
 This sort of strife was not limited to Washington, either. Seven months earlier and 2,000 miles away, to the strains of Haydn's "Farewell" symphony, the public station KUER-FM in Salt Lake City ended 40 years of broadcasting classical music, bringing condemnation from the Utah legislature and the state's major newspapers. Meanwhile, in Maine, town meetings were being held to assail the state public radio system for dropping live broadcasts of the Metropolitan Opera. (They were ultimately restored.) And in Roanoke, Va., the United States District Court prepared to hear the case of the NPR station WVTF's former manager. He was suing university and state officials for $2 million for having fired him shortly after he dropped the Met broadcasts, which were restored over his objections.
All these controversies, seemingly so disparate, traced back to a common source. His name is David Giovannoni. A brilliant analyst of public radio's audience -- who it is, how much it listens, when it listens, what it listens to, when and why it donates money -- he is quite possibly the most influential figure in shaping the sound of National Public Radio today, the sound heard by upward of 20 million Americans weekly.
Mr. Giovannoni's company in suburban Washington, Audience Research Analysis, holds contracts with the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, National Public Radio, Public Radio International and almost every major NPR member station in the country. He essentially invented the language of public radio today, terms like "affinity," "loyalty," "power" and "public service." The phrase most public stations intone in their hourly ID's -- "listener-supported" -- grew out of Mr. Giovannoni's research. What might be considered the standard public-radio schedule, with its daylong emphasis on news and talk, largely subscribes to his findings. And during the years NPR has applied Mr. Giovannoni's findings, it has more than doubled listenership and gone from near bankruptcy to financial stability.
Every one of the radio stations involved in these recent battles acted largely on Mr. Giovannoni's research. His analysis showed them that, however vociferous the audience for bluegrass in Washington or symphonies in Salt Lake City or the Met in Virginia and Maine, those programs drove away a vast majority of the most loyal listeners and donors. The way to bring them and their checkbooks back was to schedule more of the news and information programs they craved.
As such, Mr. Giovannoni is the lightning rod for the intense, often bitter debate about what course NPR and its member stations should take in their evolution from a hodgepodge of "educational broadcasting" outlets dependent on the largess of universities and the federal government to a media powerhouse increasingly independent of the public sector. Depending on whom you ask, Mr. Giovannoni either helped save NPR by pointing the path to financial self-sufficiency or helped undermine the kind of programming that made it worth saving in the first place. "A visionary," says Richard Madden, the vice president of radio at the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. "A numbers Nazi," the independent producer Larry Josephson labeled him several years ago.
For all the heated language, the conflict shaking public radio is not the stereotypical struggle between aesthetes and philistines. When Mr. Giovannoni's clients dropped country and classical music, or consigned them to weekends and the after-midnight abyss, they didn't plug in Rush Limbaugh or Howard Stern or easy listening; they put on the news and discussion programs that have earned NPR its accolades: "Fresh Air," "Talk of the Nation," "All Things Considered." NPR's superb coverage of the Sept. 11 attacks, starting with round-the-clock reporting the first week, may have served as the ultimate confirmation of Mr. Giovannoni's thesis that news-information forms the most integral, essential, irreplaceable element of public radio.
To Mr. Giovannoni's critics, however, the reliance on widely lauded programs typifies the problem. Ratings increasingly rule. Every NPR station is sounding more like every other NPR station, with the same "news stream" during the weekday, the same lineup of "Weekend Edition," "Car Talk" and the quiz show "Whad'ya Know?" on Saturday mornings. In both Washington and Salt Lake City, music devotees pointed out that nearby NPR stations already broadcast the same news and information shows that WAMU and KUER were adding. Even as NPR basks in the National Medal of the Arts it was awarded last year by President Clinton for its cultural programming, the very genres of jazz and classical music that the system was created in part to support are shrinking on the dial. Inventive new shows, Mr. Giovannoni's foes contend, will not survive statistical scrutiny long enough to build an audience. Jay Allison, an award-winning producer and station manager, likens the reliance on audience research to "a deal with the devil."
For his part, Mr. Giovannoni says he abhors sameness, formats, consultants, all the plagues of commercial radio. He insists he never tells any station what to do or not to do. He merely provides information of unimpeached accuracy to executives who used to act on intuition, personal taste and informal feedback from listeners. He merely asks the pregnant, provocative question. "I'm constantly saying the emperor has no clothes," he puts it. "I'm shining the light on reality."
Now 47, David Giovannoni has been disseminating his findings and propounding his views through essays, speeches and workshops for a quarter-century. While his research instruments have grown more sophisticated -- from a pocket calculator to interactive Web sites -- his essential message has remained consistent. Public radio cannot serve every interest. It does not exist for the benefit of its producers but for the benefit of its audience. Attention must be paid to what that audience wants. Which, he invariably adds, does not mean selling out.
"Let me be very clear on this point," Mr. Giovannoni said in a keynote address last July in Phoenix to a convention of public-radio marketing and development specialists. "I am not saying that program directors should make programming decisions based on how much money they're likely to raise. That would undermine the values at the very heart of our service, making it unworthy of support. I am saying, however, that program directors should make the difficult decisions that give the public the highest level of service. That means replacing lower-performance programming with higher-performance programming."
A workshop that Mr. Giovannoni conducted last May for WNYC in New York typified his approach, and the tensions it can create. WNYC had been deeply influenced by Mr. Giovannoni for several years as it transformed itself from a station almost entirely dependent on municipal funding to one supporting itself, buying its AM and FM licenses from the city for $20 million. Since 1995, the station had doubled its budget to $16 million and almost tripled its income from members and corporate underwriters to $12 million. Yet WNYC also prided itself on a being a "dual-format" station, equally emphasizing information and classical music, an approach that defied his principles.
At one point in the workshop, Mr. Giovannoni projected a chart showing the weekday listenership for WNYC-FM. The graph consisted of an undulating series of bars, one for each half-hour interval, peaking between 7 and 9 in the morning, dropping into a midday trough, rising again from 4 to 7 p.m. The high points, as everyone in the room knew, corresponded to "Morning Edition" and "All Things Considered," NPR's "tent poles," in public-radio parlance. As for the lulls, as everyone in the room knew, they were classical music shows.
Mr. Giovannoni indicated another chart, showing how much radio WNYC's audience tuned into, regardless of station. Those bars remained relatively stable between 9 a.m. and 4 p.m. "These are your listeners," he said, tapping the wall. "And they're not listening to you."
Someone asked, "Does that make the programming from 9 to 4 bad?" Before Mr. Giovannoni could respond, another staff member offered, "People come to us for news and information." Then is it a mistake, a third wanted to know, for the same station to have two kinds of listeners?
"That makes it harder," Mr. Giovannoni said. "A radio station should be something for the same person all the time. You become less and you become better."
By Giovannoni standards, this was an elementary tutorial and a gentle one. Without dictating what WNYC should do, he was delineating the consequences of what WNYC had done. Within its mathematical neutrality, his data was advocating a certain model of public radio, one that made no apologies for tailoring programming to the audience's proven taste. Although the terror attack several months later would leave WNYC with more fundamental problems to solve -- its FM transmitter destroyed, its replacement signal unable to reach half the normal audience -- the broader issue of programming resonated throughout public radio.
"Your challenge," Mr. Giovannoni said as the session concluded, "is to mine the existing audience. You want to support programming, right? It's hard to do that when nobody's listening. Or when nobody values what you do. The way to get more audience? The way to serve your public better? Lose what's on the periphery. Focus on a single audience and serve that audience extremely, insanely well all the time."
The eldest child of farmers in California's Central Valley, David Giovannoni stood mesmerized as a toddler by the revolution of records on the family turntable. In his teens, he began trawling barn sales for junked phonographs and joined several friends in an "Obsolete Audio Oddities Club." Then, one day when he was 16 or 17, he dialed the radio to the far left end of the FM band and heard a man urgently incanting what sounded like his life story. The station, Mr. Giovannoni later learned, was KPFA in Berkeley, beacon of the iconoclastic Pacifica network, and the voice was Allen Ginsberg reading "Howl." A whole world had revealed itself.
High school valedictorian and student-body president, Mr. Giovannoni chose the University of the Pacific in nearby Stockton partly for its public radio station, KUOP. There he first heard "All Things Considered" and logged 1,500 hours in four years. Graduate study in communications took him to the University of Wisconsin and put him under the sway of Lawrence Lichty, a young professor intent on wrenching the statewide public-radio network out of its stodgy, pedantic style. "Brilliant and innovative," in Mr. Lichty's estimation, Mr. Giovannoni was harvesting raw Arbitron data on public-radio listenership and devising means of analyzing it. "Back then, anything we found out was new," Mr. Giovannoni recalled. "There was no context about the audience. You turned on the mike and sometimes the phone rang in the studio to ask for a request or to yell at you."
When NPR hired Mr. Lichty in the late 1970's to work on the development of "Morning Edition," he brought his protege to Washington. There, along with the audience researchers Tom Church and George Bailey -- once ridiculed by Garrison Keillor as "guys in suits with charts" -- they first stepped into the conflicts that would recur through Mr. Giovannoni's career. " 'We don't do what people want,' " Jack Mitchell, a former producer and board chairman of NPR, recalled reporters and editors saying. " 'It's killed by research.' "
What ultimately made Mr. Giovannoni a fixture in public radio, however, were events far outside his control. The efforts by Ronald Reagan in 1981 and Newt Gingrich in 1995 to "zero out" the Corporation for Public Broadcasting sent NPR and its member stations hunting for more secure financial support. Mr. Giovannoni's research held the clues to how to reach the listeners themselves. "It was a terrible thing but it was a good thing," Mr. Giovannoni said of the threatened cessations of federal aid. "Those two hits forced us to become self-sufficient. And the way we were able to do that was by shifting away from a subsidized economy and focusing on the listener."
OVER the last 16 years, Mr. Giovannoni and various collaborators have released a series of reports defining the public-radio audience in ever finer detail, augmenting computer models based on Arbitron data with follow-up interviews and focus groups. These studies started by disabusing NPR of its pride in its weekly listenership, known in the trade as its "cume." Ninety percent of those listeners -- dubbed the "Cheap 90" by Mr. Giovannoni -- never donated to stations. Sixty percent listened only sporadically. The remaining 40 percent, the "core" in the Giovannoni lexicon, accounted for almost 80 percent of the hours listeners spent tuned to public radio. Over time, Mr. Giovannoni has refined his picture of who they are (middle-aged, college-educated, interested in social issues), what they listen to most ("All Things Considered,""Morning Edition"), what other NPR shows hold their interest ("Car Talk," "Prairie Home Companion"), what generally causes them to turn the dial (radio theater, children's shows, music except on stations with all-music formats), and even what encourages them to donate money at the highest rate ("Marketplace," "Car Talk," "All Things Considered").
The divide between culture and information appeared prominently in a 1993 study establishing the affinity -- that is, the demographic similarity -- of the audience for "All Things Considered" with the listenership for NPR's 71 nationally syndicated shows. Of the 27 shows that performed worst -- that, by Mr. Giovannoni's research, actively alienated core listeners -- a vast majority featured jazz, classical music and opera. In a 1998 study, Mr. Giovannoni found that music programming brought stations far less income per broadcast hour than did news, talk or entertainment. Popular music appealed to listeners a generation younger than NPR's core audience; classical music and opera appealed to listeners a decade to a generation older.
Mr. Giovannoni's conclusion, indeed his belief system, came down to one mantra: "Programming causes audience." People didn't listen to public radio because they appreciated the concept of smart, commercial-free programming; they listened for the same reason people listened to classic rock or adult urban contemporary or Dr. Laura -- because they liked what happened to be on. Putting more of it on, then, meant more listeners and more donations and more freedom from the caprice of Washington. (There are anomalies, numerically small but demonstrably generous niche audiences like WAMU's bluegrass fans.)
Following Mr. Giovannoni's precepts, NPR built its weekly cume from 9 million in 1985 to the current 22 million. It now raises more than half of its $500 million budget from individual listeners or private-sector underwriters. The number of paid-up members doubled to 2 million between 1990 and 2000. Over the same period, federal support fell from 16 cents per dollar to less than 11.
That dramatic growth has only encouraged NPR to become more cautious, which has turned Mr. Giovannoni into a convenient target. "To some extent, NPR is a prisoner of its success," said Alan Stavitsky, a University of Oregon professor who has studied public-radio consultants. "This once obscure and quirky alternative programmer is now part of the media elite. There's less room for the kind of offbeat experimenting with the medium that characterized NPR's early days."
"There's nothing fundamentally wrong with research," said Torey Malatia, the president and general manager of WBEZ in Chicago, the station that originated "This American Life," the acclaimed documentary series featuring Ira Glass. "But what happened in the commercial marketplace began to happen in the public-radio marketplace. There was this unarticulated but passionately held belief that there was a perfect formula and that if we used that formula in our community, we could be as successful as other communities that used it.
"But after believing that myself for a long time, I'd argue that public radio is at its most successful when it doesn't follow formula. Data is just one tool for ascertaining what works. And it's a shame that public radio is scared away from what doesn't show well in the Arbitron book or hasn't proven itself somewhere else or isn't understandable on first hearing."
Mr. Giovannoni's style also has wounded and alienated. He and his frequent partner George Bailey often led workshops wearing doctor's whites and Groucho glasses. A report Mr. Giovannoni released in the late 1980's, which calibrated how much or little of their audiences various NPR shows shared, branded those with the least congruence, especially opera, with frowning-face logos.
"Though I've been pilloried for it," Mr. Giovannoni says, "I don't see what I do as cynical. My role is to help people in radio understand their listeners. Public radio isn't just you in the studio. Something happens on the other side of the mike. And if people aren't listening, there's no public service." He pauses. "The thing a lot of people in public radio don't get is that I'm on their side."
Keenly aware of criticism, Mr. Giovannoni has in the past several years increasingly emphasized the importance of "taking risks" and "budgeting for failure." His own tastes in music run from Bach to New Orleans jazz to the alternative rock of They Might Be Giants. His research shows that certain stations can hold a loyal audience with programming built around music, whether classical at WQED in Pittsburgh or jazz at WBGO in Newark. What NPR listeners seek, he maintains, is not a narrow format but a "sensibility," a pattern of "interests, values, and beliefs," which explains why the audience for "All Things Considered" also responds well to the quiz show "Whad'ya Know."
Still, when the rebukes come, they do not noticeably bother him. Such equanimity owes less to patience, perhaps, than to an unshakable belief that while his critics have sentimentality, he has the facts. "Everything I've done has caused carping," Mr. Giovannoni says. "It's the allegorical loss of innocence. That's what research is. Every time you pluck somebody out of the garden, they get bent out of shape."

SECTION: Section 11; Column 2; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2919 words

HEADLINE: Second Home Market Reviving After Lull 

BYLINE:  By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
FOR two weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, the offices of real-estate firms specializing in second homes fell silent. Phones stopped ringing, inquiries came to a halt, prospective buyers stayed away. The desire to purchase a home for leisure use seemed somehow frivolous.
 "It was very quiet for a few weeks," said Carolyn Klemm, the co-owner of Klemm Real Estate in Washington, Conn. "People put their flags out and went into mourning. No one wanted to do anything. Now I think that is lifting." 
 Brokers up and down the Eastern vacation corridor agreed. Despite the financial downturn that might reasonably be expected to stifle second home sales -- they are, after all, not a necessity no matter what benefits they offer -- business has rebounded, they say. 
But, by and large, prices have leveled off, neither soaring at the rates achieved in the flush 1990's, nor sinking into the doldrums of the late '80's.
Sellers can expect their homes to move, brokers say, provided they are fairly priced. Buyers will find more inventory from which to choose than in recent years and more willingness on the part of owners to negotiate. In addition, buyers are being attracted by the steadily declining mortgage rates. 
"We have had no business fall through," said Dana Marcus, a partner of McCormick, Murtagh, Marcus & Smith, a law firm in Great Barrington, Mass., that handles numerous leisure home transactions in the Berkshires. "In fact, it is just the opposite. The activity we're experiencing at this time of year is a little busier than in Octobers and Novembers of years past."
But the economy aside, there is a sober new twist to the search, as increasing numbers of people recast the weekend house as a refuge from anxiety. 
As Robert Pearl, a Manhattan developer and broker, who has contracts out to sell two weekend houses and buy a third in Woodstock, N.Y., put it: "People are saying they want a home they can go to in case things get really bad in the city. They don't want to give up the city, but they need to know they have a safety blanket. There is a greater need to go to nurturing places where there are rivers, woods, water that is soothing and healing, where your heartbeat slows down after a few days."
In such an area in the northwest corner of Connecticut, Litchfield County, where Ms. Klemm has been selling real estate for 25 years, she said: "We are seeing people who have never considered a second home before. They say they need a safe haven and what they want is not suburban -- it is country."
Joan Lonergan, principal broker and owner of Coldwell Banker Village Green Realty, which has offices in Woodstock and Kingston, N.Y., said clients who may have been on the fence before were no longer hesitating. 
"It's been a wake-up call," she said. "When disaster happens, you realize life is short and precious and people are deciding to make their move and not wait till tomorrow. They are looking for a place to be safe and peaceful now." 
And they want that place, wherever it is, to be a magnet for families, to gather grandparents, grandchildren, siblings, in-laws.
"When people proceeded to try to make their lives normal again after Sept. 11, their focus turned to the family and the home and renewing old American values," said Thomas B. Anderson, executive vice president of the New York State and mid-Atlantic region for Sotheby's International Realty. "I have been inundated with calls from people saying they were looking for a country house with a yard where they can find a home-oriented, nurturing lifestyle. When people think about their families gathering for holidays, weekends and summertime, they are thinking less of traveling and more of being at home."
Diane Saatchi, president of Dayton-Halstead Real Estate, has detected the same pattern in the Hamptons. "People seem to want to get on with it in a way I haven't seen in this market," she said. "They used to be motivated by money, status and image. Now there is a sense that, 'If we don't buy the house now, we won't have a place where we can spend the summer with the kids.' People want to solidify their plans and not leave anything up in the air and they want to have something they can look forward to as a family." 
Requests for rentals have increased too, not only in the ski resort areas of Vermont and New Hampshire where demand would normally accelerate at this time of year, but in seashore communities as well. 
Ms. Saatchi said, "People whose leases would have ended in the middle or end of September, who were beginning to pack up, called after the 11th and said: 'We don't want to go back. We want to extend or get another house to rent or buy.' A number of people who ordinarily would come out to look for something for next summer are now looking for year-round houses." 
They may be in luck. Owners who failed to sell their properties and developers who built projects on spec are renting them so that tenants will carry the overhead. 
Compared with the cost of summer rentals, there are relative bargains to be had. "I tell owners to multiply what they would get on a summer rental by 1.2, so that a house that would be $40,000 for Memorial to Labor Day would be $48,000 for the entire year," Ms. Saatchi said, adding that carrying costs -- snow and leaf removal, opening and closing the swimming pool -- add to the tab. 
Besides the renewed desire to have a place to gather the clan around the hearth, the faltering financial markets are also adding to the attractions of the second home market. For the moment at least, there may be more pleasure to be derived from a cottage in the mountains than from stock certificates. 
As Mr. Pearl, who sold both of his houses in Woodstock within a week, one of them over the Internet, said: "People may have less money, but those who do have it have fewer places to put it. There is a surge of fear about where to put money. People are scared of the stock market, and interest rates are so low that they feel this is an alternative they can touch, feel and use." 
That may be helped by the fact that prices are no longer escalating the way they did the last few years. As Judi Desiderio, vice president of Cook Pony Farm, which has seven offices in the Hamptons and three on the North Fork of Long Island, put it: "Bidding wars are history."
In the Hamptons, she said, "Sept. 11 marked a turning point from a balanced market to a market favoring the buyer. And a lack of inventory for houses below $500,000 is the only thing holding prices firm."
Otherwise both volume and average prices are down for closings reported in the third quarter, she said, largely because of the drop in the number of sales over $2 million. Such closings would have been based on prices agreed to months earlier. 
THE picture is similarly mixed elsewhere -- up a little here, down a little there -- with no clear indications of what will happen in the future. 
"We have noticed that the market has slowed down since Sept. 11, but we are still making sales and finding that prices are holding to what they were before that date," said Norman T. Callaway, chairman of a firm bearing his name in Princeton and Sergeantsville, N.J., and New Hope, Pa. 
"Sales may be a bit more difficult to make, but buyers are still interested in coming to this area," he said, pointing out its proximity to both New York City and Philadelphia. "If houses were ambitiously priced, we notice some of those coming down." His area in southern New Jersey ranges from Princeton to the farming country around Sergeantsville to the historic villages of Lambertville, Stockton and Frenchtown. 
For $150,000 to $300,000, buyers could find a three- to four-bedroom home, perhaps an old farmhouse in the rural outskirts or an attached Victorian town house on a picturesque street in Lambertville, Stockton or Frenchtown. In the middle range, $325,000 to $800,000, they would be shown a colonial, Victorian or contemporary house with four bedrooms, a deck and a detached garage. At the upper end, $800,000 to $5 million would buy a four- to five-bedroom 19th century house with numerous architectural details, fireplaces, handcarved mantels, high ceilings and in some cases such amenities as swimming pools and tennis courts.
Across the Delaware River in Tinicum, Nockamixon and Upper Black Eddy in Bucks County, Pa., "We are starting to see more people from New York," said Laurence Elliott, manager of Weichert Realtors in Newtown. "Business is very steady right now. As far as sales go, we could use more inventory." 
Like other realtors, Mr. Elliott said he had noticed increased interest among buyers in staying home at their second home. "People want to see places with pools now," he said. "In the past a pool didn't add to value because no one wanted one. Now the presence of a pool is helping sell homes more quickly although it is not yet raising prices." 
"The effect of the economy," he continued, "is that if a house took a week to sell in the last three years, now it might take two weeks. But it is still selling. I keep waiting for prices to fall, but they are still pretty much on the high end of the curve." 
The high end, he said, sits somewhere in the $2 million range, but even at that price a property is likely to be located near less costly getaways. "Things are very eclectic here," he said. "I just listed a property for $2,995,000, and half a mile away you could buy something for $60,000."
For $60,000 to $70,000, buyers could expect to find a small two-bedroom chalet or cabin, described by Mr. Elliott as "very basic, a place to go and do hunting." 
As it is everywhere, waterfront land is at a premium. The price of a small chalet on Lake Nockamixon could hit $200,000, Mr. Elliott said.
In Vermont and New Hampshire, the first flakes of snow have begun to fall, harbingers of the ski season to come -- and of the demand for houses in areas like Stowe, Killington and Stratton, Vt., and Franconia, N.H. 
"It's still a seller's market here," said Terry Hill, a sales agent at Mountain Realty in Bondville, Vt., the village at the bottom of the Stratton ski area and a past president of the South Central Vermont Board of Realtors. "The buying season for the winter is normally July to November because people want to get in by Thanksgiving. But this year, August was a little slow and that continued after Sept. 11, giving us a late fall season. 
"Now we're seeing a lot of interest from people looking for purchase and tons of calls for rentals. I've been getting calls from people saying, 'I'm not going to my Aspen home for Christmas this year.'
"There are more buyers looking than there is inventory both on and off the mountain," she said. As bankable as a waterfront location is in summer communities, so is proximity to mountains in snow country. "Convenience to the slopes is still a priority, especially for young families," Ms. Hill said, noting that trailside properties run from $350,000 to $900,000. 
There are two new high speed six-passenger chairlifts opening this season in the Sun Bowl area of Stratton and a new complex of 80 condos called Solstice. "They're not sold out yet, but they're selling very well at $699,000 to $900,000. They have closed on 37 and have another 18 pending," she said. 
But it is not necessary to spend that much. For $225,000 to $300,000 it is possible to get a 2,300-square-foot contemporary houses with three bedrooms, a family room and two fireplaces. 
For another $200,000 or so, the choice would include condos with what Ms. Hill described as "a superb floor plan for entertaining," connected to a sports club. "Those houses in the middle range, $350,000 to $550,000 is what we really need now," she said. Such houses would be 3,000 to 4,000 square feet and sit on one to four acres. 
For those with deeper pockets, Ms. Hill has two listings now at $3.4 million and $3.5 million. "Both are more than 7,000 square feet with superb craftsmanship, five bedrooms, wine cellars, exercise rooms, state-of-the-art kitchens, family rooms with theaters," she said. "One has three ponds stocked with trout."
Stratton is about a four-hour drive from Manhattan. Stowe is another two hours north but is known for having more reliable snow. "We are getting both buyers and renters this year who would have gone to Aspen or the Alps," said Pall Spera, owner of a brokerage firm in Stowe that bears his name. "It is easier to get in your car and go to your ski house than get in a plane with the uncertainty about travel." 
But he said he was having difficulty accommodating all the people knocking at his door, especially those in the market for reasonably priced homes. 
"There is a paucity of listings at the lower end," he said. "The higher level has slowed down from last year, but prices are holding. I think attitudes change as you go higher in pricing. People who are going to spend $500,000 or less are not as ambivalent. People who are going to spend $1 million and up are shopping and not rushing."
AMONG his agency's more expensive listings is an 85-acre property that has two ponds, one of them the size of a lake; a 9,000-square-foot house with seven bedrooms, six and a half baths and a state-of-the-art kitchen; and a garage with room for eight cars that also includes an automatic car wash. 
"This is the Filene's basement of bargains -- at $1.8 million," he said. 
In Franconia, N.H., Jere Peabody, co-owner of Peabody & Smith Realty, a Sotheby's International affiliate, which does transactions in 12 towns in the White Mountains, said: "We have not seen any slowdown in our market. It's been very, very active and I hate to say it this way but we've probably seen an uptick because of what happened in New York. 
"People don't want to say they're apprehensive," he continued, "but if they were thinking about having a getaway before, this has reinforced the notion."
Mr. Peabody is currently showing everything from three-bedroom chalets for $120,000 to $170,000 "with local views but no majestic vistas" to an estate belonging to the singer Patti Page and her husband, Jerry Filiciotto, for $1.9 million. 
Called Hilltop Farm, it includes a 12-room colonial house, a caretaker's apartment suite, a six-room, 3,000-square-foot log cabana overlooking a swimming pond, a maple sugaring business and 250 acres of forest and pasture. 
Another luxurious residence on Mr. Peabody's roster is one in Lyman called Echo Ledge. "It has 140 acres and your own private valley," he said. 
The custom New England farmhouse is built almost entirely of material taken from the property itself and has a marble floor entrance hall, a large living room with massive stone fireplace, a library, formal dining room, chef's-caliber kitchen with granite countertops, a vaulted spa room, exercise room, master suite and three guest bedrooms. It is listed at $995,000. "Anywhere else it would be underpriced," Mr. Peabody said. 
In Woodstock, N.Y., Joan Lonergan estimated prices had risen about 15 percent in the last year. "It used to be easy to find something in the $150,000 to $250,000 category," she said as she conducted a tour of a dozen houses. "Now finding anything under $300,000 is difficult, and to find anything under $100,000 you would have to go to a different county."
In this bucolic area of Ulster County, land tends to be more prized than buildings. "Fifteen acres with a cabin would be $325,000, but for the same $325,000 you could get a charming artist's home on maybe two acres," Ms. Lonergan said. "We don't have developments and we don't allow our mountainsides to be cut up, so land is becoming more and more difficult to find." 
That said, she drove up Meads Mountain Road to a spectacular piece of property: a 15-acre parcel with a 4,600-square-foot post and beam contemporary house with sweeping views of the Hudson River and Ashokan Reservoir to the south, the Berkshire Mountains to the east and the Catskill Mountains to the west. The price: $1.2 million. A separate 27.8 acre parcel higher up the mountain, which includes a building site and which could accommmodate a helicopter pad, is available for an additional $750,000. 
An 1880 carriage house painted dusty mauve that once belonged to Bob Dylan's carpenter is typical of more modest dwellings in Woodstock. But it has one atypical accoutrement: a freestanding circular fireplace in the living room, which according to local lore came from the nearby Cafe Espresso, frequented by Mr. Dylan and Joan Baez in the early 1960's. To sit by that fireplace will cost a buyer $315,000. 
Jonny Bowden and his wife, Cassandra Creech, had no intentions of selling the house they transformed a year ago from a dank 1970's style structure to a graceful contemporary design based on the principles of feng shui. 
But on Sept. 11, Ms. Creech, who played Denise Maynard Dixon on the soap opera "As the World Turns," was in Los Angeles where she is about to relocate her career. 
Mr. Bowden, a nutritionist and health writer, was unable to reach her. "We had been planning to commute from here, but now we are not comfortable being apart," he said, describing the panic they each had experienced. 
So they put the house, which has four bedrooms, a striking bluestone and concrete fireplace, balusters carved to resemble ocean waves, a media room, a meditation room and several sitting rooms, on the market for $379,000. 
But the couple, who have already given up their rental apartment in Manhattan, are determined to return to Woodstock. "We got engaged here, everything began here, and someday we will settle here," Mr. Bowden said.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Those Who Did, Shopped Discount

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH KELLEHER 

 BODY:
OLD-LINE department stores suffered a sucker punch on Sept. 11. Shoppers stayed home in droves, and those who have made purchases since then have mainly bought household goods, not the fashionable clothes that department stores sell. Shoppers and investors alike have been turning toward discount stores and wholesale clubs.
 Many analysts think customers increasingly want the low prices, easy parking and broad assortment of goods that discounters provide. Wal-Mart Stores, its stock priced at a premium, continues to get strong recommendations for supplying all of that. Target stores are also favored. Only Kmart, despite a huge presence in the marketplace, has been left out. 
 Wal-Mart is the darling of the discount group in large part because it sells food and other necessities, which consumers are buying despite a slowing economy. Its stock is a "great place to park your money today," said Bruce Missett of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. Based in Bentonville, Ark., Wal-Mart reported gains in stores open at least a year of 5 to 7 percent in recent months and managed small increases in earnings. 
Food makes up 19 percent of Wal-Mart's revenue over all and 31 percent of its Sam's Club division. Next year, the company will build 185 Supercenters -- grocery and discount store combinations.
But Wal-Mart's shares may be too high for new investors. The stock closed Friday at $55.10 and has a price-earnings ratio of 38, compared to 30 for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Shari Schwartsman Eberts, an analyst for J. P. Morgan Securities, recommends waiting for a dip. "The stock has been range-bound between the mid-40's and the mid-50's," she said. "I'd be more aggressive when it's below $50."
Some analysts have reservations. Margaret Gilliam, president of Gilliam & Company, an investment research firm, cautions that as Wal-Mart Supercenters make up a bigger part of the business, the company will look more like a supermarket chain, and investors "won't get the bang on the other side of the valley" when the recession ends. Furthermore, she said, the company's domestic growth will not be that great. 
BUT Ms. Eberts is counting on international expansion to increase earnings. Wal-Mart has shifted to a decentralized way of business overseas and plans to expand in Britain, China, Germany and South Korea.
Many analysts are also confident about Target, which is based in Minneapolis. The company is eking out earnings gains and has differentiated itself from Wal-Mart with upscale merchandise. 
The company's stock is valued more modestly. Based on estimates for next year's earnings, Mark Miller, of William Blair & Company, figures Target is trading at more than a 30 percent discount to Wal-Mart. There is less risk for investors, he said, and a better chance the valuation will climb. 
On the other hand, Wall Street has been negative about Kmart. "Kmart is just kind of lumbering along doing $37 billion in sales but incapable of getting a profit consistently on that sale," said Shelly Hale of Banc of America Securities.
It has not aggressively renovated stores, said Michael Niemira, an economist with Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd.
"Kmart is up against world-class retailers with lower pricing, better merchandise and a better store base," Mr. Miller said. Kmart's stock price has moved from just over $5 at the end of 2000 to $13.55 on Aug. 8 and back down. It closed Friday at $6.50. 
Wholesale clubs, selling to consumers who have done their homework, have experienced in increase in sales since Sept. 11. In addition to Sam's Clubs, which is part of Wal-Mart, BJ's Wholesale Club and the Costco Wholesale Corporation are benefiting from a surge in stockpiling by shoppers.
Michael Exstein of Credit Suisse First Boston said that Costco had made major investments in stores and warehouses and should begin to reap benefits. Costco recently had poor sales on the West Coast because of a downturn in some economic sectors there, including high technology and aeronautics. Robert Nelson, vice president for finance at Costco, acknowledged some slowing, especially in jewelry, electronics and apparel, but said that the company was building market share in the Midwest and South to gain geographic balance.
Costco will open 36 stores next year. Its per-share earnings of $1.29 for the year ended in August were 4.4 percent below the previous year. But the consensus on Wall Street is that earnings will increase to $1.48 a share for fiscal 2002.
Most department store stocks, meanwhile, are mired in low valuations. "The values are cheap, but they may stay cheap," said Daniel Barry of Merrill Lynch.
In September, sales at stores open a year were down by double-digits for the biggest players, including Federated Department Stores, which owns Macy's and Bloomingdale's; May Department Stores, which owns Lord & Taylor, Filene's, Robinson's-May and Famous-Barr; and Saks. In October, they were down 6 percent to 9 percent.
Department stores have been losing market share for years. They sell only discretionary items -- fashion that a customer may want but does not need. They are in enclosed malls, which are out of favor with time-pressed shoppers. And they mark up prices, while bargain-hunters know to wait for the sale. Some analysts think the size and balance sheets of May and Federated will help them weather a worsening storm. 
Carol Sanger, vice president for corporate affairs of Federated, said that while she anticipated sales declines in the fourth quarter, the company was cutting capital spending to maintain cash flow, "an important key to long-term growth." 
Much of the bad news is already priced into the stocks, Mr. Missett said. "A company like May Department Stores, with a 3 percent yield, better than a money market fund, is O.K. if you're willing to hold it."
But there is no hurry, several analysts said. "It will be a very tough environment for another 6 to 12 months," Mr. Barry said. 
Ms. Gilliam said she thought J. C. Penney would improve. "It made a lot of acquisitions and getting them to mix was tough," she said. Last year, Penney hired Allen Questrom, a former chief executive at both Federated and Barney's, to turn the company around. But Penney's stock has already had a strong run-up and reflects the value of Eckerd, the drugstore chain that the company is expected to spin off.
THE future looks more challenging for Saks, Dillard's and Nordstrom because they have lower sales volume and less cash flow, Mr. Exstein said. 
R. Brad Martin, chairman and chief executive of Saks, said the company's diversity -- a mix of 60 percent traditional department stores and 40 percent luxury stores -- was a source of strength. 
The company announced on Thursday that sales for its traditional department stores increased 0.2 percent over the same period last year. Sales at Saks Fifth Avenue's luxury stores, on the other hand, declined by 15.9 percent for the period.
"Our government is doing a wonderful job seeking ways to eradicate terrorism and make citizens feel secure again," Mr. Martin said. "When that happens, New York and San Francisco and Chicago will be robust environments for Saks Fifth Avenue." Meanwhile, he said, the stores geared toward middle America will contribute to the balance sheet.
