HEADLINE: RETHINK : Manifestoes For the Next New York; 
Development : And Why Not Bulldoze Lincoln Center?

BYLINE:  By Daniel Okrent; Daniel Okrent is writing a book about the history of Rockefeller Center.

 BODY:
As landmarks, they were unmistakable. As symbols, they were tragically alluring. And in the aftermath of their destruction, the towers of the World Trade Center have become justifiably sanctified, holy stations along the line of American memory that runs past Valley Forge and Gettysburg, Normandy and Iwo Jima.
 But it does not dishonor the dead or the grieving to say what has been unsaid: these were awful buildings. In their chilly blandness they corrupted the filigreed downtown skyline. In their vain gigantism, they confused "big" for "beautiful." The open space at their feet on all but the brightest days resembled a moonscape. Disconnected from the city's grid, the trade center wasn't even really part of New York. It was, instead, a hyperthyroid Stonehenge -- an urban freak. 
 A few years ago, the architectural historian Francis Morrone nailed it: he wrote that the trade center's sole virtue was that its observation decks were "the only high vantage points in New York from which the World Trade Center itself is not visible."
It's worth holding this image in mind, not allowing the distorting lens of emotion to alter our vision and lead us to reproduce what we have lost. There is a lot of rebuilding to be done, at ground zero as well as elsewhere in the city, and we have far superior models that show us not only what to do, but also how to do it. In fact, just four miles north of the trade center site stands the outstanding example of American urban design. And now, from the post-Sept. 11 perspective, its lessons are even more vivid. Born at a moment when the city was emotionally and financially devastated, Rockefeller Center became not only an engine of New York's recovery but also the symbol of its triumph. 
John D. Rockefeller, Jr., who financed the project (and whose son, Nelson, should have known better than to be a key mover behind the trade center), got into it because the Metropolitan Opera had its eyes on a piece of land for a new house, which was not the same as being willing to pay for it. When 1929 collapsed with the crash, the Met withdrew and Rockefeller was stuck with a long-term lease on 12 acres of Midtown. He brought in a development buccaneer named John R. Todd -- grandfather, as it happens, of another local governor, Christie Whitman -- who knew that well-designed, pedestrian-friendly public space has the same effect on rents that helium has on balloons. And that the wish for economic success is a far more effective motivator of quality development than the best-laid plans of civic committees.
Todd and Rockefeller desired a profit, so they wanted what potential tenants wanted: something wonderful and something lasting. They took advantage of the Depression-devastated economy not by saving a buck on labor or materials, but by spending the original budget as planned, pouring dollars freed by dropping prices into extra wiring, more steel, all the qualitative components that would enhance the buildings' value for decades. In the process, they also employed nearly 75,000 people during the eight years of construction -- eight years in which Rockefeller Center was virtually the only private construction in New York. 
Today, more than 60 years after it opened, Rockefeller Center is as vital as it has ever been, and the profits it has made for its owners are as handsome as the place itself. It connects with the city around it, yet private maintenance helps it retain a distinctive character. The ingeniously situated skating rink -- an afterthought installed after shops in the "sunken plaza" had failed -- somehow lends the towering buildings around it a measure of intimacy. Even at midday, the cross streets are relatively calm, nearly benign, as in no other part of Midtown: the scores of trucks making deliveries to the center's buildings each day disappear down a ramp off 50th Street into a subterranean loading station. 
Someone once called Rockefeller Center "a city within a city"; more accurately, for all its imposing scale, it's a village within a city, one of the only places in New York that tourists and residents cohabit with neither self-consciousness nor sneers. 
It is too soon to say that the World Trade Center should be rebuilt as Rockefeller Center II. The anguished wound is too fresh to suture with architecture. But there's an opportunity, right now, to test the modern strength of the Rockefeller Center model. As the city suffers its sudden financial pain and as Lincoln Center's dysfunctional family bloodies itself in a series of public tantrums, it's time to forget about the proposed $1.5 billion renovation -- and simply tear the place down and begin again. If this frigid collection of architectural mishaps is not quite as soulless as the trade center, it certainly comes from the same design gulag. 
So imagine this: the city grants a 99-year lease on the necessary land to an imaginative private developer who is charged with creating an arts city. There must be theaters and concert halls, of course. But more, too: scattered among the halls, adding urban texture and pedestrian traffic, a collection of bookstores, art galleries, record shops and other businesses connected to the arts. Upstairs, rehearsal halls, Off-Broadway theaters, dance studios, art studios. On the highest floors, office space pitched directly to the cultural industries -- book publishers, theatrical agencies, arts foundations. 
The economic model, also derived from Rockefeller Center, is simple: subsidies for the tenants you really, really want -- a couple of bell-cow art galleries, say, whose very presence will attract their competitors (a scheme originally devised in the early 30's by a young Rock Center rental agent named Nelson Rockefeller). Maybe a favorite-son subsidy for locally owned retailers, to give the small bookstore a chance against the chains, and to New Yorkify the place. What pays for these subsidies? A permanent rental endowment gushing from the sale of the current Lincoln Center land. It would be fitting: the old Lincoln Center lives on in its financial contribution to the new one. And, way downtown, the World Trade Center lives on in the way it teaches us what not to do next.

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE 

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
Understanding the Mideast
A new lecture series at Yale, established to help bring about deeper understanding of conflicts in the Middle East, will be inaugurated with a talk by Martin Indyk, the former American ambassador to Israel. He will speak on Thursday at 8 p.m. in the Joseph Slifka Center for Jewish Life at Yale, 80 Wall Street.
 Mr. Indyk was appointed by President Clinton as National Security Council senior director for Near East and South Asia, participating in the development of policy toward the states of Iraq, Iran and Libya. 
 Admission is free. Information:(203) 432-1134.

Loft Artists Open House
The nonprofit Loft Artists Association of Stamford holds its annual open house today from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. at the Stamford Industrial Park, 737 Canal Street. Originally a work-cum-exhibition space for a handful of painters, photographers and graphic artists, its membership has grown and broadened to include some 60 men and women who represent a broad spectrum of the visual and performing arts.
At 2 p.m. the Chalasa Dance Theater and the Renee Kahn Repertory Company will present a Jean Cocteau mime play, followed by a performance by the Ballet School of Stamford. Admission is free.

Depression Era Photos
Forty-five black and white and color prints produced during the Great Depression under President Franklin Delano Roosevelt's Works Progress Administration are at the Bruce Museum in Greenwich through Nov. 25. "Prints of American Life: W.P.A. Works on Paper" captures an era when unemployed workers were kept afloat financially through federal aid. 
After establishing need and passing examinations determining ability, artists, writers, theater groups and musicians were provided with a living wage in conformance with the Federal Arts Project of 1935.
Etchings, lithographs, wood engravings, and silk screens are in this exhibition, in styles that hewed mostly to realism. Modern art forms in Europe were not considered appropriate for works that were to reflect the lives of ordinary Americans. 
Admission is $4 for adults, $3 for children and adults over 64. Information:(203) 869-0376.

Music at Yale
A free program of English lute songs and madrigals performed by Catherine Liddell, a lutenist, will be heard today at Yale. The Yale singers and guitarists and the Yale Collegium Musicum will also play. Curtain time is 2 p.m. at the Yale Center for British Art. 
This evening at 8 p.m., four organists will celebrate the 50th anniversary of the three-manual Walter Hotkamp organ, newly installed in Battell Chapel, with a program of Bach, Muffat, Mozart and Pepping. A $5 donation will be requested at the door.

Tickets, directions or information: (203) 432-4158.

All About Mellon
Paul Mellon, founder of the Yale Center for British Art, will be the subject of a lecture by Rosamond Bernier on Thursday at 5:30 p.m. Titled "Paul Mellon: A Discerning Collector with a Genius for Giving," the talk will be held at the Yale University Art Gallery and admission is free.

Listening to Stories
Two hours of storytelling presented as five dramatized stories for adults begins on Saturday at 8 p.m. at the Unitarian Church in Westport. Tellebration 2001 is the 13th such confluence of storytellers sponsored by the Connecticut Storytelling Center and the 41-state National Storytelling Network. Tickets are $10 in advance or $12 at the door, including a post-tellebration reception. Proceeds are used for programs and workshops in schools, libraries and community groups. Reservations: (203) 255-5710.

Inside the Machine
Edith Kramer, a Viennese artist who studied at the Bauhaus before coming to the United States in the late 30's, worked as a machinist during World War II. She received permission to draw the machinery after her shift was over, eventually amassing a collection of pen and ink sketches that documented the small, specialized machine shop of the 40's.
An exhibition of her work, titled "Industrial New York," may be seen at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield through next Sunday. In addition to the drawings, her oils and watercolors of industrial sites all over the city have been exhibited across the country and abroad. Hours and directions: (203) 365-7650. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
Florio Sees a Budget Mess, But Not as Bad as His Was

BYLINE:  By David M. Halbfinger; David M. Halbfinger is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
Jim from Metuchen was on the line again. He'd called in to a radio station after the first gubernatorial debate last month with a scathing analysis of Bret D. Schundler's performance: "stunningly uninformed, and embarrassingly superficial," he'd said in that distinctive acid tone.
 Now he was talking on the telephone about the governor-elect, James E. McGreevey. About what it was like to inherit budget deficits. About what it was like to be harangued by angry Republicans. 
 Jim Florio knows whereof he speaks.
Twelve years ago, after all, he steamrolled into office after crushing James Courter by 24 percentage points. But his response to a yawning budget deficit -- a $2.8 billion tax increase -- gave rise to a Republican revolt that made him a one-term governor and drove New Jersey Democrats into the political desert.
"His deficit's going to be more substantial than mine," Mr. Florio was saying now about Mr. McGreevey's inheritance: a shortfall in the current year of more than $700 million, and projections in the next fiscal year of a $2 billion deficit.
"The part I think he has a little bit of an advantage on," Mr. Florio said, "is that everybody understands these things are coming. My situation was, there was no understanding, no discussion. I mean, Governor Kean left office pronouncing in public that he was leaving me a $300 million surplus. And when it turned out to be a $600 million shortfall in the year that we were in, that was just -- nobody paid attention until I announced it, and all of a sudden it's now Florio's problem. I think this time it'll be a little less exclusively McGreevey's problem, which is a big benefit."
So what does Mr. McGreevey do, since he is promising not to raise taxes and campaigned on a pledge to lower state debt?
"Out of the box, the options are to bring a higher degree of efficiency to government and whatever, all the rhetoric," Mr. Florio said. "The problem is that the big-ticket items in terms of economizing are local assistance, school assistance, and that's not going to be a pleasant process, to get those things down."
Cutting local aid does little but drive property taxes up -- not a sure-fire way to mount a re-election campaign, as Christie Whitman learned.
The crucible for Mr. McGreevey and the newly rebalanced Legislature, Mr. Florio said, will come when he proposes cuts that affect the groups that helped to elect him.
"He's going to submit, undoubtedly, a budget with integrity," Mr. Florio said. "It may be a painful budget. And if in fact the Legislature says, 'We can't handle all these cuts, it's against the public interest, therefore you've got to find some way of getting more revenues,' they will have to go and bite the bullet."
Mr. Florio, who learned a painful lesson about the value of salesmanship when proposing strong fiscal medicine, said that Mr. McGreevey, if he had to do the same, would be able to draw on that fateful 1990 experience, his own unique skills and the unusual boon of an unusually friendly departing governor.
Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco, he said, "could be a great help if he wants to, by having the Treasury Department come forward with their authoritative update of what the deficit is, so that this is not something that's partisan, this is something that's acknowledged by everyone."
As for his potential as a salesman, Mr. Florio pointed to Mr. McGreevey's discipline in the campaign.
"Even some of the press people are writing that he's overly scripted," he said. "Well, he has the intelligence to write the right script and be able to go out and deliver it."
The biggest danger, Mr. Florio warned, could come from Mr. McGreevey's vanquished Republican opponent, Bret D. Schundler.
"What was most troubling to me the other night," Mr. Florio said, "was his sort of campaign harangue in his concession speech."
Mr. Florio said he expected Mr. Schundler, lacking the platform of a public office, to use the news media as a megaphone to harass Mr. McGreevey.
"He's going to be out there," he said. "And frankly, you folks will all give him a forum. You'll have no choice. He'll call a press conference and he'll say things in very picturesque ways, in colorful ways, in denunciations of things."
It was not lost on Mr. Florio, of course, that Mr. Schundler spent the home stretch of his campaign employing a not unfamiliar campaign strategy: likening Mr. McGreevey to Mr. Florio, and conjuring up the 1990 tax increases to appeal to taxpayers' fears.
But Mr. Florio said he believed that just as tarring Democrats as liberals had lost its oomph, the Florio stigma, used over and over by Republican candidates at every level in the last 10 years, had at last lost its punch.
"I think what you're going to see is this is the last time," he said, "because it's just becoming more and more transparent that trying to beat up on -- whether it be me, or the policies of 11 years ago now -- there's transparently an effort not to want to address the things that you have to address now. This is a wonderful example of how you almost are colossally insensitive to the fact that it was something of ancient history for most people.
"So I think it has run its course," he said.
So, Mr. Florio was asked, you can now rest easy in your political grave?
"Well, I think I would put it in a different way."

HEADLINE: With Sagging Economy as Ally, Democrats in Congress Go on the Attack 

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 

 BODY:
The halls of Congress will reverberate with shouts of "big corporations," "class warfare," and "bioterrorism" next week, unless the phrase "point of order" drowns them out.
 With the bipartisanship of September in tatters, Democrats are on the attack in both houses, sensing that a sagging economy will help them in next year's elections and that they can paint Republicans as insensitive to distress. 
 In the Senate they are pushing a $66.4 billion economic stimulus bill tilted heavily toward direct help for the unemployed.
Republicans argue that tax cuts for people with high incomes and corporations will lead to investments that create more jobs. Some also contend that pushing a plan that President Bush opposes verges on the unpatriotic. And they regularly condemned the Democrats for pushing ahead without trying for a compromise with them. 
"Power politics," complained Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska.
The Senate battle lines may seem familiar enough, but in the House, Democrats will be trying to outflank Republicans by contending that the country needs to spend more on homeland defense, from protection from biological terrorism to more money for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. That fight will be over adding money to the defense appropriations bill. The Republicans may stick with President Bush and block that spending, but they seem less likely to be able to thwart a bid for $11 billion more for New York City.
In the House, the Rules Committee can always erect barriers to results that the Republican leaders oppose. In the Senate, though, the rules are already there, and it will take 60 votes to allow the Democratic plan (or a Republican alternative or a centrist compromise) to go forward.
The issue would not arise over a filibuster, which could make the side forcing delay look bad, but over a point of order raised under the 1974 Budget Act.
The procedural objection would be that no stimulus bill was authorized by the joint budget resolution passed earlier this year. Republicans insist that they plan to use that rule to kill the Democratic bill, so they can make the majority sit down and negotiate.
Ron Bonjean, press secretary for Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the minority leader, said, "Senator Lott and the Republicans think this is nothing but a pork barrel bill that does nothing to stimulate the economy."
But nothing Republicans can do will preclude at last some debate on the issue, and Democrats will concentrate their fire on one element in the House bill -- about $16 billion in refunds to big corporations for payments in the last 15 years under the alternative minimum tax, enacted in 1986 to ensure that big companies paid at least some taxes. (A Senate Republican plan would also eliminate the tax, but only in the future.)
Democrats were citing some of the big beneficiaries this week and saying what could be done with the money instead of giving it back. Senator Barbara Boxer of California, for example, said that with the $1.4 billion for I.B.M. and the $1 billion for Ford "you could vaccinate every man, woman and child in America against smallpox."
Even if the corporate rebate checks are not part of some eventual legislation, Democrats plan to use the idea against Republicans next fall. Jim Jordan, executive director of the Democratic Senate Campaign Committee, called the plan "ostentatiously bad politics."
"It's amazing," Mr. Jordan said, "how the Republicans go out of their way to prove they are the party of rich folks and corporations."
The Republican strategy is two-pronged. The first is to demand that the Democrats be bipartisan and negotiate (to which the Democrats reply that they do not want to negotiate first with Senate Republicans and then with the House). The second is to denounce the Democratic bill over various items in it, like $5 billion for farmers or in a $20 billion spending amendment that the senator who assembled it, Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, says will protect the nation from bioterrorism and increase security for nuclear plants.
For example, Representative J. C. Watts of Oklahoma, chairman of the House Republican conference, this week called the Democratic plan just "a special interest grab bag."
Democrats sounded undeterred. On Friday, with most of their colleagues away for a long weekend, several Democratic senators prepared for next week by taking oratorical batting practice.
Senator Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois, said the House Republican bill amounted to "a great deal of tax relief for the biggest corporations in America."
"This is profiteering in the name of patriotism," Mr. Durbin said.
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, said the time had come "to put national interests ahead of narrow partisan interests" and support the Democratic bill.
Senator Byrd, whose hard-won reputation for looking after his state leads some people to call him a pork-barrel politician, said the House bill was "the epitome of pork."
"It drips, it drips with lard," Mr. Byrd said.
Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, attacked what she called the "big, irresponsible giveaways that the House engaged in." Like Mr. Lieberman, Mrs. Clinton contended that tax cuts would not be spent but that extra unemployment benefits would be.
"If there is any dollar that will be spent immediately into our economy," she said, "it is unemployment insurance."
The only Republican around to answer them was Senator Murkowski. "What we're going to see next week," he said, "is almost a class warfare on the issue of the stimulus."
He said the way to stimulate the economy was not federal spending but tax cuts that would encourage the wealthy to invest.
The best stimulus plan of all, Mr. Murkowski said, would be to allow drilling for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, which he said would create 250,000 jobs.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Another Useful Crisis

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Remember California's energy crisis? It illustrated, in particularly stark form, the political strategy of the Bush administration before Sept. 11. The basic principle of this strategy -- which was also used to sell that $2 trillion tax cut -- was that crises weren't problems to be solved. Instead, they were opportunities to advance an agenda that had nothing to do with the crisis at hand.
 It is now clear that, at least as far as domestic policy is concerned, the administration views terrorism as another useful crisis. 
 Let's recall the California story. Between November 2000 and June 2001 -- or, if you prefer, between last year's election and James Jeffords's defection, which gave the Democrats control of the Senate -- a shortage of electric generating capacity, exacerbated by the puzzling fact that much of this capacity stood idle, led to power outages and extremely high prices.
The appropriate response was obvious. First, encourage conservation until new capacity could be added; second, temporarily cap prices, both to limit the financial damage and to discourage power companies from manipulating the market.
But Dick Cheney dismissed conservation as a mere "sign of personal virtue," and administration officials waved aside pleas for a price ceiling. Instead, they used California's woes to push for large subsidies to the coal industry, and, of course, drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. We never did learn what all this had to do with electricity generation.
Eventually, price controls were imposed, and the idle capacity mysteriously came back on line; meanwhile, conservation led to a sharp drop in demand, and the crisis evaporated.
Now to the present. After Sept. 11, we need to spend substantial sums on reconstruction and homeland security, and the sagging economy could use a temporary stimulus. But George W. Bush has threatened to veto any additional domestic spending beyond the $40 billion already agreed upon -- "We wage a war to save civilization itself," he declared on Thursday, but apparently this war must not cost more than 0.4 percent of G.D.P. And the administration favors "stimulus" proposals that have nothing to do with helping the economy, but everything to do with its usual tax-cutting agenda.
The stimulus package introduced by Senate Democrats isn't perfect, by a long shot -- it contains billions of dollars for things like agricultural price supports, which don't belong there. But at least $70 billion of its $90 billion is real stimulus, in the form of temporary investment incentives, temporary grants of income support and medical care to the unemployed, and checks to low-income families who are likely to spend them.
The administration, however, favors the Senate Republicans' proposal; while that bill is less lurid than the one passed by the House, with its huge retroactive tax cuts for big corporations (according to Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush was "pleased" with the House bill), over all it's just as bad. It would cost $220 billion over three years; less than $20 billion of that total seems to have anything to do with economic stimulus. 
The rest of the proposal consists of tax cuts for corporations and high-income individuals, structured in such a way that they will do little to increase spending during the current recession. For example, tax incentives for investment are valid not for one year -- as in the Democratic bill -- but for three years; this is an open invitation to companies not to invest now, when the economy needs a boost, but instead to delay investments until the economy has already recovered. 
Why does the administration's favored bill offer so little stimulus? Because that's not its purpose: it's really designed to lock in permanent tax cuts for corporations and the wealthy, using the Sept. 11 attacks as an excuse. 
Ten months into the Bush administration, we've all gotten used to this. But politics, while never completely clean, didn't used to be this cynical. We used to see bills like the Democratic stimulus package: mostly serving their ostensible purpose, with the special-interest add-ons a distinctly secondary feature. It's something new to see crises -- especially a crisis as shocking as the terrorist attack -- consistently addressed with legislation that does almost nothing to address the actual problem, and is almost entirely aimed at advancing a pre-existing agenda. 
Oh, by the way: the administration is once again pushing for drilling in the Arctic. You see, it's essential to the fight against terrorism.

HEADLINE: Russia's Germ Warfare Secrets 

 BODY:
A top Russian scientist issued a little-noticed warning last week that impoverished experts from Russia's former biological weapons programs may be up for sale to any terrorist organization willing to pay the price. As the United States mobilizes to develop defenses against bioterrorism, it urgently needs reliable intelligence on just what has happened to the people and materials that gave the Soviet Union the most frightening arsenal of biological weapons ever developed. A more vigorous effort to bring Russian expertise, weapons formulas and biological materials under better control should be on the agenda this week when President Bush meets with Vladimir Putin, the Russian president. 
 The scale and variety of the Soviet program were stunning. In a cynical betrayal of international trust, Moscow took the signing of a biological weapons convention in 1972 as the signal to start a clandestine crash program to expand its biological weaponry, not abandon such weapons as required. At its peak, in the late 1980's, the program involved a vast complex of production plants and research facilities, employed some 60,000 scientists and technicians, and produced thousands of tons of anthrax and hundreds of tons of smallpox and plague, among some 50 biological agents that were studied as weapons. Soviet scientists also worked out ways to make some germ weapons impervious to antibiotics and did genetic engineering experiments that suggested a desire to combine Ebola and smallpox to make an especially fearsome weapon. 
 Then, in a 1992 change of course, Russia announced that it was terminating its germ-warfare program and dismantling its production lines. Western experts were subsequently allowed in to inspect several of the sites. But no one knows for sure whether or not some of the lethal stocks were stolen and smuggled out of the country or whether some of the unemployed scientists and technicians have sold their services to rogue nations or even terrorist groups. There are credible if anecdotal reports of Russian scientists going to Iran, Iraq and North Korea. There are also concerns that Russian military scientists may still be conducting secret research on biological weapons. The Kremlin has refused to let outsiders visit some of the former military sites.
The United States badly needs more information on the whereabouts of key scientists, engineers and materials from the former Soviet biological weapons complex. That could help determine what biological dangers may be loose in the world and thus what threats require the most urgent attention in homeland defenses. Moscow could surely help obtain such information from individuals who worked at the former weapons sites. 
If Mr. Bush and Mr. Putin genuinely want to contain biological terrorism, it should be possible to craft a deal. For his part, Mr. Bush could expand a program that already awards grants for civilian research to scientists who worked in the Soviet chemical, biological and nuclear weapons programs. The goal is to prevent the drain of weapons talent from Russia to rogue nations or terrorist groups. Mr. Putin needs to open his last remaining biological warfare facilities to inspection and help determine whether any experts and materials have already escaped.

HEADLINE: THE NATION; 
Breaking the Laws in New York City

BYLINE:  By JAMES TRAUB; James Traub writes frequently about New York City and its politics.

 BODY:
UNTIL very recently, virtually the entire community of political handicappers in New York viewed the mayoral candidacy of Michael R. Bloomberg as a self-indulgent lark. Just two weeks ago, even one of his close advisers was arguing that if Mr. Bloomberg did better than Ruth W. Messinger, a Democrat who won 42 percent of the vote in 1997, that should be deemed a moral victory. This was so not only because of Mr. Bloomberg's obvious limitations as a first-time candidate, but because of the immutable laws of New York politics. Here is how several of those laws were articulated by political experts this summer:
 "The only time Republicans get elected mayor is when Democrats are angry at the Democratic incumbent or angry at the people running the party." 
 "You can buy an election in New Jersey, where media is so expensive and free media is so ineffectual; but you can't buy an election that way in New York." 
"New Yorkers are not enormously impressed with business experience."
One of the questions raised by Mr. Bloomberg's stunning victory is whether any of those laws still hold. 
If Mr. Bloomberg is embarking on a new life, the Democrats are going through a kind of identity crisis. New York has been essentially a one-party town since the rise of Tammany Hall in the mid-19th century, and Mr. Bloomberg is the first Republican in New York history to succeed another Republican. "Politics has now been individualized," says Hank Sheinkopf, a consultant whose clients included Mark Green. "The long death of the party organizations and the influence of consultants and money have made that a fact."
New Yorkers continue to vote Democratic in other races, but in apparent violation of the first law, both moderate-to-conservative white democratic voters and more liberal Hispanics crossed party lines to vote for Mr. Bloomberg. (That he was a lifelong Democrat who switched, he said, because "You cannot as a wealthy guy get the Democratic nomination," made it easier.) 
What was unique about this election was the willingness of Hispanics, traditionally loyal Democrats, to vote G.O.P. Many of them were disgusted with Mr. Green for what they considered racially loaded campaign tactics in his primary against Fernando Ferrer, but they could have stayed home. It appears that Hispanic voters in New York, like those in Florida, Texas and elsewhere, are now open to Republican candidates. 
The rationale for the second law is as follows: In most areas, a media blitz can overwhelm local coverage. In New Jersey, for example, Jon Corzine, a former head of Goldman Sachs, was elected to the Senate after spending $63 million on TV ads. But in New York City, with four daily newspapers, weekly magazines, local TV affiliates and a television news station all its own, free media trumps paid.
And yet Mr. Bloomberg did it. There were times over the summer when campaign coverage seemed to consist exclusively of a sort of Bloomberg Gaffe Watch. But it didn't matter. Mr. Bloomberg was able to shape his public image as a pragmatic, no-nonsense business leader through a series of well-crafted television commercials that ran 6,500 times. And if even in the most clamorous media market in the country a candidate can spend his way to victory, then the "self-financed" candidate is bound to be the wave of the future everywhere.
Is it true? Many experts believe that a bizarre convergence of events and phenomena -- Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's outsized personality, the catastrophe of Sept. 11, war preparations, anthrax, the World Series -- distracted readers and thus exaggerated the value of paid media. The Democrats hope so.
THE third adage goes to the heart of the city's political tradition. "Politics" has become a dirty word in most of America. It is what you run against. Even a state like Minnesota, with its progressive political traditions, has the former wrestler Jesse Ventura as governor. In New York, politics is still an noble calling, and the Democrat, Mark Green, confidently mocked Mr. Bloomberg as an amateur. But Mr. Bloomberg called himself "a leader, not a politician," and it worked. 
Ken Sunshine, an adviser to Mr. Green, said that he was shocked that Mr. Bloomberg's gaffes were not held against him. The public attitude, he said, was, "He's not like a slick politician who would have thought before speaking." At the same time, despite Mr. Green's long record of public service and mastery of policy, Mr. Bloomberg successfully argued that Mr. Green lacked the skills to cut the budget and rebuild the city. 
Why he succeeded is suggested by exit polls. Only 26 percent of Mr. Bloomberg's voters said that he "understands the city and its problems." Just 38 percent thought he had "the right experience" to govern. Mr. Green won easily on both counts. But Mr. Bloomberg won when voters were asked if their candidate "would be strong in a crisis" and "is not a typical politician." 
The figures imply a dim view of politics as a profession, as well as an almost naive faith in corporate managerial gifts. Coincidentally, perhaps, the two other city officials elected on Tuesday, Betsy Gotbaum as public advocate and William C. Thompson as comptroller, had never held elective office before either. 
Mark Penn, a pollster whose firm worked for Mr. Bloomberg, points out that Mark Warner, another wealthy entrepreneur, was just elected governor of Virginia by offering precisely what Mr. Bloomberg offered New Yorkers: "Business acumen at a time of economic decline." Mr. Warner is a Democrat in a Republican state, and Mr. Penn argues that voters are not so much devaluing politicians as matching the candidates to the demands of the moment. 
The notion that politicians are suitable for business-as-usual, while businessmen should handle crises, would certainly have surprised the dauntless Fiorello LaGuardia, who led New York through the Depression, or F.D.R. They understood that political leadership is an art form, a public act, very different from "management." It is, Mr. Bloomberg may soon discover, harder than it looks.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE GATEKEEPERS; 
Adept in Politics and Advertising, 4 Women Shape a Campaign

BYLINE:  By PETER MARKS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 

 BODY:
Twenty-four hours after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, President Bush summoned his close aide Karen P. Hughes, telling her that the job of coordinating wartime public relations for the government would be hers.
 "When he called me in that morning, he told me that this will be an ongoing process of educating the public," said Ms. Hughes, counselor to the president. "He said, 'O.K., go for it.' " 
 In the following weeks, Ms. Hughes, a former television reporter in Texas who led media operations in the Bush presidential campaign, has settled into the role of chief keeper of the message. She works closely with three other women: Victoria Clarke, chief Pentagon spokeswoman; Charlotte Beers, under secretary of state for public diplomacy; and Mary Matalin, chief political adviser to Vice President Dick Cheney.
The four are among the Bush administration's most important shapers of the words and images that the allies are seeking to convey to a global audience. (Others include Ari Fleischer, the president's press secretary, and James Wilkinson, a Hughes deputy who has set up a comprehensive center to counter Taliban propaganda.) They talk several times a day -- including a daily 9:30 a.m. agenda-setting conference call, presided over by Ms. Hughes -- and bounce ideas off one another frequently.
In the male-dominated machinery of war, it is a rarity, even in enlightened times, to find so many women in highly visible roles with the responsibility for trying to influence public opinion about military operations and other aspects of a conflict.
And their relationship is even more unusual, founded in the deep connections at least three of them forged in long stints in Republican politics and on the campaign trail.
"Three of us have not worked together in just this war," said Ms. Matalin, who is perhaps the best known of the team, as a longtime adviser to Mr. Bush's father, a Republican commentator on television and the wife of James Carville, a Democratic political consultant. 
Of the four, Ms. Matalin, 48, also enjoys perhaps the warmest relations with Washington reporters. She also speaks warmly of the intimacy she feels in working with the other women. "I know how Torie thinks," she said, invoking Ms. Clarke's nickname. "I know what Karen thinks. We skip right past the pleasantries."
If the nature of the collaboration is unusual, so is the nature of the event. "This is a very uncommon war," said Ms. Clarke, who worked in the presidential campaign of Senator John McCain of Arizona last year and was press secretary to Mr. Bush's father in his unsuccessful bid for re-election in 1992.
"This is not just about military matters," she added, explaining that the scope of the conflict requires the message makers to consider diplomacy, economics and law.
The women have other common pursuits. Like the other three, Ms. Beers, 66, who did not return calls seeking comment, also comes from the world of image making, but her background is Madison Avenue, rather than Pennsylvania Avenue. She is the former chairwoman of the giant advertising agencies Ogilvy & Mather and J. Walter Thompson. Ms. Clarke, too, once worked in advertising, as president of Bozell Eskew Advertising, which specializes in issue advocacy and corporate communications.
That they share a background in selling images or ideas may be fortunate, some political observers say. "In some ways, the challenge this White House team faces is very similar to being in a political campaign," said Martin Kaplan, a former chief speechwriter for Vice President Walter F. Mondale and now associate dean of the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Southern California.
Although some in the administration acknowledge privately that in the early weeks after the attacks, the allies were slow to develop a response to statements by Taliban officials, Ms. Hughes and others say that a strategy is taking root. In the coming weeks, Ms. Hughes said, the press operations, under a newly formed umbrella group, the Coalition Information Center, will highlight issues, like the Taliban's treatment of women, that cast the Afghan leadership in a negative light. The first lady, Laura Bush, is expected to be enlisted as a leading voice of that information campaign, she added.
Ms. Matalin said it was perhaps not a coincidence that such issues would be front and center.
"I think we probably bring -- and I don't mean this to sound sexist -- but we probably have more of a subconscious outrage at these issues," she said. "This is something that crosses my mind every day: a third of these women in pre-Taliban days were doctors, lawyers and teachers. You can't help but be outraged."

HEADLINE: 'Fog of War' Marks Campaign as Australia Re-elects Leadership 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SHAW 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 10 

 BODY:
Prime Minister John Howard and his conservative government won a third term today in national elections that focused on security and immigration issues. 
 Mr. Howard, 62, who took a hard-line stance against illegal immigration and emphasized his support for the American-led war against terrorism, won with an increased majority, according to counts by election officials and computer projections by news media analysts. 
 With 80 percent of the vote counted, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation reported that Mr. Howard's Liberal Party had won 67 seats in the 150-seat lower house of Parliament. Its junior coalition partner, the National Party, won 12 seats, giving them a majority. The rival Labor Party, led by Kim Beazley, 52, a former defense minister, won 65 seats, the network reported. 
Australians also chose lawmakers for 40 of the 76 seats in the Senate. 
Mr. Beazley, who has led his party for six years, conceded defeat and withdrew from the leadership, saying, "We fought in the adverse circumstances of the fog of war."
The re-election of the Howard government will consolidate Australia's cordial official links with the United States. "All of us are deeply conscious of the changes that have come over the world and therefore over our nation since the terrible events in the United States of Sept. 11," Mr. Howard said.
Labor's promises for modest improvements in health, education, tax and welfare programs were not enough to oust a government that oversaw six years of general economic progress. 
A clear majority of the 12 million voters approved of Mr. Howard's prompt commitment of a 1,500-strong Australian force to support the American war effort in Afghanistan and also of his recent refusal to grant asylum to nearly 2,000 refugees from Muslim countries.
Elected to Parliament in 1972, Mr. Howard is the fourth Australian prime minister to win a third term.He is perceived as being more conservative than many of his colleagues on issues like reconciliation with the Aborigines, the indigenous black minority, and the nation's evolution to a republic, severing ceremonial ties to the British monarchy. 
His foreign policy priority will be to improve relations with neighboring Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim nation, which has been accused of tolerating smugglers that ferry Muslim refugees and economic migrants into Australian waters. 
Throughout the five-week election campaign, reports of the 2,000 asylum seekers on about a dozen boats that were turned back by the navy or shipped to detention camps, received extensive coverage, reinforcing the government's emphasis on border protection and overshadowing Labor's focus on social reforms.
The Labor Party held a slim advantage in opinion polls until August when Mr. Howard's rating surged by 15 percentage points after he refused entry to the asylum seekers. Most were refugees from Afghanistan, Iraq, Iran and other Muslim countries seeking asylum in Australia. 
Australia grants only three-year "temporary protection" visas to unauthorized arrivals deemed to be genuine refugees but gives full rights to about 12,000 United Nations-authorized refugees each year.
About 1,200 candidates from three mainstream parties and three minor groups, including environmentalist and watchdog activists, sought election to the House of Representatives where the government had held a seven-seat margin since re-election in 1998.

HEADLINE: Putin Urges A 'New Level' Of the Trust With America 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 10 

 BODY:
Days before a much-anticipated meeting with President Bush, President Vladimir V. Putin called tonight for Russia and the United States to bury the vestiges of their cold war suspicions and form an alliance with "a qualitatively new level" of trust.
 Underscoring that, he said emphatically that Russia did not regard the mushrooming role of the United States in Central Asia, the heartland of the former Soviet Union, as either a strategic or an economic threat. 
 While he offered no details, Mr. Putin also said he was "very optimistic" that the two nations would eventually strike a deal to rewrite the 30-year-old rules of nuclear-arms control fundamentally. 
In a broad-ranging interview with American journalists in the Kremlin's presidential library, Mr. Putin clearly intended to set a high tone for his American visit, which includes a two-day stopover at Mr. Bush's ranch in Texas next week.
He said several times that he felt not only that he and Mr. Bush had established a close personal relationship, but also that the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the United States had given their nations a common cause and the seeds of a lasting alliance.
"We would like our joint struggle against terrorism to lead to positive results, that terrorism not only in Afghanistan but the entire world be destroyed, uprooted, liquidated," Mr. Putin said. Only a coordinated strategy will allow civilized nations to respond quickly and adequately to what promises to be a long campaign against terrorists, he said.
"It is quite obvious to any objective observer," he said, "that we can find an effective response to these challenges only if we pull our efforts together."
Beyond that, Mr. Putin said both nations must shed "the fears of the past" linked to their cold war rivalry, and accept that they now share not only democratic values and ambitions, but also the same commitment to market economics. 
Americans who think otherwise, he said, "simply do not understand the way the world has changed."
Perhaps his most striking example was Russia's new attitude in the former Soviet nations of Central Asia, where the growing American military presence has convinced many Russian military officials and private experts that Washington wants to push Moscow out of its historic sphere of influence.
Mr. Putin rejected that argument as an example of cold war thinking that automatically pits the United States and Russia as rivals. In fact, he said, their common cause against terrorism and their increasing cooperation in developing oil fields in the area make clear that they have common interests.
"What was important in the former system of coordinates and the former reference framework now is losing its importance," he said. "If Russia is now becoming a full-fledged member of the international community, then we must not fear, and we will not fear, the development of relations between its neighbors and other countries and nations."
"The times have long gone when Russia viewed the world as needing a confrontational approach," he said. "We are not for this. We are quite the opposite now." 
He also called for Russia and the United States to move toward settlements on other issues that have divided them, led by the yearlong standoff over Washington's plans to build a limited national missile defense.
He said Russia was prepared to negotiate changes in the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, which prohibits national defenses against missiles, "when we see specific options" from American experts, something he said had yet to occur.
"It will be up to the political leaders to make a choice between different options, and I am very optimistic that they can be found," he said.
Mr. Putin reiterated Russia's opposition to a proposal that would expand the NATO alliance to include three Baltic nations -- Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, which once were part of the Soviet Union.
But at the same time, he suggested that a shift of NATO's mission away from the purely defensive alliance that once opposed Soviet force, and toward a group that combats international terrorism and weapons proliferation, could "rekindle the nature of the alliance."
Russia could offer a great deal to such an organization, he said.
"I can tell you frankly that I have certain ideas of a general nature," he said. "I can't elaborate on them now, but they are very promising."
Asked tonight whether he believed a claim by Osama bin Laden that the Qaeda organization possesses nuclear and chemical weapons, Mr. Putin said such statements were generally made in an attempt to sow panic. He said he was certain that none of Russia's weapons of mass destruction had fallen into terrorist hands.

HEADLINE: Bloomberg Recipe: Luck, Lots of Cash and a Hands-On Role 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

 BODY:
Thirty-six hours before the polls opened on Election Day, a wave of gloom swept through the Republican mayoral campaign of Michael R. Bloomberg. After a steady climb in the opinion polls, the race was suddenly threatening to slip away. 
 The problem was a politically explosive brochure being distributed in support of Mr. Bloomberg by Republicans in Staten Island. In some ways it was not unlike racially charged materials used against Fernando Ferrer by supporters of Mark Green in the final days of the Democratic runoff. Mr. Bloomberg had denounced that effort and the Staten Island brochure threatened to cast him as a hypocrite. 
 "It hit like a bullet," said William Cunningham, a top Bloomberg strategist. 
Said another campaign staff member: "I actually did think the race was over."
That the race was not over is very much the story of Mr. Bloomberg's astonishing evolution from a first-time and sometimes clumsy candidate to mayor-elect of the nation's biggest and most complex city. There was a lot of luck. There was a lot of money and high-priced strategy. And there was a lot of Mr. Bloomberg's being a hands-on manager who liked a good fight, but who had imposed one cardinal rule about his campaign: he would not sacrifice his good name to win the election. This triple combination helped navigate the candidacy through a series of rocky moments over five months of campaigning that might easily have sunk other candidacies, and that nearly took his down as well.
As it turned out, some of Mr. Bloomberg's biggest doubters were regulars at 126 East 56th Street, where the eventual victor's campaign was based. As late as 10:30 p.m. on Tuesday, one of Mr. Bloomberg's paid consultants was quietly telling reporters at the Bloomberg party at the B. B. King Blues Club and Grill on West 42nd Street that Mr. Green would win. Meanwhile, across the street at the Hilton, Mr. Cunningham was contemplating the makings of a legal team in case the election ended up in court.
In a suite down the hall, Mr. Bloomberg was working on his speech, which he had crafted into three versions: win, lose and too close to call. Despite having made billions in the news-information and computer industries, his words were handwritten, as was his custom throughout the campaign. Even the election results, as they came in by telephone that night, were scribbled on a yellow pad with a felt pen.
"Mike is a very big boy," said David Garth, Mr. Bloomberg's top strategist, who would offer only hints about his candidate's expectations for the night. "He understands reality. He knew from the beginning what he was getting himself into."
As for himself, Mr. Garth was unequivocal. He always thought that Mr. Bloomberg would lose. He was not persuaded otherwise until after midnight on Wednesday.
"I thought we were going to have a terrific race and lose by about five points," Mr. Garth said.
As circumstances would have it, the worst act of terrorism in American history would not only make Mr. Bloomberg's private-sector credentials more appealing to the electorate, but it would also turn his most influential backer -- Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- into a national hero. "When Rudy put his arm around Mike, literally, that was the campaign," Mr. Garth said.
As money would have it, Mr. Bloomberg would break campaign spending records by pouring at least $41 million of his personal fortune into the race. The money bought him people like Mr. Garth and Mr. Cunningham who, together, cost Mr. Bloomberg about $1 million. It also allowed him to bypass a press corps he regarded as hostile.
He swamped the postal system with targeted direct mail, some of it in Spanish, and sent videotapes to individual voters. He bought advertisements in ethnic and community newspapers in all five boroughs. And he inundated the airwaves with a variety of commercials, including one featuring Mr. Giuliani that appeared several times in high-priced slots during the late innings of the World Series.
"He didn't poor-mouth you over the money and didn't complain," Mr. Garth said. "His attitude was don't cut unless it was not helpful to the campaign."
And as Mr. Bloomberg would have it, he would not be intimidated by his rookie political status, picking and choosing the advice of his veteran campaign staff and generally exercising control over his own destiny. His decisions sometimes frustrated his advisers -- when, for example, he rejected some hard-hitting advertisements against Mr. Green -- but he said he was most comfortable living with his own mistakes.
"There are times that it gets frustrating and you want to tear your hair out," Mr. Bloomberg said on his final day of campaigning. "But the faults in the campaign are mine, not my staff. My staff has done everything I could ever ask for."
Last Sunday, it was his staff that first confronted the looming crisis in Staten Island. As reporters began calling with questions about the brochure -- which featured pictures of Mr. Green with former Mayor David N. Dinkins, the city's first black mayor, and contained some ominous language about their relationship -- several of Mr. Bloomberg's closest advisers convened an urgent meeting on the seventh floor of the East 56th Street headquarters. It was around dinnertime and Mr. Bloomberg was campaigning in Queens, first with former Mayor Edward I. Koch and then with Gov. George E. Pataki. He would be filled in when he returned to Manhattan.
Mr. Cunningham was at the meeting. Among the others were Patricia E. Harris, Kevin Sheekey, Edward Skyler and Vincent Lapadula. Calls were put out to Leticia Remauro, the Republican Party chairwoman in Staten Island, and to Christopher Hellstrom, the campaign's borough coordinator there. Though some details were hazy, the information gleaned from those telephone conversations made for some of the most anxious hours of the campaign.
Ms. Remauro had indeed printed and distributed the brochures and Mr. Hellstrom, while apparently not involved, had been aware of what she had done and had not passed the information along. It was even possible that some brochures had been distributed to Mr. Bloomberg's volunteers from the campaign's Staten Island office.
"I thought we were dead," one campaign staff member said. "We needed to bring it to resolution that night and make Mike look more positive than negative."
Mr. Lapadula, who is from Staten Island and who had worked for Mayor Giuliani before joining the campaign, was sent to Staten Island, where he fired Mr. Hellstrom that night. Ms. Remauro was told to pull back the literature. A fax went to the state Republican Party demanding the same.
And when Mr. Bloomberg returned to Manhattan, he reacted swiftly, using a scheduled radio interview that night to denounce the brochure and express outrage and unhappiness with the turn of events. The next morning, he called Mr. Dinkins. "I felt personally insulted and apologized to him," Mr. Bloomberg said of their conversation.
As things turned out, the incident was not the candidate killer that Mr. Bloomberg's staff had feared. In fact, it was almost forgotten by the time the polls opened on Tuesday. The immediate effort by Mr. Bloomberg's advisers to limit the damage had been successful. And Mr. Bloomberg's decision to confront the problem head-on -- both on radio and in a telephone conversation with Mr. Dinkins -- clearly distinguished his approach from that of Mr. Green during the aftermath of the Democratic runoff with Mr. Ferrer.
"Mike said to us very often during the campaign: 'I must be able to look myself in the mirror. I have to be able to tell my daughters what I did that day without being embarrassed,' " Mr. Cunningham said. "He needed to know that his core values and reputation would be intact when this was over. He was not going to sacrifice 59 years of building a name and being honest and straightforward at the altar of politics in New York."
The staff had done its part. Mr. Bloomberg had done his. And then there was the luck.
This time it came from the Yankees. The brochure had to compete for attention with Game 7 of the World Series and the Yankees' heartbreaking loss in the bottom of the ninth inning. Most New Yorkers were talking Monday morning about the Yankees closer Mariano Rivera, not Mr. Bloomberg. Mr. Cunningham said he was relieved when he picked up the newspapers on Monday morning and saw the Yankees everywhere.
"Luck plays a very big part in politics," he said.
There were other times when Mr. Bloomberg's road to City Hall was as bumpy -- and unconventional -- as it was unlikely.
After he officially announced his candidacy on June 5, the campaign survived a spate of verbal miscues by Mr. Bloomberg that alternately offended some police officers and firefighters, some Jews, some African Americans and some civil libertarians. 
Many of his comments, if taken in context or if expanded upon by Mr. Bloomberg in a different setting, were not nearly as outlandish as they first appeared. But the damage was done. Mastering the sound bite was one of the hardest lessons for Mr. Bloomberg.
"There were times when he was just dispirited by the press," said Jonathan T. Capehart, a campaign staff member who had been a journalist at The Daily News. "He would say: 'I just don't get it. Why are they doing this?' "
As he became a more experienced campaigner, Mr. Bloomberg made fewer off-the-cuff slip-ups. In the final month, a new speechwriter was added to the staff who seemed to have a better appreciation for his tone and mannerisms, making it more likely that Mr. Bloomberg would follow his texts. Nonetheless, Mr. Bloomberg continued to resist efforts by some handlers to make him more scripted and to stay on message.
"Mike didn't feel that he could be compelling if he was checking every word he said," said Mr. Skyler, who as Mr. Bloomberg's spokesman spent more time with him on the campaign trail than any other staff member. "He knew that if he wasn't compelling, he wouldn't be able to win people over. It was a chance that he took. And obviously he made the right choice."
At a breakfast speech to Crain's New York Business on Oct. 17, he surprised his own staff when he broke from the prepared text about economic development and proposed turning Governors Island into an educational center with high schools and college campuses. Though the idea had been bantered about before, it was never intended to be publicly disclosed that morning.
The suggestion became one of the most talked about parts of Mr. Bloomberg's speech -- and was ultimately turned against him by Mr. Green in campaign appearances and in one of their debates.
"Mike, for better or worse, spoke his mind," said Maureen Connelly, a former press secretary to Mayor Koch and a Bloomberg consultant. "Mike is someone who wants to try out ideas. He is an inventor. He was more involved than any other candidate I have worked for in the development of policy."
In another pivotal defeat for conventional wisdom, Mr. Bloomberg was able to turn his enormous personal wealth into a political asset, beyond just being able to buy more advertising than his opponents are. He made the case that his independence from special interests put him above reproach. He talked openly about his philanthropy and doing good with his money and humbly about the roots of his own success.
As the campaign progressed, public opinion polls began showing that most voters were not concerned about his money.
When the economy began to sour, even ahead of the Sept. 11 terror attacks, the luck factor again came into play. The idea of a rich, self-made businessman with lots of connections to the private sector suddenly seemed more comforting than threatening. 
"He was always such a long shot, that when things started to turn, I remember turning to his daughter Emma, and saying, 'You know, your father can really win this,' " Ms. Connelly said. "She said, 'Yeah, I think so too.' "

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL: INSIDE THE N.B.A.; 
A Dip in Attendance And a Rise in Angst

BYLINE:  By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
Gary Payton tried to keep up with Jason Kidd on Thursday night in the Meadowlands, a hoop-junkie matchup between two Oakland playground legends acknowledged as the game's two elite point guards. The listed attendance was 5,277 -- for a building holding 20,049 seats.
 Tim Duncan, David Robinson and the San Antonio Spurs played the same night before 9,511 in Charlotte Coliseum, barely half full. 
 The Nets and the Hornets, whose attendance woes are hardly new, play in arenas with few amenities compared with some of the league's more modern facilities.
Also, during the season's first week, a riveting World Series competed with the N.B.A. for fans' time and attention. 
Yet even with those disclaimers, and based on very early returns, the league may experience more economic pain over the next few months.
Through Thursday night's games, the N.B.A. has seen a slight drop of 3.3 percent in average attendance, to 16,153 a game from 16,784 at the end of last season.
The Nets may be the most disturbing harbinger of all. They made a blockbuster trade for an All-Star -- Kidd for Stephon Marbury -- and signed a bona fide center in Todd MacCulloch to upgrade their roster. The Nets won four of their first five games to take the lead in the Atlantic Division.
Still, the Nets are last in attendance, averaging 6,547 fans; yesterday's game against Cleveland drew 5,631. The Nets finished 27th in attendance last season, averaging 13,807.
The drop in attendance comes even as the league posted its first decrease in the 11-year history of the Fan Cost Index, an annual independent survey by the Team Marketing Report that calculates the average cost for four people to attend a game.
The average ticket price in the N.B.A. is $50.10, down 2.3 percent from last season. The average cost of four to attend a game fell to $277.19, a decrease of 1.6 percent.
Although the figures are arrived at through several sources, league and team officials have long questioned the accuracy of the Team Marketing Report. They insist that average ticket prices and fan cost indexes obscure median prices and group packages offered by many teams that allow four people to spend less than $100 total a game.
The N.B.A. contends that ticket prices have actually risen, albeit modestly, this season.
Interestingly, Detroit is leading the league in attendance after two games, averaging 22,076 at the Palace at Auburn Hills. At $31.90, the Pistons' average ticket price dropped 20.3 percent from last year, Team Marketing Report said.
"This is about responding to the needs of our fans, our stakeholders," Tom Wilson, the president of Palace Sports and Entertainment, said. "People were making decisions not to come here, and the No. 1 reason was dollars."
Only two teams raised their ticket prices more than 10 percent, Team Marketing Report said. Average season ticket prices for the Dallas Mavericks jumped 55 percent, almost solely because of a new arena. At $58.27, the Mavericks have the league's sixth-highest average ticket price.
The Sacramento Kings are charging their fans 12.1 percent more than they did last season, mostly because of supply and demand in a one-team town.
For the fourth straight year, the Knicks topped the average ticket price category: $89.80, a decrease of 1.5 percent from last season. On average, it costs $460.70 for four people to see a Knicks game at Madison Square Garden. By comparison, it costs $198.20 for the same night out in Charlotte.
"Obviously it's very early in the season for any projections, but thus far we're very pleased with attendance," said Bernie Mullin, the league's senior vice president for marketing and team business operations. "When you look at all the after-effects of Sept. 11 in the hospitality and entertainment industries, we feel very fortunate right now."
Though he could not provide exact figures, Mullin added that season-ticket sales have actually increased. "Clearly what's going on is the average fan on the street has decided to stay home the first couple of weeks," he said. "That's what's contributing to the small decline. With everything that's happening in the world, we understand that."

Learning the Ropes
On the surface, Keon Clark's elbow to the head of Troy Murphy on Wednesday night was just another knucklehead, roughhouse play perpetrated by an impetuous young player. But the suspension that followed Clark's flagrant foul in the fourth quarter of the Warriors-Raptors game -- one game without pay and a $7,500 fine -- may have hinted at something else.
One of the plays not shown on television during the game was Jerome Williams's apparent swing at Murphy while he was on the ground after Clark elbowed him.
Murphy, the Notre Dame rookie taken in the first round of the draft by Golden State, was also involved in an altercation last Sunday against Portland. After Dale Davis and Murphy were assessed double technical fouls for tangling under the basket, Murphy dunked over Davis and briefly stared at him. He was assessed a technical for taunting and ejected from the game.
Murphy is averaging 7.8 points and 6.6 rebounds a game. He can shoot, drive and bang inside. Because he is one of those defenders who annoys -- fronting the post, swiping at the ball, basically acting like a gnat -- the consensus is that veterans are testing the rookie's resolve.
Preceding Clark's elbow in the Toronto game, Murphy drove past Clark twice, drew fouls and completed consecutive 3-point plays, prompting an irate Lenny Wilkens, Toronto's coach, to send Clark to the bench.
One veteran official said on condition of anonymity: "I don't know why, but a lot of players are going after this Murphy kid. I don't think it's because he's dirty or too physical. I think it's because he can play a little and he doesn't back down."

Hill Assesses Jordan
Grant Hill is like any other fan who enjoys watching Michael Jordan play. Hill just hopes Jordan eventually understands the importance of his position off the court.
"At some point, I'd like to see him succeed in the front office," Hill, the Orlando Magic forward, said in a recent interview. "He needs to understand at some point that he has to give it up, whether it's next year or the year after.
"There are so few of us in that position. And finally we have someone who has the resources not just to be in the front office but also to be an owner, calling the shots. I'd rather see him in that position than playing for the Wizards.
"He set the example, especially for African-American athletes. All athletes. He's opened doors with marketing. Now that you have guys making the kind of money we make and the kind of resources we have, it would be nice to see him stick it out in the front office."
Unlike many athlete-activists calling for Jordan to be more involved politically, Hill does not subscribe to the notion that Jordan needs to take on larger causes after his playing career is finished.
"I read something Bill Russell said in his book, that so many people compare Jordan to athletes of Russell's era, the Jim Browns, the Alis," Hill said. "And he said: 'Times are different. People have different realities.' What Bill Russell had to endure as a child growing up or as an athlete are not the same realities that Michael Jordan has had to endure. So because of that, don't get on Michael for not being like Bill. Times have changed."
As a player who doubted his own ability to play the game at a high level because of injuries the past two years, Hill, in a way, now empathizes with Jordan.
"My dad used to say athletes die twice," Hill said of his father, Calvin, the former Cowboys running back. "We die when we retire, and of course we naturally die. I'm just guessing he's prolonging that eventual death as a player.
"As a fan, I like watching Michael play. For me the excitement now may not be him winning games or be him dunking on people -- it won't be.
"But to see how classy he can be at his age, kind of showing you, like Larry Bird did, that you don't have to be a great athlete to dominate. I also think it will give people an appreciation for his fundamentals. Because physically, he's not where he was. Fundamentally, he is a Larry Bird. But I don't think he ever truly got credit for that."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: HEARTS AND MINDS 

BYLINE:  By SARAH SLOBIN

 BODY:
 A history of how the government has presented images of war and controlled information, and of how the message got out.
 SARAH SLOBIN

WORLD WAR I

SPEAKING AT SILENT MOVIES
In 1917 an army of 75,000 volunteers called the Four-Minute Men, like those at left, were recruited by George Creel, a journalist and advertising man. They made patriotic war speeches to audiences before the start of (silent) movies.

"Matters lying outside our own life as a nation and over which we had no control, but which, despite our wish to keep free of them, have drawn us more and more irresistibly into their own current and influence. It has been impossible to avoid them."
--President Woodrow Wilson

WORLD WAR II

MOVIE REELS AND MOVIE STARS
President Roosevelt touted Hollywood as an essential war industry. Movie stars and entertainers like the Andrews Sisters, right, collaborated on newsreels. Support was easy to generate as Pearl Harbor came on the heels of the Depression, and war brought with it not only hope for an economic bounce but clear-cut enemies to despise.

"Today we seek a moral basis for peace. . . . It cannot be a lasting peace if the fruit of it is oppression, or starvation, cruelty, or human life dominated by armed camps. It cannot be a sound peace if small nations must live in fear of powerful neighbors. It cannot be a moral peace if freedom from invasion is sold for tribute."
--President Franklin D. Roosevelt

THE KOREAN WAR

PSYCHOLOGY AND PUBLIC RELATIONS

The propaganda machine was in full swing, but its focus shifted toward the Korean people and American soldiers. Psychological warfare leaflets, like those being packed into a shell at left, were dropped in the hopes of inducing the North Koreans to surrender. General Douglas MacArthur, who censored news reports from the front lines, disagreed with the Truman administration's war policy and was later dismissed.

"It must be the policy of the United States to support free peoples who are resisting attempted subjugation by armed minorities or by outside pressures."
--President Harry S. Truman

COLD WAR

NIXON IN THE KITCHEN

At a model of an American kitchen, an exhibit in Moscow to showcase capitalism, Vice President Richard M. Nixon and the Soviet leader, Nikita S. Khrushchev, fell into a much-publicized and heated debate.

"The cold war isn't thawing; it is burning with a deadly heat. Communism isn't sleeping; it is, as always, plotting, scheming, working, fighting."
--President Richard M. Nixon

VIETNAM WAR

SPINNING OUT OF CONTROL

While fear of spreading communism initially generated support for intervention in Vietnam, it was not enough to sustain it. The government had counted on television to promote its cause. Reporters were invited in to cover battle events. But when the television images began to include body bags and terrified children fleeing napalm attacks, popular support for the war eroded, and the media grew critical.

"Just like the Alamo, somebody damn well needed to go to their aid. Well, by God, I'm going to Vietnam's aid!"
--President Lyndon B. Johnson

GULF WAR

A 24-HOUR OPERATION
The lessons of Vietnam brought tight restraints on the release of information even as cable news speeded the rhythm of war news on display. General Colin L. Powell presented remote airwar targeting techniques, while the voice of soldiers was delivered via the White House.

"Listen to Master Sergeant J . P. Kendall of the 82nd Airborne: 'We're here for more than just the price of a gallon of gas. What we're doing is going to chart the future of the world for the next 100 years. It's better to deal with this guy now than 5 years from now."'
--President George Bush

WAR AGAINST TERROR

SHAPING OPINION
Pictures of patriotism, like the photo backdrop, below, that President Bush spoke in front of on Thursday, are designed by recruits from media and advertising.

HEADLINE: Voter Portraits: New York City 

BYLINE:  By MARJORIE CONNELLY 

 BODY:
After a campaign marked by the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center and record-breaking campaign spending, Michael R. Bloomberg was elected the 108th mayor of New York City last week, defeating his Democratic opponent, Mark Green. Pre-election polls showed Mr. Green leading by about 15 percentage points until the week before Election Day. After Mayor Giuliani endorsed him, Mr. Bloomberg began to close the gap and the last polls before the election showed the candidates tied. 
 Mr. Bloomberg was elected with the support of the same groups that elected Mr. Giuliani: Republicans and independents, moderates and conservatives, Catholics, older voters and men. Unlike Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Bloomberg did well among Hispanic voters, particularly Hispanic men. Mr. Green's best showing was among blacks, Democrats, liberals and voters with low incomes. 
 This table, based on surveys of voters leaving polling stations in New York City, shows how different groups have voted for mayor since 1989. Because large numbers of people are surveyed, the polls can measure the preferences of groups whose proportion of the voting population is often too small to examine in a typical telephone survey.

Race, Ethnicity and Religion
Like Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Bloomberg received the support of most white voters. But Mr. Bloomberg did better than Mr. Giuliani among both black and Hispanic voters. Four years ago, when Mr. Giuliani easily defeated Ruth W. Messinger, 43 percent of Hispanic voters and 20 percent of black voters voted to re-elect the mayor. This year, the Republican candidate's share of the black vote rose to 25 percent. Hispanic voters divided their votes almost evenly between the Republican and the Democrat.
In addition, Hispanic voters made up a smaller percentage of voters who went to the polls this year, perhaps in reaction to the Democratic primary campaign in which Mr. Green defeated Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, after accusations that Mr. Green ran a harsh, racially divisive runoff campaign.
In the previous three elections, more than 60 percent of Catholics supported Mr. Giuliani. And Mr. Giuliani received the backing of most Jewish voters. This year, while about as many Catholics backed Mr. Bloomberg, the Jewish vote was more closely divided, with Mr. Green receiving the support of more than half of the Jewish voters.

Pocketbook Concerns
The higher a voter's income, the more likely he or she was to back Mr. Bloomberg. More than half of voters whose incomes were less than $50,000 supported Mr. Green, while voters with incomes of more than $75,000 preferred Mr. Bloomberg.
While it is not surprising that wealthier voters supported the Republican candidate, Mr. Bloomberg did much better than Mr. Giuliani with two groups that often back Democratic candidates. Unemployed workers strongly supported the Democratic candidate in 1997, but this year, Mr. Bloomberg received more than half of their votes. Four years ago, Ms. Messinger was backed by almost two-thirds of people whose financial situation had deteriorated since the previous mayoral election. This year, only about half supported Mr. Green, while Mr. Bloomberg received the votes of 40 percent. MARJORIE CONNELLY
