HEADLINE: The Empire Strikes Back 

BYLINE:  By Jeff Stein; Jeff Stein is the author, with Khidhir Hamza, of "Saddam's Bombmaker: The Terrifying Inside Story of the Iraqi Nuclear and Biological Weapons Agenda."

 BODY:
 HIT TO KILL
The New Battle Over Shielding America
From Missile Attack.
By Bradley Graham.
Illustrated. 430 pp. New York:
PublicAffairs. $27.50.

THE UNFINISHED TWENTIETH CENTURY
By Jonathan Schell.
96 pp. New York:
Verso. $19.
 THE case for a trillion-dollar missile defense system would seem to have collapsed on Sept. 11. In the time it took for suicide bombers to fly into the World Trade Center towers and the Pentagon, it seemed instantly clear that even the most sophisticated antimissile missile system would have been worthless against hijacked domestic passenger jets. Or pretending for a moment that a missile shield could be made to work -- at any cost -- how would it cope with anthrax? 
Questions of nuclear strategy would seem laughably passe now -- if they weren't so serious. But with nuclear-armed India and Pakistan very much in play, and Iran and Iraq engaged in their own arms race, readers who've been emptying bookstores in search of instant wisdom on low-tech terrorism and early Islam would be wise to pick up "Hit to Kill" and "The Unfinished Twentieth Century," thoughtful but very different books that, taken together, tell how we got into this nuclear mess and how we might get out of it. 
The single most important proponent of missile defenses, in any event, thinks the case for perfecting rockets to knock out incoming missiles is still strong. "Envision a world in which a terrorist thug and/or a host nation might have the ability to develop -- to deliver a weapon of mass destruction via rocket," President Bush urged last month. "At the very least it should be in our nation's advantage to determine whether we can shoot it down." 
"Whether," of course, is still the big question, as Bradley Graham ably shows in "Hit to Kill." No one said it would be easy, but after the billions of dollars spent since 1962 trying to hit a bullet with a bullet, critics have earned the right to raise questions. Missile defense, of course, is not just rocket science, as Graham, a tenacious military and foreign affairs reporter for The Washington Post, recounts with resolute evenhandedness; it has far-reaching military, diplomatic and economic ripples as well. But what's astonishing in his tale is how much the quest for a missile shield remains, as Bill Clinton put it, "a matter of theology, not evidence" for its mostly Republican proponents. 
Graham aptly starts his story where many disciples first get Star Wars religion, in the darkened command center of the North American Aerospace Defense complex inside Cheyenne Mountain, Colo. On a global radar screen, visiting officials get to see a glowing dot rising in the Far East -- a simulated North Korean missile launch. As the warhead floats toward the United States, most people naturally ask how it'll be stopped. When they learn there's no way, they leave shaken. That was the show that hooked the presidential candidate Ronald Reagan in 1980. George W. Bush got the fever from Reagan back then, he told Graham in an interview last summer. "I don't think I'd really focused on missile defense until Ronald Reagan brought up Star Wars." 
Graham pushes the story through seemingly every study, commission and political fight from the mid-1980's through the Clinton administration, which had about as much enthusiasm for missile defense as it did welfare reform. In the end, Clinton kept the program alive because he calculated that letting it die would be politically dangerous, which is saying a lot for a $60 billion idea. 
Graham finds some lovable rogues to blow needed air into his story, like Gen. Larry Welch of the Air Force, a missile proponent who battled political pressures that created a "rush to failure" in the tests, and Donald Rumsfeld, now secretary of defense, who served as chairman of a hardheaded 1995 commission that destroyed the C.I.A.'s mushy reports on enemy missile threats. Then there are the missile scientists themselves, who often seem only grown-up versions of the rocket-shooting boys in the movie "October Sky." It's easy to feel their pain when yet another test goes awry.
But Graham gives too little voice to crusty skeptics like Gen. Charles Krulak of the Marines and Gen. Hugh Shelton of the Army, a former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who winced at the billions thrown at Star Wars at the expense of better equipping and training ordinary troops. "Do you really think North Korea would send a missile?" Krulak barks. "We'd vaporize them. They would never get a missile off." How refreshing: a hawk's argument for missile-defense doves. 
But even if a shield were perfected -- a subject that is part of the backdrop to the three-day meeting between Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia scheduled for this week -- Moscow and Washington may well cling to just enough missiles to guarantee "mutually assured destruction," which could destroy all life itself. 
That prospect chills Jonathan Schell, who became sort of a poet laureate of the nuclear freeze movement in the late 1970's and 80's, offering eloquent arguments about the psychology of weapons and the inevitablity of their use when they are in hand, whether in a Vietnamese hamlet or a high-tech bunker in Cheyenne Mountain. Terror "became the lingua franca of 20th-century politics," he writes, from poison gas in the trenches of 1914-18 to the wholesale bombing of cities in World War II to nuclear doctrine now.
It wasn't supposed to be this way after the giddy days of Gorbachev and Reagan, when the whiff of disarmament was in the air. But, Schell writes, the "startling fact is that nuclear arms control is faring worse in a world without the Soviet Union than it did in the last days of the cold war." 
In the context of current events, "Hit to Kill" already seems like distant history, a maddening chronicle of Washington fiddling while South Asia burns. One need not entirely agree with Schell that "if in the early 1990's the existing nuclear powers had committed themselves to the elimination of nuclear weapons and had by 1998 traveled some of the distance to that goal, it is hard to believe that South Asia would be engaged in a nuclear arms race today." But his somber plea for the major nuclear powers to adopt an abolitionist agenda before the minor nuclear players do us all in, written well before Sept. 11 shattered our false sense of security, comes freighted with a poignant urgency.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
A Deficit Ahead, Many Forks In the Road

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
LAST spring, when Congress was debating President Bush's $1.35 trillion tax cut, many Democrats warned that the amount was too big, that the reduction left no buffer for unexpected bad news and would ultimately lead to spending cuts.
 In many ways, they have already been proved right. 
 Even before Sept. 11, it was clear that the tax cut and the economic slowdown had eaten away much of the projected budget surplus. Since the terrorist attacks, it has become nearly certain that the federal government will lapse into a deficit for at least a year or longer. While the administration is pushing hard for another round of tax cuts to revive the economy, it is also drawing up plans to squeeze spending on domestic and social programs in next year's budget and has threatened to veto any additional spending passed by Congress this year. 
The situation helps to explain the bitterness of the partisan debate over the proposed economic stimulus package.
Feeling that they were rolled once by Mr. Bush on taxes this year, Democrats seem determined this time around to ensure that any stimulus plan reflects their priorities.
"It seems that many in the Senate Democratic caucus want some kind of payback against the bipartisan tax relief legislation," said Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa. "In their view, the bipartisan deal was wrong, and with their caucus now running the Senate, they do not want to see it repeated in any way."
But Republicans, having once succeeded in pushing through a big tax cut against the odds, are equally determined to go to the well a second time. And they remain convinced that they can get most of what they want even though the Democrats took control of the Senate soon after Congress passed the Bush tax cut in May.
The immediate consequence of the standoff has been to make Congress and the White House appear more interested in scoring ideological and political points than in preserving jobs and helping people who are suffering in the early stages of what seems sure to be a recession. The slow pace of their effort to help the economy stands in contrast to the Federal Reserve's rapid-fire series of interest rate cuts.
But it also raises long-term questions for both parties. 
Can Republicans credibly maintain, as they have for years now, that tax cuts are the solution to every economic problem? 
And can Democrats stick with the economic policy framework they adopted during the Clinton administration -- a somewhat uncomfortable marriage of fiscal responsibility and continued belief in activist government -- when the basis of that policy, the budget surplus, may be disappearing?
Stanley Greenberg, a Democratic pollster, surveyed voters recently about the economic stimulus plans put forth by the two parties. Nearly every major idea from both sides of the aisle got strong support. 
Cutting the capital gains tax, a Republican proposal, was favored by 70 percent of those surveyed. Providing more federal money for building projects, a staple of Democratic fiscal policy, was backed by 85 percent. A Democratic plan to subsidize at least half of health insurance premiums for the unemployed won 68 percent support.
Of the proposals still under serious consideration in Congress, only one polled badly: the Republican plan to repeal the corporate alternative minimum tax and allow some of the nation's largest corporations to claim immediate refunds totaling billions of dollars from past liabilities under the tax. That proposal got just 28 percent support.
Both parties say they are more interested in doing the right thing for the economy than in scoring political points.
There is clearly room for compromise. Privately, members of both parties suggest that they could live with a package that includes immediate and permanent income tax rate cuts in the low- and middle-income brackets, investment incentives for business, more money to help the unemployed and one-time rebates for people who did not qualify for the first round this summer.
But their approaches so far could not be more starkly different. The Republican bill passed by the House focuses on tax cuts for business. The Democratic bill under consideration in the Senate directs money primarily to the unemployed and to new spending programs.
That gulf creates a situation in which both parties are sorely tempted to dwell on their differences. By doing so, they can energize their political bases and reap material for campaign commercials a year ahead of a midterm election in which control of both the House and the Senate is up for grabs.
The question is whether they indulge that temptation for so long that they render themselves irrelevant to the economy.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; 
Consumers Ready To Spend for Holidays

BYLINE:  Compiled by Vivian Marino 

 BODY:
Perhaps people are following President Bush's suggestion that they go on with their lives in a normal way, or maybe they are just plain sentimental about the holidays.
 Whatever the reasons, a survey released last week says that the majority of households have no plans to curtail holiday spending this year despite the bruised economy and the terrorist attacks. 
 Fifty-seven percent of the 1,019 people questioned nationwide in late October said they would spend about the same amount as last year, while 28 percent planned to spend less and 18 percent more. 
"The contraction in holiday spending may not be as pronounced as we might have expected," said Bill Hampel, chief economist for the Credit Union National Association, which conducted the survey with the Consumer Federation of America.
With that said, consumers should still be careful not to overspend, especially if they plan to do most of their buying on credit. Here are some suggestions:
* Draft a budget and stick to it. Start by listing proposed expenditures for gifts, food, decorations and travel, then tally up the totals from each category. If the figure seems high, make some trims.
* Set aside money. Although it would have been ideal to have started an account a year ago, there is still time. 
* Reduce interest payments. If you are buying on credit, look for credit cards with the lowest interest rates; with rates declining, now is a good time to find them.
* Shop wisely. Make an effort to comparison shop and to avoid buying on impulse or shopping when rushed.

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 The Enemy and the Ally

PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS -- President Bush tried to cast the war against Osama bin Laden and the Taliban in the broadest global context as he told the United Nations that every member country was a potential target of terrorism and that the responsibility for fighting to stop it was "binding on every nation with a place in this chamber." Mr. Bush's speech, his first to the General Assembly, opened two days of intense diplomacy to enlist more support for his war against terrorism. A1

DEFINING TERRORISM -- A reflection of the degree to which Sept. 11 now dominates the agenda of international affairs was displayed at probably the most focused General Assembly session in years. It got under way with a lecture from President Bush on the evil of terror, followed by a procession of world leaders seeking to distinguish between terrorists and freedom fighters. B2

Progress on the Ground

REBELS ADVANCE -- Fresh from their victory in Mazar-i-Sharif, Northern Alliance troops attacked Taliban positions across a broad front in the far northeast of Afghanistan, consolidating their gains and claiming to have secured a string of provincial capitals from the retreating Taliban forces. Moving forward under a deafening barrage of artillery fire and American bombs, the offensive appeared aimed at catching the retreating Taliban forces in a pair of vices, one in the east of the country and the other in the west. A1

CHEMICAL WEAPONS -- The United States has identified sites in Afghanistan that are suspected of being involved in Osama bin Laden's efforts to acquire and produce chemical and biological weapons, but none have been bombed since the military campaign began. Administration officials refused to say why the sites have not been bombed. B1

DIVISIONS EMERGING -- As Northern Alliance commanders relish their success in seizing Mazar-i-Sharif and prepare to mount an offensive against the capital, Kabul, signs of division are emerging in the group's political leadership. B3

NEWS ANALYSIS -- The first victory for the Northern Alliance at Mazar-i-Sharif after a month of fighting brings both opportunity and potential risk for the Bush administration in Afghanistan. The first order of business, according to experts, should be to demonstrate that the Northern Alliance will not be allowed to plunder the city. B3

Hearts and Minds

DAMAGE CONTROL -- Matching old-fashioned patriotism to the frantic pace of modern communications, the Bush administration is trying to persuade audiences here and abroad to support the war. The highly orchestrated efforts are meant to counter the propaganda of the Taliban and Osama bin Laden while keeping tight control on the flow of news about how the war is being waged. A1

THE ARAB MEDIA -- The main message delivered by most Arab newspapers and television has been that the United States has moved arrogantly, blindly, even callously into conflict in a country that it does not understand, and that the consequences could be worse than if the Americans had left well enough alone. B5

THE MESSAGE MAKERS -- Four women -- Karen P. Hughes, the White House communications director; Victoria Clarke, chief Pentagon spokeswoman; Charlotte Beers, under secretary of state for public diplomacy; and Mary Matalin, chief political adviser to Vice President Dick Cheney -- are among the administration's most important shapers of the words and images that the allies are seeking to convey to a global audience. B6

HOLLYWOOD'S ROLE -- Several dozen top Hollywood executives are to meet with Karl Rove, President Bush's senior adviser, this morning to discuss how the entertainment industry can contribute to the war effort. They confront a different world than Hollywood and Washington faced in the opening months of World War II. B6

PUBLIC OPINION -- In dozens of interviews across the country, Americans said they generally were satisfied with the amount of information being disseminated by the government about the combat in Afghanistan and the war on bioterrorism at home. B6

Assessing the Damages

BIOTERROR PROGRAM -- Although the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention started a bioterrorism initiative two years ago, nearly a dozen experts, including current and former government officials, said that the program was not given a high enough priority. A1

PAIN AND SUFFERING -- Hundreds of lawyers are beginning to calculate the potential value of cases of those who lost their loved ones in the Sept. 11 terror attacks. In addition to damages for economic losses, intangible things, like the suffering before an inescapable death, are given a price tag. Lawyers say they are struggling to analyze how such intangibles should be computed. B1

Autopsy of the Towers

WHY THEY FELL -- Engineers think they are closing in on the specific structural failures that set off the deadly sequence of events that ended in the collapse of the trade center towers. B1

Life in Wartime

U.S.-CANADIAN BORDER -- Point Roberts, Wash., is perhaps the most isolated community in the United States outside Alaska. Since Sept. 11, residents there have felt even more cut off, as border crossings that used to take about 35 minutes now take up to half a day because of tightened security. B7

INNOCENT VICTIMS -- Egyptian newcomers in Evansville, Ind., learned a startling lesson about this country last month when four Islamic restaurant workers and five Islamic friends were taken off in chains and held for a week without being charged with anything. B7

WELCOME HOME -- Nearly 10,000 people in Norfolk, Va., cheered and waved patriotic banners as one of the first aircraft carriers to strike at Afghanistan, the Enterprise, returned to her home port. B7

Portraits of Grief B8-9

HEADLINE: A Shaky Economy May Threaten Future Giving 

BYLINE:  By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
IN the four weeks after Sept. 11, more than half of American adults gave money to disaster relief efforts, and 7 in 10 donated money, blood or time, according to a survey released by the Independent Sector, a Washington nonprofit group dedicated to strengthening the efforts of other nonprofit groups.
 The outpouring of contributions, which totaled more than $1 billion, brought in many new donors: more than a quarter of those who donated money after the terrorist attacks had never contributed to a disaster relief effort before. 
 While many charities nationwide have experienced sharp drops in contributions since the attacks -- and almost all have worried that the faltering economy would diminish year-end fund-raising -- the survey offered some reassurances about future giving. Almost three-quarters of those who donated money to the relief effort said they expected to give as much as or more than usual this year to other charities. But others expressed concern about that finding. 
"Usually, a hundred percent will say they're planning to continue giving," said Jack Shakely, the president of the California Community Foundation in Los Angeles. "If a quarter are admitting that they're not going to give as much, that's a very soft underbelly to worry about."
The worsening economy is a serious threat to charity. Almost half of those polled said they would reduce their charitable giving in the next six months if the economic slowdown worsens, and 1 in 10 said they would completely stop their giving. 
Financial contributions were the most common donation toward the relief efforts. Nationwide, 58 percent of those surveyed donated money, with those age 35 to 54 being the most active donors. Support was strongest in New England, where more than three-quarters of those surveyed sent in money. 
The survey found that 13 percent of Americans donated blood, with those under 35 the most likely to make such donations. Overall, the survey found, 11 percent of Americans contributed their time, and African-Americans were almost twice as likely as whites to give as such. 
The telephone poll of a representative sample of 1,009 American adults was conducted Oct. 5 to 8 by Wirthlin Worldwide, and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

HEADLINE: PARTIES; 
Benefits Are Toned Down, or Called Off

BYLINE:  By SHELBY WHITE 

 BODY:
NOT surprisingly, this fall's benefit season in New York has been unlike any other in recent memory. The shock of the World Trade Center attack, coupled with the troubled economy, affected almost every event scheduled for September or October. Some were canceled outright; others postponed. Almost every one that went on was toned down.
 A few examples: The Animal Medical Center, with almost $1 million in advance ticket sales, called off its Top Dog Gala Dinner Dance scheduled for Sept. 19 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Although ticket holders had the option of asking for their money back, only four donors requested it. 
 At the New York Philharmonic's opening night on Sept. 20, the cocktail hour and dinner were canceled. Instead, the orchestra gave a memorial performance of Brahms's "German Requiem." At the conclusion, the members of the audience were asked to remain silent.
The Actors' Fund of America Gala, scheduled for tonight, has been moved to April 29. James Nederlander, the honoree, said he was uncomfortable having a fund-raiser so soon after the attacks. The postponement came at a time when the organization, which provides social services to workers in the entertainment industry, was facing a $1 million increase in demand for its services as many Broadway shows were closing. Joe Benincasa, the executive director of the Actors' Fund of America, estimated the loss at $600,000. 
Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts also canceled its fall benefit, which was to be a concert by the Philharmonia Orchestra of London. It plans to go ahead with its spring gala in April, but Daisy Soros, who has been the spring benefit co-chairwoman for the last eight years, said "the evening will be scaled down, less la de da, less flowers."
"It's not in good taste," she said. "You have to use judgment."
Canceling or postponing an event means more than simply losing a party. The nonprofit organization risks a loss of revenue that is often a major part of its annual budget. In addition, deposits have been made to hotels and caterers who, along with other services, also lose business. More than 100 benefits, large and small, were listed in New York Masterplanner, a monthly guide to the forthcoming year of events in the city, for just the first two weeks in October.
Susan Burden, a family therapist and the treasurer of New Yorkers for Children, a nonprofit group that supplements the city's child welfare services, said the organization debated whether to cancel or postpone its dinner on Sept. 19 at Cipriani 42nd Street. Yet after speaking with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the event's honorary chairman, the organizers decided to go ahead with it. The evening, Ms. Burden said, served a much-needed purpose.
"Although we complain about them and we struggle to find other ways to raise needed support," she said, "in the end we keep coming back to benefits to raise private funds for organizations."
The event raised $800,000 for the charity, and was attended by about 700 people, including the mayor, who arrived after dinner with the fire commissioner.
WHILE organizers of events that did go on worried that people would stay home, New Yorkers proved remarkably resilient, turning out in significant numbers. And benefits may have had a healing effect. "When people go to events they are glad that they went through with it," said Dr. Hadassah Brooks Morgan, a New York City psychiatrist. "The respite gives them the sustenance to go on." 
Still, anxieties remain. Jim Kirsch of Abigail Kirsch Culinary Productions, a caterer based in Tarrytown, N.Y., said that many groups were still uncertain just how to proceed. "People are holding dates, but they are having trouble lining up honorees," he said. "Many people are unwilling to make a commitment too far in advance."
Daisy Soros is concerned about the prospects for Lincoln Center's spring gala, which usually brings in $2 million. "We don't know whether we can set our goal so high," she said. "Everything is very iffy."

HEADLINE: After the Day When Time Stopped, How One Cause Went Forward 

BYLINE:  By JUDITH WARNER 

 BODY:
A CELEBRATORY spirit pervaded the Vanderbilt Room of the Roosevelt Hotel on the evening of Sept. 10. Many of the volunteers and staff members of the New York City affiliate of the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation had been working night and day since mid-August to organize Race for the Cure, the annual event they hoped would raise $1.5 million for the foundation. 
 As the final details were nailed into place, the organizers congratulated themselves on a job well done. Everything was ready for the more than 30,000 walkers and runners who were to stream through Central Park that Sunday. The permits were in place, 32,000 T-shirts were folded and the Parks Department was on the alert. 
 Back at the Komen Foundation, near Times Square, 185 pink flags lay wrapped in plastic, ready to be unfurled around the skating rink at Rockefeller Center in the annual effort to color the city pink in honor of National Breast Cancer Awareness Month, the annual series of charity and awareness-raising events that would kick off two weeks after the race. 
The organization had come far in making the breast cancer cause visible in New York. "We'd been working round the clock and we were just getting to the reward," said George Ann Garrison, 67, a breast cancer survivor and volunteer.
But then Sept. 11 came, ushering in the tragedies that consumed the city's public resources for weeks to follow. Laraine Mancuso, the volunteer president of the Komen Foundation's New York affiliate, had to make a hard decision: what should be done about the race? 
Every year, the Komen Foundation, the largest breast cancer organization in the United States, holds dozens of races nationwide to raise money for breast cancer research. The fall races are some of the most popular activities in and around National Breast Cancer Awareness Month, which since 1985 has become a crucial fund-raising and educational event. Last year, the New York race raised $1.3 million. Thousands of survivors of breast cancer attend it each year. Some measure their years free of cancer by the number of times they cross the finish line.
"I thought there had to be a way we could go forward,"' Ms. Mancuso said. "I was caught -- knowing our community was basically down on one knee and not wanting to do anything to make it shakier than it was. I kept asking myself: how to do the right thing?"
That question plagued the consortium of breast cancer groups that sponsor Breast Cancer Awareness Month.
"We all trod very carefully," said Elizabeth Woolfe, a spokeswoman for the National Alliance of Breast Cancer Organizations. "We didn't want to feel we were shoving anything down anyone's throat or grabbing the spotlight."
In the days immediately after Sept. 11, the 17 organizations involved in planning the awareness month delayed press releases, questioned the wisdom of holding large outdoor events, reviewed concert plans and canceled a handful of races. 
In New York, the Komen affiliate struggled to find a way to carry on and hold the race, before finally deciding it had to be canceled, because the anticipated crowd would have overwhelmed police and Parks Department resources. The group would have to swallow the financial loss.
"All of us questioned what we were doing in the face of the tragedy of losing 5,000 people," said Susan Nathanson, the national coordinator of National Breast Cancer Awareness Month. "But then we realized we lose 40,000 people to breast cancer each year, and we had to get back to what we were doing. We had to move forward even though we didn't have much hope of getting people to focus on us."
Everyone expected the worst for October. Even before Sept. 11, fund-raising goals had been lowered in response to the slowing economy. The Komen Foundation, which had annual donation increases of 15 to 30 percent over the last five years, expected that its 2000 donations of $131 million would hold in 2001. Other groups, however, readied themselves for steep declines. "We had very low expectations," Ms. Woolfe said. 
Yet, as October played out, the fund-raising disaster did not happen. On the contrary: as the calls for a return to "normalcy" grew, supporters of the cause rallied. With the nation still reeling, Laura Bush came through with a public service announcement for Lifetime Television. Even with anthrax dominating headlines, the "Today" show broadcast a five-part series on breast cancer the week of Oct. 22. While the races scheduled for New York, Chicago and Virginia Beach were canceled, 53 others went ahead, with participation even higher than last year and many runners and walkers carrying American flags. 
All the celebrities scheduled to fly into Los Angeles to tape Lifetime Television's "Women Rock!" benefit concert showed up. Despite its losses from Sept. 11, American Airlines went ahead with a celebrity benefit golf tournament the first weekend in October. And American Express, whose headquarters were one block west of the World Trade Center, carried on with its Charge for the Cure drive. Despite stock market turmoil, Gerard, Klauer, Mattison, an investment bank, rescheduled its Trade for the Cure Program, donating net commissions from institutional trading to Komen.
Some smaller breast cancer groups say they have been hit hard by the diversion of funds to disaster-related charities. Susan Braun, the president and chief executive of the Komen Foundation, thinks there will be a "short-term loss" in fund-raising this fall. But she also predicts that by year's end her group may actually be ahead of last year's levels. "The giving spirit Americans are so famous for has been rekindled in many people," she said.

HEADLINE: FUNDING; 
At Differing Speeds, Foundations Adjust to a World Transformed

BYLINE:  By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
FOUNDATIONS are used to acting with deliberation, not dispatch. But that, along with just about everything else, changed after Sept. 11. In the aftermath of the terrorist attacks, they showed uncharacteristic speed in pledging millions for disaster relief.
 The Council on Foundations, based in Washington, estimates that by mid-October, its 2,000-plus members had put up more than $278 million for disaster relief. They did this despite the fact that the value of their assets had plummeted with the stock market. Indeed, most had planned to rein in their grant-making this year. Foundations also picked up the slack in some crucial but hard-to-sell areas of the relief effort, like administrative costs and overhead. 
 But where longer-term grant-making is concerned, most foundations are still moving slowly, stepping cautiously in this newly transformed world. "It will take time for this to translate into programs," said Susan V. Berresford, the president of the Ford Foundation. In the weeks after Sept. 11, Ms. Berresford helped coordinate discussions, conference calls and e-mail exchanges among foundation leaders about their responses to the attacks. 
Ms. Berresford said that Ford, like many foundations, had allocated money immediately after the disaster, including $5 million for victim relief and administrative costs incurred by the relief funds. Ford plans to take up the question of longer-term program changes in the weeks and months to come, Ms. Berresford said.
The MacArthur Foundation, based in Chicago, also approved $5 million in grants soon after Sept. 11, though the grants were of a different nature. They included $250,000 to Human Rights Watch to pay for observers to interview refugees fleeing Afghanistan about human rights and to monitor threats to civil rights in the United States.
"If you were going to try to eliminate difficulties with the antiterrorist legislation when it was enacted, it couldn't wait until January or March," said Jonathan F. Fanton, the foundation's president. "Or if you were going to put observers on Afghanistan's borders to talk to refugees about human rights violations, you had to move quickly."
Although most foundations were moving less urgently, many began to re-examine their giving, usually starting by talking with existing grant recipients. David C. Speedie, the chairman of the Carnegie Corporation's international peace and security program, said the corporation already financed many programs in areas closely related to the events of Sept. 11, including research on biological weapons, nuclear weapons studies and emerging security threats. He said that grant recipients had the option of refocusing their work. 
"Some of our grantees are pretty imaginative people," Mr. Speedie said.
Some primary themes are emerging from the responses of foundations to Sept. 11, including how to combat the conditions that foster the growth of terrorism; how to increase understanding among Americans about the nature of the problems in third-world countries and the threats they may pose; and how to deal with some of the possible aftereffects of the attacks in America, including problems with civil liberties, immigration policies, interethnic relations, the economy and philanthropy.
Foundations always try to leave room for new initiatives. Considering the state of the economy and the stock portfolios of most foundations, however, many organizations will have to do some juggling to make room for such spending. 
Gordon Conway, the president of the Rockefeller Foundation, whose endowment is about $3 billion, said that he expected this year's spending to be down at least 5 percent to 10 percent. (Last year, the foundation spent about $190 million.)
Yet despite the declines in their assets, many foundations said they were determined to allocate funds for projects related to Sept. 11. The MacArthur Foundation, whose assets shrank to $3.8 billion from a high of $4.5 billion, took the $5 million it used for its attack-related grants from its $30 million reserve fund.
Of all the problems that foundations seek to solve, perhaps the most overwhelming, financially and otherwise, is the struggle against poverty and other conditions that seem to foster terrorism.
"Even though the terrorists themselves may be middle class and Osama bin Laden may be rich, they get their enormous support from people in poverty," Mr. Conway said. He said his organization planned to continue its efforts to alleviate poverty and hunger and to provide health care around the world -- not just around Afghanistan and the Middle East but in Africa and elsewhere.
"We are continuing with what we were doing before Sept. 11, but intensifying it," Mr. Conway said.
Ms. Berresford said it was not just poverty that produced terrorists but also the lack of democratic traditions in some cultures, which limits the flow of information and thwarts any sort of evolution. She predicted that foundations working overseas would try to do more "to build open, democratic systems and to cultivate more open media systems around the world."
Closer to home, many foundation officials expressed concerns that despite the huge sums contributed for victim relief, there would be gaps in the victim relief safety net. Some provided money to help people like illegal immigrants or those who speak poor English who they believed were most likely to be left out.
The Rockefeller Brothers Fund, a foundation affiliated with the Rockefeller family, is talking with immigrant community groups and legal aid organizations to identify needs but had not made specific grants as of early November. The Rockefeller Foundation gave $500,000 to the New York Foundation, a private organization that focuses on the city's neighborhoods, to distribute to community organizations helping immigrants.
There are also concerns that as the United States strengthens its antiterrorist programs, civil rights and immigration protections might be compromised. "We want to make sure we don't sacrifice what is unique about this country in trying to protect it," said Lance E. Lindblom, the president of the Nathan Cummings Foundation in New York, which allocated $500,000 for projects focusing on national security, civil liberties and tolerance after the attacks. 
ONE grant approved by the foundation was $100,000 to the National Security Archive Fund, based in Washington, for research into restrictions on public access to information for national security purposes, and for a public education campaign to increase the awareness of policy makers and the public on how to achieve security while respecting civil liberties and constitutional processes.
Some foundations are eager to educate the American public about issues related to the attacks. The MacArthur Foundation, in addition to supporting public radio, which has incurred larger-than-normal expenses in covering the war against terrorism, provided financing for a "Frontline" series on public television on topics like the origins of terrorism and Pakistani fundamentalism. The foundation also plans to make grants to groups that work with Islamic communities in the United States.
"There's a thirst for information on that part of the world," said Mr. Fanton, MacArthur's president.
Interethnic relations and training for psychological counseling are the focus of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, which allocated $250,000 for grants after Sept. 11, including several to organizations it had worked with through its refugee studies program. Among these were grants to the International Rescue Committee for work on interethnic harmony and to Mercy Corps International for a study of trauma counseling programs in the New York area.
Many foundations said that in the post-attack world, they would also try to protect existing grantees who were less directly affected. Madeline Lee, the executive director of the New York Foundation, said that groups supported by her foundation feared cutbacks in support from both New York State, with its bare-bones budget, and from traditional donors who were directing their money to victim aid.
"An organization that works with Haitian women refugees said, 'Who's going to care about us now?' " Ms. Lee said. "You don't just stop what you are doing."

HEADLINE: Twilight of the Expos 

BYLINE:  By Paul E. Greenberg; Paul E. Greenberg is an economist.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
Perhaps it will require the intervention of 28 baseball team owners to confirm what many have long thought: Major league baseball in Montreal was never meant to be. 
 Growing up in Montreal, I listened to my mother talk about going with her father, in the 1940's, to Montreal Royals games at Delormier Stadium. Those were glorious times for minor league baseball, and Montreal was the jewel in the rich farm system of the Brooklyn Dodgers. This was the era when Jackie Robinson broke the color barrier, not in New York in 1947, but in Montreal one year earlier. Roy Campanella, Don Newcombe, Tommy Lasorda and Roberto Clemente also played with the Montreal Royals. 
 Then, in the 1960's, just as the Royals and minor league baseball were fading from Montrealers' memories, we got our Parisian-style metro system and played host to Canada's 100th birthday, Expo '67. This extravaganza became the namesake for the Montreal Expos, a franchise that was created on May 27, 1968, for the astronomical price of $10 million. 
During those first years in Jarry Park in the 70's, fans took to the team, though it was rarely a winner, and in the early '80's attendance at Expos games peaked. In 1981 the team made it to the playoffs, and in 1982 the city was host of the all-star game. That game -- which was held at Olympic Stadium, known affectionately as "the Big O," appropriately as "the Big Owe" and in my neighborhood as "the Big Oy!" -- was our proudest moment. With four Expos in the starting lineup -- Steve Rogers, Gary Carter, Andre Dawson and Tim Raines -- it seemed the team had finally made it. 
But since 1983, fan interest has fallen precipitously. Much has been said about the Expos being the Triple-A team for the rest of Major League Baseball, supplying stars like Randy Johnson, Pedro Martinez, Larry Walker and Moises Alou to other teams. The truth is that Montreal is not a small city but it is a small market for this sport, and the economics of baseball doomed this once glorious franchise to its current fate. It didn't help that that in the past 25 years there was a huge outflow of the English-speaking minority that was once its fan base.
But major league baseball in Montreal was never a perfect fit. At the outset, an entire French-language translation needed to be created to describe basic baseball terminology: voltigeur (outfielder), lanceur (pitcher), receveur (catcher), arret-court (shortstop) and assorted other baseball lingo that didn't make much sense in French. Baseball did the best it could in a country constantly in search of its identity.
The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation once ran a contest to complete the phrase "as Canadian as --." If this kind of question were posed for Americans, the immediate and assertive reply would be "apple pie." But the winning entrant in Canada was "as Canadian as possible under the circumstances." 
I have always found comfort from the fact that separations don't come easily in Canada. The discussion in the Province of Quebec over breaking away from the rest of the country predates the Expos. Despite this long debate, a final decision is still nowhere in sight. Somehow, I always thought the Expos would linger in an ambivalent status for many more years, too.

HEADLINE: SPREADING THE WEALTH; 
In Silicon Hills, Making Good On Vows of High-Tech Profits

BYLINE:  By COURTNEY BARRY 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex. 

 BODY:
DURING the 1990's, Austin's new high-tech millionaires, marching lock step with the city's largely Birkenstock ethos, promised to help their community realize many goals -- a new performing arts center, a new art museum, more money for the local United Way. 
 Now, one steep Nasdaq slide later, the wallets of high-tech philanthropists here are noticeably thinner, and in some cases, empty. But while the fortunes of these executives have dissipated, their overall generosity has not -- not yet, at least. 
 In fact, Austin has only recently become acquainted with enormous wealth. "Traditionally, Austin was a salary town," says Paul Burka, the executive editor of Texas Monthly, who has lived here for 30 years. "There was very little money here. Most of the jobs were either in state government or at the University of Texas. If you look at where the decade of the 80's ended, it had no museum, no permanent collection. There wasn't much here in the way of a philanthropic base." 
"Probably the biggest cultural institution in town in the 70's was the Armadillo World Headquarters," Mr. Burka said, referring to a bare-bones National Guard armory that served as a music hall and was torn down in 1981 for high-technology development. The digital revolution transformed the simple, unpretentious city into Silicon Hills, thanks to new suburbs and the five-county surrounding region doubling in population to about 1.25 million. Austin boomed, thanks to the Dell Computer Corporation, which produced Dellionaires -- workers who became rich from stock options.
Other companies, like the Vignette Corporation, which sells software for Internet commerce, also helped spread the wealth.
From 1995 to 2000, Austin added 17,000 millionaires. In 1999, Austin companies generated about $18 billion in stock option wealth alone, according to AngelouEconomics, an economic development consulting firm in Austin. 
"High tech just changed everything," Mr. Burka said. "You had real money, real giving."
At first, many people in Austin were worried that those with new wealth would not give to the community. But in 1997, Michael and Susan Dell personally gave $1 million to the Austin Children's Museum. Since then, the Dellionaires and other entrepreneurs have elevated philanthropy to a new level -- and much of the donated money has flowed straight into Austin.
Austin's philanthropic boom almost matched the levels of the high-tech boom. The new philanthropists started about 80 foundations in Austin, said George Kozmetsky, the executive associate for economic affairs at the University of Texas System. "We started giving back while we were still making it," he said.
The question is whether the economic downturn will affect future giving. Austin's once vaunted $18 billion in stock option wealth hovers around $10.3 billion, according to AngelouEconomics.
At Dell, executive wealth -- which is based on the number of stock shares that are owned by company executives -- tumbled in mid-October to $8.4 billion from about $14.6 billion in 1999.
Vignette's executive wealth fell to $69 million last month from $1.3 billion in 1999. Other companies, like Living.com and Handtech.com, are simply no longer around. 
Even with the severe economic slowdown, giving has continued, but not at its former robust pace. Both the corporate and the family foundations set up by Michael and Susan Dell plan to continue the same rate of giving, even as the stock price of Dell has plunged. The Dell Foundation, the corporate giving arm that primarily supports groups and programs that benefit children in central Texas and central Tennessee, expects to hand out at least $5 million this year.
The Michael and Susan Dell Foundation, which is the personal giving arm, plans to maintain its yearly $5 million in donations, as well as $20 million in future commitments. Just last February, the foundation announced a $10 million donation to the Long Center for the Performing Arts in Austin. This gift followed major contributions to the center by other top Dell executives, totaling $15 million in bequests. 
AFTER the Sept. 11 attacks, the family foundation announced a $1 million "challenge fund" to Dell employees for the Red Cross Disaster Relief Fund. As of mid-October, contributions from employees topped $1.1 million, which Mr. Dell announced the family foundation would match. 
Despite its steep stock dive, Vignette gave the local United Way $600,000 in 2000 and was named as the top first-time giver that year. This year, Vignette's chief executive, Greg Peters, and his wife, Tess, gave $1.5 million of their own money to the Trinity Episcopal School.
In Austin, the United Way reported a mild drop in corporate giving this year. It expects to meet its $20.5 million goal, which is slightly higher than last year's amount.
"We've seen increases to some gifts," said Marlene Rich, the director of major gifts for the United Way Capital Area, which is based in Austin. Other pledges have been reduced, she said, "like $100,000 pledges cut to $75,000. It's almost balanced out, and I would have said the same thing before Sept. 11." 
Ultimately, Austin is likely to experience a slowdown in philanthropic giving.
Many local nonprofit groups have already suffered. For example, SafePlace, a center for domestic and sexual abuse, has laid off almost 10 percent of its work force. 
Long-term projects may become even more so. The Austin Museum of Art, which has also laid off staff members, had hoped to raise $92 million in a capital campaign for its endowments and a new building. It has raised about one-third that amount. 
The groundbreaking on the new building has "lost a year," said William J. McLellan, the museum's chief executive. The last significant gifts were made in December 2000, one for $750,000 and another for $300,000. Since then, things have slowed down considerably. 
A year ago, Mr. McLellan said: "There were many people in town who had net worths that would enable them to give us a million dollars. That wealth has disappeared in a lot of cases.
"If the party kept going for a couple more years," he said, "I'd be down there with a hard hat and a shovel. But the party is over."

HEADLINE: SENDING HELP; 
International Agencies Give Aid, While Trying to Avoid the War

BYLINE:  By BILL BERKELEY 

 BODY:
WHEN the huge American transport planes dropped their first cargo of 37,000 ready-to-eat meals over Afghanistan last month, crew members were said to have cheered wildly as the yellow packages labeled "Food gift from the people of the United States of America" fell earthward. No doubt famished Afghans devoured the beans and rice, lentil stew, biscuits, peanut butter, jam and pastries.
 Yet among some veteran humanitarian relief workers, the televised images of American benevolence, broadcast on the eve of the bombing campaign against the Taliban, were cause for disquiet bordering on alarm. Relief workers have complicated memories of humanitarian efforts in places like Somalia and Sudan, Kosovo and northern Iraq, not to mention Afghanistan itself. 
 "When I heard that the dropping of food by U.S. military aircraft was announced as a humanitarian gesture, I had in mind the lessons of Somalia," said Dr. Rony Brauman, a former head of Doctors Without Borders, the Nobel Prize-winning international relief agency, which has been critical of the food drop. 
In 1993, he recalled, an American military operation in Somalia to combat a famine became mired in warlord politics, and 18 American marines and at least 12 humanitarian aid workers were killed by Somali militias. Although the United States tried to present the military campaign as a humanitarian intervention, the warlords were able to persuade their militias of just the opposite -- that the humanitarian intervention was actually part of a military invasion.
Dr. Brauman worries that something similar may happen to relief workers in Afghanistan. "We are viewed as people coming from abroad, maybe having direct relations with Western powers," Dr. Brauman said. "If a Western power confirms this impression, then we become really part of the military drive, and we as aid workers can become transformed into war targets. And this is a problem not just for us, but for the people we are trying to help." 
Not all humanitarian relief professionals share this view, and some support the American airdrops. But given that as many as 7.5 million Afghans are at risk of starving by year's end, many Western relief groups have criticized the Pentagon's food program as little more than public relations.
Relief workers have long struggled with the reality that there is rarely such a thing as pure humanitarian aid -- especially in war. Food and other forms of relief almost always become manipulated for strategic advantage. For instance, if combatants get their hands on food, they can use it to feed themselves -- as has happened for a decade in Sudan. Or they can sell it and enrich themselves -- as happened in Somalia. If refugee camps are established, they can become havens for war criminals -- as happened in eastern Zaire in the mid-90's.
Yet humanitarian aid is never more needed than in a violent conflict. Thus, the never-ending conundrum: how to give aid without prolonging the war, how to comfort the afflicted without refueling the combatants. It is a business replete with murky moral hazards, relief workers say, in which all types of compromises may be necessary.
"War is intense business," said Austen Davis, the director of Doctors Without Borders in the Netherlands. "It is maximum politics, if you like. Your compromises are taken very seriously. At the same time, in the intensity of war, a lot of compromises are accepted."
In Afghanistan, relief aid has been politicized for decades, said Lionel Rosenblatt, former president of Refugees International, an independent aid and advocacy group in Washington. "During the Soviet occupation," he recalled, "the United States subsumed all other interests to the imperative of getting the Russians out. It didn't look to the long-term effect on either Afghanistan or Pakistan."
Instead, the United States channeled food aid through the Islamic militants and armed groups. "Most were not savory characters," Mr. Rosenblatt said.
Even before the current crisis began, the United States Agency for International Development had warned that Afghanistan, after two decades of war and three years of drought, was on the verge of widespread famine. A large percentage of the urban population depended on United Nations agencies for food. In Kabul, half the 1.2 million residents relied on them.
Ahmed Rashid, the author of "Taliban: Militant Islam, Oil and Fundamentalism in Central Asia," described Afghanistan in 1999 as an economic black hole that was destabilizing a larger region already in severe crisis. He said that basic amenities in even the poorest countries were unavailable in Afghanistan. There was no running water, and other essentials -- electricity, telephones, proper housing -- were almost impossible to obtain.
Now that the war has begun, at least a million people have abandoned their homes, according to Refugees International. Hundreds of thousands have fled cities for the Afghan countryside, a migration that makes emergency food distribution enormously difficult, because relief agencies do not know how to find people.
At the same time, the war has wreaked havoc on existing relief efforts. American bombs have destroyed some aid stockpiles -- a Red Cross warehouse was destroyed by bombs in October. Foreign relief workers have left Taliban-controlled areas of Afghanistan, while Taliban forces have seized United Nations warehouses and relief supplies. Looting and banditry have been reported by nearly every humanitarian aid group.
BEFORE the Sept. 11 attacks, the United States was the largest foreign-aid donor to Afghanistan. Now, the United States Agency for International Development is trying to ensure that 250,000 tons of food are transported into the country by the end of the year, said Andrew S. Natsios, the administrator for the agency..
The effort, Mr. Natsios said, is a crucial part of Washington's campaign to convince the Afghan people that the United States is their friend. But most of this food will probably be trucked into the country by Afghans themselves, who must somehow obtain the cooperation of the powers that be, whether they are Taliban commanders or independent warlords and bandits.
"Very likely, aid providers and their partners will have to deal with local authorities in a highly decentralized and highly militarized environment," said Arthur C. Helton, a senior fellow specializing in refugee affairs at the Council on Foreign Relations. "Inevitably, food is the price of entry and the currency of acquiescence. The deals struck recognize that a percentage reaches combatants and oppressors, but that nevertheless, an understood level reaches needy people."
In Afghanistan, the potential for a huge refugee exodus remains. So far, Afghans do not seem to be fleeing to the Pakistani border in such numbers. But the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has estimated that as many as 1.5 million new refugees may flee to neighboring countries in the next six months. 
Should there be a flood of refugees, humanitarian agencies will undoubtedly have to deal with the political fallout, and that can be dicey. In 1994, for example, more than a million Rwandan Hutus descended on eastern Zaire. Aid agencies quickly faced not only a cholera epidemic, but also the discovery that they were not only feeding innocent refugee women and children, but many Hutu men and boys who had participated in the genocide of more than 500,000 Rwandan Tutsis.
Those loyal to the old Hutu regime used the camps to regroup and start guerrilla attacks on Rwanda. Some agencies, notably Doctors Without Borders and the International Rescue Committee, withdrew from the camps in early 1995.
In the current crisis, the borders around Afghanistan have been officially closed. Pakistan is wary of yet another flood of mostly Pashtun refugees, who could destabilize its fragile government. The United States, in turn, has refrained from pressuring Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's president, on this issue, because he has already put his government at risk by helping the military campaign.
There has been some talk of creating safe havens within Afghanistan where displaced people can receive food and shelter. But the history of safe havens is not encouraging. Such zones would need to be protected by thousands of ground troops, which poses its own problems. In 1995, for example, the United Nations created a safe haven in Srebrenica in eastern Bosnia. Yet in July 1995, it was overrun by Bosnian Serb forces, who massacred 7,000 Bosnian men and boys in front of 300 Dutch peacekeepers.
"There is no good solution anywhere," said Dr. Brauman of Doctors Without Borders. "There is a war. There is violence. It is an illusion to believe that there can be a clean war with civilians enjoying protection. There is no pure solution. There is no real satisfaction. The only real solution will come with peace."

HEADLINE: TOUGH TIMES, TOUGH CHOICES; 
Charities Get a Big Helping of Uncertainty

BYLINE:  By JOHN O'NEIL 

 BODY:
AFTER an extraordinary string of fat years and rapid growth, the nation's charities are facing the toughest times and toughest choices in decades.
 The shock of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the flood of money pouring into relief efforts, the sudden contraction of the nation's economy, the slump on Wall Street and the recent disruptions in the mail have nonprofit groups rushing to adjust during what is traditionally the busiest fund-raising period of the year. 
 So far, the worst fear of charities in the first days after the attacks -- that support for the relief efforts would come at their expense -- has not come to pass. The early indications, according to more than 30 interviews with philanthropy executives, researchers and consultants, are that, in general, the gifts by individuals to relief efforts are being made on top of, not instead of, their usual donations. And the approximately $1.3 billion given to the relief funds amounts to far less than 1 percent of the $203 billion Americans gave to nonprofit groups in 2000. 
What is happening appears to be both less dire and more complex. There are groups whose revenues have fallen drastically, especially in New York and Washington. Across the country, arts groups and some social service organizations are having difficulties. And many of the thousands of new charities formed during the boom, especially those that relied on stock gifts from the newly rich, may not be able to survive harder times.
But other groups, from the American Diabetes Association and the National Trust for Historic Preservation to the Archdiocese of Boston and Tampa General Hospital, reported in an informal sampling that they had been meeting or exceeding their fund-raising goals. Interest in volunteering has risen sharply, and not only for disaster relief efforts, according to Volunteermatch .com, which links volunteers and causes.
This mix of reactions is even being felt overseas. Dr. Eugene R. Tempel, executive director of the Center on Philanthropy at Indiana University, said he recently attended a conference on philanthropy in Europe, where the prevailing mood was summed up by the leader of a Belgian charity: "We're keeping up, but we're working harder than ever."
The bigger worry now is not the direct aftermath of the attacks but the steep economic slide. Foundations cut their giving when their stockholdings fall; corporations when profits recede. State and local governments are already planning deep budget cuts, and large gifts are often put off during uncertain times. And downturns, of course, also mean more people in need of help.
The result has been a scramble on many fronts. Charities have been making some concrete changes, from rewording the letters in their holiday appeals to canceling trips, postponing projects and in some cases laying off staff members.
But a reassessment of broader trends has begun as well, experts say. The national mood has changed, and the high-powered tactics of the boom years, when no capital campaign goal seemed too big and no gala too glittering, are likely to change as well. Dr. Tempel said that charities could no longer grow simply by chasing big grants or promoting the financial benefits of big donations. "That kind of giving will probably slow," he said.
Leaders of charities large and small spoke in interviews of the need to get back to the basics: serving their communities, explaining their missions and building a base of support one donor at a time. 
"Right now, we're coming back to what you might call demand-side giving," Dr. Tempel said. "You have to talk about people's needs." 
Food for Survival, which distributes food to 1,200 programs throughout New York City, is dealing with needs on both sides of the issue: the aftermath of the attacks and the creeping hardship caused by the downturn. It has become an integral part of the recovery effort, moving 8 to 10 tractor-trailer loads of food each day to feed workers at ground zero. 
Its president, Dr. Lucy Cabrera, is confident that relief funds will cover the costs involved in essentially doubling the group's work. "But we've seen a dramatic decrease in the individual giving" that supports its usual work, she said. Donations fell 25 percent in September and close to 30 percent in October, compared with those in the same months last year. And that work is becoming more pressing, she said. "Even before the disaster we had seen an increase in the demand for food at pantries and soup kitchens," she said. "Since then we've seen a lot more." 
For Dorine N. Gordon, the president of the ALS Association's greater New York branch, the disruption began when the first of the World Trade towers fell, just blocks from her office, and the street below "filled with smoke and screams," she said. She and her staff of 12 fled to safety, were unable to return to work for 10 days and were without reliable phone service for weeks.
The group, which supports services and research for patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or Lou Gehrig's disease, felt the financial impact immediately. A fund-raising walk in Liberty State Park that was expected to bring in $100,000 was called off because the area was requisitioned for the recovery efforts. Corporations also disrupted by the attacks began to cancel their tickets for the group's Oct. 30 gala, leaving Ms. Gordon facing a $400,000 shortfall from the event's goal. "It's totally understandable," she said. "They're focusing right now on taking care of their people."
The biggest threat to the Brooklyn Public Library is the citywide budget cuts of up to 15 percent that are now being considered, which would take $11 million out of the library's $85 million budget. That dwarfs the $300,000 the Brooklyn Library Foundation had set as a goal for its Nov. 1 gala. But the foundation's money is crucial to some of the library's most cherished programs, like tutoring in reading skills, and the event has an importance in itself as a means of building a network of support, said Cheryl J. Haywood, a trustee and co-chairwoman of the event. 
Arts organizations traditionally suffer more than other types of nonprofit groups during hard times, said Dr. Patrick M. Rooney, director of research at the Indiana center. "They basically do well when there's a lot of extra income or wealth around," he said. 
But arts groups in New York have been particularly hard hit, and not just in their galas and mail campaigns, said Richard J. Schwartz, the chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts. "The big loss so far has been in earned income -- performances with a lack of attendance, museums with a dearth of tourists and a loss of shopping income," he said.
Causes far from home are also suffering more: a planned $700,000 gift for an H.I.V.-prevention campaign in Africa went to a Sept. 11 fund instead, said Carrie Svingen, a spokeswoman for EngenderHealth, a women's health organization.
Liz Andrews, a spokeswoman for the American Heart Association's Midwestern branch, said that the national organization's fall fund-raising walks could almost provide a map showing the severity of the fund-raising disruption: the closer to New York, or the sooner after Sept. 11, the more poorly they did. Nationwide, the walks -- which were recast as marches, with flags replacing corporate banners -- raised 15 percent more than they did a year ago, she said. That was far better than the organization had feared at first, she said. But it was 10 percent below its goal for the year.
Similarly, Habitat for Humanity International had its "best October in history" but fell short of its "ambitious" goals, a spokesman said.
Ambitions had soared during the boom. According to Melissa S. Brown, the managing editor of Giving USA, which tracks charitable trends, donations have grown steadily since 1987, but the trend really took hold when Wall Street took off in 1995. The fastest-growing portions of the charitable pie have been grants by foundations and corporations and large gifts of stock by individuals. 
Bryan K. Clontz, a vice president at the Community Foundation for Greater Atlanta, said that groups like his "live and die by December," when the bulk of big gifts are made toward the end of the tax year. But this year the uncertainty about the economy, the stock market and the estate tax have created "a perfect storm" buffeting upper-income donations. "It creates a lot of fear about making major gifts," he said. 
Dr. Rooney, the Indiana economist, said that businesses also traditionally pulled back on donations in tough times. "Corporations average donations of 1 percent of pretax profit," he said. "When profits go down, so does giving."
As a result, there are many who believe, like Rick Cohen, president of the National Committee for Responsive Philanthropy, that "this is a special moment for foundations."
"They have a role to play," he said, "to shore up the nonprofit community so that nonprofits don't become another victim of the attacks." 
But Sara L. Engelhardt, president of the Foundation Center, which provides information on foundations and corporate philanthropy, said that most foundations were likely to hold to the standard formula of giving 5 percent of assets. Some foundations may dip deeper into their holdings to honor grants already committed. Even so, she said, groups facing shortfalls in other financing should realize that "it's not realistic to expect foundations to make up the difference."
Dr. Rooney said these losses would fall most heavily on newer groups that had not yet developed a solid donor base. Robert F. Sharpe Jr., a nonprofit-group consultant based in Memphis and Washington, was more blunt, predicting a significant winnowing. "A lot of the charities that were formed in recent years aren't going to make it," he said. "They are creatures of discretionary income -- of easy money -- and they're facing a day of reckoning." 

Linking to the Attacks
In the last two months, nonprofit groups have turned to a range of strategies. The most direct -- and the most delicate -- is to stress any link to the events dominating the nation's attention.
Consultants warn, however, that this should be tried only by groups that have a real and significant role. Food for Survival certainly qualifies, and is being reimbursed in full for its expenses in feeding rescue workers. Dr. Cabrera plans extra mailings to try to make up for the shortfall in donations to support the group's regular work and hopes that its role in the city's crisis will translate into broader support.
"We've been a pretty large player in the disaster relief efforts," she said, "and we're able to put that in our appeal as well." 
Public radio stations from Hawaii to Mississippi have recorded their best-ever pledge drives this fall, which executives at National Public Radio attribute to gratitude for its in-depth news coverage of recent events. In New York, WNYC raised $3.1 million to meet the $4 million in damage it suffered during the attacks, more than double its previous one-week record, said a spokeswoman, Emma Dunch.
Sometimes relief-related aid can be provided in a way that helps a group's broader purposes as well as serving a need stemming from the disaster. The New York Times Company Foundation recently gave a $2.5 million matching grant (from the $45 million it has raised for The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund) to the After-School Corporation, a nonprofit group, to open free after-school programs in 16 schools near ground zero.
The South Street Seaport Museum lost about $750,000 when it was forced to close for two weeks by the attacks, said its president, Peter Neill. But the museum has already landed a $30,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities for an exhibit on the maritime response to the attacks. 
Another important reaction to the new uncertainty is budget cuts, even in groups that have not had a drop in donations. Elizabeth Birch, executive director of the Human Rights Campaign, an advocacy group for gay and lesbian rights, said the group's events after Sept. 11 sold out nationwide. "A lot of gay people died in the attacks," she said. "People want to come together to mourn the loss." 
But even so, within 10 days of the attacks she had put in place a contingency plan that included cuts of up to 20 percent. "Any nonprofit would be foolish not to prepare for a shortfall," she said. 
Eileen R. Heisman, president of the National Philanthropic Trust, said she had been cutting what she called the obvious things. "We're looking much more closely at public relations and marketing dollars, at travel," she said. "We're holding off on things that if I put them off a bit, nothing terrible is going to happen." 
Ms. Gordon of the ALS Association's New York branch said she was trying not to pull back on any programs the association had in place. "But we had plans to expand into underserved areas that we're reconsidering," she said, "and we're looking at some research in terms of putting that off." 

Tending to Donors
And charities have been talking. "We're advising our clients to call their donors -- talk, don't just send letters," said Nancy Raybin, a New York consultant and a former chairwoman of Giving USA. "If that means 300 calls, then make 300 calls." 
Philip Coltoff, the executive director of the Children's Aid Society, a New York City charity that has added new relief duties to its regular work, said that he and his staff members were working at "making a connection between what we do for the community and how those services need to be sustained." 
"You take the time and educate your board -- that's your first donor base -- so from there you can have a larger collective effort," he said.
Roger Craver of the direct mail firm Craver, Mathews, Smith & Company said that charities for which his company made telemarketing calls were reporting unusually positive reactions. "People in these situations like to feel like a part of the organizations they have been supporting," he said. "Established donors rarely slack off." 
Mr. Craver also said that so far there had been no sign that the fears about anthrax in the mail had led to any significant drop in responses to fund-raising appeals. H. Robert Weintzen, the president of the Direct Marketing Association, agreed. "We've been expecting to see a falloff, but so far we haven't," he said. 
Mr. Craver said that many charities had modified their fund-raising letters to take account of recent events and that they had been very careful about putting their names and return addresses on very clearly. "People are creatures of habit," he said. "If they know the source of the mail, I suspect they're going to open it and keep on giving." 
Jennifer Leonard, president of the Rochester Area Community Foundation, said that recent fund-raising events there had been attracting many people looking for some way to connect, to find a sense of community. Strong charities and their core of donors have always shared that kind of bond, she said, and groups that can ingrain what she called "habits of the heart" will continue to find support.

Commitments Renewed
In the end, both the ALS dinner and the Brooklyn Public Library's gala did better than their organizers had feared. The ALS Association collected $1 million, down from its $1.2 million goal, but $200,000 ahead of Ms. Gordon's mid-October estimate. And the library's $253,000 in gifts was almost equal to last year's -- also down from the original goal, but better than Ms. Haywood had expected.
But in her mind the greater importance of the event was the renewed commitment inspired by a speaker, the illustrator Leo Dillon. He described the time a half-century ago when he, as an African-American boy, had stopped day after day to stare at the most beautiful book cover he had ever seen, locked in a glass bookcase until a white librarian came over unbidden and handed him the rare and expensive treasure.
"People who heard him talk about how he was transformed by that -- they're going to be our cheerleaders," Ms. Haywood said. "They didn't walk out saying, 'That's the last money I'm giving.' They walked out of there skipping."
To H. King McGlaughon, the director of the Center for Philanthropy and Nonprofit Management at Merrill Lynch, a new emphasis on deepening such connections could turn out to be a positive. "It's a return to mission-focused fund-raising: talking directly about what you do and the value of your programs to the community," he said. "In the 90's there was a fairly significant trend toward donor gratification."
Nancy Raybin said the long-term challenge would be to build on this fall's extraordinary outpouring of generosity. "We have new philanthropists, and that's a wonderful thing," she said. "If we can get some small percentage of them to keep on giving, then we'll do better as a country." 
Even some leaders of groups getting hard hit are optimistic. "Right now the sympathy is with the disaster, and that's where it should be," said Dr. Cabrera of Food for Survival. "But I have a lot of confidence. New Yorkers always come through."
And Ms. Gordon said her spirits were revived by an ALS walk at Jones Beach on Sept. 30. It was a cold and rainy day, and there had been nothing but bad news for weeks. Then a crowd of 1,000 showed up, bearing pledges for $100,000 more than had been projected. "It was an amazing outpouring," Ms. Gordon said. "These people just wanted to be together."

A Camp Fund As His Legacy
SOME donations are as sad as they are sweet.
Every summer, a Bronx group called Happiness Is Camping operates a free program in Blairstown, N.J., for children with cancer. Medical services are provided by volunteer doctors and nurses from Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, said Kurt Struver, the group's executive director. 
Eight years ago, Julie E. Siard, a nurse at the camp, met Robert D. McMahon, a New York City firefighter who was also volunteering there, Mr. Struver said. They married and had a son in 1999. This year, Mrs. McMahon became pregnant again. 
On Sept. 11, Mr. McMahon, a member of Engine Company 20 in Chinatown, went into the World Trade Center. His funeral is today. Mrs. McMahon has asked that donations in her husband's memory be made to Happiness Is Camping. "She knows that as a firefighter's widow she's going to be taken care of financially," said Dr. Herbert Janick, Mrs. McMahon's uncle. "She wanted to do something that fits the kind of person he was."
The camp plans to hold a session next July for children of firefighters killed on Sept. 11. In an e-mail to Mr. Struver, Mrs. McMahon wrote, "It never ceases to amaze me how so many positive things can come out of such a disastrous moment."
 JOHN O'NEIL
