HEADLINE: New Economy; 
A rush to appropriatesymbols of the day terror punctured New York's skyline.

BYLINE:  By Sabra Chartrand 

 BODY:
HOPING to find a dark cloud's silver lining, and mine it, more than two dozen enterprising types have applied for trademarks related to the events of Sept. 11.
 All the applications involve slogans and symbols directly related to the terrorist attacks. Most involve trademarks intended for use on general retail merchandise -- the kind of T-shirts, coffee mugs, canvas bags and trinkets sold in tourist shops in Times Square. Many incorporate the date of the attacks with sketches of the twin towers, playing on the fact that the two skyscrapers looked like the number 11. 
 For example, Benjamin Zapp, from the Upper East Side of Manhattan, applied for a trademark for "09-11-01," with the "11" rendered as the twin towers, including an antenna on the left tower, and the slogan "We will always remember" under the date. The image is superimposed on an outline of the American flag. Mr. Zapp says he intends to use the mark for apparel, jewelry, paper goods and ceramic and glassware.
The Patent and Trademark Office, which has not yet registered any of the trademarks related to Sept. 11, said it was still examining them to determine whether they qualify.
Dates, whether written as September 11, 2001, or as 9-11-2001, are usually not eligible by themselves for a trademark. And adding other words, like "September 11th Fund" may not help, either.
Descriptive words cannot win trademarks, said Sharon Marsh, an administrator at the Trademark Office. If applicants use the date in conjunction with other words or emblems, they may win a trademark if they file a disclaimer stating that they expect no rights to the date outside its use in the design. Dates alone, or names like World Trade Center, may not be eligible. 
"If what the party is trying to register just wouldn't be recognized by the public as a mark, then it can be refused," Ms. Marsh said. 
Although most of the Sept. 11 trademark applications are for commercial purposes, several have been submitted for fund-raising, including a request from the United Way of New York City for "The September 11th Fund," and one from the World Trade Center Disaster Relief Fund in Las Vegas for "Walk4America." 
Don Rogers, who lives in Rockville, Md., has applied for trademarks for "World Terrorist Reward Fund" and "USA Terrorist Reward Fund." The September 11th Memorial Fund, in Orlando, Fla., has applied to trademark its name.
The Wall Street Rising Corporation, a nonprofit organization, also wants a trademark on its name. Its application is for the words "Wall St Rising" around a sketch of city skyscrapers. In its request, the organization says it aspires to "promote the retention and location of businesses at and around the location of the World Trade Center."
Michael Heiden, who lives in New York on the Upper East Side, anticipated the trademark rush the day of the attacks. By the end of the day on Tuesday, Sept. 11, he had put together an application to trademark the term "World Trade Center" for use in entertainment like TV programs, videos and movies about the attacks.
In his application, Mr. Heiden explained that he was not trying to exploit a national tragedy -- in fact, he said he wanted to stop others from doing so. "This trademark was originally created and designed for charity purposes," Mr. Heiden wrote. "In the event of any movie made about the horrific act of cowards on Sept. 11, I wanted to make sure that all proceeds went directly to the people affected by this tragedy."
A month later, Mr. Heiden decided not to pursue the trademark, and asked the Patent and Trademark Office to cancel his application. 
The applications are not only by people in the United States. From Israel, Moti Shniberg applied for a trademark covering the words "Sept. 11, 2001" to be used for books, news radio programs, TV news and entertainment shows, theater, musicals, comedy or operas. 
So far, no trademark applications have been filed using "Taliban" or "Al Qaeda." But there are several incorporating variants of the name Osama bin Laden into slogans on clothing, knickknacks or bumper stickers. These include "Osama -- Can you see the bombs bursting in air?" "Trash Bin Laden," "Bin Laden to rest," "Bin there, bombed that," and "Osama, Yo Mama."
Here is a sampling of other timely ideas that trademark applicants have submitted: 
*Suzette Tarantini, Scottsdale, Ariz. "09-11-01, The Day God Needed More Angels" for use on clothing, bumper stickers, memorial statues, computer software or Internet services. 
*Richard Stewart, Venice, Calif. "9-11/911" for clothing, jewelry, shoes and sports equipment. 
*Paul Gross Corporation, San Diego. Exclusive rights to put "Sept. 11" on clothing and shoes.
*Constance Romano, Bradenton, Fla. "Now that we're united, will you meet me halfway?" for use on T-shirts and bumper stickers. The words "united," "you" and "me" appear with red, white and blue stripes.
*Imelda Roberts, Frederick, Md. "Twin Towers Light" for lamps and other commemorative items.
*Hoover & Strong Inc., Richmond, Va. A metal bracelet similar to the POW bracelets popular during the Vietnam War. Each bracelet will bear the name of one victim from the terrorist attacks and the date "9-11-01."
*Liberty Ball Ltd., Concord, N.H. "The Liberty Ball, 9-11-01," featuring an American flag between the words and the date. The design will be used on "golf balls to be sold to benefit the victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, attack."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Benjamin Zapp has applied for a trademark on this design, for use on clothing and jewelry.

HEADLINE: Compressed Data; 
Software Helps Workers Start -- and Finish

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
Smart security experts often say they do not worry as much about hackers as about disgruntled insiders who might commit acts of sabotage against their company's computers. One of the quickest and easiest ways to upset employees is to give them pink slips -- and there are plenty of those going around lately.
 Business Layers, a two-year-old software company in Rochelle Park, N.J., says it has a way to keep employees from firing digital parting shots. 
 Its flagship product, eProvision Day One, is normally used to help automatically set up new employees with the computing communications equipment and corporate network access that they need. Chevron and dozens of midsized companies use the product.
Now, though, many of the customers that use Day One are finding that the same automated tools can be used to speed up the process of cutting off network access, preventing a fired employee from deleting or altering files or continuing to read or send e-mail messages on the company account. The software even tells the company's technology support staff that someone needs to pick up the former employee's laptop computer and cellphone.
The same software that can help an employee boot up, in other words, can speed the process of booting them out.
As the company's Web site more delicately puts it, the former employees are "systematically, securely and automatically removed from the corporate network." They are "kept productive from day one" by the automated access controls and are "prevented from becoming counterproductive beyond the day they leave." It is the perfect tool, in short, for making those mass layoffs less troublesome -- for the company, at least.
With the United States economy having gone from boom to bust, Day One has watched its software be put to increasingly pragmatic purposes, said David Lavenda, a co-founder of the company. 
"I would say in the last six to nine months, there has been a pretty big shift" among users, he said -- from the first-day, money-saving functions of the product to its last-day defensive uses. 
Companies that have not enrolled new employees with the product can enter them later, Mr. Lavenda said, noting he has received inquiries recently "that are more related to security" from the start.
A name change for Day One is not planned, Mr. Lavenda said.
 JOHN SCHWARTZ

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
High-Technology Exports From China Create Tension
China's high-technology industry finds itself treading on geopolitical fault lines these days as Chinese companies have become suppliers of advanced communications equipment to nations that Western companies avoid, or are barred from doing business with, including Iraq, Cuba, North Korea and, at least before Sept. 11, the Taliban leadership in Afghanistan.
 Industry analysts and United States trade officials say China has been responsive to efforts by the State Department to help the nation set up a system of export controls, which are crucial now that China has joined the World Trade Organization. Page C2. 

Intel Chairman's Wartime Boyhood
While Intel was becoming a Silicon Valley institution, its chairman, Andrew S. Grove, was known for many things: his attention to minute details, his secrecy, his acute paranoia of competitors, his often cantankerous leadership. There was little room for sensitivity or sentimentality. But now, at age 65, Mr. Grove can afford both. He has published a memoir, "Swimming Across," that tells of the experiences -- some mundane, some extraordinary -- of a nonobservant Jewish boy growing up in Hungary through a fascist regime, a Nazi invasion and a Soviet occupation. C3.

Intel plans today to announce equipment for a new generation of wireless Internet access technology. In a separate deal, MobileStar Network has agreed to sell most of its assets to VoiceStream Wireless. C6.

Privacy Expert Shifts to Security
As perhaps the nation's most vocal authority on data privacy, Richard M. Smith spent the last two years trying to keep Americans' personal information private from corporate intrusions. But seeing bigger threats, he is now turning his attention to studying whether the public is sufficiently secure. C4.

Trademarks Sought on Attacks
More than two dozen people have applied for trademarks related to the Sept. 11 attacks. All the applications involve slogans and symbols directly related to the attacks, and most involve trademarks intended for use on general retail merchandise. New Economy. C3.

Cosmetics Rivals Cooperate on Site
Some of the biggest names in the beauty industry, including Estee Lauder, Chanel and Clarins, are backing Gloss.com as the sole Internet-only retailer to carry some their products. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C6.

Esquire Navigates Rapid Changes
On Sept. 11, David Granger, the editor in chief of Esquire, was about to ship the last few pages of his November issue when terrorists attacked the United States. Staring at a mockup of the cover -- a photo of the actress Cameron Diaz --Mr. Granger knew that three weeks later, when the issue reached newsstands and mailboxes, it would seem "wrong." He quickly revamped the issue, but he soon faced a bigger, more complex problem: what to do the next month, and the ones after that. Other monthly editors are also wrestling with the difficulty of forecasting events and moods. C8.

In the wake of steep revenue declines, magazines have continued to shrink staffs and pages, cut back on salaries or health care plans, and merge or even disappear. C8.

Goldman to Buy Bad Loans in Japan
Goldman Sachs plans to establish a subsidiary to buy bad loans from Asahi Bank of Japan, which plans to write off up to $2.5 billion of its most troubled lending in two years. C5.

Treasury Market Is Closed Today
Some financial markets will be closed today in observance of the Veterans Day holiday. Stock markets will be open during their normal hours. The bond market will be closed.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: U.S. Officials Complain That Chinese Companies Supply Rogue Nations 

BYLINE:  BY JENNIFER 8. LEE 

 BODY:
China's high technology industry finds itself treading on geopolitical fault lines these days, as Chinese companies have become suppliers of advanced communications equipment to nations that Western companies avoid, or are barred from doing business with. 
 The Chinese customers have included the governments of Cuba, Iraq, North Korea and Yugoslavia and, at least before Sept. 11, the Taliban leadership in Afghanistan. 
 Other than their dealings with Iraq, which were a violation of United Nations sanctions and were halted by the Chinese government after the United States complained in February, the companies have done nothing that violates international trade agreements or diplomatic strictures. Instead, they seem to be exercising the capitalist rights to entrepreneurial aggressiveness and low pricing. 
So far, according to industry analysts and American trade officials, the Beijing government has been responsive to efforts by the State Department to help China set up a rigorous system of export controls to regulate increasingly feisty businesses. Such controls and cooperation are considered crucial now that China has joined the World Trade Organization. 
And American officials say that Chinese companies have not been involved with telecommunications projects in Afghanistan since Sept. 11. Still, some officials remain wary.
"A modernizing China with more aggressive entrepreneurial activity will bleed into diplomatic complications that are sometimes unpredictable," a Bush administration official who has worked closely with the Chinese government on trade issues said.
And the installation of digital fiber optic cables in rogue nations -- or those considered potential rogue nations -- raises concerns in intelligence agencies because the cables are nearly impossible to monitor with conventional ground, air or space surveillance systems. 
Even if fiber optic lines could be tapped, strong modern data-encryption methods can make the information hard to decipher for intelligence gathering. And as with almost all telecommunications systems, the digital equipment has both military and civilian uses. "You can't attack a military target without attacking a civilian target," a Defense Department spokesman said. 
In the Iraq incident earlier this year, Washington accused Chinese telecommunications companies of helping to modernize the Iraqi air defense system, in violation of a United Nations embargo on the sale of military equipment to Iraq. 
Although administration officials say the Chinese government moved quickly to rein in the companies, the episode helped elevate telecommunications to an issue of concern in discussions of technology export controls with China and placed telecommunications systems, along with supercomputers and data encryption, among the technologies that draw scrutiny. 
The ascendancy of these companies is part of a technological vision that combines economic development and national security through a government program known as Project 863, named for a March 1986 letter that four senior Chinese scientists wrote to Chinese leaders criticizing the nation's dependence on Western technology.
"The technology that the United States and its allies have been providing to the Chinese end up propagating in a nonlinear way that is unpredictable and unanticipated," said Peter Leitner, a senior strategic trade analyst for the Defense Department, who has been a forceful opponent of advanced technology transfers to China.
A number of prominent Chinese communications technology companies engage in partnerships with top American manufacturers including Lucent Technologies, Qualcomm, Compaq Computer, Motorola and I.B.M. Other Western producers that have formed partnerships in China include Nortel Networks of Canada, Ericsson of Sweden and Siemens of Germany. 
A longstanding concern has been that through such relationships, Chinese companies might channel technology to parts of the world that American equippers shy away from for diplomatic or security reasons. But the Chinese are not the only ones willing to do business where Americans will not; Alcatel, of France, has agreed to rebuild some of Iraq's civilian telecommunications network.
Industry analysts say that Chinese technology companies are becoming much more competitive in their own right, as the result of research and development efforts complemented by government support. China's four telecommunications manufacturing stars -- Huawei, ZTE, Julong and Datang -- all invest more than 10 percent of their revenue into research and development, a substantial share by international standards.
At this point, the Chinese companies' main advantage is price, which can be as much as 30 percent below that for comparable Western products. "There are countries that don't necessarily need the latest switch or the latest mobile technology, and are price-sensitive," said Ted Dean, managing director for BDA China, a consulting firm that tracks China's telecommunications industry. "The Chinese companies are growing there."
Although the bulk of sales still go to China's huge domestic market, over the last four years the telecommunications manufacturers have exported equipment to more than 20 developing nations including Libya, Pakistan and Yemen.
"There is a certain gray area where certain countries are not blacklisted, but for some reason, U.S. companies don't go," Mr. Dean said. "There is no political pressure from the Chinese government not to sell. In some cases, there might be pressure to sell."
Wendy Wu, a spokeswoman for Huawei, defended the industry's export practices. "Like all other telecom companies," she said, "we operate in different countries. We abide and respect the applicable laws in the countries and the rules by the United Nations. Ms. Wu maintained that contrary to American accusations, "Huawei has never supplied equipment to Iraq." 
In the cases of Cuba and North Korea, Chinese companies are taking advantage of supply vacuums created by American sanctions. Elsewhere, it is a matter of being willing to deal with pariahs. 
In Yugoslavia in September 1999, despite the virtual isolation by then of President Slobodan Milosevic's regime after the Kosovo conflict, ZTE signed a $225 million contract with a Yugoslav telecommunications company to provide equipment, technical support, engineering supervision and training.
ZTE spoke of the sale as a chance to break American and European dominance of communications markets in Eastern Europe. Some diplomats also viewed it as payback of a sort for the inadvertent bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade. Beijing also extended hundreds of millions in loans to Yugoslavia after the American bombing. 
"One has to assume that in some of those relationships, China is making clear and determined decisions," an administration official said. "However, for whatever narrow self-interest it enters a market or a region, it sometimes discovers after it's gotten involved that it's more complicated than it would have predicted." 
One such case may be in Afghanistan. Even as the United Nations was imposing an arms embargo on the Taliban last December, Afghan news media reported existing agreements to install digital equipment with ZTE and another Chinese company known as CEIEC. The company, formally the China National Electronics Import and Export Corporation, describes itself in its marketing brochure as "the only government-authorized company in China dealing in defense electronics." Among its products are radar, encryption, and navigation systems.
American officials say, though, that there is no evidence of any arms-related work by the Chinese companies in Afghanistan and that the uncompleted telecommunications projects were only rudimentary in a country whose infrastructure has been ravaged by two decades of war. China's foreign ministry has denied any formal relationship with the Taliban.
American officials say that any Chinese work in Afghanistan before Sept. 11 more likely grew out of Beijing's desire to keep an eye on Afghanistan, a bordering country. The government is concerned about Muslim separatists in its western provinces and any relationship they may have with Osama bin Laden's Qaeda network. 
Even projects developed under civilian auspices are of concern to some analysts. "For a country with few phones, the only conceivable purpose for a high-speed data network is governmental or military," James Mulvenon, who analyzes the Chinese military for the RAND Corporation, said.

HEADLINE: CNBC Struggles To Stay Relevant; 
With Stocks No Longer the Big Story, News Viewers Are Looking Elsewhere

BYLINE:  By JIM RUTENBERG 

 BODY:
Think back to the distant past: last year.
 CNBC was something more than a business-news cable channel. It was the winning team's locker room, a cultural phenomenon of the heady 1990's and a mainstay in bars, sports clubs and offices. 
 It became the most-watched information source on cable as its anchors and correspondents reported on the stock market with the same cool confidence with which Internet entrepreneurs strode through Lower Manhattan. Chief executives like Jeff Bezos of Amazon and John T. Chambers of Cisco Systems were treated like rock stars on its programs as the once-stodgy lexicon of Wall Street -- I.P.O., P/E ratio -- became the hip new idiom of the day. 
Now, however, CNBC is in rough seas. Its buzz has faded, its daytime ratings are falling, and it is having to rethink its direction as the ground has shifted beneath it -- with the Sept. 11 attacks, the news has entirely moved away from the investment arena, a trend that was already under way as the economy slowed and stocks slumped.
CNBC executives acknowledge that its slogan, "Profit From It," seems a bit out of place, as can its sundry bells and whistles -- the stock ticker and fancy graphics -- and the occasional, irreverent banter of its anchors.
Just as CNBC's rise was driven by the public's obsession with the stock market and its waning interest in general news from Washington and abroad, the network's decline now reflects the new urgency of foreign affairs and public policy. In fact, the progress of the war on terrorism could affect the economy far more than any other factor.
So CNBC executives are busy trying to plot a new course, one that will focus more closely on general news as it influences the economy while treating market coverage less like a sports event, with less fanfare and less of the network's jocular tone.
By doing that, its executives face a tough question: How can they reposition the network without becoming New Coke?
The job falls to a new chief executive, Pamela Thomas-Graham, who, though considered a young talent, has relatively little experience running a network. She has taken over for Bill Bolster, one of television's looming figures, a master of marketing and TV gimmickry who is now running CNBC International.
There is plenty at stake. Though CNBC remains a huge profit center for NBC, its advertising revenues are believed to have dropped some this year. It is struggling to end the year on par with last year, though executives say it will. CNBC's core advertisers, financial services companies, for weeks after Sept. 11 avoided advertising and some are only now returning.
Ms. Thomas-Graham, who is 38 years old and has spent most of her career as a media management consultant and partner at McKinsey and Company, does not try to skirt the difficulties she faces.
But she maintains that things could be worse and that CNBC has retained its core business audience.
Ms. Thomas-Graham said that because the economy was in decline well before the terrorist attacks, "CNBC was already in a challenging period." She added, "Sept. 11 has given everything more urgency and more focus."
CNBC's daytime ratings are falling even as cable-news viewership overall has increased tremendously since the attacks. The audiences of CNN, the Fox News Channel and MSNBC have doubled and tripled, joined in part by some of CNBC's business-news viewers.
CNBC is losing audience during its most important period, the business day from 5 a.m. to 8 p.m. In that period, CNBC is being watched at any given moment, on average, in 273,000 households, 13 percent fewer than last year.
Meanwhile, the average audience for its flagship, evening business program, "Business Center," is one-fourth that of "Lou Dobbs Moneyline" on CNN since Sept. 11. "Moneyline" is clearly riding the CNN ratings surge. But it had been trailing "Business Center" for a couple of years in the most visible sign of CNBC's strength.
CNBC's saving grace so far has been the general-news oriented "Rivera Live," which has greatly contributed to a 32 percent rise in CNBC's prime-time audience over a year ago. But the program will end next week when its host, Geraldo Rivera, becomes a war correspondent for the Fox News Channel.
Mr. Rivera's departure has been portrayed as motivated by his desire to seek adventure as a war correspondent. But CNBC did not exactly bar the door.
Disagreeing with the NBC News executives who controlled their prime-time schedule, CNBC executives had resented Mr. Rivera's presence for some time. Back when business news was hot, CNBC executives said Mr. Rivera's general-news talk show blocked the possibility of more profitable business programming. Mr. Rivera's program does not go over well with advertisers, who shy away from its controversial tone.
But the program has also worked as a hedge against bad business-news cycles. Just as CNN lags in the ratings when the general-news environment is slow, CNBC lags in the ratings when the general-news environment is good. Mr. Rivera's program tends to capitalize on big general-news events. Watched on average by 650,000 viewers since Sept. 11, it often has the largest audience on the network.
Ms. Thomas-Graham said CNBC would replace "Rivera Live" with a business-news program. The new program, she said, would reflect the network's new broader focus. The program does not yet have a name or a specific format, she said. But people at CNBC said Tyler Mathisen, a CNBC anchor, would be its Washington host and would focus on budgetary politics, the Federal Reserve and the war abroad.
Mr. Mathisen, they said, would be named CNBC's Washington bureau chief, a new visible position for the network, which has been almost completely New York-centric.
"We've added more general-news coverage," Ms. Thomas-Graham explained, because "we believe that business leaders are asking for more information from Washington and more information from the war zone."
This, she said, is not inconsistent with CNBC's role as a provider of information vital to the economy. "For instance, anthrax is general news, but it clearly does move the markets we cover," she said.
During the day CNBC has reported heavily on the war, including coverage from the MSNBC correspondent Ashleigh Banfield in Islamabad, and nightvision video of the bombing in Afghanistan. CNBC has also shown the same White House and Pentagon briefings as have the general-news networks.
Taken together, the changes signal a shift in philosophy for CNBC. It rode to prominence by treating each day on the stock market much like a sports event, sandwiched between pre-game and post-game shows. Wisecracking anchors had just the right pitch for the hyperventilating economy.
"I think that my approach to business news is less about the sports analogy," Ms. Thomas-Graham said.
CNBC's longtime slogan, "Profit From It," may soon be changed to something more fitting for the times, she said. She would not say what new slogans are being considered.
But there are differing opinions inside and outside NBC as to just how far CNBC should stray from its trademark style. General news is already well covered by CNN, the Fox News Channel and MSNBC. Some fear CNBC could lose its identity by becoming more broadly focused.
"Just as CNN had the risk that they were trying to chase Fox and get more personality driven, CNBC has the same sort of risk of trying to go much more mainstream-news and losing its brand identity," said Tom Wolzien, senior media analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein. "When the market place, when these very strange times we're in, become more stable, they would lose their clear differentiation."
Ms. Thomas-Graham said she was aware of this, and she was being careful not to alienate viewers by being "knee-jerk" in the changes she was making.
In the meantime, CNBC correspondents and anchors are trying to tone down some of their irreverence and to judiciously include general-news items. "It's a really hard editorial challenge," a CNBC anchor, David Faber, said. "What should be included? When do you take a press conference of Tom Ridge?" he added, referring to the director of homeland security.
Others at CNBC said they were confident that its strong ratings would be back soon.
"In the relatively near future," Ron Insana, another CNBC anchor, said, "given the concerns about the economy, this is the story that naturally gravitates back toward us -- absent a military failure overseas that is meaningful, or another attack."

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
Reasons to Give Are as Varied as Donors

BYLINE:  By KATHLEEN CARROLL 

 BODY:
Donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund often cite personal encounters with the city's needy as inspiration for their gifts -- whether it's the disabled panhandler on 42nd Street they pass every day or someone down on his luck whom they've read about in the articles that appear in The Times each winter. 
 But sometimes, unexpected windfalls, happy occasions or just plain thankfulness prompt people to remember New York City's poor during gentler seasons. 
 Throughout the spring, summer and fall, donations continued to arrive at P.O. Box 5193. In its 2000-2001 appeal that ended last March, the fund received 12,291 donations totaling $8,033,582.22, the largest amount raised in its 90-year history. 
In August, Charles Drew of Manhattan sent a check for $300 to the fund, accompanied by a note. "Dear Editor: Your paper has carried many articles about President Bush's refund check," he wrote. "One letter from a reader, who obviously was going to spend it, suggested to those who did not approve of the refund to donate it to charity. This is what I am doing. I hope it encourages others."
Mr. Drew, an actor born in Port Washington, N.Y., said he had been reading the stories of those who benefited from the fund for 50 years. He was inspired to send his tax refund to a charity that benefits his neighbors. "The people they help just need a little help to get to live normally. These are poor people starving in their apartments," he said. 
"I thought that if the purpose of the tax refund was to boost the economy, this was the best way to do that," Mr. Drew said. 
In May, the fund received 25 separate donations honoring the wedding of Jeremy Barnum and Caitlin Macy, who had suggested giving to the fund as a way to celebrate their marriage without giving a gift. 
When planning the wedding, "We felt our cup runneth over, and the implied solicitation for gifts made us both balk," Ms. Macy said. "We did register, but if people asked, we also mentioned the charity as a suggestion."
Donating to the fund is a tradition for the couple. At Christmastime in 1999, their first holiday together, both Ms. Macy, a fiction writer, and Mr. Barnum, a trader at J. P. Morgan Chase, were celebrating the close of banner years. Her first novel was in bookstores, and he was celebrating a profitable year on Wall Street. 
Surrounded by plenty, Ms. Macy felt a tugging need to share the wealth, which she expressed to Mr. Barnum. So when he presented her with a jewelry box, there was an extra gift alongside a new pearl necklace: a check made out to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. 
"It feels very direct," she said. "You give money, and later you read about how the money is used, exactly." Because The New York Times Company Foundation pays for the fund's administration costs, every dollar goes to those in need. 
In March, Sophia Ryan of Larchmont, N.Y., then 16, mailed in a check to the fund for $350, raised during a luncheon she organized at her school. About 60 attendees paid $5 each for a feast of soups and breads donated by local stores and cookies baked by students, as well as a few unexpected homemade dishes of lasagna and quiche.
The idea for the luncheon came from her own surroundings at Mamaroneck High School. "Everyone here is so generous, you just have to focus that generosity and funnel it toward a common cause," she said. 
Sophia was inspired to do just that after learning that Dr. John Ruskay, chief executive of the UJA-Federation of New York, one of seven local charities that benefit from the Neediest Cases Fund, organized a class donation to the fund when he was a grade-school student in Cedarhurst, N.Y. 
"I wanted to make a significant donation, to really try and help as many people as I could," she said. 
In Larchmont, Ms. Ryan does not often encounter people who may have received aid from the fund. Even if she did, she said, "I don't know that I would feel the need to discuss it with them. It's not something that needs to be discussed, just something that needed to be done. If it helps someone, that's what's really important."

HEADLINE: Pittsburgh Jury Sentences Man To Death in Racial Killing of 3 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 

 BODY:
After two days of deliberation, a jury decided today that a black man should be sentenced to death for killing three white men in a racially motivated shooting rampage.
 The man, Ronald Taylor, 41, was convicted on Friday in the March 1, 2000, violence that started at his apartment in suburban Wilkinsburg and continued at two nearby restaurants. 
 The jury could have decided that Mr. Taylor should spend life in prison without the possibility of parole. 
Judge Lawrence O'Toole will sentence Mr. Taylor, but he is bound by the jury's decision on the three first-degree murder charges. No date was set for the formal sentencing, which will make Mr. Taylor the 246th person on Pennsylvania's death row.
"I feel Mr. Taylor brought it on himself," said Michaela Sanielevici, whose 20-year-old son, Emil, was among those killed.
Defense lawyers had argued that Mr. Taylor was insane and suffered from delusions that whites were persecuting him. At the time of the killings, he was unemployed and receiving disability checks because of mental illness.
One defense lawyer, Lisa Middleman, had asked the jurors to show compassion because of Mr. Taylor's mental state.
Prosecutors maintained that Mr. Taylor knew what he was doing when he singled out whites. Even a defense psychiatrist testified that Mr. Taylor had an awareness that killing was considered wrong.
In the trial, prosecutors showed jurors copies of hate writings found in Mr. Taylor's apartment that railed at whites, Jews and gays. One of the writings said, "Jesus Christ made a very big, costly mistake by putting white trash people on the face of the earth."
Mr. Taylor was convicted of killing a maintenance man at his apartment and two men at nearby fast-food restaurants. Two other men were wounded in the shootings at the restaurants.

HEADLINE: Sagging Economy Threatens Health Coverage 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 

 BODY:
Yohannes Gezu is one of the economic casualties of the terrorist attacks. A well-paid waiter at a big Chicago convention hotel before Sept. 11, he is now lucky to get a few days of work a week.
 Just as troubling for a man with a stay-at-home wife and a 1-year-old son, Mr. Gezu says he will also soon be confronted with paying a $400-a-month premium if he wants to keep his family's health insurance. "How can you afford to pay $400?" he asks. 
 As the economic downturn takes hold, the plight of people like Mr. Gezu underscores the vulnerability of most Americans' health coverage. Sixty-five percent of Americans under 65 get insurance through their employer, meaning that the loss of a full-time job can quickly translate into the loss of health benefits.
A 1986 federal law allows people to keep their health insurance even after they lose their jobs, but they must pick up the full cost of the premiums -- a huge burden for someone laid off, as much as $500 or $600 a month for coverage of a family, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation.
At the same time, state officials and health care experts are warning that the basic government safety net for covering low-income people -- the Medicaid program, jointly financed by the states and the federal government -- is under increasing strain. Declining tax revenues because of the economy, rising health care costs and an expected jump in the Medicaid caseload because of layoffs all make for a dangerous combination, officials say.
"States need help," Gov. John Engler of Michigan, a Republican who is chairman of the National Governors Association, declared last week in an appeal to Congressional leaders. "Increasing the federal share for Medicaid would be a way to put desperately needed funds where governors need them the most -- providing health care to poor families."
These health care needs are now entangled in the fiercely partisan debate over the economic stimulus package in the Senate. Democrats are backing a plan that would provide $9 billion to cover 75 percent of the premiums of people who have lost their jobs since Sept. 11 and are trying to keep their private insurance. Their plan would also provide $5 billion to increase the federal contribution to Medicaid, and another $3 billion for states that want to help unemployed workers not otherwise eligible for assistance with coverage.
Republicans say the Democratic plan is too costly, not focused enough on the neediest Americans and runs the risk of creating an expensive new entitlement. Although the premium assistance in the bill would be limited to just over a year, some Republicans say it is hard to let a program lapse once it develops a constituency.
Democrats counter that the Republicans, who provided a $3 billion grant for health care in the economic stimulus plan that passed the House, are more concerned about rewarding big corporations with tax cuts than helping the unemployed.
Behind the partisan fight are people scrambling to adjust. Connie Cretsinger, 58, furloughed last month from her job at United Airlines outside Chicago, figures she will pay the $173 a month it will take to maintain her individual health insurance coverage. With a history of breast cancer, she cannot afford to let her insurance lapse, she said.
But Krystyna Oskierko, a single mother laid off from her job at an airline catering company in Chicago, said she did not see how she could afford to keep her coverage for herself and her 13-year-old daughter. She takes home just $153 a week in unemployment, she said. "Cobra is expensive," she said. "I don't have the money for it."
She was referring to the Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act, the 1986 law intended to provide a bridge for workers between jobs. It has been used by millions of workers, but it has major holes; for example, it does not apply to people who work for small businesses, with fewer than 20 workers.
Most significantly, health experts and advocates say, it is expensive. It requires workers to pay the full cost of their health insurance premiums, plus 2 percent for administrative costs. That could eat up half or two-thirds of the average monthly unemployment benefit, analysts note.
"The vast majority of the public doesn't understand the problems associated with Cobra," said Ron Pollack, executive director of Families USA, a liberal advocacy group. "Cobra provides a very crucial right for recently laid off people, but it is unaffordable for the intended beneficiaries to exercise that right."
Representative Nancy L. Johnson, the Connecticut Republican who is chairwoman of the health subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee, argues, "The problem with the Democratic approach is that it sounds nice on paper, but low-income people on the whole don't work for companies covered by Cobra." She defended the House Republican approach -- a $3 billion grant to the states -- and argued that it gave states the flexibility to help those who need it most.
Health analysts say there are two different populations that will need help in a serious downturn -- those eligible for Cobra, who could take advantage of it with an adequate subsidy, and those who could obtain health coverage through Medicaid or the Children's Health Insurance Program.
The Cobra population is more middle class, and may not qualify for programs aimed at lower-income parents and their children. (Lower-income people without children often fall between the cracks of both systems, advocates say.)
Moreover, many Democrats believed it would be easier to win support for money to maintain private health insurance through Cobra than to expand government programs. Conservatives are often dismayed at the idea of expanding Medicaid, a Great Society program like Medicare that liberals once hoped would be the precursor of universal health insurance.
What is clear, a range of health experts say, is that recessions -- if this is a recession -- take a heavy toll on health coverage. In the downturn of 1990-92, more than half of the workers who lost their jobs became uninsured, according to Families USA. In fact, the intense anxiety among the middle class about their health care sparked Bill Clinton's campaign in 1992, and his failed effort to enact universal coverage in 1994. "Health security" was the catch phrase, aimed squarely at the anxious middle class.
Robert J. Blendon, an expert at Harvard on public opinion and health, predicted: "It will take a little while, and then I think we'll see this issue re-emerge. Like '92, we have premiums going up, people losing jobs, people losing health insurance who traditionally thought they had it, and people finding no real safety net of coverage."

HEADLINE: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK; 
Equality at Trade Talks: No Country Gets a Vote

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: DOHA, Qatar, Nov. 11 

 BODY:
World trade ministers say they fear that they will deliver a shock to the world economy unless they agree to liberalize trade at their meeting here. But the only shocking thing may be if they manage to agree on anything at all.
 The World Trade Organization, the umbrella trade body, is sometimes described as the ultimate capitalist club, but it is far from exclusive. It has 144 members -- with the addition of China and Taiwan this weekend -- including many of the poorest as well as the richest countries. The United States, Uruguay and Uganda have exactly the same voting power, which is none. 
 Voting is forbidden. Even the United Nations General Assembly's rule of one country one vote smacks of a tyranny of the majority to ministers here. The trade organization operates by consensus, meaning that the smallest holdout can in principle sink the weightiest agreement.
If discussions get that far, that is. Two years ago in Seattle, the last time the organization called together its sponsors for what it calls a ministerial, delegates never fully agreed on procedures for deciding if they agreed on the trade issues at stake.
Some poor countries complained bitterly about a so-called green room, where selected delegates haggled over details. Though anything they decided there was liable to be rejected by the all-inclusive plenary, talk of conspiratorial cabals felled the entire enterprise.
This time, ministers gathering in this Persian Gulf state decided to make the least hierarchical of multilateral institutions more democratic. Any country that wants to participate in any discussion at any time is at least theoretically permitted to do so, with delegate counts and the need for sleep the only limiting factors.

A Twisted Flow Chart
 This is how it works. The chiefs of the delegations select facilitators to build consensus on various issues. The facilitators convene working groups of people intrigued by a particular issue. The groups themselves can subdivide to debate proposals. Working groups draft text to be reviewed by delegation leaders, any one of whom can start the cycle all over again.
One anti-globalization group attending the meeting passed out leaflets protesting "domination of the heavyweights." But the United States disguises its power well. In one recent session to debate a particularly thorny dispute over patent rules, a lone American delegate was swamped by representatives of Brazil, India, Kenya and Zimbabwe, who did not share the American perspective.
The consensus approach has its origins in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a cold war-era forum for deciding trade policy that operated like a gentlemen's club. At the trade organization, its supposedly more potent successor, officials talk more about the art of gelling and coalescing than about making decisions.
Keith Rockwell, the trade organization's spokesman, was pressed today to reveal something -- anything -- that had been agreed to after three days of talks.
"Reaching agreement ahead of schedule is not something for which we are famous," he deadpanned.
The World Trade Organization may make the United Nations look like a model of corporate efficiency. But the trade group has an edge in diplomacy.

Trade-Dollar Diplomacy
 Though the ministers have come to Qatar, a conservative Islamic society that borders Saudi Arabia, Israel's delegation is here en masse, with three ministers and a large team of negotiators. It is the first meeting in the region to accept an Israeli delegation in two years, said Majallie Whbee, the director of Israel's Ministry of Regional Cooperation.
"Our view is that from the economic side we can build confidence and build peace," he said.
India and Pakistan do not have good relations at home and are often conspicuously cool toward each another abroad. But not at the trade meeting.
The two nations are founding members of the Like Minded Group, half a dozen developing countries that press rich countries to open their markets to exports of the poor, like textiles.
When reporters today questioned Munir Akram, Pakistan's permanent representative to the trade organization, on subtle differences in the trade goals of India and Pakistan, he demurred. "I do not wish to disagree with the distinguished minister from India," he said with a smile.
Trade does not soften all rivalries, however. China and Taiwan spend billions of dollars in two-way trade. They both entered the trade organization during this meeting. But China used its sway to make sure that Taiwan's accession ceremony came a day after its own. 
Moreover, while China's membership documents use the title People's Republic of China, Taiwan had to settle for Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu, the latter three being tiny islands under Taiwan's control. Chinese Taipei was permitted as shorthand.
The 1999 meeting in Seattle, the trade group's last such meeting, attracted a dozen heads of state, including President Clinton, two dozen members of Congress, hundreds of trade negotiators and tens of thousands of protesters. Qatar is another story.
The location is remote. The global economy is weak. There is a war on. And Americans were warned of credible threats of terrorism. Many lawmakers and government trade experts and at least one cabinet member, Commerce Secretary Don Evans, stayed home.
The defections took a toll. European nations have 508 delegates. Japan comes in second with 159. Canada has 62. The United States barely ranks in the top 10, with 51. Indonesia has 60.
Peter Allgeier, the deputy United States trade representative, acknowledged that his contingent would have been larger in normal times, but called the team "pared-down, effective and cooperative."
Is the United States underrepresented? "We haven't missed a single meeting that we wanted to attend," he said.

HEADLINE: Electric Cars May Lose Push In Northeast 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 11 

 BODY:
Two years after New York, Massachusetts and Vermont announced that they would require the sale of electric cars, they are considering postponing that requirement by four years and promoting the use of other emission-reduction technologies instead.
 State officials say the change could actually produce a deeper cut in tailpipe pollution in the first few years, while giving car companies needed flexibility. Environmental groups question that claim and say the plan may not be legal. Most important, they say, a retreat by the Northeast states would damage efforts to make electric cars commonplace and economically viable. 
 The move would leave California as the only state requiring sales of electric cars over the next several years, cutting the market for them roughly in half. California's plan begins with the 2003 model year, which goes on sale in just 9 to 10 months. It requires that at least 10 percent of the cars sold by each manufacturer be much cleaner than current cars, and that 2 percent be zero-emission vehicles, or ZEV's -- in other words, electric-powered.
Two years ago, Gov. George E. Pataki's administration, followed by Massachusetts and Vermont, adopted the California regulation with considerable fanfare, boasting that the Northeast would help create a national market for electric vehicles. The proposed rule now under consideration would take effect in the 2007 model year.
"It's hard to believe that Governor Pataki, arguably one of the most vocal electric vehicle advocates, would consider a four-year delay in the program," said Peter M. Iwanowicz, director of environmental health for the American Lung Association of New York State. "The ZEV program is the key to a long-term strategy to rein in emissions, and any delay is a setback, and long-term air quality will suffer."
Top environmental officials of the three Northeast states insist that the change is, at this point, just an idea that they are weighing. But they spent several months negotiating it with the auto industry, producing a detailed proposed regulation. Officials in all three states say they expect it to take effect. New York's environmental conservation commissioner, Erin Crotty, said her department would decide next month whether to adopt the rule. She said postponing the electric car mandate would simply be a recognition that automakers are not yet ready to produce them. "While New York is very committed to zero-emission vehicles, they do have technology constraints," she said.
Automakers have protested for years that they would be unable to make commercially viable electric cars in time to meet the California mandate. The electric cars produced now run on batteries, have limited ranges and must be recharged frequently, making them less attractive to consumers. Car companies are betting instead on fuel cells to power electric cars, but that technology still needs improvement. Fuel cells use oil, natural gas or other fuels to produce electricity through chemical reactions, not combustion.
For the last decade, New York has consistently been the leader among the handful of Northeast states that have gone along with each step of the California Air Resources Board's emissions reduction program. Environmentalists credit that program, which is stricter than federal rules, with helping to drive advances in pollution control.
The Northeast states' participation has roughly doubled the share of the national car market operating under the California rules, to about 20 percent. In some cases, that has helped set a de facto national standard, as automakers have decided to build cars for the entire country that meet California standards.
California requires that by next year, 10 percent of vehicles sold must produce far less pollution than cars sold now. While 2 percent must have no emissions at all, the other 8 percent can have some, using technologies like more advanced versions of gas-electric hybrids now on the market, and seals that prevent fuel vapors from escaping.
The proposed Northeast rule would push the plan back by four years. In the interim, it would allow automakers to earn credit against the future requirement by producing alternatives like hybrids. California also awards credits, but the Northeast plan would give far more. For example, the sale of one advanced hybrid next year would relieve the maker from having to produce 12 electric cars in 2007.
The Northeast plan would also allow car companies to earn ZEV credits by using existing technology to cut pollution from light trucks, vans and sport-utility vehicles, which are not covered by California's plan. Officials involved in drafting the rule said the Pataki administration had insisted on that provision, which was ardently sought by the manufacturers.
For the first several years under the plan, "We'll actually end up with far more of the vehicles being very clean" and lower overall emissions, said Sonia Hamel, the Massachusetts director of air policy and planning.
Ms. Crotty, the New York environmental chief, said, "The alternate compliance plan is intended to get more, cleaner cars out there sooner." She said she did not know if the proposed rule would cut emissions more in the short run than California's, saying that was a central question her department was studying.
Environmentalists are extremely skeptical of such claims, and argue that they miss the point.
"What this program is primarily about is jump-starting the production of vehicles with no tailpipe emissions, zero, none," said Roland J. Hwang, senior policy analyst at the Natural Resources Defense Council. "Until this technology takes off and starts to take over a big chunk of the marketplace, the reductions you get are fairly small, but when you get to that point, the benefits become huge."
Congress long ago authorized California to adopt pollution rules that are more stringent than the national standards. It gave other states a choice between accepting California's rules as their own, or living with those set by the federal government. Environmental groups say that federal law might prohibit states from charting a third course, and that they are deciding whether to sue if the Northeast plan is adopted. When asked if the plan was legal, Ms. Crotty said she was not certain.
Mr. Pataki's environmental record is a central part of his crossover appeal, as a Republican governor in a state that leans heavily Democratic. Democrats have made clear that as he prepares to run for re-election next year, they will make an issue of what they call a pattern of environmental programs that do not live up to their original intent.
In 1999, the governor announced that he would impose the toughest pollution controls in the nation on old power plants. So far, he has put no rule into effect, and the proposed rule does not go quite as far, or as quickly, as the plan he outlined two years ago. In the meantime, a few other states have imposed stricter standards.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE IMMIGRATION AGENCY; 
Effort to Discover Terrorists Among Illegal Aliens Makes Glacial Progress, Critics Say

BYLINE:  By SOMINI SENGUPTA and CHRISTOPHER DREW 

 BODY:
In placing the Justice Department on a wartime footing, Attorney General John Ashcroft has ordered the Immigration and Naturalization Service to lead the charge in ferreting out potential terrorists among the nation's illegal immigrants.
 But on the ground, the order is being translated into reality at a glacial pace, if that, critics say. 
 Even though at least three of the Sept. 11 hijackers were in the country illegally, the immigration agency has not been culling its files of other people here on expired visas, saying that the pool is too big to make it a useful tool in finding terrorists.
Nor is the agency quickly able to track people coming in and out of the country, since its antiquated system still records such information in paper files. About 200 people have been detained on immigration violations as part of the terrorism investigation, but nearly all of them were identified by federal or local law enforcement officers, not by immigration agents. 
Indeed, the terror attacks have laid bare the country's longstanding ambiguity on the question of what to do about illegal immigration. Before Sept. 11, the Bush administration was engaged in serious negotiations to offer legal status to some of those immigrants, particularly Mexicans, who were in the country illegally.
Guest worker programs had been expanded, workplace raids had been suspended and much of the focus was on the economic benefits of attracting foreign workers.
But since the terror attacks, the political pendulum has swung toward greater caution, and the immigration service is trying to shift course.
In the hours after the World Trade Center towers fell, for instance, New York City police officers and F.B.I. agents rushed to the Port Authority bus terminal to check for possible accomplices on buses bound for Canada.
They stopped two Middle Eastern men, who admitted to overstaying their visas, police officials said. But when immigration agents arrived at the scene, they let the men go, just as as if nothing had changed that day.
Since then, law enforcement officials say, the immigration agency has been working more closely with the F.B.I. and detaining the illegal immigrants that are the bureau's target. But in recent interviews, immigration officials said they did not want to be seen as singling out Middle Eastern men, and they did not plan to search for undocumented immigrants on their own.
"No raids, no roundups, none of that," said Joseph Greene, the immigration agency's assistant commissioner for investigations.
So it remains to be seen just what the service will do to carry out the new initiatives set out by President Bush, who recently pledged that the government would become "very diligent with our visas and observant with the behavior of people who come to this country."
Critics on Capitol Hill are not optimistic, saying the service has been managed too poorly for too long to be fixed without even more radical changes. But while that debate goes on in Washington, the new reality is becoming clear in the courthouses where deportation cases are heard.
That was evident in Newark recently when an immigration judge, William Strasser, turned to a Pakistani man sitting before him in forest-green jail-house scrubs and spelled out the new rules of engagement. Immigration violations, the judge declared, would no longer be handled as they had been in the past.
"We live in different times than a year ago, you understand me?" Judge Strasser said. "There weren't threats before, possible threats."
The Pakistani man, Azhar Iqbal, 36, had been smuggled into the country with a forged visa and had been picked up in mid-October by the police and federal agents with several other Pakistani men in an apartment in Ardsley, a Westchester County town. He was quickly deemed to be of no use to the F.B.I. terrorism investigation and was held in jail on immigration charges.
As it has done with all the detainees who have been picked up since Sept. 11, the immigration agency objected to releasing Mr. Iqbal on bond.
In many cases, those objections have been overruled. But with Mr. Iqbal, Judge Strasser asked him why he should be allowed to stay in the country.
As it turned out, Mr. Iqbal had no good reason other than his own desperation. Barely able to communicate in English, he said something about floods having ravaged his family's farm in Pakistan. He told the judge he had paid a smuggler $16,000 to come into this country. "I stay for work, some money," he mumbled. "I am very poor. Flood in Pakistan."
The judge ordered him to leave the country in 30 days, and for him to be released from the custody of the immigration service in the meantime on an $8,000 cash bond. Though the judge entered his order on Oct. 26, Mr. Iqbal has not yet come up with the bond money.
Other detainees have also found that getting out of jail is not an easy feat.
Mahmood Abbasi, a limousine driver who had lived in this country illegally for more than a decade, was detained on Oct. 8. But even after a judge authorized his release on a $10,000 bond, and his family came up with the cash, it took eight days and a complaint to the immigration judge to obtain his release, said Mr. Abbasi's lawyer, Roland Gell.
The latest crackdown is being driven by Mr. Ashcroft and other top officials, who say there is no easier way to prevent further terrorist attacks than enforcing immigration laws.
Many of the arrests have come from traffic stops, old warrants for petty crimes and tips about suspicious activities from neighbors. So far, the focus is on people of Middle Eastern and South Asian descent, though more subtle distinctions are being made.
Mr. Gell said another client, an Indian man nicknamed "the pilot," was questioned by F.B.I. agents shortly after the Sept. 11 attacks. He, too, had overstayed his visa. But when they learned he was a Hindu, and not a Muslim like the hijackers, the F.B.I. released him.
Still, the difficulties in picking through the vast pool of illegal immigrants, and deciding which ones might be connected to terrorists, are immense.
Last year, more than seven million foreigners arrived with tourist visas, while the State Department issued more than 100,000 temporary work visas and 280,000 student visas. Of the estimated eight million illegal immigrants now thought to be here, 40 percent are believed to have overstayed their visas.
In the past, illegal immigrants usually came to the agency's attention only if they were caught in a smuggling ring or picked up in a workplace raid. "If you laid low, life was fine," said Janet Sabel, a lawyer for the Legal Aid Society.
But critics, including several powerful members of Congress, say that can no longer be tolerated.
Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., a Wisconsin Republican who heads the House Judiciary Committee, said the immigration service had been so poorly managed that some 250,000 immigrants who had received deportation orders were still in the country illegally.
"It's not just immigration enforcement," Mr. Sensenbrenner said in an interview. "Talk to anyone who has tried to get a green card for themselves or their loved ones. They will tell you that that part of the I.N.S. is just as incompetent."
Mr. Ashcroft said on Thursday that he planned to address these problems by breaking the immigration agency into two services, separating border enforcement from immigration processing. Mr. Sensenbrenner supports this general idea. But he has also proposed legislation to create a new post high in the Justice Department to take control of the immigration bureaus.
Mr. Sensenbrenner also said that Congress had more than tripled the immigration service's spending authority since 1993, and he had little patience for the notion that a lack of money had delayed its efforts to create a better immigrant tracking system.
But some experts warned that even with half of the 1,900 immigration enforcement agents assigned to work with the F.B.I., there were limits to what could be done.
"We're at risk of developing an exaggerated view of what immigration law can do in response to terrorism," said David Martin, a former immigration service general counsel who is now a law professor at the University of Virginia. "There's all this talk of monitoring either students or anyone who comes in on temporary admission. Those may be very good in their own right.
"But it's not an efficient way to win the struggle against terrorism."
And even as the talk is tougher on illegal immigration, there is, in truth, no rush to deport most of the illegal immigrants in the country.
In fact, the service recently encouraged illegal immigrants to report tips on terrorists and anthrax scares without fear of being caught.
And last month, on his visit to New York City, the commissioner of immigration, James W. Ziglar, urged illegal immigrants who had lost jobs or their family breadwinners in the trade center attacks to seek government relief, also without fear of retribution from the agency.
Mr. Ziglar said the service would not ask for the victims' immigration status. "We would not use that information against them," he said. "Frankly, we don't want that information."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Attorney General John Ashcroft announcing new antiterror focus at Immigration and Naturalization Service. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Lost Jobs, Ragged Safety Net 

BYLINE:  By Robert B. Reich; Robert B. Reich, former labor secretary, teaches economic and social policy at Brandeis University and is author of "The Future of Success."

 BODY:
The economic fallout from terrorism is hitting some Americans much harder than others, and we need to respond. Last year, when the slowdown began, layoffs and pay cuts hit hardest at manufacturing workers, white-collar managers and professionals. But since the terrorist attacks, consumers have cut their spending, and now a different group is experiencing the heaviest job losses: the mostly low-paid workers in America's vast personal-service sector.
 With retail sales down, there's less need for sales clerks. Half-empty hotels don't need nearly as many cleaners and bellmen. Vacant convention halls have no use for platoons of custodians and staffers. Unfilled restaurants can't keep waiters and busboys busy. And so on through all the workers who attend, drive, pamper, launder, polish, clean, prepare and otherwise make life more pleasant for the people who pay them. 
 In October 439,000 private-sector jobs were lost -- the largest monthly decline in more than a quarter-century. Hotels alone lost 46,000; retailers, 81,000; airlines, 42,000. Minority workers, with a disproportionate share of low-wage service jobs, have been especially hard hit. Unemployment among blacks rose to 9.7 percent last month, a full percentage point higher than in September and up 2.3 points from a year ago. Unemployment among Hispanics is 2.2 percentage points higher than it was last year at this time.
There is reason to expect that job cuts at the lower end of the wage scale will get even larger and occur even faster in the months ahead. That's because so much consumer spending is discretionary, turning more on psychological wants than on physical needs. Consumers don't have to dine outside the home, travel, enjoy live entertainment or go on shopping binges. They can choose to spend less on these services as soon as their wallets feel even slightly pinched. And when they do, lower-wage workers feel a bigger pinch. The Fiscal Policy Institute estimates that 48,000 of the 80,000 jobs that New York City will have lost by the end of the year pay an average of $23,000, significantly below the citywide average of about $58,000.
Another vulnerability of lower-income service workers is that they have fewer means of cushioning the blow than they had in prior recessions. Most have no savings and are deeper in debt than they were last time, because their inflation-adjusted earnings never really got off the ground in the 90's. The steady decline in higher-paying manufacturing jobs and an influx of low-skilled immigrants combined to keep wages down.
Government will be less helpful this time around. Safety nets are in tatters. Welfare-to-work programs made sense when work was plentiful, but without work, those no longer eligible for welfare have nowhere else to turn. Even job losers who still qualify will find that welfare payments in most states are worth less than before.
Unemployment insurance is also harder to get. Fewer than 30 percent of people who lose jobs now receive it, down from more than half several decades ago. Eligibility rules have grown steadily tighter. Since part-time workers, temps, the self-employed and people who have moved in and out of employment often don't qualify, a large portion of the lower-wage work force is excluded. Many who don't qualify are women with young children. 
Meanwhile, federal programs for job training and low-income housing have been shrunk by budget cuts. State and local governments are in no position to step in. They're already strapped by rapidly declining tax revenues. Rather than beefing up social services, they're starting to cut them.
In short, the fat years of the 90's have left us woefully unprepared for a deep recession that's likely to take a particularly large toll on the poor and lower-wage workers. Given all this, a "stimulus" plan like the one that passed last month in the House of Representatives and is being backed by the White House, which confers most of its benefits on large corporations and upper-income households, seems exactly the reverse of what's needed. Large corporations, already reeling from too much capacity, won't be induced to add more. Wealthier households, already spending whatever they want, won't be inspired to spend more. It's the bottom half who are in trouble. They're most likely to spend whatever extra they get. And they desperately need whatever government can supply. 
At a time of national crisis, when the nation must pull together, it seems only logical that we do what we can to avoid pulling further apart.

HEADLINE: In America; 
The Sadness Within

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
If you stay away from Ground Zero, which remains a landscape out of Dante, the city can seem pretty normal. The pre-Thanksgiving throngs in Midtown over the weekend were impressive. A gorgeous eight-ton, 81-foot Norway spruce is up and waiting for its Christmas decorations at Rockefeller Center.
 The weather for the most part has been sunny and crisp and there have been lines for discount theater tickets at the TKTS booth in Times Square. Tourism may be off, but getting a prime-time Saturday night reservation at one of the elite restaurants is as difficult as ever. 
 That's the surface picture.
Beneath the surface, the sorrow continues. The grief has not eased much, if at all, for the families of those killed at the World Trade Center. This will be the hardest of holiday seasons for them.
But the waves of hardship and sorrow have had an extraordinary reach, touching every neighborhood. New Yorkers, in varying degrees, remain both emotionally and economically shaken by the Trade Center attack and its aftermath. As many as 80,000 jobs will have been lost by the end of the year, most of them paying less than $25,000 annually. Onetime breadwinners are looking aghast at rent bills they can't pay, credit card obligations they can't meet, Christmas presents they won't be able to buy.
An article in The Times last Tuesday said: "The terrorists who attacked the World Trade Center may have been trying to crush American capitalism and its masters of the universe on Wall Street. But the economic impact of the attack is felling a very different group of people: cooks, cabdrivers, sales clerks and seamstresses."
Among those witnessing this disaster close up are the staff members of Safe Horizon, a victims' services organization that is offering financial assistance and counseling to people affected by the Trade Center attack, including displaced workers and people who were forced from their homes.
"Initially we saw a lot of people who were just in shock, disbelief that this was happening," said Nancy Arnow, a Safe Horizon vice president for family and clinical programs.
After several weeks, she said, the initial anxiety and fear began to be accompanied by increasing anger as the Trade Center attack was followed by the anthrax scares, bomb threats and other traumatic developments.
Nervous workers were finding it difficult in some cases to ride the subways or go into tall buildings, making it difficult to get to work. Absences have increased. Safe Horizon and other groups have reported that friction at work, particularly between employees and supervisors, has also increased. The looming threat of layoffs has not helped.
The more immediate fears are being faced by people who have already lost their jobs. Safe Horizon's Christa Stewart said she and other staff members are seeing hundreds of newly unemployed men and women every day, most of them from Lower Manhattan. "The range has been very striking in terms of the economic base they're coming from," she said. "We're seeing attorneys who worked in the area. We see the pushcart vendors. We see a lot of restaurant workers."
Some have savings to fall back on, but most don't. Many are frightened and depressed. They show up at Safe Horizon with stacks of bills and blurt out -- sometimes with tears in their eyes -- that they have no idea how they'll be able to pay them.
For many of the displaced workers, according to another Safe Horizon staff member, Christy Gibney, "There's really no end in sight to the devastation. It's frustrating for us to be working with them knowing that we are only giving them this immediate help to get them through the next couple of weeks, or the next month or two. The long-term issues are still there."
The holidays are coming and New York will put the best possible face on them. But there's a difference between normalcy and the appearance of normalcy. To the extent that there's an emotional thread running through all the days since Sept. 11, I would say that it's a deep sense of sadness that is felt by nearly all New Yorkers, certainly for the tremendous loss of life, but also for the gruesome physical damage downtown, and for the loss -- at least temporarily -- of that sense of security and confidence, the swagger, that contributed so much to the essence of New York, and thus was so meaningful to so many.

HEADLINE: With Rangers Diverted to Security, Parks Feel the Strain 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: MUIR WOODS NATIONAL MONUMENT, Calif., Nov. 11 

 BODY:
The already overburdened resources of the National Park Service have been stretched even further since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, with hundreds of federal rangers reassigned to security details and many state parks even harder pressed as local law enforcement officers investigate anthrax scares.
 At the same time, parks near large cities have experienced an average 15 percent increase in attendance, a Park Service spokesman, David Barna, said.said. 
 At Shenandoah National Park in Virginia, about 60 miles from Washington, attendance jumped 39 percent in September, he said. Attendance at Yosemite National Park, in California, was up about 10 percent. 
"People are going back to the parks to get away from the news," Mr. Barna said. "They are those special places we set aside for solace, for reflection."
The park service prepared for a surge of visitors over Veterans Day weekend after offering free admission to promote "unity, hope and healing."
"This is not about money," Mr. Barna said. "It's not significant enough compared to the significance of helping this country heal. We all have families. We're all in this together. We're not counting dollars this weekend."
Not all parks have seen higher attendance since Sept. 11. Tourism has been hurt at places like the Grand Canyon and the Muir Woods, which depend to a large extent on air travel and foreign visitors. Fully 78 percent of the 1.8 million people a year who visit the Muir Woods, a forest of towering redwoods in a hidden valley just north of San Francisco, are visiting from outside the Bay Area, and 22 percent are foreign tourists, the park said.
John and Betty Parker of Concord, Calif., took their nieces, visiting from Canton, Ohio, to the park on Friday.
With many tourists suffering from post-attack jitters, Mr. Parker said all the popular spots have seemed less busy than usual.
"We walked across the Golden Gate Bridge on Wednesday and no one was there," he said. "This is a perfect time for people to get out."
B. J. Ray, his wife, Rainey, and their two friends decided to take advantage of low air fares from Dallas and celebrate their wedding anniversaries with a trip to San Francisco.
"There's definitely been a mentality that we're not going to live in fear," Mr. Ray said.
The suspension of park entrance fees through Monday should provide an economic lift to businesses in and around parks.
State parks in California and at least 25 other states also waived admission fees.
"There are certain parks where people will flock to if the fees are dropped," said Roy Stearns, California's deputy parks director.
National parks expect to break even this weekend, reasoning that the money visitors do not spend on entrance fees will probably be spent at concession stands, gift shops and visitors' centers.
California's parks expect to lose less than $100,000, Mr. Stearns said.
"When you think of the honor we can pay to veterans, I think that far outweighs the money loss," Mr. Stearns said. "We may take a little hit, but I think the communities around those parks will feel the benefits."
About a third of the nation's parks charge admission fees, adding up to $145 million a year. Since 1996, that money has gone directly back into the park system for much-needed maintenance and repairs, Mr. Barna said.
There is a $4.9 billion maintenance backlog, which President Bush has proposed to eliminate in five years with additional money.
Annually, the service spends $2.5 billion on 385 parks, which, last year, had 287 million visitors.
Since Sept. 11, about 200 park employees have been reassigned to homeland security. Park rangers are patrolling dams in the West, parks near the Canadian and Mexican borders and major monuments in the Washington area. A handful are alsogetting sky marshal training, Mr. Barna said.
The service's 200 seasonal law enforcement employees, who work primarily in the summer, have been asked back to the parks to help compensate for the loss.
