HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE LIABILITY; 
Daschle Seeks Compromise On Aid Plan For Insurers

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 

 BODY:
Striving to break a political logjam before the Senate adjourns, Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, will try this week to forge a compromise to offer financial assistance to insurers for any more large terrorist attacks, his colleagues say.
 In the House of Representatives, meanwhile, lawmakers expect to move a bill with a different approach to the floor soon. The House bill would provide billions of dollars in loans to the insurers to cover losses from any large attacks next year, but the White House has instead proposed direct assistance. 
 The House made significant progress on a bill last week when the House Financial Services Committee approved a measure by voice vote. The bill would generally provide loans to the industry to cover 90 percent of the costs for attacks with damages greater than $1 billion. For attacks causing more than $20 billion in losses, the bill would impose a special assessment on insurance policyholders to help defray costs. It would also offer tax breaks to the industry so it could build reserves for future attacks. 
But the Senate has been unable to get a bill out of committee. Lawmakers say Senator Daschle plans discussions this week with the heads of three committees -- on banking, commerce and the judiciary -- that have stalled progress on a measure because of a jurisdictional squabble.
For weeks, lawmakers and the administration have struggled to write a law that would provide aid to the insurance industry for any more large attacks. While a broad consensus has emerged about the need for legislation, sharp disagreement remains about its contours. 
Executives from the insurance industry and other sectors have said that lenders would be reluctant to finance real estate and manufacturing projects if new policies no longer protect against terrorism losses. Administration officials have predicted an economic crisis if Congress fails to act before it adjourns, which is expected soon.
Lawmakers agree that they must encourage insurers to continue to offer reasonable coverage for terrorism, but disagree about how the federal government, which has never regulated the industry, can do that. 
The debate in Congress has centered on these four points: How much should insurers be required to pay before the government intervenes? Should the insurers have to pay back any government assistance? What steps should the federal government take to require insurers to continue to provide reasonably priced coverage for vulnerable properties, like the Empire State Building and the Sears Tower, and for distressed areas, like Lower Manhattan, that have found it difficult to get insurance? Should a measure limit the legal liability of the insurers in terrorist attacks -- perhaps by restricting punitive damages, as the administration is demanding -- or should it leave the nation's tort law system unchanged, as some leading Democrats have urged?
An earlier plan proposed by the chairman and ranking Republican on the Senate banking committee and endorsed by the administration has stalled because of limits on the insurers' legal liability. Some lawmakers also criticize it for failing to protect smaller insurance companies from significant losses.
A compromise that would drop the legal liability protections and meld provisions from House and Senate bills will be filed this week by two Democrats on the Senate banking committee, Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York and Senator Jon Corzine of New Jersey.
Their measure would generally require the industry to pay $10 billion in claims before the government would intervene. For incidents costing $10 billion to $30 billion, the government would provide financial assistance of 80 percent, to be repaid through a special assessment on the insurers. For attacks costing more than $30 billion, the industry would not have to repay the 80 percent paid by the government. The bill protects smaller insurers by capping any individual company's liability at 5 percent of its premiums.
"There's gridlock and all sorts of cross-cutting disputes," Mr. Schumer said. "We try to come to a happy medium."
Mr. Corzine said the legislation tried to overcome a number of political and ideological obstacles, including changes in tort law. He said it was important to make sure that vulnerable properties could get reasonable insurance coverage. "It's crucial to have that risk covered, or you will have huge exposures that I don't think banks or the bond market will tolerate at a reasonable price" in financing projects, said Mr. Corzine, a former chief executive of Goldman, Sachs.

HEADLINE: Mental Health, on Equal Terms 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The World Trade Center tragedy ushered in understanding for the crippling symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder and depression, and highlighted the urgent need for access to quality mental health clinicians. Such overdue recognition has now backfired and mobilized opposition to parity, which would broaden access to service (front page, Nov. 6). 
 People who battle severe psychiatric symptoms must also fight this pervasive discrimination and archaic stigma. The opposition to parity defies our surgeon general, who has advocated for more diagnosis and treatment, and the economics that has demonstrated that any modest cost is offset by increased productivity and decreased absenteeism. 
 If we substituted heart disease, cancer, diabetes or hypertension for mental illness, would we defer diagnosis and treatment of such diseases to the insurance lobby?

SUE MATORIN
New York, Nov. 6, 2001

The writer is treatment coordinator, Affective Disorder Team, Payne Whitney Clinic of New York Presbyterian Hospital.

HEADLINE: DONATIONS; 
A Company Scrambles to Keep Its 'Strategic Philanthropy' Going

BYLINE:  By DANIEL GROSS 

 BODY:
IN 1984, American Express revolutionized corporate philanthropy when it introduced a highly successful campaign to restore the Statue of Liberty. The company offered to donate 1 cent from every charge made on its cards over a three-month period to help rebuild and restore the statue. The campaign raised $1.7 million and encouraged customers to pull out their cards to make purchases. During the campaign, card use rose 28 percent compared with the same period a year before.
 Aligning business campaigns with nonprofit ventures has become known as cause-related marketing. The idea is to enlist consumers in a philanthropic effort by using a company's services. 
 Such efforts can help worthy causes, bolster business and spruce up a company's image.
Cause-related marketing is also a staple of "strategic philanthropy," in which executives of corporate foundations work closely with their colleagues on the business side of the company. 
"Corporations have recognized that their philanthropy should be as strategic as all of their business operating programs," said Carole Cone, a strategic philanthropy consultant in Boston.
Because large corporations like American Express have aligned themselves with philanthropies, there were expectations after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks that the business world would help with the relief efforts. Initially, their response involved donations of cash and services. Then, American Express and other companies found ways of responding through strategic philanthropy.
For American Express, the challenge was complicated by the company's own circumstances. The foundation's headquarters were on the 48th floor of the World Financial Center, a block west of the World Trade Center. When the staff evacuated its offices on Sept. 11, several checks for nonprofit groups were left behind. 
"We had just cut checks to several of our grantees, and we had no way to retrieve them," said Mary Beth Salerno, the president of the American Express Foundation. "So, we made lists from memory and began contacting our grantees to assure them they would receive their grants as soon as possible."
Every year, the American Express Foundation makes about $30 million in grants to a range of nonprofit groups, many of which indirectly help promote the company's services. About a third of the foundation's grants support cultural heritage projects around the world; many of these promote travel and tourism. 
For example, the company has given $10 million over the last decade to the World Monuments Fund, which tries to protect endangered works of art and architecture. The foundation also supports financial literacy programs.
In the aftermath of the attacks, Ms. Salerno and her staff helped to shape the company's philanthropic response. Like other large companies, American Express's immediate reaction was to donate cash. On the morning of Sept. 13, the company's executives committed initial grants of $250,000 each to the Red Cross and to the newly formed September 11 Fund. 
The company announced that it would give $1 million to the families of its 11 employees who were lost at the World Trade Center. And the American Express Foundation set aside $1 million to create and administer a disaster relief fund. 
Then came Part 2. "The cash and supplies were the first wave, and now there is a second wave, dealing with other issues not as immediate or obvious," said Bradley Googgins, the executive director of the Center for Corporate Citizenship at Boston College. 
One of the company's first decisions was to use philanthropy to cement bonds with employees. American Express wanted to acknowledge that employees were deeply affected by the events of Sept. 11. 
A WEEK after the attacks, the company held a rally at Madison Square Garden for 5,000 employees. At the rally, the company announced that its relief fund would be part of the employees' giving campaign. The company promised to match donations made to the fund by retirees, financial advisers and employees. 
"We don't usually collect money at the foundation, but we opened it up to allow employees to contribute," Ms. Salerno said. So far, employees have pledged $1 million.
Then, foundation and business executives worked together to redirect cause-related marketing programs. Those campaigns are run by the business side of the company, but its executives frequently turn to Ms. Salerno for advice. 
"Our role in many of these is to be advisory, to help with contacts," she said. 
American Express helped to reschedule Restaurant Week, which encourages cardholders to patronize New York City restaurants that offer $20.01 lunch specials. After the attack, the event was moved to Oct. 15 instead of January and was extended to two weeks from one. 
The company also used advertising to remind diners that Lower Manhattan restaurants had reopened.
"We ran newspaper ads noting that the lights are on, and now the customers need to come," said Steve Squeri, the president of the company's establishment services division for the United States and Canada, which handles relationships with businesses that accept the card.
Another company campaign, Membership Rewards, was also tweaked. That program allows cardholders to accumulate points and redeem them for travel certificates, merchandise and donations to groups like United Cerebral Palsy and the Special Olympics. American Express added Sept. 11 relief groups to its list of eligible charities and offered to match 2001 donations to all charities, up to $200,000 over all. 
A result: "We have had a 250 percent increase in redemptions for charities since Sept. 11," said Susan Sobbott, the company's senior vice president for loyalty rewards and alliance development.
The question now is how long the outpouring of generosity can last. In the months before the attacks, American Express laid off 6,100 employees as its stock price plunged. The company is now facing an even tougher business climate. Late last month, it reported that quarterly earnings fell 60 percent, while travel sales fell 28 percent from the year before.
In an economic downturn, will corporations like American Express continue to finance both relief efforts and other commitments to nonprofit groups?
"If these large donations come out of existing budgets, then something has to give," said Curt Weeden, the chief executive of the Contributions Academy in Charleston, S.C., and a former vice president of corporate contributions at Johnson & Johnson. "If something else happens, are those deep pockets still going to be there?"
Ms. Salerno said that American Express was making contributions to the relief fund partly from discretionary money.
"I think it is important to not just take a 180-degree turn from other things that we're doing," she said. "A lot of nonprofits, in New York and elsewhere, were having a difficult time before Sept. 11."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: ATOMIC ENERGY; 
Lax Nuclear Security in Russia Is Cited as Way for bin Laden to Get Arms

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Nov. 10 

 BODY:
In the last year, there have been dozens of violations of nuclear security rules in Russia and at least one loss of fissile material; Taliban emissaries have tried to recruit Russian scientists, and terrorists have tried to stake out a Russian nuclear storage site at least twice, say senior officials of the International Atomic Energy Agency and Western governments.
 The officials detailed the incidents, citing conversations with Russian officials and verified news reports. Despite significant improvements in Russian nuclear security in the 1990's -- some of it with American money and advice -- up to half of ex-Soviet civilian and military nuclear stockpiles with weapons-grade material are not well protected. 
 Officials of the Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Agency, the United Nations body for monitoring nuclear programs, are deeply skeptical of Osama bin Laden's claim, in an interview published in Pakistan on Friday, that he possesses nuclear weapons.
On the other hand, given the vulnerability of material in the former Soviet Union, the increasing professionalism of nuclear smuggling and the relative ease of fabricating a primitive weapon, they cannot rule it out. 
In the Kazakh port of Aktau on the Caspian shore, one ton of plutonium and two tons of highly enriched uranium sit near a now closed breeder reactor.
Ukraine, with 17 nuclear reactors and one research reactor, is considered a country of "serious concern" by officials because of its climate of government corruption and crime. Enough highly enriched uranium to make a bomb remains at a research reactor just outside Belgrade throughout the 1999 Kosovo war.
Just last week, Turkey announced it had broken up a gang of smugglers who tried to sell 2.2 pounds of what appeared to be highly enriched uranium for $750,000 to undercover police officers, material they said they had bought several months ago from a Russian of Azeri origin.
Officials are increasingly concerned that terrorists willing to die could create a "dirty bomb," wrapping more easily stolen radioactive materials used in medicine and industry around a conventional explosive, like dynamite, to try to make a significant area of a city uninhabitable for many years.
Russian officials say their fissile nuclear material is under strict and improving controls. But only 10 days ago, in a discussion with officials at the United Nations agency here, Yuri G. Volodin, chief of safeguards for the Russian nuclear regulatory agency, revealed that in the last year, there were dozens of violations of Russia's regulations for securing and accounting for nuclear material.
Mr. Volodin noted one loss of nuclear material, which he called of the "highest consequence." He said he could not be more specific about the type of material or the size of the loss.
Last month, Col.-Gen. Igor Volynkin, head of nuclear security for Russia's military, said that twice this year Russian forces discovered stakeouts by terrorists of a secret nuclear arms storage facility, although he did not say where.
Also last month, an official of the Russian Security Council, Raisa Vdovichenko, told Russian journalists that emissaries of the Taliban had asked an employee of "an institution related to nuclear technologies to go to their country to work there in this field."
There is continuing evidence of efforts to traffic in nuclear material that give many officials deep concern. 
In April 2000, the police in Georgia seized, in Batumi, several hundred fast-reactor fuel pellets, containing 920 grams -- nearly a kilogram -- of highly enriched uranium; in September, at Tbilisi airport, the police confiscated half a gram of plutonium.
The Russians say they thwarted an effort, at the very end of 1998, by an organized gang to steal 18.5 kilograms -- more than 40 pounds -- of highly enriched uranium from a military weapons facility near Chelyabinsk in the Urals.
Still, senior officials here and in Washington do not believe that Mr. bin Laden or even any state interested in a shortcut to a bomb -- from Syria and Iran to Iraq and Libya -- has been able to obtain the roughly 25 kilograms (55 pounds) of highly enriched uranium required to make a simple bomb, or the roughly 8 kilograms (17.6 pounds) of plutonium, a much more difficult material with which to work.
But they also admit that they cannot possibly know for sure.
The atomic energy agency has built a database of incidents of nuclear trafficking since 1993 -- only counting incidents confirmed by the states involved. Of the 175 cases of trafficking in nuclear material and 201 cases of trafficking in medical and industrial radioactive materials, only some 18 cases involved even small amounts of the fissionable material needed for a nuclear bomb -- plutonium or highly enriched uranium (enriched by 20 percent or more).
Altogether in all these cases, agency officials say, there have been seizures of about 400 grams (nearly one pound) of plutonium and an additional 12 kilograms (26.4 pounds) of uranium at varying levels of enrichment, equivalent to only some 6 kilograms of uranium 235.
The most serious cases, involving large amounts of material, took place in 1993 and 1994, when Russian, German and Czech police officers made large seizures of very highly enriched nuclear material manufactured in the former Soviet Union, usually at nuclear-fuel fabrication plants.
In March 1993, in St. Petersburg, nearly three kilograms (6.6 pounds) of 90 percent enriched uranium-238 were seized; in August 1994, in Munich, the police seized about 360 grams of Russian-made plutonium; in December 1994, 2.7 kilograms (just over 5 pounds) of 80 percent enriched uranium-235 were seized, part of a shipment that showed up in smaller amounts in other places -- and which officials hope was not part of an even larger shipment, apparently stolen from the Russian nuclear research center in Obninsk, about an hour's drive southwest of Moscow.
For context, officials point out, Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein had made only 1.5 kilograms (3.3 pounds) of bomb-capable uranium before the gulf war broke out.
But in fact the atomic energy agency's database is only a guide, and perhaps not even a good one. "Are we seeing half the iceberg or only the tip?" said one official, noting that the police consider seizures of drugs, a commodity far easier to secure, to represent only some 10 to 20 percent of what is shipped. Nor does the agency, devoted to civilian nuclear energy, know much about the military programs of states with nuclear weapons.
Friedrich Steinhausler, a physics professor at Stanford University and co-director of a Stanford center on the physical protection of nuclear materials, said, "It's clear that we're seeing a typical move toward professionalism in this smuggling business, with increasingly fewer incidents of significance, but of greater significance, as professionals are probing the market."
He noted that traffickers increasingly are going south, over traditional smuggling routes through Turkey, the Caucasus and especially central Asia, closer to Afghanistan, where borders are extremely long and lax. 
Matthew Bunn, assistant director of the science, technology and public policy program at Harvard University's Kennedy School, was a Clinton White House adviser. The main source of loose nuclear material remains the former Soviet Union, he says, with some 600 tons of weapons-grade nuclear material stored there outside of warheads.
The key question, he says, is to improve the security around military and especially civilian nuclear installations. In as many as half, he said, there are no automatic detectors that sound an alarm if material is smuggled out, and no security cameras where material is stored.
"For all the work we've done with Russia, after seven years, we still have most of the job to do," Mr. Bunn said. "This is a serious threat, and we know how to fix it," he said, urging that President Bush agree with Russia at the this week's summit meeting to account for and secure all nuclear material.
Some safeguards put in place by the Americans in the former Soviet Union no longer function, agency officials said -- spare parts are expensive and available only from the United States, and sometimes guards do not bother to use the equipment.
The Vienna agency is also looking for a 10 percent increase in its own budget of some $320 million, said Graham Andrew, the special assistant for Scientific and Technical Affairs, to upgrade security standards around the world. He and other officials regard a terrorist nuclear bomb to be "highly unlikely."
But the likelihood of terrorists compiling the radioactive materials necessary to make a dirty bomb with immense economic and psychological impact is much higher, the officials say.
The dirty bomb is an almost ideal instrument of terror, Mr. Bunn said. It would not kill many people, but it would terrify, and make a large area unsafe to work or live in, possibly for decades or longer. 
One official said: "Imagine a dirty bomb on the Washington mall. Do you abandon the White House?"

HEADLINE: Democrats Contend a Pataki Lobbyist Has a Conflict 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 11 

 BODY:
A longtime Republican associate of Gov. George E. Pataki has found himself playing a dual role in recent days, at times lobbying Congress on the governor's behalf, at others representing American Indians in negotiations with Mr. Pataki.
 On the one hand, the lobbyist, Bill Paxon, a former Republican congressman from western New York, has been hired by the Seneca Nation of Indians, along with three other members of his law firm, Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld, to negotiate a contract with the state for three casinos in the Buffalo area. 
 On the other, Mr. Paxon has been prowling the corners of the Capitol at the governor's request, helping -- informally and free of charge -- to persuade Congress to grant Mr. Pataki's request for $54 billion to help rebuild New York's economy after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. 
"He's one New Yorker who's helping us out," the governor's spokesman, Michael McKeon, said. "We are going to call on any and all New Yorkers to help us out."
But Mr. Paxon's dual role has drawn criticism from some Democrats and advocates for open government, who maintain that his favors for Mr. Pataki in Washington cast doubt on whether the governor's negotiations with the Seneca Indians are at arm's length.
Mr. Paxon maintains he has been urging key members of Congress and their staff to support the governor's request for more aid because of his deep roots in New York, not because he expects any favors from Mr. Pataki. It is, he said, a labor of love.
Mr. McKeon said that Mr. Pataki himself was taking the lead role in lobbying Congress, and that Mr. Paxon's informal help would have no bearing on the casino negotiations.
Mr. Paxon lobbied the State Legislature earlier this year to pass a law giving Mr. Pataki the ability to negotiate a pact with the Seneca Indians. He said he has not been at the table for substantive negotiations with the governor's office over the compact itself, though others in his firm have. "It's been a hard-fought negotiation," he said.
The Seneca tribe hired Akin, Gump in late December 2000, members of the firm and the tribe said. 
Besides Mr. Paxon, the firm dispatched Donald R. Pongrace, an expert on Native American legal affairs, and Barry W. Brandon, a Seneca Indian who has expertise in gaming law and is a former Justice Department lawyer, to New York to hammer out a framework for an agreement with Mr. Pataki s office. 
Mr. Paxon and Anthony P. Foti, a former Republican aide to the Assembly minority leader, were added to the team because of their knowledge of the state's politics. "My role was to add some of the political direction to the team," Mr. Paxon said.
According to state lobbying records, Mr. Paxon's firm has been paid $344,000 by the Seneca tribe since January.
For the state, negotiations have been handled by Patrick Kehoe, an assistant counsel in the governor's office, and John O'Mara, a former judge from Elmira. Mr. O'Mara is an influential Republican fund-raiser with close ties to Mr. Pataki. The state has paid his firm $23,000 for its work negotiating with the Senecas, state records show.
Earlier this year, Mr. Paxon's firm also received a $600,000 lobbying contract from the State University of New York to seek more federal financing for state colleges, university officials said. As a practical matter, Mr. Pataki's appointees control the university's board. SUNY's chancellor, Robert L. King, was a senior aide to the governor and served as state budget director before taking over the university system.
But a SUNY spokesman, David Henahan, said the trustees had chosen Akin, Gump for "the strength of the firm, not just one individual."
Mr. Pataki, Mr. King and Mr. Paxon were all members of the Assembly's Republican minority during the 1980's. In June, Akin, Gump firm hired another influential Assembly Republican from that era, Clarence D. Rappleyea, to lobby state lawmakers on the Senecas' behalf. He is paid $10,000 a month, state lobby records show. Mr. Rappleyea also has close ties to Mr. Pataki, who appointed him to head the New York Power Authority. He recently stepped down to become a lobbyist. 
Several Democratic lawmakers said Mr. Paxon had a conflict of interest. They pointed out that Mr. King, a former Pataki administration insider, had given Mr. Paxon's firm a lucrative contract at the same time Mr. Paxon was lobbying Mr. Pataki on behalf of the Senecas.
In addition, the free work in Washington that Mr. Paxon has done for the governor leaves Mr. Pataki in his debt at a time when the governor is supposed to be holding arm-length negotiations with the Senecas, who also have land claims pending against the state, these critics said.
State Senator Richard A. Dollinger, a Rochester Democrat, said the arrangement blurred ethical distinctions so much that they were nearly hidden. But he said they still existed. "They are involved in a dispute with the state of New York," he said referring to Akin, Gump's work for the Senecas. "I don't see how they can be out there lobbying on behalf of the state of New York."
Advocates for open government also questioned the governor's decision to enlist the help of Mr. Paxon while Mr. Paxon was working for the Senecas. "It's hard to say you are at the table for one conversation but not at the table for another," the executive director of Common Cause in New York, Rachel Leon, said. "Hiring lobbyists that at the same time are lobbying them on other issues just doesn't cut it."
But Stephen Gillers, a professor of legal ethics at New York University Law School, said Mr. Paxon had violated neither the American Bar Association's code of professional conduct nor the New York Bar Association's professional rules. Those codes would prohibit Mr. Paxon only from lobbying on the governor's behalf while working in opposition to the state, representing, for instance, someone suing the state.
"Lobbying the governor is not seen as opposing the state," Professor Gillers said.
He added, though, that scholars disagree about whether lawyers negotiating a contract with the governor's office can be considered in inherent opposition to the state. "It's a muddy area," Mr. Gillers said. "In the view of some lawyers and ethics committees, negotiating against a current client, even if it's a friendly negotiation, is a conflict, unless the client consents to the activity."

HEADLINE: MEDIA; 
Like Other Monthlies, Esquire Dances to a New Rhythm

BYLINE:  By DAVID HANDELMAN 

 BODY:
On Sept. 11, David Granger, the editor in chief of Esquire, was about to ship the last few pages of his November issue when terrorists attacked America. Staring at a mockup of the cover -- a photo of the actress Cameron Diaz -- Mr. Granger knew that three weeks later, when the issue reached newsstands and mailboxes, it would seem "wrong," he said, "that Esquire would be represented to the world by that cover."
 Mr. Granger faced the same challenge as all his peers editing monthly general-interest magazines. With life changing underfoot, and an unwieldy lead time (three weeks between finishing the pages and distributing the issues), he needed to be somehow newsworthy and a must-read. 
 His short-term plan was swift and sure. For November, Mr. Granger rewrote his editor's letter and shelved the Diaz cover and eight-page profile. Instead, he ran photographs by Patricia McDonough of the World Trade Center burning outside her Battery Park apartment window; first-person articles by two war correspondents, Scott Anderson and John Falk; and an essay about the imminent war by Walter Russell Mead, the policy expert. A new cover depicted the towers exploding in the pupil of an enlarged eye, headlined, "What They Saw."
Yet those stories were jarringly juxtaposed with previously shipped features about bacon, corduroy and the best ways to photograph celebrities. And soon, Mr. Granger faced a bigger, more complex problem: what to do the next month, and the ones after that, with a war under way and signs of biological warfare dominating newspapers, television, weeklies and the Internet. Other monthly editors are also wrestling with the difficulty of forecasting events and moods.
"I've been a magazine editor for a long time," said Mr. Granger's colleague, Ellen Levine, editor in chief of Good Housekeeping, which, like Esquire, is owned by the Hearst Corporation, "but I'm not used to editing in the age of anthrax, with this kind of psychological uncertainty in the country. Anticipating whether two months from now, people will want something totally escapist or totally relevant is impossible."
Since taking over Esquire in June 1997, Mr. Granger had run a provocative, inventive, sometimes overreaching magazine, publishing some powerful long-form journalism, as well as some less successful experiments, like the profile of the singer Michael Stipe, which uneasily blended fact and fiction. In the wake of Sept. 11, Mr. Granger felt forced to re-examine his vision, trying to calculate how many stories should reflect Topic A, and which others needed to be rethought or jettisoned.
"As opposed to the newsweeklies or the New Yorker, we can't cover the war," Mr. Granger said in an interview. "I'm not going to run anthrax covers, because three weeks from now, who knows, it may be smallpox." Instead, he said, "our role is to do a great magazine." For him, that means dispensing with what he calls "curiosities -- like, 'Oh, well, that's interesting.' "
He cited articles that had been planned about a ventriloquists' convention and about a psychology guru who coaches men "how to be less nice,' which are now in limbo. "Stories need to seem necessary," he said. 
The same holds true for Mr. Granger's primary competitor, Advance Publications' GQ. After Sept. 11, the editor in chief, Art Cooper, canceled articles on feral surfing in Indonesia and the last of the Nazi hunters.
"It just seemed like octagenarian Nazis are not much of a threat any more," Mr. Cooper said. Most readers do not understand publishing schedules, he said, noting that he had been misguidedly complimented by many people for publishing a divertingly off-topic sports issue in October, which came out on Sept. 18.
Meanwhile, he said, he was "going crazy" because the magazine had nothing about Sept. 11.
In November, Mr. Cooper compensated with a 14-page package, including an article by Jeff Greenfield, the CNN commentator, and an interview (conducted in 1996 and 1997) by Robert Fisk with Osama Bin Laden, but he did not alter the annual Men of the Year cover. In the December issue, with Will Smith on the cover, the magazine will begin a monthly column called "The Shadow War" by a former F.B.I. special agent, Christopher Whitcomb. In addition, it will have a previously planned article on a plot to blow up Los Angeles International Airport, and a humor article by Joe Queenan on unemployment among ironists. Mr. Cooper said he planned to devote two of each month's six main articles to the new world order for the foreseeable future.
The women's magazines also feel a need to relate current events to readers' lives. At More, a publication of the Meredith Corporation, the editor in chief, Myrna Blyth, commissioned an interview with a Bush adviser, Karen Hughes, and replaced a Christmas story called "50 Glittering Gifts" with one called "50 Ways to Give Back."
"We're certainly going to keep writing about this event," Ms. Blyth said, "but it's hard to give specific information three months later that hasn't been in the newspaper."
In Esquire's December issue, Mr. Granger will have a long-planned article by Mike Sager about a marine, which was written as the life of a professional soldier in peacetime. After Sept. 11, the marine was sent off to battle, and Mr. Sager updated the article, transforming it, in Mr. Granger's words, from "kind of a nice profile to a great look at an American figure, the kind of person who is going to wage war for us."
The issue also contains a recently commissioned article by Charles Pierce called "162 Reasons It's Good to Be an American Man." The reasons include Hawaiian Punch, the mirror scene in Duck Soup and skyscrapers. "Before Sept. 11, I might not have run it. It would have seemed hokey," Mr. Granger said. "But given what we lost, the things we have seem more precious." 
But the issue also contains the magazine's annual survey of the best new American restaurants, and a cover article in which the stars of "Ocean's 11," Julia Roberts and George Clooney, interview each other. 
"An equally important part of my mission is to entertain and delight," Mr. Granger said. "When somebody puts the magazine down, they should be looking forward to the next issue."
The January issue has short interviews with notable men, called "The Meaning of Life: Good Advice for Challenging Times." Among the subjects are one of the inventors of the hydrogen bomb, Edward Teller, and a man who climbed up from under the World Trade Center on Sept. 11.
The February cover story, Mr. Granger says, will profile "two of the most important people in our war effort. But at most, I'm going to have opportunities like that once a month, and I've got 100 pages to fill."

HEADLINE: London Journal; 
Recipe for Roasting the Sacred Cow, Tastelessly

BYLINE:  By SARAH LYALL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 11 

 BODY:
In its first post-Sept. 11 issue, the satirical magazine Private Eye included a clip-out cancellation form for infuriated readers. This was a wise move.
 For starters, the cover that week showed the now-famous photograph of President Bush learning about the World Trade Center attack. Under the headline "Bush Takes Charge," the president and his aide were having a little annotated exchange, sotto voce. 
 Aide: "It's Armageddon, sir."
Bush: "Armageddon outahere!"
Hundreds of cancellations duly ensued, along with the by-now-familiar complement of outraged letters, one of which denounced Private Eye as a "silly, misinformed, poisonous little rag." Be that as it may, such outrage does not remotely discomfit Private Eye's unapologetic editor, Ian Hislop, who feels that at times of unified national piety, Britain needs his magazine's brand of irreverence more than ever. 
Private Eye turned 40 this fall, and it is fitting that, once again, it is embroiled in a furor about the limits of taste in times of tragedy. It has been here before.
In 1991, when the unscrupulous media magnate Robert Maxwell drowned, the magazine devoted its cover to his funeral, with the headline "Here lies Robert Maxwell." Down below, it wrote: "He lied everywhere else."
Six years later, when the death of Diana, the Princess of Wales, provoked a spontaneous effusion of rage at the news media -- even as Britons bought more newspapers than ever -- the cover showed a photograph of grieving crowds descending on Buckingham Palace.
"The papers are a disgrace," one mourner was saying.
"Yes, I couldn't get one anywhere," answered another. 
In many respects, the magazine has changed little in the last four decades. It still resembles a college gossip sheet. It still defines its mission as taking on the powerful and the influential, the famous and the puffed-up, and it still seeks to wrestle to the ground things it finds hypocritical, ridiculous and sycophantic, particularly in the government and the news media.
At a time when Prime Minister Tony Blair's Labor government has virtually neutered its political opposition, Private Eye often has an important, if mischievous and sometimes borderline, role in taking on Mr. Blair.
"I'm all for bad taste if you can justify its making a point," said Mr. Hislop cheerfully. "Merely saying, 'Guess what, some people have died,' is not funny. But jokes arising, for instance, from the lunacy of what's happened since Sept. 11, are."
Britain has had publications of this sort for a long time. "Private Eye is in a long English tradition of satirical journalism," Mr. Hislop said. "The 18th-century journals exposed vice, folly and humbug, and we're in that tradition, to tell the truth smilingly, to question the official view. It's fantastically useful in democracies to have someone saying No."
It often works, said Roy Greenslade, who writes a column about the news media for the liberal-leaning Guardian.
"I always think of it as the court jester, and the great thing the court jester was able to do was to dress up serious things in such an amusing fashion that the king laughed rather than cried," Mr. Greenslade said. "But the king also received messages from the jester that no one else dared tell him." Private Eye's humor is very English and very public school, meaning that it is full of puns, unkind nicknames and relentless parody, and it can veer dizzyingly between the funny and the puerile. The magazine, put out every other week in a cramped Soho office by a ragtag group of staff members and hangers-on, is an equal-opportunity criticizer, carpet-bombing the British establishment and sometimes causing collateral damage.
Its targets range from Mr. Blair, who has been recast as a more-pious-than-thou vicar, to the London police force, whose officers last year shot and killed several unarmed people. Other targets are media figures like Piers Morgan, the editor of The Daily Mirror, a scrappy tabloid. Even Mr. Greenslade, the media commentator, has a Private Eye nickname, Roy Greenslime. 
Mr. Morgan declined to comment about Private Eye's tendency to call him Piers Moron. 
Along the way, the magazine sends up newspapers' habit of printing space-filling features -- unlike this one -- about practically nothing; the tendency of important novelists to think very highly of their own glaringly obvious opinions; the tendency of doctors to make mistakes and then try to cover them up; and the tendency of public officials to say stupid things. 
The Eye's regular news columns, written anonymously by aggrieved whistle-blowers in medicine, farming, business and the like, occasionally break new ground. The magazine was the first to print allegations about what became a full-fledged malpractice scandal in the pediatric cardiac department at a hospital in Bristol. 
Printed on cheap paper and with production standards it keeps low because of the $360,000 a year it spends to defend itself against frequent libel suits, the magazine manages to sell a healthy 180,000 copies or so an issue. But it is no Economist, caring particularly for accuracy. Its biggest fault, perhaps, is its reliance on that legendary British journalistic staple: the fact too good to check. 
While acknowledging that the Eye is not as strict as it might be -- "The American system, where you have fact checkers ringing up and saying, 'Is Paris really in France?' is completely alien to us," Mr. Hislop said -- the editor added that when it counts, the magazine gets it right.
"If you put the boot into someone and they were innocent and we were wrong, then I do feel bad, rightly," he said. "But I never regret going after the big guys."

HEADLINE: Bush and Putin Expected to Agree to Reduce Nuclear Arsenals and to Fight Terrorism 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

 BODY:
President Bush will hold a summit meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia this week and will try to close a number of agreements that could profoundly change the post-cold-war trajectory of relations between Washington and Moscow.
 Meeting against a backdrop of war in Afghanistan and the national mobilization against terror at home, the two leaders are expected to announce deep reductions in the offensive nuclear arsenals that have stood -- needlessly in the view of much of the world -- like overhanging threats from the era of superpower competition. 
 The two men are also poised to establish a strong bond of cooperation -- perhaps an alliance of sorts -- in the struggle to quell the Islamic violence that has been welling up in Central Asia. The movements there directly threaten Russia's security and that of former Soviet republics that are striving -- many with American investment -- to tap one of the last great reservoirs of oil and natural gas on the planet. 
Mr. Putin has also telegraphed that he is ready to reach an accord that will allow the United States to proceed with rigorous testing of antiballistic missile systems as long as Mr. Bush will agree to preserve the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, which Russia sees as the cornerstone of strategic stability.
To critics who say that Russia has nothing to offer the United States, Mr. Putin has broadcast in a number of pre-summit-meeting interviews that Russia, the world's second-largest oil producer, stands ready to ensure the West's energy security in the event of war or disruption in the Middle East and the Persian Gulf.
A number of American leaders have been impressed. 
"Russia has a tremendous capacity of being an alternate energy source for the United States," Senator Bob Graham, the Florida Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said last week.
Russia's churlish intelligence services have -- under orders from the Kremlin -- unloaded into American hands an inestimable amount of information about the networks that radiate out from Osama bin Laden's Al Qaeda network into the Middle East and Asia. 
"This is a very different relationship now," said Condoleezza Rice, the president's national security adviser, in briefing reporters last week. "This is a different relationship than the one that Leonid Brezhnev and Richard Nixon had, or even that George Herbert Walker Bush and Gorbachev had," she said. "It is a relationship that got new impetus to shared cooperative security issues concerning Sept. 11 and counterterrorism," she added, and one that will be based on growing economic ties and an expanded role for Russia in the West's security. 
"I believe you will start to see the United States and NATO talk to Russia about how NATO and Russia can better relate," she said.
In Moscow, Kremlin officials told reporters this past weekend to expect as many as seven statements to emerge from the three-day meeting, which will begin in Washington tomorrow and carry over to Mr. Bush's Crawford, Tex., ranch on Wednesday and Thursday. The statements are likely to include one on the future of Afghanistan, an accord on joint efforts in counterterrorism, an agreement on missile defenses and reducing offensive weapons and an elaboration on Russia's role with NATO. 
In addition, administration officials in Washington said they were pushing for a "significant proliferation element" in any new strategic framework sealed with Russia, an apparent reference to its continuing sales to Iran of weapons and civilian nuclear reactor technology that the United States fears will assist Iran's quest to develop nuclear weapons.
Bush administration officials have sought to tamp down expectations that the meeting will produce significant results. But it has been increasingly apparent since Sept. 11 that both leaders view the attacks on the United States as a galvanizing event to overcome resistance to a new Russian-American partnership, broader even than the one forged by President Clinton and Boris N. Yeltsin.
It was not so long ago that Mr. Bush himself was a factor in resisting Russia and Mr. Putin. The Bush administration came to office espousing the view that Russia did not account for much as a world power anymore. 
There is little agreement on what changed the course of Mr. Bush's thinking last spring. Some specialists have speculated that the confrontation with China over the collision of an American spy plane was a signal event that persuaded Mr. Bush and his advisers that their indifference to working collectively in foreign affairs was both alarming allies and driving other powers like China and Russia together. 
Mr. Bush sought to overcome these apprehensions with a European tour in June. In his first meeting with Mr. Putin, in Slovenia, Mr. Bush said that he had found in Mr. Putin a partner he could trust, a step that was essential if only to quiet the apprehension Mr. Bush had incited among European leaders about America going it alone on missile defense. Of Mr. Putin, Mr. Bush said, "I am convinced that he and I can build a relationship of mutual respect and candor." 
The sweep of events after Sept. 11 continues to impel the two leaders toward one another, notwithstanding the deep reservations many Americans harbor over Mr. Putin's background as a K.G.B. officer, whose political rise were orchestrated by Mr. Yeltsin and built on a brutal military campaign in Chechnya. 
In Shanghai last month, Mr. Bush, with some emotion, noted that his first call from a world leader after the Sept. 11 attacks came from Mr. Putin. Since then, the distance between the two leaders' positions on a host of issues had closed rapidly.
To some experts, Mr. Bush has traveled the greater distance toward Mr. Putin's view of a collaborative new security structure in the world. It was Mr. Putin who, earlier this year, spoke forcefully in an interview with American correspondents in Moscow about the need for Russia and the United States to confront the threat of the Taliban regime in Afghanistan. 
"I feel that I personally am to blame for what happened," Mr. Putin said in the wake of the attacks. "Yes, I talked a great deal about that threat, but I guess it wasn't enough."
Mr. Putin's goal has been "to shift the United States away from the illusion that it is leading a unipolar world," said Clifford G. Gaddy of the Brookings Institution in Washington during a forum last week. "I stress the word illusion because Putin and other Russians never thought that this was objectively possible," he added.
There are still many prominent skeptics, like Zbigniew Brzezinski, the national security adviser under President Jimmy Carter, who argue that it is premature to conclude that Russia has made a historic choice in favor of the West, but rather may simply be maneuvering cleverly to lay the most advantageous foundation for a long-term rebuilding of Russian national power.
"I would say that joining the West is exactly what Putin is not about," Mr. Gaddy said. "What Putin is about is, with respect to the U.S., is that he is absolutely convinced that the U.S. must not be allowed to continue to go it alone."

HEADLINE: For the New Mayor, a City's Advice on Challenges That Must Be Faced; 
Saving Public Schools

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
Memo to: Michael R. Bloomberg.
 Re: Advice from experts, academics, union leaders, politicians and ordinary New Yorkers on coping with business, transportation, housing, education, race relations and municipal labor unions. 
 Effective: Jan. 1, 2002.
Institute tax-free days on some retail goods. Begin charging tolls on East River bridges. Build housing on industrial sites. End political fighting over schools and think of the one million pupils as your children. Make your administration racially and ethnically diverse and its spending policies fair. Keep a lid on city labor costs, but don't lose teachers or police officers to the suburbs. Hold down the deficits, but preserve those city services. 
These are just a few ideas to get you started. Good luck!
As the city's economic health worsens, it is important to remember an undisputed lesson of the 70's fiscal crisis: as crime and schools go, so goes the city.
"I think everybody feels kind of depressed because everybody's kind of worried," said Sylvia Wertheimer, the mother of a seventh grader in Chelsea. "I know of several people who have moved out of the city partly because they lived close to downtown, but also because if you think your kids can't get a good education, it could be another tipping factor."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's attitude toward city schools, at least before Sept. 11, was often confrontational, even obstructionist. Many people hope Mr. Bloomberg's tone will be different. "I would not like to see the situation of the mayor continuing his role of sort of strong-arming the school system," said Bertha Lewis, an organizer for Acorn, a neighborhood advocacy group in Brooklyn. 
The mayor-elect has said he wants to put city schools under mayoral control, and Assembly Democrats have said they are willing to talk about it in a civil manner. "I don't begrudge anyone that there ought to be some form of major change in the administrative structure of education," said Assemblyman Steven Sanders, chairman of the education committee. "But a cooperative venture between City Hall and public education is desperately needed."
In the mayoral election, black, Hispanic and white voters were split. So were reading and math scores in the public schools. Everyone agrees that this needs to be fixed. "Here's what a Republican would look at," said Diane Ravitch, the education historian. "Not, are the employees happy, but are the customers satisfied -- and the customers are the children. There are a million-plus children, and I think it's an immensely important leap to say, what if every child were the mayor's child?"
Chancellor Harold O. Levy's contract expires July 1, and the Board of Education must decide before then whether to extend it. "There are many good people out there who could do this job," Randi Weingarten, president of the teachers' union, said about the chancellor's job. "My advice would be to make those decisions quickly, depoliticize the situation."
There is more important work to be done, like teaching grammar and algebra and creating safe, competent high schools for average students, parents said. "We need more emphasis on basic instruction," Ms. Wertheimer said. "Our kids need it. I think probably a lot of teachers would agree. That's not a money thing, that's a frustration. For some reason that message doesn't seem to get through. There's some kind of invisible barrier. I don't know what it is." ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

HEADLINE: For the New Mayor, a City's Advice on Challenges That Must Be Faced; 
Halting Business Flight

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Memo to: Michael R. Bloomberg.
 Re: Advice from experts, academics, union leaders, politicians and ordinary New Yorkers on coping with business, transportation, housing, education, race relations and municipal labor unions. 
 Effective: Jan. 1, 2002.
Institute tax-free days on some retail goods. Begin charging tolls on East River bridges. Build housing on industrial sites. End political fighting over schools and think of the one million pupils as your children. Make your administration racially and ethnically diverse and its spending policies fair. Keep a lid on city labor costs, but don't lose teachers or police officers to the suburbs. Hold down the deficits, but preserve those city services. 
These are just a few ideas to get you started. Good luck!
Dozens of businesses, employing thousands of workers, could not help but leave Manhattan after Sept. 11. If their offices were not reduced to dust, they were shrouded in it, caught in the zone around ground zero where debris and rescue equipment dominated the landscape. Weeks later, most of them have not returned, preferring to wait out the continuing economic aftershocks in temporary space elsewhere.
To lure those businesses back, and to keep others from fleeing, will require a tactical and a strategic response, said Arthur Levitt, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission and, before that, the chairman of the city's Economic Development Corporation.
In the short term, Mr. Levitt recommends creative promotional incentives to restore business activity in Lower Manhattan, like tax-free days for certain kinds of retail goods, and other incentives to attract companies to the area. Keeping companies downtown will require Mr. Bloomberg to address issues like transportation. A light-rail project or regionally sponsored ferry service that offers access from more distant points should be considered, Mr. Levitt said. And using devices like special economic zones to attract construction will be critical.
In either the short or long term, he said, "One thing I would not do would be to use the remedy that is most often used and which I used myself: pure tax subsidies to keep companies and to induce companies to come down there."
The most important long-term strategy, he maintained, is to avoid bidding against other other states or cities to recruit or keep businesses. "You can't do that without getting the cooperation of other regional long-term planners," Mr. Levitt said. "Companies will simply delight in playing you off one another."
As important as large corporations are to any plan to keep businesses from fleeing the downtown area, small businesses also have to have an attractive environment in which to work, said Fred P. Hochberg, a former administrator of the Small Business Administration. For them, he said, physical amenities are not as important as financial ones. 
For example, he said, the city could promote legislation or actually put up the money to guarantee up to 90 percent of the amount of a small-business loan, 15 percent more than the maximum 75 percent guarantee already provided by the federal government. This could encourage banks to lend to businesses that they might otherwise reject.
Also, Mr. Hochberg said, Mr. Bloomberg should encourage federal agencies to spend more of their $200 billion annual budget for goods in New York City. Currently, 40 other states get more of those federal dollars than does New York State. "I think the key thing is that New York should not be asked to go it alone," he said. EDWARD WYATT

GRAPHIC: Photo: BUSINESS -- Luring businesses back to the area around ground zero will be a challenge. (Nancy Siesel/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For the New Mayor, a City's Advice on Challenges That Must Be Faced; 
Healing Ethnic Rifts

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
Memo to: Michael R. Bloomberg.
Re: Advice from experts, academics, union leaders, politicians and ordinary New Yorkers on coping with business, transportation, housing, education, race relations and municipal labor unions.
 Effective: Jan. 1, 2002. 
 Institute tax-free days on some retail goods. Begin charging tolls on East River bridges. Build housing on industrial sites. End political fighting over schools and think of the one million pupils as your children. Make your administration racially and ethnically diverse and its spending policies fair. Keep a lid on city labor costs, but don't lose teachers or police officers to the suburbs. Hold down the deficits, but preserve those city services. 
These are just a few ideas to get you started. Good luck!
After one of the city's most fractious elections, Mr. Bloomberg, a novice politician, is faced with the daunting challenge of healing ethnic rifts and addressing minority concerns against the backdrop of a looming fiscal crisis.
Oddly, that task has been inadvertently eased by Mayor Giuliani, whose policies, many of them unpopular with blacks and Latinos, Mr. Bloomberg promised to build upon. As the Rev. Al Sharpton, one of the current mayor's most outspoken critics, said of Mr. Bloomberg: "Coming behind someone that is perceived to be as hostile as Giuliani, he almost can't help but do better. The question is, how much better?"
Already, officials and advocates said, Mr. Bloomberg has made all the right moves: an early breakfast with Fernando Ferrer, a picture-perfect handshake with Mr. Sharpton at a gala reception for the group 100 Black Men, and festive meetings with representatives of organized labor.
But his honeymoon may not last long. Mr. Bloomberg's first task is making appointments, and several officials and consultants said that he must make the administration reflect the ethnic diversity of the city it serves. Bill Lynch, the vice chairman of the Democratic National Committee, a senior adviser to Mr. Ferrer's campaign, said that this is important because members of minority communities feel that they have been shut out of government under the Giuliani administration.
Others said that an integrated cabinet would make unpopular decisions easier to swallow for minorities. "When they see people that look like them," said Luis Miranda, a political consultant, "it's not some foreign power that's making these decisions."
Across City Hall from the mayor's office, Mr. Bloomberg will find a remade City Council, including a new generation of younger, more aggressive and more activist-oriented members. Bill Perkins, a council member from Harlem, said that because blacks and Latinos (and one Asian) will compose nearly half the body, the new mayor would be wise to forge a relationship with them. "We are the voices of our communities, the leaders of our communities that are here, in the city, every day, not in Albany, not in Washington," he said. 
But beyond appointments and relationships, several consultants and officials said, the new mayor should also put the city's money where his mouth is.
"The proof is always in the pudding, said Adolfo Carrion, the incoming Bronx borough president. "The way you mean what you say is how you spend the resources that you have."
In other words, the officials and advocates will be watching the mayor's first spending plan in January to make sure that the economic belt tightens evenly across the belly of the city, and that education and social service programs considered crucial in minority communities are not automatically cut. They will also be watching, they said, to make sure Mr. Bloomberg tackles their ongoing concerns about police-community relations and includes them in the rebuilding effort from Sept. 11.
"Political people have to see themselves in the planning, and business people have to see themselves in the rebuilding," Mr. Lynch said. "They can't be left out or we'll have the same divisions as we had over the last eight years." DIANE CARDWELL

HEADLINE: For the New Mayor, a City's Advice on Challenges That Must Be Faced; 
Easing the Housing Crunch

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. MCFADDEN 

 BODY:
Memo to: Michael R. Bloomberg.
Re: Advice from experts, academics, union leaders, politicians and ordinary New Yorkers on coping with business, transportation, housing, education, race relations and municipal labor unions.
 Effective: Jan. 1, 2002. 
 Institute tax-free days on some retail goods. Begin charging tolls on East River bridges. Build housing on industrial sites. End political fighting over schools and think of the one million pupils as your children. Make your administration racially and ethnically diverse and its spending policies fair. Keep a lid on city labor costs, but don't lose teachers or police officers to the suburbs. Hold down the deficits, but preserve those city services. 
These are just a few ideas to get you started. Good luck!
If there is one thing that government officials, community leaders, academic experts and ordinary residents agree on with virtual unanimity, it is that New York City is in the grip of its worst housing crisis in years. Of course, New Yorkers have said that for generations, with justification.
The litany never seems to change. Rents are staggeringly high. Vacancy rates are minuscule. Overcrowding abounds. Construction and rehabilitation of housing are thwarted by high costs and a maze of city regulations. And the city is short of money for subsidies, especially since Sept. 11.
Mr. Bloomberg, in his campaign, offered no detailed housing plan, but said he philosophically opposed new subsidies and would try to encourage private development by uncluttering city regulations and searching for building sites in waterfront areas and former industrial brownfields.
Mayor Giuliani had a new plan last January calling for for $600 million in city financing and an equal amount from the private sector to build or renovate 10,000 housing units over the next four years. (Some experts have said the city needs 30,000 units a year to keep up.) Mr. Giuliani also spoke of the great dream: reforming the bureaucracy and cutting construction costs.
Many of his ideas were based on a book of which Michael H. Schill, a housing expert and professor of law and urban planning at New York University, was a co-author. Asked the other day what he might advise Mr. Giuliani's successor, Professor Schill bubbled with ideas.
Mr. Bloomberg's top priorities, he said, should be changes to make the city a partner rather than an impediment to housing construction, an all-out effort to rehabilitate existing housing, and targeted subsidies for low- and moderate-income housing.
To cut building costs and streamline city bureaucratic processes, Professor Schill urged Mr. Bloomberg to order a sweeping review of zoning regulations to identify land that could be shifted from manufacturing to housing; to direct city agencies to expedite permits and other costly, time-consuming paperwork, and to modernize a complex 1961 building code that bars many cost-saving materials and practices that are standard elsewhere.
"Some agencies, like the Buildings Department, need a complete overhaul," Professor Schill said. "This should be catnip for someone like Bloomberg. He's a manager. The Buildings Department is years out of date, not fully automated with computers and new technology. A lot of it is paper records. It's operating back in the 1950's and 60's, not 2001. Bloomberg can make enormous strides."
Professor Schill urged the next mayor to expand a Giuliani program that has turned tax-delinquent housing over to new owners who pledge to rehabilitate it with the help of subsidies. He noted that the city faced big deficits and that housing money may be hard to find, but said that available subsidies should be used for low- and moderate-income housing.
"Even though housing subsidies are limited, they should be targeted to people who need it most," he said. "It's ludicrous, its scandalous, that even middle-class people can't be adequately housed through the market." ROBERT D. McFADDEN

HEADLINE: EXAMINING THE VOTE: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
Who Won Florida? The Answer Emerges, but Surely Not the Final Word

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 

 BODY:
The comprehensive review of the uncounted Florida ballots solidifies George W. Bush's legal claim on the White House because it concludes that he would have won under the ground rules prescribed by the Democrats.
 But the analysis does not diminish the heartbreaking might-have-beens for Al Gore. It suggests that more Floridians intended to vote for Mr. Gore but were deterred, in some cases by ballots that were confounding even to elderly voters who are accustomed to having five bingo cards going at once. (No wonder networks reported on election night that, based on polls of voters leaving the polls, Mr. Gore had won Florida.) 
 The reality, therefore, is that Mr. Bush's victory in the most fouled-up, disputed and wrenching presidential election in American history was so breathtakingly narrow that there is no way of knowing with absolute precision who got the most votes. After all, there is no perfect way to decide which disputed ballots should be counted and rejected. 
And there never will be.
"You had the perfect tie," said Walter Dean Burnham, a professor of government at the University of Texas at Austin, making a statistical point that many scholars have fastened on to. "When you've got an election this close, the most sensible way to determine the outcome is to flip a coin."
Had the analysis concluded that under every conceivable circumstance, Mr. Gore would have triumphed under a statewide recount, or that there had been fraud or other mischief, the Democrats would have had reason to speak out today. But it found that even if the Supreme Court had not stepped in to block a statewide manual recount, Mr. Bush would have won.
Absent an unambiguous outcome, a debate could fester for decades around kitchen tables of partisan Americans: Did the right guy capture the prize?
Diehard Bush supporters will always declare themselves the deserved winners. Just as passionately, diehard Gore supporters, the ones who cried at Mr. Bush's inaugural, will always believe they were robbed. There will also be the conspiracy theorists, the same people who thought publication of this analysis was delayed because of a plot by newspapers to keep secret that Mr. Gore would have won. (The reality is that it took months to count, tabulate and analyze the results, which were further delayed by the events since Sept. 11.)
And of course, there may never be closure for Mr. Gore himself -- unless he ultimately becomes president. In recent weeks he has been ambling alone around Iowa and New Hampshire in a rental car, knowing that were it not for a twist of fate -- or a faulty voting machine here and there -- he might be commanding a nation at war.
But for all the drama of those 36 days last fall, most of the country moved on long ago. In history, the two anchors of the American political process are whether an election is regarded as final and whether there was an orderly transition of power. Mr. Gore, in fact, did his best to encourage that stability last December when he implored the nation "to unite behind our next president."
Today, in a statement, Mr. Gore recalled that concession, saying, "As I said on Dec. 13 of last year, we are a nation of laws and the presidential election of 2000 is over."
That message has taken hold well beyond the capital. "People quickly accommodated themselves to the notion that it's over," said Richard G. Niemi, a political scientist at the University of Rochester who specializes in voting. "What are we to do? Cut short Bush's term?"
Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, was more mesmerized by football this evening than the consortium's findings. "This inconclusive number crunching doesn't change anything," he said. "Anybody who invests time and money in this is wasting their time and money. The president is paying no attention to this -- and neither is the country."
While the recriminations over last Nov. 7 were fading anyway, the attacks on Sept. 11 drowned them out even more. Many partisan Democrats are loath to question the legitimacy of a president in wartime. Even if they wanted to, how do you challenge a president who is basking in job approval ratings of close to 90 percent?
William J. Daley, Mr. Gore's campaign chairman, said he, for one, never dwells on the election. "Anybody who speculates on such stuff at this point is wasting air, especially in the middle of what's going on," he said. "Do people care anymore? I don't think they do."
With their fiery cries of injustice, Democrats had hoped to seize on the muddled outcome to, at the very least, rev up partisans for the 2002 midterm elections, particularly blacks who said they had been disenfranchised from voting. When he was elected Democratic Party chairman last February, Terence McAuliffe, vowed, "We will transform the anger about Florida into energy about politics."
Today, Mr. McAuliffe was far more tame, mindful that he not inflame an electorate that may be struggling with matters of war. "I am determined to turn the voters' disappointment into action," he said. But Mr. McAuliffe's only mention of Mr. Bush was that Democrats stand united with him against terrorism.
The lack of a crisper verdict in his favor means that it could be more difficult for Mr. Gore to again seek the presidency in 2004 on the argument that he was unjustly denied the White House.
Many of his supporters from last year say he has forfeited an opportunity to establish himself as the Democratic president-in-waiting by refusing to speak out critically about Mr. Bush. After all, they say, Mr. Gore won the popular vote.
But Mr. Gore, presumably not wanting to appear to be a sore loser, chose not to go the route of President Grover Cleveland, who in 1888 won the popular vote but lost the Electoral College -- and the White House -- to Benjamin Harrison. Mr. Cleveland never let the public forget that he thought he should be president. Four years later, he defeated Mr. Harrison, a Republican.
Mr. Gore's reticence prompted a onetime supporter, Representative Maxine Waters, a California Democrat, to say late this summer, "I don't think Al Gore acts like a man who wants to be president of the United States."
By the time Mr. Gore had decided to question Mr. Bush's policies, it was too late: the terrorists had struck.
The legacy of the troubled election may be tighter voting procedures, but only if the government is willing to spend the money on them.
More important, the ultimate verdict on the 2000 election will be the election of 2004. If Mr. Bush is re-elected, that would go far to quash lingering talk of illegitimacy. But if Mr. Gore runs again, and the economy is in peril, that could give the former vice president an opening to cast the election of 2000 through the prism of what people's lives are like at the time.
If Americans are hurting financially in 2004, Mr. Gore could say he was cheated out of the presidency -- and that the people were cheated too.

HEADLINE: Under Bloomberg, Kelly Will Guide Police Again 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Raymond W. Kelly, who was New York City's 37th police commissioner, under Mayor David N. Dinkins, has accepted Mayor-elect Michael R. Bloomberg's offer to return to 1 Police Plaza as the city's 41st police commissioner, two people familiar with the transition plan said yesterday.
 The announcement could be made as early as today, they said. 
 When Mr. Kelly led the Police Department during the last 17 months of the Dinkins administration, the crime rate began to fall. He became familiar to many New Yorkers as a reassuring presence on television after the World Trade Center bombing in February 1993. 
In returning to a city left shaken and apprehensive by the recent destruction of the twin towers, Mr. Kelly will become the first man in the history of New York to serve as police commissioner in two nonconsecutive administrations.
Mr. Bloomberg declined to confirm the appointment, which was first reported in Newsday yesterday. "Well, I did read that in the papers yesterday," he said in an interview on NBC-TV's "Meet the Press." "Stay tuned. He's a great guy."
In the interview, the mayor-elect went on to show a great familiarity with Mr. Kelly's resume, praising the work he did after leaving the Police Department, as the head of an international police force in Haiti and then as the commissioner of the United States Customs Service.
In an interview last week, Mr. Kelly, who served as a campaign adviser to Mr. Bloomberg on law enforcement issues, laid out some principles that he said would guide the Police Department under a Bloomberg administration. He spoke of building on the crime-fighting successes of the Giuliani years while working to improve police-community relations.
Since leaving the Police Department, Mr. Kelly headed an international police force sent to help reform the Haitian police; was appointed an under secretary at the Treasury Department, overseeing its law enforcement agencies; and became the commissioner of the Customs Service. There he was credited with finding more efficient ways to intercept contraband without racial profiling. Most recently he has been the global head of corporate security for Bear Stearns.
By appointing a police commissioner, Mr. Bloomberg would fill a visible and politically important post. 
Until the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 reshaped his legacy, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani made crime-fighting the hallmark of his administration. The Compstat program begun under his watch -- in which police commanders use up-to-date computer statistics to map out crime trends -- has been widely credited with helping the police drive crime down to levels not seen since the 1960's. 
Crime and the selection of the next police commissioner became major issues in the recent mayoral campaign, as Mr. Bloomberg and his Democratic rival, Mark Green, sought to reassure voters that neither would roll back the successes of the last eight years.
Both candidates telegraphed their would-be choices to run the department. Mr. Green campaigned frequently at the side of Mr. Giuliani's first police commissioner, William J. Bratton. Mr. Bloomberg talked of trying to retain the current police commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik, but he also campaigned with Mr. Kelly.
An advertisement for Mr. Bloomberg that was mailed to voters during the last week of the campaign stated: "When Mark Green served in the Dinkins administration, in 1993 alone there were nearly 2,000 murders -- 6 per day." Now Mr. Bloomberg has tapped the man who was Mr. Dinkins's police commissioner at that time.
Mr. Kelly, a former marine, graduated first in his class in the Police Academy, then served in 25 different commands during the next 31 years. 
As police commissioner under Mayor Dinkins, he took over a department that had just faced some of the deadliest years in city history, as the lethal combination of a crack epidemic, a recession and easily available guns drove the murder rate above 2,000 a year. 
Mr. Kelly carried out the Safe Streets, Safe City program, which helped increase the number of police officers to 28,500 from 25,465 during his tenure. The force now stands at nearly 40,000, driven up by more hiring and a merger with the old Transit Police Department. Mr. Kelly championed community policing, in which beat officers were encouraged to get to know their neighborhoods and help solve their problems as well as arrest their criminals. 
Murders and overall crime began to fall under his watch, but when Mr. Giuliani defeated Mr. Dinkins and took office in 1994, he looked to Boston for his own commissioner, appointing Mr. Bratton, who was that city's police commissioner. Giuliani administration officials let it be known right away that they disapproved of community policing, disparaging it as "glorified social work," and Mr. Kelly let it be known that he was not happy about their attempt to tarnish his legacy.
Mr. Kelly's supporters have long lamented that he was never given much credit for beginning to turn the tide against crime. Now he is about to receive a rare second chance to try to prove himself. 
One person familiar with the transition plan, who spoke only on the condition that he not be identified, said that Mr. Kelly, 60, accepted the job on Friday, and that the official announcement would be made today. Campaign officials would not confirm that.
As he prepared to march in the city's Veterans Day Parade yesterday, Mr. Bloomberg was mum about his plans for the Police Department. 
"Today we're here to celebrate our current police commissioner, Mr. Kerik, who's been a great commissioner," he said. "I think it's important to remember that during the entire Giuliani administration, crime kept coming down, and every time it gets to a low, you say you can't make it any better, and Bernie showed that that's not true; there's always room for improvement."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Raymond W. Kelly was commissioner when crime began to fall. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)(pg. F2)

HEADLINE: LVMH Sales Dropped 5% In October 

BYLINE:  By K ERRY SHAW 

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 12 

 BODY:
In its third warning of deteriorating results since the Sept. 11 terror attacks, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton said today that its sales in October fell 5 percent from the period last year and that its operating profits for the full year might be 15 percent lower than forecast.
 The company, which manufactures and markets a wide range of luxury goods under well-known brands like Louis Vuitton leather goods, Kenzo clothing and Dior perfumes, said that the trouble stemmed from the deep slump in a crucial market segment: tourists. 
 "People stopped traveling," said Olivier Labesse, a spokesman for the company. "When people travel, they love to buy a bag or a watch." 
The company said the outlook in North America remained bleak but signs of improvement were "gradually appearing in some European countries, in Asia and in Japan."
LVMH has more than 600 retail outlets specifically aimed at tourists, including 292 in the United States, 26 of them in New York City. Duty-free stores at airports around the world are also an important sales channel.
"Our strategy is the same as it has been in times of crisis, for example, during the gulf war in 1991 and during the Asian financial crisis," Mr. Labesse said. "We're going to maintain advertising for main brands, keep developing new stores and reduce costs. We can win market shares during the crisis -- we can be poised to be the leader when the market rebounds. We just don't know when that will be."
After the profit warning, shares of LVMH fell 3.1 percent today, closing at 40.78 euros in Paris.
Rival luxury goods makers are also hurting; Prada Holding and the Gucci Group have reported slow sales, and Escada said today that it would post a loss for the year.
There is one step LVMH has said it will take to try to reduce its costs: cutting back on travel.
