HEADLINE: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 587: THE VICTIMS; 
Grief Echoes From New York to Santo Domingo

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARSTOW and MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Several times a day, the flights depart from Kennedy Airport, providing a crucial link between the Dominican Republic and New York City's Dominican neighborhoods. The first flight out, American Airlines Flight 587 to Santo Domingo, is so familiar that some Dominicans talk about it as if it were the morning train. With holidays approaching, Flight 587 was packed.
 Tito Baustita, 37, who worked in a factory by day and a bodega by night, was heading home to visit two sons. Angela de la Cruz, 38, who made the trip every few months, was returning with her father to sell a house. Ivelisse Taveras, 42, a Washington Heights hairdresser, left her two children with relatives to visit her husband. Felix Sanchez, a Merrill Lynch employee who worked in the World Trade Center but was lucky on Sept. 11, was on his way to visit family in Santo Domingo. 
 But at 9:17 a.m., the link home was severed in horrifying fashion. Dominicans in two distant cities, joined by culture, family and commerce, suddenly had grief to share, too. 
In Santo Domingo, hundreds packed the Las Americas International Airport, normally the setting for joyful reunions. Some relatives collapsed, hands shaking uncontrollably. Others wept, inconsolable.
In Washington Heights in Upper Manhattan, the hub of Dominican culture in New York, residents shared their grief on street corners and at lunch counters. In some places they set up sidewalk memorials, lighting candles and laying bouquets. At a social service agency on Amsterdam Avenue near 180th Street, Carlos Lora, 33, said he only wanted to find the body of his 3-year-old son, Karl Steven Lora, who, with his grandmother, had been on Flight 587.
"I just want to be able to bury him," Mr. Lora said.
Officials said that 260 people were on Flight 587, and by some early estimates 150 to 175 of the passengers were thought to be Dominicans. "Dominicans who live in New York do not in any way sever their ties with the Dominican Republic," said Kirk Bullington, a Baptist missionary there to console families. "They are as much part of Dominican life as if they lived here."
Luis Eludis Perez, consul general of the Dominican Republic, searched for words yesterday to describe his emotions and then gave up. "The pain is too big," he said yesterday at his offices in Manhattan.
Throughout the day, in frantic phone calls and e-mail messages, friends and relatives separated by an ocean tried to learn whether loved ones had been on the flight. With some phone lines jammed, it took several hours for government officials in Santo Domingo to contact the consulate in New York. There were initial fears that high-ranking officials might have been on the flight, returning from the United Nations General Assembly. But by late afternoon, most had been located. 
For many, though, the news was almost too much to bear. In Santo Domingo, one man, a customs officer on duty at the airport, fainted upon learning that his wife and children were on the flight.
Freddy Beras Boyco, a Dominican television personality, said he had confirmation that Papi La Fontaine, a show business impresario who lived in New York, and Norma Guzman Valoy, the daughter of a famous singer, Cuco Valoy, were on the doomed flight. Ms. Valoy was traveling home with her three children.
Although no official list of the dead had been released last night, Guillermo Linares, a City Council member who represents Washington Heights, said that he dreaded the toll this crash would surely exact on his community. The terror attacks on Sept. 11 killed 41 Dominicans, he said. The effect of yesterday's disaster, he predicted, will be nothing less than devastating. He was referring to the human cost, but there were also fears of an economic loss. The crash comes as the Dominican Republic is struggling to recover from a steep decline in tourism after Sept. 11. The resulting hotel closings and layoffs prompted President Hipolito Mejia to commit more than $20 million for tourism marketing.
Indeed, Aurora Martinez, a 62-year-old factory worker, was a reluctant passenger on Flight 587. "After Sept. 11, she was a little afraid to fly," said her son, Victor Caceres. "She didn't want to go, but she had to sell the property." Mr. Caceres kissed his mother, hugged her and told her: "I'll call you in four or five hours. You should be there by then."
The Sept. 11 attacks had also made Oneida Mercedes Acosta, 42, who worked seven days a week at a beauty salon in the Bronx, a reluctant passenger. "She was always afraid of planes," said her brother, Hervio Mendoza, 37. 
"This year it was worse."
But the annual trip back to Santo Domingo, to five of her brothers and sisters and countless friends, was always a high point of her year. So she went, taking her two children, Giovanni, 22, and Wendy, 26. "I went to her house last night to say goodbye," Mr. Mendoza said, his eyes welling up.
Mr. Mendoza looked for help, and solace, to Alianza Dominicana, a social services agency that went into full throttle as soon as the news of the crash spread. As mothers and fathers and sisters and brothers wept to guidance counselors inside, neighbors lit candles and brought flowers to a small memorial outside. "Estamos de Luto," or We are in Mourning, a banner read.
Cid Wilson dropped by to see what he could do. He said that the friend he lost, Mr. Sanchez, 29, the Merrill Lynch employee, "was a true example of what's gone right in this community." Mr. Wilson said that they had met in a group called Dominicans on Wall Street. "This was way before his prime," he said.
Flights like 587 form a kind of air bridge to the Dominican Republic, allowing many Dominican immigrants to keep up with their lives in both countries. Along some stretches of Broadway in Washington Heights, small travel agencies can be found on almost every other block, advertising cheap fares and offering services that range from wiring money to the Caribbean to doing income taxes to processing divorces, in some cases. Travel agents in Washington Heights said that even as the rest of the airplane industry has suffered in the wake of the Sept. 11 attacks, flights to the Dominican Republic were often full, in part because people who felt shaken by the disaster at the World Trade Center longed to see their relatives and in part because they longed to escape the city for a while.
There have been reports of parents taking their children out of school in New York and sending them back to the Dominican Republic, where they felt safer.
Mr. Bullington said he spoke with the brother of one passenger who had just recently decided to leave New York for good. "The guy said to me that his brother had not been back in three years, but that he was making this trip to buy land to move his family back to the Dominican Republic because of what had happened on Sept. 11," Mr. Bullington said. "He perished most likely, along with his baby son who was with him."
Gladys Basora, a manager of the EZ Vision travel agency on Broadway near 207th Street, told a similar story about a longtime customer who was on Flight 587. "He was scared by Sept. 11, and he wasn't sure if he wanted to stay here any longer," she said. "He was making the trip to see if he could go back to stay. He told me, 'I would rather live on a farm.' "
But instead, relatives in both countries were left wondering whether terrorism had now touched them, too, despite early indications from officials that mechanical failure was a more likely cause of the crash.
At the Ramada Plaza Hotel near Kennedy Airport, some relatives gathered at a family center set up by the authorities. Families absorbed the news that charred bodies were being recovered on the streets of Rockaway, some still strapped into their seats.
Last night, in front of the Ramada, Genaro Moran stood holding a photograph of his brother, Francisco Diaz, a taxi driver who was returning to the Dominican Republic to visit his wife and two children. 
As for many other Dominicans in New York, the trip home for Mr. Diaz was a chance to shower gifts on relatives, proof of his hard labors in a cold country.
"He worked every day, to have enough money to bring his family here," Mr. Moran said. "Just last night, he was saying how happy he was to be going to see them."
In Santo Domingo, officials also set up a family center, this one behind a blue plastic curtain on the second floor of the main airport terminal. By late afternoon, only a few dozen relatives remained at the airport, where two people had to be taken away by ambulance for medical care. 
Even as the Dominican government declared three days of official mourning, mental health workers and Red Cross volunteers streamed into the airport, some carrying boxes of food.
"This is a great hurt for the Dominican Republic and the United States," said Vice President Milagros Ortiz Bosch. "I want to say to Mayor Giuliani, 'We are in solidarity now more than ever.' "

HEADLINE: G.M. Starts to Back Off on Its Price War 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 12 

 BODY:
General Motors has begun a slow retreat from the auto industry's price war that was spurred by the Sept. 11 attacks.
 G.M., the nation's largest automaker, said today that it would extend its Keep America Rolling incentive package and continue to offer interest-free financing through Jan. 2. But the new phase of the plan will be less generous than the current one and will not include Cadillacs, Corvettes and some Saturn vehicles. 
 Beginning Nov. 19, interest-free financing will be offered only on three-year purchase plans, which are less attractive to many buyers than four- and five-year deals because they have overall lower monthly payments. Interest-free deals will continue to be restricted to customers with good credit ratings.
And financing rates on four- and five-year deals will rise. For instance, four-year deals on 2002 pickups will carry rates of 3.9 percent, instead of the current 2.9 percent.
G.M. started offering interest-free financing deals on its entire vehicle lineup when sales fell sharply after the Sept. 11 attacks. Company executives said they were trying to do their part to stimulate the flagging economy. But they also saw a chance to gain market share while they had a newer lineup of sport utility vehicles and trucks than their chief rivals, Ford Motor and the Chrysler Group.
Ford and Chrysler, a unit of DaimlerChrysler, unenthusiastically followed with their own interest-free financing plans, which are set to end this month, and some foreign automakers have also offered limited deals. As a result, sales of cars and trucks in this country surged in October to the highest monthly level in the auto industry's history.
Analysts, however, worry that the sales boom came at the expense of profits. Last month, incentive costs for the Big Three carmakers rose to an average of $2,744 per vehicle, up 67.5 percent from the month a year earlier, according to a recent report by UBS Warburg.
"I think G.M. overreacted about the impact of the events of Sept. 11 and put in incentives that were too generous," said David Healy, an analyst with Burnham Securities.
He and most other analysts expect the record sales to be short-lived.
"It's a question of when they're going to give up this artificial volume, take the hit and see where the real bottom is," said Scott Sprinzen, the managing director for automotive credit at Standard & Poor's, the rating agency, which recently downgraded the credit ratings of the Big Three.
"I don't view it as a positive in any sense," he said of today's announcement, though he added, "It is good news, maybe, that they're being more selective."
Paul Ballew, G.M.'s general director for global market and industry analysis, said sales had already slowed from October's record pace. The rollback of incentives is likely to cause that trend to continue, even if it makes each individual vehicle more profitable.
Keep America Rolling "is a very expensive program," Mr. Ballew said. "We need to transition down, and this is one way of doing it."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE DRUG MAKERS; 
Antibiotics Business Is Again Popular

BYLINE:  By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
Like other pharmaceutical companies, Eli Lilly & Company rushed late last month to offer the government help in fighting bioterrorism. It volunteered to increase production of its antibiotics and even to allow its plants to be used to produce antibiotics made by other manufacturers. 
 Lilly could make the offer because it has excess capacity in its antibiotics plants, a spokesman said. Once a giant in that part of the pharmaceuticals business, the company, based in Indianapolis, has scaled back the development of antibacterial drugs to focus on what it saw as richer opportunities, like drugs for psychological disorders and osteoporosis. 
 Lilly is not alone. The pharmaceuticals industry, convinced that antibiotics had already vanquished most bugs, de-emphasized development of new antibiotics over the last two decades, leading to a dearth of new drugs to fight bacterial infections. Antibiotic sales, about $24 billion worldwide, declined 1 percent last year, according to a report by Friedman, Billings, Ramsey. Drug sales over all rose about 10 percent, according to IMS Health, a health care information company.
Still, the need for new antibiotics has been increasing. Bacteria that cause everything from tuberculosis to hospital infections have been evolving to be resistant to existing antibiotics, at times turning what were routine infections into potentially life-threatening illnesses. 
Now, fears of bioterrorism may lead more companies to develop new drugs to fight bacterial infections. Martin Rosenberg, who recently retired after leading research on infectious-disease drugs at GlaxoSmithKline, said, "It's certainly made people aware that there are issues around the fact that the number of drugs we have against micro-organisms is relatively small and shrinking." 
Several young biotechnology companies and a few big drug makers are turning to a new tool -- genomics -- to unravel the inner workings of bacteria and devise new ways to attack them. 
Among the reasons that making antibiotics has been out of favor is that these drugs are taken for a few days, while drugs for conditions like high blood pressure and arthritis may be taken for life.
And despite bacterial resistance, older antibiotics like penicillin and tetracycline still work for many infections, limiting the demand for new drugs. 
"If the drugs that are out there are good enough for 80 to 90 percent of infections, why bother to have major research on infections?" said Neil Sweig, pharmaceuticals analyst at Ryan, Beck & Company.
The Food and Drug Administration is contemplating rule changes that would make it harder for antibiotics to win approval, possibly discouraging development. But Dr. Mark Goldberger, acting director of the F.D.A. office that reviews antibiotics, said no decision had been made and the agency was also looking at changes that would ease the way for some drugs to be approved. 
Scientific factors also limit the appeal of research on antibiotics. Most antibiotics are chemicals produced by bacteria or fungi to kill rival microbes and have been found by sifting soil samples. But it has become harder to find new chemicals this way. So companies have concentrated on modifying existing drugs to develop variations that are more potent, or work against a broader range of bugs and are different enough to patent. 
"In many cases the compounds were me-too's," said Julian Davies, a microbiology professor at the University of British Columbia and executive vice president of Cubist Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology company in Lexington, Mass.
Some industry executives and analysts say there is little incentive to develop antibiotics just to treat biological terror agents, despite the recent boom in the sales of the Bayer drug Cipro. Sales of such drugs, they maintain, will be sporadic and small, especially compared with drugs used to treat common infections that affect millions of people each year. 
"Bioterrorism at this point in time is a short-term business opportunity," said George F. Horner III, chief executive of Versicor Inc., a biotechnology company in Fremont, Calif., that is developing antibiotics. "We're not interested in fads." 
Despite these limitations, a big-selling antibiotic can have sales of more than $1 billion a year. The world's best-selling antibiotic, Augmentin from GlaxoSmithKline, had sales exceeding $1.8 billion last year, making it the industry's 14th-best-selling drug over all, according to Mr. Sweig. Cipro, the first brand-name antibiotic to be specifically approved to treat inhaled anthrax, was Bayer's biggest-selling drug last year, with revenue around $1.6 billion. 
Much of the new research is aimed at understanding the inner workings of bacteria. The complete DNA sequences are now available for more than 50 strains of bacteria. The hope is that such work will lead to many new ways to attack bacteria. 
"If you take the known antibiotics in the world, they are against 30 different molecular targets within various bacteria and fungal pathogens," said Harry Hixson, chief executive of Elitra Pharmaceuticals, a privately held biotechnology company in San Diego. 
Elitra is systematically inactivating genes in various pathogens. If blocking a gene kills the bug, then that gene is deemed essential for bacterial survival and could be a target for a drug. Late last month, the company licensed some of the targets it had discovered to Merck & Company.
Other companies are already aiming at certain aspects of bacterial behavior. Essential Therapeutics of Waltham, Mass., which until a merger last month was known as Microcide Pharmaceuticals, is trying to design drugs to disable tiny pumps that bacteria use to eject antibiotics. 
Microbia, a privately held company in Cambridge, Mass., is focusing on blocking bacteria and fungi from forming slimy films that coat surfaces. 
Yet no antibiotics using genomics have entered clinical trials, and the first new antibiotics that will come out of the biotechnology industry will probably have been derived or descended from discoveries made the traditional way, in soil. 
These include Cubist's daptomycin, which is in the final stages of clinical trial. Versicor is also in the final phase of trials for anidulafungin, which it says would be the second drug in a new class of antifungal drugs. InterMune of Brisbane, Calif., is in late-stage tests of oritavancin, a new version of vancomycin.
All three drugs have something in common -- they were discovered by Eli Lilly, which decided not to develop them as it concentrated on what it saw as better opportunities.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
American Airlines Faces Problems From Plane Crash
Before Flight 587 crashed, American Airlines was seen as one of the carriers best positioned to weather the drastic downturn that came after September's terrorist attacks. But now -- depending on what is determined to have caused the crash -- American could find itself in much deeper trouble, experts said.
 The best that American can hope for is that the crash turns out to be an accident, and even then it could be severely harmed. American has had a higher number of fatal accidents than its competitors in recent years. Another one could harden the impression that the airline has a safety problem. Investors punished the company's stock, sending its shares down $1.64, or 9 percent, to $16.49. Page D10. 

Americans continued to board planes and seemed to stay aloft on the shared hope that the passengers of Flight 587 had not died at the hands of terrorists. D10.

Airlines' Insurance Costs to Rise
The crash of the passenger jet is expected to further increase the cost of insurance for the airlines, industry experts said. C2.

G.M. Begins Retreat in Price War
General Motors has begun a slow retreat from the auto industry's price war that was spurred by the Sept. 11 attacks. C2.

Few Antibiotics Being Developed
The pharmaceuticals industry, convinced that antibiotics had already vanquished most bugs, de-emphasized development of new antibiotics over the last two decades, leading to a dearth of new drugs to fight bacterial infections. B6.

Senate to Take Up Stimulus Bill
With prospects for a compromise clouded by politics, ideology and pressure from interest groups, the Senate plans to take up today a Democratic economic recovery package that has left the two parties bitterly divided. A14.

Japan Carriers Move Toward Merger
Japan Airlines and Japan Air System, the country's largest and third-largest airlines, plan to set up a holding company, a first step toward merging. World Business, Section W.

Values of Family-Owned Company
SC Johnson, the maker of Raid, Glade, Pledge, Ziploc bags and Windex, has created a series of national television ads featuring Samuel C. Johnson, the 73-year-old patriarch of the Johnson family. The television spots, which will be shown nationwide beginning today, feature Mr. Johnson, the retired chairman of SC Johnson, talking about the strengths and values of a family-owned company. Advertising. C4.

Celebrities Pitch Bristol Drug
Seeking to improve its third-place position in the booming $10 billion market for cholesterol-lowering drugs, Bristol-Myers Squibb has tapped celebrities to help sell Pravachol. C2.

Europe Seen Ignoring U.S. Request
European Union lawmakers are expected to ignore a Bush administration request to revise data-privacy legislation to allow the authorities greater access to information about phone calls and Internet messages. C7.

Russia to Cut Oil Output Slightly
Russia said that its oil industry had agreed to cut production, but the small size of the cut will have virtually no effect on oil prices, analysts said. World Business, Section W.

LVMH Sales Fell 5% in October
LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton said that its sales in October fell 5 percent compared with figures a year earlier and that its full-year operating profit might be 15 percent lower than forecast. World Business, Section W.

Chiquita in Deal With Creditors
Chiquita Brands International said that it had reached a long-awaited agreement with creditors that would give senior debt holders almost 88 percent of the company's equity in return for cutting its debt and interest expenses. C2.

HEADLINE: Tibet's Quiet Protest 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "China's Upbeat Governor in Tibet Promises Investment" (news article, Nov. 7):
 The Chinese government clearly -- and misguidedly -- hopes that increased investment in Tibet will discourage Tibetan nationalism. 
 Although Tibetans have been kept poor by discriminatory Chinese policies, their primary grievance is not economic but rather the occupation of their country by a foreign army. Suppression of dissent, economic policies intended to encourage Han immigration, and severe restrictions on the practice of religion only add insult to injury.
It would be wise of the American government to pressure China more actively to negotiate with the Dalai Lama and end human rights abuses in Tibet. If we wish to combat terrorism worldwide, we must show that nonviolent resistance is a more effective way to command world attention.

ANDREW AYERS
Brooklyn, Nov. 7, 2001

The writer is chairman of Students for a Free Tibet.

HEADLINE: On Eve of Putin Visit, Red Belt Sees Greenbacks 

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

DATELINE: TULA, Russia 

 BODY:
They call this region south of Moscow the Red Belt, because of its fealty to Communist leadership. But these days when talk turns to Russia's newly warm relations with America, dollar signs seem to glow in people's eyes and words like "credits, investment, joint ventures" spill off their tongues.
 "We need the money," said a woman who gave only her first name, Tamara, and her age, 53, as she sold hats and gloves at an outdoor bazaar just off Leninsky Prospekt, hoping to supplement the $100 a month her husband earns at a factory making hunting guns. "Putin promised that soon we'll live a happy life here. We've been waiting a long time." 
 As Russian President Vladimir V. Putin heads to President Bush's ranch in Crawford, Tex., for what some here call a "summit without ties," military topics will be high on the agenda. But for most people here, America matters much more as an economic superpower than as a military one.
Not everyone likes America, or welcomes America's war on terrorism and the presence of American troops in former Soviet republics like Uzbekistan, or, for that matter, the invasion of American culture. But everyone seems to agree that, economically at least, Russia needs all the American good will it can get.
"Just look around and you will see -- Russia is lagging behind," said Anatoly Ivanovich, 51, a jewelry vendor who left a factory job because it did not pay enough to live.
Or, as Anatoly Gololabenkov, a 60-year-old businessman, put it: "We're not as rich as we used to be."
For good or ill, America's influence is felt most here as a producer of the goods, like Nike and Adidas, advertised almost everywhere; as a creator of employment through joint ventures like the one Procter & Gamble has in a nearby town; even as a source of unemployment, when managers at a local steel factory blamed American quotas for laying off 1,500 workers.
Negotiations on the missile treaty are weighed largely for their economic repercussions.
Sergei G. Volkov, a former policeman who now manages the city's municipal markets, said if the United States went ahead with a missile shield, Russia -- which he called a "country of paupers" -- would have to compete. "We're not afraid of attack," he said, "but of another spiral of the arms race that could make us even poorer."
Tula was once a famous center of gunsmithing -- Peter the Great put a small arms factory here in 1712 -- and a pinion of Russia's defense industry. But in the 1990's, with falloffs in state orders and failed attempts to privatize, the industry, and thus the local economy, plummeted. 
Even the city's production of samovars, or Russian tea urns, suffered badly -- and most of those made now are for export, too expensive for local residents. Official unemployment in this city of 575,000 is put at 9,000, but it is much higher in the surrounding region, where huge collective farms have struggled to modernize.
Things have improved since President Putin took office almost two years ago. In an effort to consolidate the defense industry, he announced this month that Tula would become a center for manufacturing small missiles, which means guaranteed state orders. And then there are the joint ventures that have come in the last few years -- Procter & Gamble, which manufactures soaps and detergents, and Knopf, a German company producing construction materials. They pay well by Tula standards -- $300 to $400 a month.
"These two enterprises play the role of the defense industry in old times," said Aleksandr G. Yermakov, the editor of Molody Kommunar, an independent local newspaper. "They are the engines of our economy."
But Stanislav P. Kupriyanov, the Communist Party's regional secretary and a local deputy in the State Duma, criticized the Procter & Gamble plant for streamlining production so much that workers had been laid off. America's attempt to dominate Russia economically, he said, had replaced the effort to dominate it militarily.
That sentiment has some currency in a place where the Communist mayor is expected to be re-elected with 80 percent of the vote, and the region's Communist governor is equally entrenched. ("Those democrats know nothing but demagoguery," Mr. Kupriyanov said in explaining the party's continued popularity. Besides, he said, they had ruined the economy.)
A few weeks ago, Mr. Yermakov said, during the World Economic Forum in Moscow, what appeared to be a small, staged protest in Tula against globalization by a group of disinterested young men suddenly swelled when old people joined it, drawn by anti-American slogans.
"What kind of anti-globalists are these that Tula has?" he wondered.
They represent this city's aging population, which sometimes still sees America as the enemy. One woman said sarcastically that America had already "helped" Russia -- by disarming and therefore weakening it.
Among the young, attitudes toward America are considerably more nuanced, shaped by the lack of Communist propaganda against the United States, personal contacts formed through exchanges or business deals, or by the Internet or television. They don't see America as the enemy, but they don't see it as Utopia, either. They bristle at the suggestion that they should ape the West, and say American imports corrode their culture.
"I think after perestroika, when we opened to Western culture, after such a long period of being closed, we absorbed too much of it," said a student at Tula State University, Ileana Glinsteva, 18.
Another student, Daniel Medvedev, 18, praised Russian support for the antiterror coalition, but said the United States still interfered too much with other countries' interests. He did not like how the United States took sides in the conflict over Kosovo, or how it had judged Russia for fighting a war in Chechnya.
America's official attitude toward the Chechen war has been considerably softer since Sept. 11, and that perceived hypocrisy grates on some here. "When we're fighting terrorists, we're doing something wrong,"Mr. Volkov said. "But now, well, fighting terrorists is right."
But a trio of policemen, celebrating National Policemen's Holiday with on-the-house shots of vodka in a Tula cafe, said they were delighted that America was joining Russia in a fight against terrorism. They had wept when the World Trade Center collapsed, they said, and now included its victims in their toasts.
"We are ready to fight terrorism with the people of the United States," said Sergei Tsyastus, 43. "Chechnya and their leaders for us is what bin Laden is for the United States." He even praised the multinational corporations in the region. "What our governor cannot do for people," he said, "these companies can do."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ALLIANCE; 
U.S. Says Aid To Pakistan Won't Include F-16 Fighters

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 

 BODY:
The Bush administration has rejected Pakistan's request to release a fleet of F-16 jet fighters that it bought in the 1980's, American officials said today, adding that the United States wanted to avoid destabilizing relations in South Asia.
 In an interview with The New York Times published on Saturday, the president of Pakistan, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, said transferring the fighters would be an important symbolic gesture of American gratitude for his nation's strong support in the war in Afghanistan. 
 Pakistan purchased 28 F-16's in the 1980's, but their delivery was blocked when Congress cut off all aid and military sales in 1990, citing Pakistan's secret development of nuclear weapons. 
President Bush announced on Saturday that the United States was providing an aid package worth more than $1 billion to Pakistan in exchange for its war support, but the F-16's were conspicuously absent from the deal.
Mr. Bush and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell discussed the matter with General Musharraf in meetings in New York but decided against making the fighters a part of renewed ties with Pakistan.
"They would like to have the planes," Secretary Powell said in an interview today, "but at the moment we are restarting our military-to-military relationship in a more serious way, and the planes are not an issue that we expect to be discussing in the very near future."
The Clinton administration settled the longstanding dispute over the planes by sending Pakistan cash and commodities worth more than $500 million, officials said today.
Despite the settlement, General Musharraf said Pakistan still wanted the planes, advanced fighter-bombers, as a visible sign that the United States was restoring Pakistan to the status of a genuine ally.
"I did take up this case, frankly, not because that much of it was significant from defense point of view," General Musharraf said on Sunday. "It has its significance, certainly, but not as much as I should have highlighted it. It's more for public perceptions in Pakistan."
Having his public request turned down flat was an embarrassing setback that he said would be "received negatively" in Pakistan.
Administration officials did not rule out releasing the fighters in the future, holding back an important carrot in Washington's evolving relationship with the general.
"We're at the very beginnings of resuming military-to-military contacts with Pakistan," an administration official said, "and right now we're looking at more modest requests, like providing spare parts and assisting their border security with helicopters."
Indeed, much of the calculus appeared to hinge on the United States balancing its diplomatic and military relations with Pakistan and India, Pakistan's neighbor and longtime rival. Both countries are nuclear powers.
Since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, the United States has tried to patch up its relations with General Musharraf, who took power in a coup two years ago. Pakistan, the most prominent Islamic ally in the war in Afghanistan, has allowed American search-and-rescue aircraft and Special Operations forces to operate from several of its bases.
At the same time, the United States has improved its relations with India, and Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld praised the improved ties on a recent visit there.
Transferring the F-16's now could upset that delicate balance, especially because the fighters are a combat aircraft that is capable of dropping nuclear weapons. "Any transfer of advanced weapons would get everyone all riled up," a State Department official said.
Lee Feinstein, a State Department official in the Clinton administration who worked on South Asia policy, said: "The United States has a new role in South Asia, and that is as a kind of guarantor of stability for Pakistan. At the same time, it wants to deepen relationship with India. The trick will be whether officials in all three capitals can can accommodate this."
There are other constraints to releasing the fighters, officials said.
In September, Mr. Bush lifted economic sanctions against Pakistan and India that were imposed after both countries conducted nuclear tests in 1998. But Pakistan's Defense Ministry remains under American sanctions for buying M-11 missiles from China in the early 1990's.
Mr. Bush waived some of those missile-related sanctions in September to allow Pakistan's military to help in the war in Afghanistan, but the full restrictions do not expire until November of next year, a State Department official said.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: SECRETARY OF STATE; 
Global Kaleidoscope: Powell Notes Shifts After Sept. 11

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

 BODY:
Within 48 hours of September's terrorist strikes, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell telephoned Gen. Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan and said, "General, you have got to make a choice."
 The choice was whether to cast Pakistan's lot with the United States in the war that was coming, or remain an isolated and economically beleaguered state, crushed by foreign debt and sliding toward the same Islamic extremism that had brought the Taliban to power in neighboring Afghanistan. 
 "He knew the call was coming and said 'I'll talk to you soon,' " Secretary Powell recounted in an interview with The New York Times yesterday. "He took 24 hours to consult with all his political leaders and his generals and he made that choice -- not just a choice with respect to the Taliban, but a strategic choice with respect to where Pakistan was going to be in the future." 
In the wake of the horror of the September assault on America, a number of nations are examining the strategic choices they face, Secretary Powell said.
In this sense, disaster has also brought opportunity on a wide range of diplomatic fronts.
The Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, also "made a strategic decision when he came out solidly and squarely for the campaign against terrorism, and essentially said, 'We are going to be a part of this, we are going to be a leader in this, with the U.S.' Now that was an important strategic choice," Secretary Powell said.
He suggested that contacts with several other countries -- including Iran and Syria -- could emerge from their frozen state as a result of the strategic shifts since Sept. 11.
"It remains to be seen in some of these states where we have had strained relations for many years, such as Syria and Iran, how that will play out," Secretary Powell said. "There have been contacts that we have never had before with these kinds of countries, and let's explore those opportunities without putting Vaseline in our eyes." He added, "When we hear that Iranians are willing to provide search and air rescue for American pilots, this is pretty interesting." In addition, he noted, "When you hear that there are pro-American demonstrations in Iran in support of President Khatami, things are going on."
Things already are going on in South Asia. Secretary Powell made clear today that he saw a deepening, long-term American engagement in South Asia and a "robust" military relationship with both India and Pakistan aimed at minimizing the risk of nuclear confrontation over the disputed territory of Kashmir and at containing extremism.
The secretary of state said he also saw new opportunities to address the civil conflicts and health crises holding back Africa's development, an issue on which he is becoming something of a missionary in the administration. 
Perhaps most important, in the Middle East, Secretary Powell said he was hoping for a strategic shift in the positions of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, and Ariel Sharon, the Israeli prime minister, two unlikely candidates for staging the strategic breakthrough for a peace that seemed possible not so many months ago, but that has been shattered since.
Secretary Powell suggested today that the "humiliation" caused by the unresolved Palestinian homeland issue was a spawning ground for terrorism, of which Israeli civilians were most often the victims.
He expressed the hope that the strategic impetus for another push for comprehensive peace in the Middle East might flow from the traumatic events that have conferred on Mr. Bush a more influential role as arbiter. Secretary Powell said he himself was determined to "keep a broader view out as to what opportunities have been presented to us."

HEADLINE: Putin, Starting U.S. Trip, Predicts Missile Accord 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 

 BODY:
President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia arrived on his first official visit to the United States tonight hours after predicting that a deal was within reach that would allow President Bush to speed ahead with tests of an antiballistic missile system.
 That deal would be the centerpiece of a meeting that begins Tuesday morning here, and moves on Wednesday and Thursday to the Bush ranch in Crawford, Tex. 
 When Mr. Putin arrives at the White House on Tuesday morning, he and Mr. Bush are widely expected to exchange their bottom-line figures for the mutual reduction of their nuclear arsenals. Mr. Bush has said he has reached a decision -- the guesswork is a cut to between 1,750 and 2,300 -- but has declined to release it before he tells Mr. Putin. 
Tonight, meeting Russian reporters at the White House, Mr. Bush said that he would give Mr. Putin tomorrow a number "substantially lower than today's weaponry, and I presume he'll have a number he'll share with me. The point is, what we don't need is the endless hours of arms control discussions."
With a least five or six statements expected during the course of the summit meeting, any arms control deal is not expected to be the first, or indeed only, tangible result of Mr. Putin's visit.
On Tuesday, Mr. Putin and Mr. Bush will release some of the five or six joint statements and letters that administration officials said their staffs have drafted in recent days.
The statements cover everything from nuclear reductions to economic initiatives to a vague statement by Mr. Putin that the White House hopes will temper any crackdown on Russia's independent media, which Mr. Putin critics say he has attempted to intimidate through a series of legal and financial pressures. 
One omission from the statements appears to be Chechnya, where Russian soldiers have employed often brutal tactics in their fight against Muslim rebels cast by Mr. Putin as Islamic extremists akin to Osama bin Laden.
During the presidential campaign, Mr. Bush said he doubted he could reach any agreement with Russia while Moscow was involved in human rights violations in Chechnya.
Now, with Mr. Putin a needed and valuable ally in the fight against terrorism, Washington has muted its criticism of Russia's behavior.
Saved for the Crawford meeting, where Mr. Bush has planned a Texas barbecue and country music for the Russian president, is an accord reinterpreting the 1972 ABM treaty to allow just the kind of missile defense testing it was meant to ban.
Mr. Bush, speaking wtih the Russian reporters, called the "a vestige of the past," adding, "We're having a lot of discussions about how to move beyond it."
Mr. Bush, officials say, will not repeat his threat to withdraw from the treaty, though his aides say that option will be held open. In return, Mr. Putin has strongly hinted that he would allow testing of the antimissile system -- a project in which Russia would become a parts supplier and participant. If an accord is reached, Mr. Putin would be able to return to Moscow claiming he has staved off American efforts to kill the treaty outright and immediately.
But several administration officials insist that Mr. Putin has come to the conclusion that the treaty will die a slow death, or be replaced by other agreements in future meetings. "We think that Putin has come to accept the ABM's ultimate demise," one administration official said today. "The question now is funeral arrangements."
Both men have traveled a considerable distance. Mr. Bush said during and after the campaign that he was determined to kill the treaty, which he has often said is "antiquated" and "dangerous." Mr. Putin traveled the world in the spring whipping up opposition to the American missile defense project. Now, he has apparently decided that the wiser course for Russia is to participate in its creation.
A few months ago, Mr. Bush might not have had the political latitude to reach any accord that keeps the ABM treaty in place, even temporarily.
But Russia's decision to side with Washington in the counterterrorism campaign, and Mr. Putin's move toward the West in general and Mr. Bush in particular, have silenced many conservatives who long desired to kill the ABM treaty.
Over the weekend, American and Russian officials met in New York to hammer out the wording of the joint statements and letters, and that process was still under way tonight.
Officially, Mr. Bush's aides are still playing down expectations for the visit. Condoleezza Rice, his national security adviser, has called this meeting -- the fourth between the two leaders, but the first on American soil -- "another step in a process." It has been clear for months, however, that if a broad accord is to be reached to begin building what Ms. Rice calls "a new strategic relationship," it should happen in Crawford.
At a joint press conference on Tuesday at the White House, Mr. Bush is expected to announce that Russia will be permanently removed from the list of countries subject to cold war-era sanctions under the Jackson-Vanik amendment, which concerned freedom of emigration. Those sanctions have not been imposed in a decade, but Russia wanted the threat of reimposing the penalties eliminated.
The administration will also vow to press for Russia's relatively swift inclusion in the World Trade Organization -- a feat China completed last weekend after 14 years -- and begin discussions on using Russian equipment as a central part of the antimissile system.

Heart Pump Found Effective
An implanted mechanical pump that assists a failing heart, but does not replace it, can significantly prolong the lives of people dying of heart disease, a landmark study found. The pump, known as a VAD, for ventricular assist device, is superior to the most potent drugs for heart failure and may eventually prevent the deaths of up to 100,000 Americans a year, the study's authors said. A10

Japan Physics Lab Is Crippled
A huge underground chamber outside Tokyo that made historic observations of neutrinos, ghostly particles neutrinos that stream through the cosmos, was crippled over the weekend when thousands of light detectors imploded in a chain reaction. The accident at the Kamioka Neutrino Observatory halted an experiment that had been considered a candidate for a Nobel Prize. A5

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Stocks Fall, Then Rise as Fears of Terrorism as Crash's Cause Abate

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks tumbled in the wake of the American Airlines crash near Kennedy International Airport yesterday but rebounded when it appeared that the crash might be an accident rather than a result of a new terrorist attack.
 Airline, travel, entertainment and insurance stocks, all of which were hit hard after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, dropped sharply as the news of the plane crash about 9:17 a.m. hit the stock market just before it opened. 
 "It was difficult news for the market, coming just two months and a day after Sept. 11," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment officer at Credit Suisse First Boston.
Stocks began to rally, however, after a White House briefing at noon. In the briefing, the White House spokesman, Ari Fleischer, seemed to calm fears that the crash was another terrorist attack. "I want to be very cautious about any conclusions at this early time about what is the cause of this," Mr. Fleischer said. "We have not ruled anything in, not ruled anything out." 
But Mr. Fleischer did say that communications with the plane before the crash had been normal and that the airport shutdowns in the New York City area would be over soon. He also said that the government had not received any credible threats of terror attacks in connection with yesterday's plane crash.
While oil stocks were also pulling the market lower, technology stocks like Ciena, Microsoft and Intel rose and helped push the Nasdaq composite index back into positive territory early in the afternoon.
The Nasdaq composite index, which was down as much as 2.5 percent, ended the day up 11.65 points, or 0.6 percent, to close at 1,840.13. The Dow Jones industrial average, which fell almost 2.7 percent, finished the day down just 53.63 points, or 0.6 percent, at 9,554.37. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was down almost 22 points, or 2 percent, but ended the day off just 1.98 points, or 0.2 percent, at 1,118.33. The Nasdaq and the S.& P. are still above where they were before Sept. 11. The Dow is now just below its close of 9,605.51 on Sept. 10.
The stock of the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, plunged as much as 13.7 percent but finished the day down $1.64, or 9 percent, at $16.49. It has already fallen 40 percent since Sept. 11. Delta Air Lines fell $2.72, or 10.5 percent, to $23.27. It had fallen as low as $22.20. The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, which manufactured the Airbus that crashed, dropped 9 percent, to 12.60 euros ($11.27) in Paris.
Other travel and entertainment related stocks also rallied later in the day. Walt Disney, which was down as much as 4 percent, finished the day down 24 cents, or 1.3 percent, at $18.71. Marriott International, the hotel company, fell 6.3 percent and then ended the day at $32.50, down $1.50, or 4.4 percent. American Express plunged 5.2 percent early but closed at $32.09, down 62 cents, or 1.9 percent. Boeing, the aircraft maker, dropped 4.9 percent, then bounced back to be down 18 cents, or 0.5 percent, at $33.06.
Some insurance stocks also rallied after the initial downdraft. American International Group was down 3.4 percent early but ended the day up 11 cents, or 0.1 percent, at $79.80.
Oil company stocks fell as oil prices declined. Exxon Mobil dropped 19 cents, to $40.06. ChevronTexaco was off 26 cents, to $89.23. The price of a barrel of crude oil for December delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange was down 99 cents, to $21.23. Analysts said the airplane crash might mean another decline in air travel and, therefore, a decline in fuel consumption. In addition, Russia's proposed reduction in oil production was much less than expected.
The losses in the Dow and the S.& P. 500 were reduced by Microsoft, which was up 58 cents, to $65.79; Intel, which rose 50 cents, to $28.38; I.B.M., which gained 78 cents, to $114.86; and Hewlett-Packard, which jumped 31 cents, to $19.30.
Ciena rose $1.65, or 9.6 percent, to $18.83. Ciena, a manufacturer of fiber optic equipment, said that its profit in the fourth quarter would meet or beat company forecasts. Ciena also said it would cut 380 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force.
While the stock market was open yesterday, it was a government holiday and the bond market was closed. So trading volume was below average, which can exaggerate moves in the prices of stocks and main market indexes. On the New York Stock Exchange, 1 billion shares traded, below the 1.2 billion average for daily trading over the last year.
Mr. Galvin of Credit Suisse First Boston said that he worried that the market had rallied so far and so fast recently that it might falter if new economic data did not show a turnaround soon. "The market has made a substantial move in a short period of time, and some people have their finger on the profit-taking button," he said. So far, he added, "stocks are up in the hope of a recovery,"
Thomas C. van Leuven, an equity strategist at J. P. Morgan, said that corporate earnings "are expected to improve very soon, but we are not convinced that is going to happen." With a background of weak earnings and continued disappointments, he said, the "market will have trouble making headway."

HEADLINE: Jobs That Recession May Never Touch 

BYLINE:  By WELD ROYAL 

 BODY:
Two and a half years ago, as seniors at St. Peter's College in Jersey City were flocking to the glamorous dot-com world across the river in Manhattan, Krzysztof Augustynowicz turned passionate about accounting.
 It happened at the end of his sophomore year, when Mr. Augustynowicz was hired by a medium-size accounting firm as a summer intern and given the job of managing government audits. "If the numbers weren't working out right, I had to spend my time interviewing people to understand the books," he said. "It was kind of like being a detective." He was hooked. 
 Mr. Augustynowicz, 22, went on to earn a bachelor's degree in accounting from St. Peter's and will finish a master's in finance next May. Though accountants are often pegged as boring -- an attitude he says is wrong -- they do have one big advantage: they will probably never be out of work.
Despite the shrinking economy, the slump in consumer spending and almost daily headlines about layoffs, some professions appear to be recession-proof simply because there are not enough people practicing them to meet demand. Since Sept. 11, not surprisingly, other fields have joined the list. They include security, biotechnology and bioinformatics, the use of computers to organize huge amounts of biological data into useful information -- now emerging as a tool to help fight bioterrorism. 
But a large number of more typical occupations -- from high school teachers to health care workers to computer engineers -- are also likely to flourish, as far as labor market prognosticators can see.
A review of how three people -- Mr. Augustynowicz; William Picot, a medical equipment technician, and Tammi Byrd, a dental hygienist -- found their way to careers they consider immune to shifts in the economy holds one simple lesson for people looking for job security: All three took a hard look at the labor market and singled out a livelihood where people seemed to have more to do than they could handle.
Mr. Augustynowicz, who moved to New Jersey from Poland as a boy, was inspired by the success of a cousin who works as an accountant at PricewaterhouseCoopers.
"He has a really nice apartment, and a nice car -- an Audi," Mr. Augustynowicz said of his cousin. "He travels whenever he wants and wherever."
Even before he got his summer job, he was leaning in that direction, taking accounting courses and being elected president of the St. Peter's Accounting Club. It will be months before he finishes school, but he has already received four job offers and accepted one from KPMG International, beginning next fall at about $50,000.
That does not surprise Peter Gotlieb, associate dean for Experiential Learning and Career Services at St. Peter's. "Demand for accounting graduates and interns is still outstripping supply," he said, with companies luring the best candidates with offers that start as high as $51,000. The Bureau of Labor Statistics projects as much as a 20 percent increase in jobs for accountants and auditors, to around 1.3 million in 2008.
William Picot thinks he can make a lot more than $51,000 repairing medical equipment. Though he is only 23, he says he believes that he will be able to start his own business in a couple of years and bring in a six-figure income.
Mr. Picot tripped into his line of work during a visit to a friend's home during his junior year in high school. The friend's parents cared for ill foster children, and the apparatus that helped one of them breathe had broken down. Mr. Picot struck up a conversation with the technician who came to fix the life-support ventilator. As he watched him work and listened to him talk about how much he liked his job -- and how much money he made -- he thought maybe that was where his future lay.
"I always knew I wanted to do something technical, and knew that a four-year degree wasn't for me," he said.
So he investigated two-year programs in medical equipment service and enrolled in the Biomedical Equipment Technology Department at Texas State Technical College in Waco. Roger A. Bowles, a senior instructor at the department, said graduates usually get three or four job offers starting anywhere from $39,000 to $50,000. The Bureau of Labor Statistics does not break out medical technicians in its projections, but Mr. Bowles says openings could increase to as many as 4,000 within seven years from an estimated 1,000 last year.
Mr. Picot finished his studies in 1999 and joined the Children's Medical Center of Dallas, where he specializes in the repair and maintenance of respiratory equipment. But when he is on call, usually for a week once a month, he repairs any kind of medical device that malfunctions.
"There's a big demand for small biomedical companies that take care of specialty doctors' clinics, even veterinarians," he said. "They all need working equipment and are willing to pay outrageous dollars for it."
Ms. Byrd, the dental hygienist, does not expect to make outrageous money, but she has already started her own business. She worked for two decades in dental offices in Columbia, S.C., before founding Health Promotion Specialists in nearby Irmo last December. For start-up money, she mortgaged her house and persuaded her parents to mortgage theirs.
Dental hygienists -- the people who clean teeth and take X-rays -- are in high demand anyway. The bureau projects at least a 36 percent increase in jobs in that occupation, to around 195,000 by 2008.
Nonetheless, Ms. Byrd developed what she hopes is a foolproof plan for success: she went to an area where the shortage was acute. In one county she serves, there is only one dentist for every 10,000 people, she said. Business boomed, and now her firm counts a staff of 21, among them 16 hygienists.
"We had planned on being in three to four counties in South Carolina during the school year that ended in June, but we ended up in 34," Ms. Byrd said.
Her income has not increased much from her days as a salaried employee, but that does not bother her. "I'm not looking to be a multimillionaire," she said. "But I am looking to pay off the mortgage on my house."

HEADLINE: Cablevision Says Its Loss Grew Wider In 3rd Quarter 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BETHPAGE, N.Y., Nov. 13 

 BODY:
The Cablevision Systems Corporation, the cable operator that owns Madison Square Garden and the New York Knicks, posted a wider third-quarter loss today after writing off some player contracts.
 The loss widened to $77.1 million, or 46 cents a share, compared with $40.1 million, or 23 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales slipped 3.8 percent, to $1 billion from $1.04 billion after the company sold some cable systems. 
 Sales at Madison Square Garden fell 11 percent because of fewer concerts and shows. The company said last month that the Sept. 11 attacks would reduce attendance at events. Cablevision would not disclose which players' contracts hurt results. An injury forced the Knicks forward Larry Johnson to retire last month, ending a 10-year career.
"Given the weak economy and people being afraid of congregating in places with a lot of people, Madison Square Garden is a problem," said Uri Landesman, chief investment officer of AFA Management Partners. 
Shares of Cablevision declined $1, to $35.42. Cablevision, which also controls the New York Rangers, owns cable systems serving three million homes in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. 
Third-quarter depreciation and amortization costs rose 14 percent, to $271.2 million, as Cablevision upgraded its cable systems for digital television, which offers hundreds of channels and fast Internet service. 
Cablevision expects to have more than 490,000 subscribers for fast Internet service by the end of the year, more than the 475,000 previously forecast. Cablevision had 423,100 such customers as of Sept. 30.
Sales at the company's cable systems and assets that are not included in the Rainbow Media tracking stock, including the Wiz chain of consumer electronics stores, fell 6 percent, to $864.4 million.
Sales from the Rainbow Media business, which includes cable TV networks like Bravo and American Movie Classics, jumped 19 percent, to $143.5 million.

HEADLINE: Earnings Rise At Wal-Mart, Home Depot And Penney 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Home Depot Inc. posted gains in third-quarter profits yesterday, while the J. C. Penney Company rebounded from a loss.
 Net income rose 8.2 percent at Wal-Mart and 20 percent at Home Depot, the largest home-improvement chain. J. C. Penney reported a $31 million profit, in contrast to a $30 million loss in the quarter a year earlier. 
 Each retailer took a different approach to keep earnings afloat in the slowing economy. Wal-Mart added stores and cut prices to take customers from rivals. Home Depot scaled back inventory and expansion plans to lower expenses, while J. C. Penney reworked its merchandise. 
At Wal-Mart, based in Bentonville, Ark., net income rose to $1.48 billion, or 33 cents a share, compared with $1.37 billion, or 31 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. The results matched analysts' estimates, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
An expanded selection of groceries and steeper-than-usual discounts helped Wal-Mart increase sales 15 percent, to $52.7 billion. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 6.7 percent, outpacing the industry's composite gain each month of the quarter.
The low margins on groceries and the discounts on other goods dragged the gross margin lower, though, as did the increased costs of utilities, insurance, store maintenance and medical benefits. Gross margin, the percentage of sales left after subtracting the cost of goods sold, fell to 21.52 percent from 21.85 percent in the quarter a year earlier.
Shares of Wal-Mart fell 58 cents, to $55.
Home Depot, based in Atlanta, said net income rose to $778 million, or 33 cents a share, compared with $650 million, or 28 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales in the quarter rose 15 percent, to $13.3 billion from $11.5 billion.
The company's chief executive, Bob Nardelli, has demanded lower prices from suppliers in his cost-cutting efforts and relied on high-margin services like tool rentals to increase profits.
Sales at stores open at least a year were unchanged, below analysts' forecast for a 1 percent gain.
Home Depot's results met analysts' expectations.
Shares of Home Depot rose $2.88, to $44.
J. C. Penney, based in Plano, Tex., reported net income of 9 cents a share, matching forecasts. The loss in the quarter a year earlier was 30 cents a share. Sales rose 2.5 percent, to $7.73 billion.
Allen Questrom, the chairman and chief executive, has added Disney children's clothing and Avon makeup to J. C. Penney stores to revive sales, while the company's Eckerd drugstores filled more prescriptions.
Shares of J. C. Penney rose $1.50, to $25.25.

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
Assessing Money's Role In Making Schools Better

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein; E-mail: rrothstein@nytimes.com

 BODY:
MANY school reforms today are intended to narrow the achievement gap between middle-class and poor children. Holding all pupils to the same high academic standard is one approach. Increasing school funds is another.
 Courts in several states have ordered equal spending on schools in communities that differ in wealth. In New York earlier this year, a judge found the state system unconstitutional because it results in less money for city schools compared with suburban ones. 
 But even if such judicial decisions were fully enforced, equality would remain elusive.
Some advocates of higher standards say that more spending would not raise academic performance. The Bush administration opposes big budget increases in the Senate version of an education bill currently being debated, arguing that more money for schools has not, in the past, produced better results.
But the notion that extra money doesn't matter would be hard to sell to suburban parents who exert great efforts raising money to supplement what taxes provide to schools.
If graduates must vie for society's rewards, privileged parents understandably want to position their own children for the competition. For this, maintaining school differentials is as important as high standards. So if city schools improve, suburban parents want their children's education to improve even more.
This is one reason for the extraordinary growth of private gifts to public schools in wealthier areas. Nationwide, parent contributions lead to smaller classes, enriched curriculum (like theatrical performances), more computers, added college counseling and better-stocked libraries.
These extras put policy makers in a quandary. Private gifts counteract judicial efforts to equalize resources across all social classes. But in a free society, parents should have the right to provide added benefits for their own children. Occasional efforts by school officials to ban private fund-raising have failed, either because parents figure out how to evade the bans or take steps to transfer children to more exclusive private schools.
The dilemma is stark in large, diverse districts where resources of schools attended by the rich should, in principle, equal those of other schools. The Washington suburb of Montgomery County, Md., for example, prohibits affluent schools from hiring additional regular teachers with private money. But wealthier parents have circumvented this effort to equalize spending by financing building improvements, extra library books and even faculty salary increases, euphemistically called appreciation payments.
New York City also prohibits private payments for additional regular classroom teachers, but parents in more affluent neighborhoods achieve a similar result by financing art and music teachers, called "consultants." Los Angeles gave up trying to enforce its policy that "no donation shall provide a substantial advantage in educational benefits if such benefits cannot be balanced in all schools."
In wealthy suburbs like Brookline, Mass.; Shaker Heights, Ohio; and Beverly Hills, Calif., parent-sponsored foundations with multimillion-dollar endowments provide extra income for public schools that neighboring cities can't emulate.
Many urban districts try to compete by enticing corporate donors to provide extra dollars for schools with disadvantaged students. But while this philanthropy helps, it doesn't bring spending close to amounts in the more affluent suburbs.
Financing extra art, music or computers partly reflects laudable parental ambition for enriched children's experiences. But middle-class families also buy other private advantages that accomplish nothing for society as a whole, like SAT coaching that typically costs $150 a week. Its only purpose is to give a child an edge over others who may be just as qualified for college but can't afford cram sessions.
California legislators, disturbed by how suburban SAT tutoring nullified the competitive value of improved scores among urban students, hoped to level the field by financing SAT coaching in low-income schools. State dollars now pay for test preparation classes of 15 to 20, certainly a help, but nothing like the one-on-one tutoring the rich can buy.
Better urban education is an end in itself, even if it can't keep up with schools in the suburbs. But we've come to expect initiatives like more accountablity and equalized school spending to shoulder almost the entire burden of making competition between graduates fully fair.
Schools alone can't accomplish such leavening. Greater social equality will always have to rely on economic and social tools (progressive tax policies or even affirmative action in employment, for example) to equalize the results of inevitably unequal educations.

HEADLINE: Loan Activity at Fannie Mae Sets Record

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
Fannie Mae, the No. 1 buyer of home loans, said today that it had made commitments to buy a record $33.6 billion in mortgage loans in October, as home loan refinancing surged to a record.
 The amount of loans that the company agreed to buy was up from $16.4 billion in September, when loan production was down because of the terrorist attacks, and exceeds the previous high of $30.2 billion in October 1998. 
 Fannie Mae is benefiting from a housing boom spurred by 10 interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, which lowered the 30-year mortgage rate to a record low of 6.45 percent last week. HEADLINE: Gold Coin Sales Rose Sharply After Sept. 11 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Sales of gold as an investment soared worldwide after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, but the rise in the third quarter was offset by weakness in the jewelry market, the World Gold Council said yesterday. 
 The trade group said that in the United States, sales of new gold coins, often seen as a safe-harbor investment in times of uncertainty, rose more than 400 percent to 3.5 metric tons in the July-September period from a year earlier. 
A metric ton is equal to about 2,205 pounds. 
 That offset a drop in the demand for gold for jewelry, resulting in total third-quarter demand in the United States of 104.4 tons, a 1 percent increase from a year earlier. For the first nine months of the year, demand for gold in the United States was 278.3 tons, a 3 percent rise from a year earlier. 
Worldwide, a sharp decline in jewelry demand because of slowing economies outweighed the increase in gold for investment, the World Gold Council said. 
Global demand was 755 tons in the third quarter, down 7 percent from a year earlier, the council said. The figure was pulled down by weak demand for gold for jewelry. Investment demand was up 17 percent at 106 tons. For the first nine months of the year, demand was 2,356 tons, down 2 percent. 
"Both the global slowdown and the aftermath of Sept. 11 affected demand in most countries, but the manner and extent of the effects varied widely," the council said.

HEADLINE: $25.8 Million Loss Logged at OfficeMax 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
OfficeMax Inc., the office products discount retailer, reported a loss of $25.8 million in the third quarter today and blamed the weak economy and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks for a drop in sales.
 The loss was wider than expected. 
The company reported a net loss of 23 cents a share, compared with a loss of 20 cents a share a year ago. Excluding a reserve for legal matters, the loss was 17 cents a share. Wall Street analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had predicted a loss of 11 cents a share. 
 OfficeMax, which is based in Cleveland, had expected a loss in the third quarter because of infrastructure improvement costs, but it said the loss was more severe because of the attacks. 
The company, comparing sales trends before and after Sept. 11, estimated that the attacks resulted in a sales decline of $30 million, a spokesman said. OfficeMax's third-quarter sales dropped to $1.18 billion, an 8.5 percent decrease. 
OfficeMax operates 993 superstores in 49 states, Puerto Rico and the United States Virgin Islands and joint-venture stores in Mexico and Brazil.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Rally on Hopes for Quick End to the Afghan War

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks rallied yesterday, with the broad market hitting levels unseen since late August, on expectations of a speedy conclusion to the war in Afghanistan.
 Investors scooped up stocks across the board as it became clear that the deadly plane crash in New York on Monday was probably an accident, not a terrorist attack. Helping fuel bullish sentiment were upbeat financial results from retailing giants like Home Depot and a positive forecast from a top semiconductor company, Texas Instruments. 
 "Today the political concerns have abated a little bit," said Rick Meckler, president of the investment firm LibertyView, which oversees $1 billion. "It has allowed those people who would prefer to focus on the economic stimulus in the market to go out and buy." 
The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average jumped 196.58 points, or 2.1 percent, to close at 9,750.95 -- its biggest percentage gain since Nov. 1. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 20.76 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,139.09. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index climbed 51.98 points, or 2.8 percent, to 1,892.11.
It was the highest close for the Nasdaq and the S.& P. since late August and the strongest finish for the Dow since Sept. 6. The Taliban's hard-line Islamic rule of Afghanistan appeared to be in tatters after the opposition Northern Alliance took control of the capital, Kabul, and other critical areas. 
Charlie Crane, a strategist at Victory SBSF Capital Management, which oversees $4 billion, said investors were acting as if the war was "not going to be a protracted drag on economic activity.
"It allows investors to focus on what positives may unfold as a result of monetary and fiscal stimuli that have been applied with a very heavy hand over the last several months," he added.
Airline and hotel stocks rebounded from steep losses after the Monday plane crash in New York. United States officials said early information suggested that the crash of the American Airlines passenger jet was an accident. Shares of AMR, parent of American Airlines, rose 52 cents, or 3 percent, to $17.01.
The S.& P.'s airline index rebounded 4.68 percent as fears faded that Monday's crash would take another bite out of the travel industry. Delta Air Lines rose $1.41, or more than 6 percent, to $24.68. 
Semiconductor makers like Intel gained on hopes the chip industry had scraped bottom. Texas Instruments rose $1.92, to $33.82, after saying the third quarter might have been the low point for semiconductor orders. Intel added $1.67, to $30.05. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange semiconductor index rose 4.1 percent, reflecting gains by other companies in the sector like Applied Materials, up $1.84, to $40.80.

Treasury Prices Fall
Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as the advance of United States-backed forces into the Afghan capital prompted investors to buy stocks, reducing demand for the safety of government debt.
"It's a little bit of stocks, a little bit of Kabul" that is pushing Treasuries lower, said Barry Evans, who oversees $10 billion at John Hancock Funds in Boston. "There's no new negative news; it's slightly more positive."
The 10-year Treasury note fell 16/32, to a price of 104 29/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.38 percent from 4.31 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 20/32, to 107 2/32. The bond's yield rose to 4.92 percent from 4.88 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: Citing Sept. 11, 2 Sides Avert Janitors' Strike 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
New York's largest janitors' union signed a tentative three-year agreement with the real estate industry yesterday, seven weeks before the contract deadline. Both sides said the surprise move was intended to minimize uncertainty during an anxious time for the city's businesses.
 The development is a far cry from the usual practice, when every third Thanksgiving the managers of Manhattan's office towers warn thousands of tenants of a possible janitors' strike that could force them to clean their own offices and haul their garbage out themselves. 
 The agreement saves tenants -- and the new mayor -- from having to worry about a replay of early 1996, when 30,000 janitors walked out for a month, as garbage piled up inside office towers and unshoveled snow piled up outside. 
"This is anti-stress medication," said Paul Salvatore, a lawyer for the building owners and managers.
The agreement applies to almost all of Manhattan's important commercial buildings, including the Empire State Building, the Chrysler Building and Rockefeller Center.
Negotiators for the two sides said they did not want the talks to drag on until Jan. 1, when the current contract expires, because that would have forced building managers to concentrate on dealing with a strike, instead of their biggest current concern -- keeping security tight after the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.
In an unusual twist, the two sides talked far less about the details of the new accord than about the importance of reaching an agreement early to help calm the city's frayed nerves. The negotiators voiced fears that if a contract dispute erupted into a strike, it could increase the number tenants thinking of leaving Manhattan after the terrorist attack.
As part of the tentative agreement, which must still be voted on by the rank and file, nearly 30,000 janitors, handymen and elevator operators will receive a 9.5 percent wage increase over three years. Wages for janitors, already the highest in the nation, will rise to $763.92 a week at the end of the contract, which calls for annual raises of $21, $22 and $23 per week in consecutive years.
In addition, the real estate industry agreed to increase its health insurance contribution by more than $1,000 per worker per year by the end of the agreement. The industry, which currently pays $105.51 per worker year for insurance, will increase its weekly payment to $129.51 per worker, meaning an annual contribution per worker of $6,735.
James F. Berg, president of the Realty Advisory Board on Labor Relations, an association of building owners and managers, estimated that when improvements in fringe benefits were included, the contract translated into a 3.8 percent annual increase in compensation.
Some labor experts said that management gave the workers slightly more than might have been expected because it was so intent on insuring labor peace in a time of stress and uncertainty, when Manhattan's real estate vacancy rate is rising and some businesses are threatening to leave. But because of such unusual factors, the contract might not have much influence on other labor contracts negotiated in New York.
"This is a good example of labor-management cooperation," said Esta R. Bigler, director of the New York City campus of the Cornell School of Industrial and Labor Relations.
"Given the economic situation we're facing in the city, a contract of more than 3 percent a year for three years looks like an excellent contract for the union."
After Sept. 11, the union, Local 32B-32J of the Service Employees International Union, and the real estate industry agreed to seek to speed up negotiations to prevent their usual December tensions.
Michael Fishman, president of the Local 32B-32J, said, "With the instability in the market and people packing up for the suburbs, stability is very important, and this contract helps achieve stability."
The two sides signed the agreement yesterday after the union's 500-person contract advisory team overwhelmingly approved the deal. The union will mail ballots to all its employees working in New York City commercial buildings later this month.
To keep the negotiations from deadlocking, the two sides took off the table many issues that they had usually wrestled over right up until deadline. For instance, management was so eager for a settlement that it decided not to insist on increasing the amount of square footage each janitor was expected to clean -- an issue that management had traditionally dug in on.
The agreement also includes increases in pension benefits and in the employers' contribution to workers' 401(k)'s.
In an unusual provision, the real estate industry agreed to contribute $2 million to a training fund that would be used for management and workers to develop better security procedures for matters like handling mail and responding to threats.
Kenneth Patton, a member of management's negotiating committee, said: "Usually negotiations are us against them. But it's different now. There's a recognition that the well-being of the tenants and of the city is the overarching concern."
Local 32B-32J and the industry have developed a stronger relationship in recent years. Most recently, the union and management agreed to far-reaching steps to help more than a thousand janitors, security guards and others who lost their jobs when the World Trade Center was destroyed.
Management pledged to work with the union to provide the workers with health insurance and supplemental unemployment insurance equal to 80 percent of their gross pay for six months.
Several dozen cleaning contractors also agreed to give preference to laid-off janitors in future hiring.
