HEADLINE: Shift From Food Stamps To Private Aid Widens 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
Five years after the government scaled back its responsibility for the poor, more people get food from private charities over the course of the year than participate in the federal government's food stamp program, according to a yearlong survey to be released on Wednesday.
 Emergency feeding sites around the country serve more than 7 million people in a given week, the survey found, and more than 23 million people at some point in the course of a year obtain food from food pantries, soup kitchens and shelters, most of them run by religious charities. Four years ago, a similar survey found 21.4 million Americans using private food charity. 
 During the same time, 17.7 million people used federal food stamps, a drop from the 21.9 million who received food stamps in 1997, according to the Agriculture Department. 
The survey was conducted on behalf of America's Second Harvest, a national network of nonprofit food banks that provides 80 percent of the food distributed by private charities.
While the Agriculture Department does not keep records on a weekly basis, there is no dispute that fewer people are using food stamps and more people are turning to private food aid. But the food stamp program still provides far more food in a given year than the private food emergency network.
"People are now turning to us as an alternative, a replacement when we had considered ourselves a back-up or emergency system," said Douglas O'Brien, director of public policy and research at Second Harvest.
In New York City, the number of people who in the course of a year obtained at least some emergency food relief tripled in the last four years, to 1.5 million this year from 425,000 in 1997, surveys showed. Those figures mean one out of five New Yorkers was visiting food pantries or soup kitchens this year.
"These figures really underscore the enormity of the hunger crisis that existed well before Sept. 11," said Lucy Cabrera, president of Food for Survival Inc., a New York food bank.
Since then, Dr. Cabrera said her group had seen a decrease in individual contributions, while demand had grown to 6.4 million pounds of food in October from 4 million pounds a month. 
The report presents this portrait of hunger in the nation: Instead of homeless people dying of starvation on the streets, hungry Americans are working families, skimping on food to meet their monthly bills. They are children whose parents eat the family leftovers. They are the elderly poor, rural and suburban Americans, and the permanently unemployed who scrape together government payments like Social Security and food stamps.
And it includes people who have been dropped from federal social services since the 1996 welfare overhaul and are finding their sole support in the lines at food pantries and hot meals served in churches.
By coincidence, the survey is being released as Congress debates the $171 billion farm bill, which includes reauthorization of the food stamp program.
The food stamp program was cut by $26 billion over six years in the last farm bill as part of the welfare overhaul. Congress also instituted more stringent rules to reduce fraud in the program. That led many states to increase the paperwork required to receive food stamps, which helped discourage as many as 12 million eligible people from applying for food stamps. 
Even before this survey, lawmakers said the food stamp program needed to be strengthened to help the poor deal with the recent economic downturn.
The question is whether to increase financing by $3.6 billion over 10 years, as recommended by the House, or by $6.2 billion or $10 billion, proposals that are under consideration in the Senate this week. Congress is also trying to simplify the rules for receiving food stamps so more people will take advantage of the program.
The survey by Mathematica Policy Research of more than 32,700 people receiving private food aid and 24,000 local agencies providing it nationwide painted this picture of the people receiving private food aid:
*Women account for nearly two-thirds of the adults receiving emergency food aid. 
*Nearly half of the households receiving aid included children. 
*People receiving food stamps made up nearly one-third of those seeking emergency food aid. They said their food stamps covered only half their monthly need, on average.
*Half the people receiving food aid said they were regularly forced to choose between buying food or paying for utilities or heat.
*Working families made up 40 percent of people receiving food aid.
Further propelling the shift toward private relief aid was the Bush administration's initiative to encourage religious charities to provide more social services.
Not surprisingly, religious groups, which run most of the food pantries and kitchens, strongly support increasing money for food stamps. 
"We think there is no substitute for a strong food stamp program," said the Rev. David Beckman, president of Bread for the World, a group made up of Protestant and Roman Catholic churches. "It is much better for kids to have their Mom and Dad serve them food around the table rather than drag them into a food kitchen. And I'm not sure we churches, synagogues and mosques can keep up with the demand."
Doug Besharov, an expert on welfare at the American Enterprise Institute, said private food programs were unfairly burdened because they were often the only help available for the poor. He argued that in some instances, particularly the elderly, they might need money to pay utility bills, rather than more food stamps.
"I'm uncomfortable about anyone being hungry, but the question now is how do we fix it without making it worse," he said. "Sometimes the food program is the wrong program to look for the fix."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Private food charities like the Community Kitchen at 252 West 116th Street in Manhattan are filling gaps left by scaled-back federal aid. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 587: THE DOMINICAN REPUBLIC; 
Strong New York Ties Bind Families in Grief

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: BANI, DOMINICAN REPUBLIC, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
The 15 years that Diego Lugo owned several bodegas in Brooklyn left him scarred with bullet holes in his arm, his leg and his head from three violent robberies. It was the price he paid for a better life, working 12-hour days alongside his wife, Ramona Pimentel, as they saved money to return in 1997 to this town, which they had fled after Hurricane David devastated the island and its economy.
 Today, however, the spacious two-story home that they had built selling beer, soda and cigarettes is desolate. The candles they had planned to light Monday night to celebrate their common birthday instead were replaced by a solitary votive light. Mr. Lugo sat sobbing in a wheelchair, trembling at the fact that Ramona, his wife of 36 years, died on American Airlines flight 587, returning home after a brief, but regular, visit with her stateside relatives. 
 "Fifteen years working in New York for nothing," Mr. Lugo cried, railing at God and his misfortune. "I lost my partner, that is all I accomplished. The greatest thing I had in my life was her. All I want is for God to take me and end this life."
The sorrow inside his house was shared among many residents of this town of about 57,000, 41 miles west of Santo Domingo, where officials estimated at least 15 of their neighbors perished in the crash. The toll reflected both the financial lure of New York City for these scrappy people as well their enduring love for their homeland. 
Those twin tugs were evident in the pastel-colored cinder-block homes built with dollars from New York, or stores that sold Dominican flag bumper stickers alongside books with titles like "Learn English to Earn Money." In an age of cheap flights and easy phone calls, New York was as familiar to them as any Dominican village.
On a street corner near the town plaza, dozens of people clustered around a passenger list mounted on a propped-up sandwich board, nervously pointing to names and gasping or refusing to believe that a friend had died. Many long-lost sons and daughters in self-imposed exile were returning here to celebrate the nine days of feasts, music and processions in honor of the town's patron, La Virgen de Regla. Instead, there will be nine days of rosaries.
"This city has a deep feeling for New York, since there is not a single family here without a relative there," said Radames Altagracia, an adviser to the mayor. "New York is a place of hope. There you can resolve all your economic problems. But you always return here, to your home."
Mr. Lugo was used to coming home in his 28 years as a sailor, first with the Dominican Navy and later with the Dominican Merchant Marine. Ramona, was always there to greet him at dockside, eagerly scampering on board to embrace him. But in the early 1980's he decided on one last adventure, to New York, where many of his countrymen had ventured into the bodega business that had helped a previous generation of Puerto Rican migrants achieve their modest dream -- an education for their children and a house back home as their reward.
He borrowed from a cooperative, sometimes selling his store when sales soured or rents increased. In 1987, Ramona joined him in Brooklyn, where they finally settled by the mid-1990's in an apartment above their bodega on Tompkins Avenue and Quincy Street in Bedford-Stuyvesant.
Though they were robbed at gunpoint several times, Mr. Lugo and his wife clung to their dream of saving enough money to return to Bani triumphant, not defeated. But in 1997, robbers shot Mr. Lugo and beat his wife. He spent 15 days in Kings County Hospital, his second time there, just as previous robberies had landed him at Woodhull Hospital and in other emergency rooms.
"She begged me to leave the business and never return to New York," Mr. Lugo said. "So I took a loss and abandoned it."
Their home is roomy and neat, with a huge kitchen and bright bedrooms, built over the years as their savings allowed. She returned to New York every year, to visit family and renew her American residency papers, always coming to back to Bani with presents for her grandchildren.
Today, the children are quiet and the adults are dazed.
"All those years of sacrifice, all those bodegas, and this house here is from the little success they enjoyed," said her sister, Josefina Pimentel. 
A few blocks away, Jose Hilton Sanchez and his brother Elvis had grown up with the idea of moving to New York, too. They had been there more than 10 years already, working at a bodega their uncle owned on 134th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Jose had already grown tired of the city and was looking to come back. Elvis was a little more adventurous, and wanted to stay a while longer, though both were headed to Bani for the religious festival and an early Christmas holiday.
"They went to New York aspiring to get something and return to their country," said their mother, Altagracia Sanchez. "I cannot say they accomplished a lot, because the economy is bad everywhere you go. But Jose was coming back, hoping to buy a house."
Silence has descended upon the town plaza, where a stage sits empty as the country mourns until Friday. Vendors who had stocked up on food, drinks and toys, wait for customers to return. Some murmured that the crash was divine retribution for some neighbors who went to New York to sell drugs or make trouble. Others asked if this might not humble those who returned here to lord over their less fortunate neighbors. Some of them said they would never want to go to New York now, not after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 or Monday's plane crash, which they refuse to believe was an accident.
But Jose Ramirez sat by his stall, which overflowed with unsold toy trucks and dolls, thinking of Washington Heights, a place as storied to him as the Lower East Side was to European Jews a century ago.
"We Dominicans will never stop going to New York," he declared. "Here, we find nothing. There you struggle, but your get money. Everything and everybody is over there. If someone asked me, I jump up and leave right now."

HEADLINE: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 587: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS; 
A Plane Crash Deeply Wounds a City's Dominican Heart

BYLINE:  By MIREYA NAVARRO 

 BODY:
Washington Heights had a facade of normalcy about it yesterday. Traffic was bumper-to-bumper on Broadway. Schools and bodegas were open. Beauty salons and lunch counters were full.
 But behind the bustle, the city's Dominican heartland was in deep mourning. 
 Some signs were quiet. There was the post office at West 180th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue, where the flag flew at half-staff. And the hair salon on Broadway and W. 175th Street, with a mirror with two black ribbon wreaths taped to it. 
Other signs were less subdued. At Alianza Dominicana, the social service agency, Rosa Mota gave her sobbing cousin, Luna Estrella Soto, a tight hug to ease the pain of the loss of her brother, Daniel Estrella Soto. At the makeshift memorials that sprung up on sidewalks, passers-by gathered, some gasping as they recognized their neighbor's face in a photograph.
At one memorial, at the corner of West 163rd Street and Amsterdam Avenue, a large picture of "La Virgen de Altagracia," the Dominican Republic's patron saint, watched over dozens of votive candles that had been dropped off by neighbors like Yolanda Frias, 74, who had not lost family or friends on American Airlines Flight 587 but nevertheless broke into tears at the news of its crash.
"We may not be friends but in this neighborhood we know each other by sight," she said. "These were human beings, all lost in a matter of three minutes. It's so unbelievable."
But even in this upper Manhattan neighborhood, some people wondered whether the catastrophic events of Sept. 11 had somehow dulled the grieving over Flight 587. They said residents already seemed sadder and more reflective since the terrorist attacks, a mood that perhaps made this latest horrifying episode less convulsive than it would have been otherwise.
"People are in another world," said Alexandra Reyes, whose family owns "Botanica Reyes," a shop that sells herbal remedies and religious paraphernalia and has done a brisk business on candles since the World Trade Center attacks. "They are preoccupied, pensive. It's like, 'We're all going to go.' People are praying more than ever."
While Washington Heights suffered losses from the World Trade Center attack like the rest of New York, this time it took a more direct hit, feeling the impact of the crash almost as instantaneously as Belle Harbor, the Queens neighborhood where the Santo Domingo-bound plane fell. The majority of the 260 people on board were of Dominican descent, many of them with addresses in this working-class section, which has the highest concentration of Dominicans in the city.
This time, amid the American flags that hang from windows and lampposts, the candles in vigils and sidewalk memorials burn for compatriots who were livery-cab drivers and small-shop owners, laborers and professionals, all making a living in New York with one foot planted firmly in the homeland.
A candlelight vigil at J. Hood Wright Park last night drew about 200 people, including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. He told the gathering he would work with the Rockaway Peninsula and Washington Heights communities to organize a memorial service next week.
"I think it would be a beautiful thing for this city if we could bring both communities together so that we could all pray together and show how united we are," he said to loud applause.
The disaster took a heavy toll in the public schools of the area, where most of the 29,000 students in District 6 are Dominican. The ripple effect was also felt at the F&P Food Market on West 184th Street, where owner Ruth Paez mourned the death of a customer, Felix Gervacio, 36, who bought calling cards to telephone his family in the Caribbean and had wanted to marry a friend of hers.
"How's that girl?" he would ask Ms. Paez, even after he was turned down.
At the Church of the Incarnation Roman Catholic Church on St. Nicholas Avenue, a memorial Mass for the community was planned for Nov. 20. 
More than a third of Dominican households in the city are poor and more than three-fourths are headed by people born in the Dominican Republic, the latest census data shows. But a community whose immigration started in earnest in the 1960's also has established business and social institutions that now have been called on to help residents cope with the loss of many family breadwinners.
An estimated 25 percent of the about 500,000 Dominicans in the city live in the area encompassing Washington Heights and neighboring Inwood, according to the Census Bureau.
"Unemployment is so large here," said the Rev. Ricardo Fajardo of St. Catherine's of Genova Roman Catholic Church on West 143rd Street, where a Sunday Mass is planned for the victims.
"The families will need help with rent and food to survive." said Father Fajardo.
Alianza Dominicana, which is playing a key role in comforting victims and directing them to government assistance and had helped more than 60 families by noon yesterday, and the Rev. Ruben Diaz, head of a Bronx ministry, announced the formation of a fund, "Aid to the Victims of Flight 587" to provide families with long-term help.
And officials with the Dominican Republic Consul General office in Times Square said the Dominican Republic had established a commission on Monday to assist families and investigate the crash. The consulate was negotiating with American Airlines to transport bodies to the Dominican Republic while Senator Charles E. Schumer said he had received a commitment from the Justice Department to expedite visas for family members who want to travel to New York to attend funerals.
David Rivas of Rivas Travel, a travel agency in the area that sold 20 tickets for the ill-fated flight and does $4 million in annual ticket sales to the Dominican Republic, said that business was normal and agents had registered few cancellations for future American Airlines flights. He said the airline had changed the flight number from 587 to 619.
Some said life was hardly normal anymore.
"Friends of friends died in the crash," said Humberto Rivas, an empanada vendor.
"I'm telling you, this community is in pain," he said. "We just don't understand it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mourners held a vigil last night at 173rd Street and Fort Washington Avenue, in the heart of an area where a quarter of the city's Dominicans live. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Survey Finds Tougher Lending Practices by Banks 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
Banks imposed tougher standards on business and consumer loans over the last three months because of the slowing economy, a Federal Reserve survey of bank loan officers showed today. Loan demand also fell.
 The survey found that 28 of the 57 banks surveyed had "tightened somewhat" the availability of loans to large and midsize companies with sales of at least $50 million a year. One had tightened its standards "considerably," and 28 had not changed their policies, the Fed said. 
 The Fed reported that 14 of 22 foreign-based banks operating in the United States "tightened somewhat" over the last three months, while one had "tightened considerably." Six foreign banks had not changed their policies, and one had relaxed the availability of credit somewhat.
"All survey respondents," the Fed said, "pointed to a less favorable or more uncertain economic outlook as at least a somewhat important reason for changing their commercial lending policies."
John Moore, an analyst at Wachovia Securities, said banks had slowed lending to some industries, like airlines and textiles, more than to others. "The quality of the borrower is not what it was a year ago," Mr. Moore said, citing the weak economy as the reason banks are more reluctant to lend. 
One in five banks in the new survey reported that they had tightened standards for credit card and other consumer loans over the three months, the Fed said. But standards for approving residential mortgages did not change in the period. The Fed said that 25 percent of banks surveyed reported weaker demand for consumer loans.
The Fed reported that the percentage of domestic banks that reported tighter lending standards for business loans had risen to 51 percent in October, from 40 percent in August. The percentage of United States branches of foreign banks that tightened standards rose to 64 percent in October from 50 percent in August.
Among its findings, the Fed reported that more than 70 percent of domestic banks reported weaker demand for commercial loans from large and midsize companies, up from 50 percent in August.
Banks cited less demand for capital to finance capital expenditures and a decline in mergers and acquisitions and inventory as a reason for the drop in demand, the Fed said.

HEADLINE: Trade Officials, Feeling Pressure to Avert a Damaging Setback, Extend Talks in Qatar 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: DOHA, Qatar, Wednesday, Nov. 14 

 BODY:
Representatives of 142 nations wrangled into the early morning today, past their deadline to reach agreement on a comprehensive plan to liberalize world trade.
 The negotiations are widely seen as crucial to stimulating the global economy and restoring confidence in the trading system, which suffered a severe blow two years ago when similar talks collapsed in Seattle. 
 Ministers here said their willingness to continue talks suggested an agreement remained within reach. But the possibility of failure continued to hover over the discussions, which bogged down over food-export subsidies and environmental and investment rules. 
The participants, exhausted by five days of nearly nonstop haggling, still tried to forge compromises on core trade issues that have been on the agenda for years. One incentive to continue discussions is a common feeling that a setback could damage prospects for economic recovery and potentially reduce the rate of growth in trade that powered the world economy in the 1990's.
There is also concern about the viability of the World Trade Organization itself, the umbrella trade body that depends on consensus agreements by its members to work toward freer trade.
"If we fail, this is the end of the W.T.O.," the agriculture minister of Brazil, Marcus Pratini de Moraes, said. "You fight recession with more trade, not with less trade."
The talks snagged for many hours on the sensitive issue of payments to European farmers, which at midnight, the French trade minister, Francois Huwart, called a "deal breaker." Nearly all parties had agreed that unless Europe promises to eliminate some $4 billion in annual export payments to its farmers, the talks will collapse.
But by this morning, Europe had accepted revised language in a draft text on agriculture in exchange for a proposal to conduct broader negotiations on environmental issues involved in trade, only to have the negotiations run into a fresh obstacle. India, which has strongly opposed beginning any negotiations on environmental issues, rejected the compromise, as did some African nations, leaving the talks in limbo nine hours after the deadline had passed.
Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, had already given ground on two trade issues that are highly sensitive to American businesses -- revising patent rules and allowing talks on antidumping measures. Those compromises propelled negotiations into the final stages and put heavy pressure on Europe, the other main proponent of global negotiations, to offer its own sacrifices.
Mr. Zoellick focused today on helping Europe win benefits in some contested areas that would allow it to claim success at the talks even after compromising on the farm question. Among these is Europe's desire to begin negotiations on competition and investment issues as well as the environment.
Critics fear that any attempt to dictate laws or regulations in those areas would intrude on sovereignty of nations and give a big advantage to large multinational companies.
But agreeing on talks about these so-called "new issues" -- even vaguely worded commitment to begin studying their relationship to trade -- was seen as pivotal to give Europeans the political cover they need.
"There's a sense that our issues are settled," an American trade official said. "Bob is spending his day on Europe."
It is not clear, however, that European concerns were the only remaining barrier.
The United States has come under pressure to accelerate reducing tariffs and increasing quotas on textiles and clothing, an issue of special importance to India, Pakistan and some southeast Asian nations.
Mr. Zoellick has already offered to make textiles and clothing a subject of negotiations in future years. But he has so far rejected demands to take immediate steps to increase market access for developing countries. There is some sentiment here that the United States may have to offer more on textiles as part of a multifaceted tradeoff in the final hours.
Some delegates also say India, which until China's entry into the trade group this weekend was the most populous and most influential developing country, has so far refused to accept any element of the proposed negotiating agenda. Its commerce minister, Murasoli Maran, "has just said no to everything," an American trade official said.
India has warned for months that it opposes a new round of talks, because, it says, developing countries have yet to receive the full benefits promised them earlier. But after days of talks, most other poor nations say they have a great deal to gain from the proposals under discussion here.
An American trade official said he was confident that India would not say no to new talks if it was faced with a "binary choice," meaning that it would not want to be seen as the one to veto the agenda if others agreed. But Indian officials have so far said little to justify that optimism.
The ministers have reached some significant agreements. On Monday, they settled an emotional battle over rules on drug patents that pitted African nations, as well as Brazil and India, against Switzerland, United States and some other industrial countries.
Some poor nations, backed by an aggressive campaign by health advocates, have argued that international rules to protect intellectual property have kept the price of essential medicines too high, making it impossible for the poor to afford lifesaving treatments for epidemic diseases like AIDS and malaria.
Drug companies, backed at times by the United States, argue that patents were not the problem and that the trade rules already allowed nations to violate patents if they faced health emergencies. The standoff exploded into an ideological North-South dispute over whether trade took precedence over the lives of the poor. 
The United States and several African nations agreed to a compromise on Monday, a settlement that was finished today, in the form of a political declaration that makes it clear that patents will not stand in the way of public health. 
Some drug companies complained that the implied exception to patent rules was too broad, reducing their incentive to develop medicines for the poorest countries.

HEADLINE: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; 
Turning Away From the Holocaust

BYLINE:  By MAX FRANKEL; Max Frankel is a former executive editor of The Times.

 BODY:
AND then there was failure: none greater than the staggering, staining failure of The New York Times to depict Hitler's methodical extermination of the Jews of Europe as a horror beyond all other horrors in World War II -- a Nazi war within the war crying out for illumination.
 The annihilation of six million Jews would not for many years become distinctively known as the Holocaust. But its essence became knowable fast enough, from ominous Nazi threats and undisputed eyewitness reports collected by American correspondents, agents and informants. Indeed, a large number of those reports appeared in The Times. But they were mostly buried inside its gray and stolid pages, never featured, analyzed or rendered truly comprehensible. 
 Yet what they printed made clear that the editors did not long mistrust the ghastly reports. They presented them as true within months of Hitler's secret resolve in 1941 to proceed to the "final solution" of his fantasized "Jewish problem." 
Why, then, were the terrifying tales almost hidden in the back pages? Like most -- though not all -- American media, and most of official Washington, The Times drowned its reports about the fate of Jews in the flood of wartime news. Its neglect was far from unique and its reach was not then fully national, but as the premier American source of wartime news, it surely influenced the judgment of other news purveyors.
While a few publications -- newspapers like The Post (then liberal) and PM in New York and magazines like The Nation and The New Republic -- showed more conspicuous concern, The Times's coverage generally took the view that the atrocities inflicted upon Europe's Jews, while horrific, were not significantly different from those visited upon tens of millions of other war victims, nor more noteworthy.

Six Years, Six Page 1 Articles
Only six times in nearly six years did The Times's front page mention Jews as Hitler's unique target for total annihilation. Only once was their fate the subject of a lead editorial. Only twice did their rescue inspire passionate cries in the Sunday magazine.
Although The Times's news columns in those years did not offer as much analysis or synthesis as they do today, the paper took great pride in ranking the importance of events each morning and in carefully reviewing the major news of every week and every year. How could it happen that the war on the Jews never qualified for such highlighted attention?
There is no surviving record of how the paper's coverage of the subject was discussed by Times editors during the war years of 1939-45. But within that coverage is recurring evidence of a guiding principle: do not feature the plight of Jews, and take care, when reporting it, to link their suffering to that of many other Europeans.
This reticence has been a subject of extensive scholarly inquiry and also much speculation and condemnation. Critics have blamed "self-hating Jews" and "anti-Zionists" among the paper's owners and staff. Defenders have cited the sketchiness of much information about the death camps in Eastern Europe and also the inability of prewar generations to fully comprehend the industrial gassing of millions of innocents -- a machinery of death not yet exposed by those chilling mounds of Jews' bones, hair, shoes, rings.
No single explanation seems to suffice for what was surely the century's bitterest journalistic failure. The Times, like most media of that era, fervently embraced the wartime policies of the American and British governments, both of which strongly resisted proposals to rescue Jews or to offer them haven. After a decade of economic depression, both governments had political reasons to discourage immigration and diplomatic reasons to refuse Jewish settlements in regions like Palestine.
Then, too, papers owned by Jewish families, like The Times, were plainly afraid to have a society that was still widely anti-Semitic misread their passionate opposition to Hitler as a merely parochial cause. Even some leading Jewish groups hedged their appeals for rescue lest they be accused of wanting to divert wartime energies.
At The Times, the reluctance to highlight the systematic slaughter of Jews was also undoubtedly influenced by the views of the publisher, Arthur Hays Sulzberger. He believed strongly and publicly that Judaism was a religion, not a race or nationality -- that Jews should be separate only in the way they worshiped. He thought they needed no state or political and social institutions of their own. He went to great lengths to avoid having The Times branded a "Jewish newspaper." He resented other publications for emphasizing the Jewishness of people in the news.
And it was his policy, on most questions, to steer The Times toward the centrist values of America's governmental and intellectual elites. Because his editorial page, like the American government and other leading media, refused to dwell on the Jews' singular victimization, it was cool to all measures that might have singled them out for rescue or even special attention.
Only once did The Times devote its lead editorial to the subject. That was on Dec. 2, 1942, after the State Department had unofficially confirmed to leading rabbis that two million Jews had already been slain and that five million more were indeed "in danger of extermination." Even that editorial, however, retreated quickly from any show of special concern. Insisting in its title that Jews were merely "The First to Suffer," it said the same fate awaited "people of other faiths and of many races," including "our own 'mongrel' nation" and even Hitler's allies in Japan if he were to win the war.
In only one 48-hour period, in early March 1943, was the paper moved to concede in multiple ways that Europe's Jews merited extraordinary attention. The impetus apparently came from Anne O'Hare McCormick, the foreign affairs columnist, a favorite of Sulzberger and a member of his editorial board, who thought that a Madison Square Garden rally pleading for the rescue of Jews had exposed "the shame of the world."
"There is not the slightest question," she wrote, "that the persecution of the Jews has reached its awful climax in a campaign to wipe them out of Europe. If the Christian community does not support to the utmost the belated proposal worked out to rescue the Jews remaining in Europe from the fate prepared for them, we have accepted the Hitlerian thesis and forever compromised the principles for which we are pouring out blood and wealth."
Beside her column on March 3, the last of seven editorials allowed that Hitler had condemned the Jews to death "where others are sometimes let off with slavery." Vaguely urging the United States to revise "the chilly formalism of its immigration regulations," it urged other free nations to let no "secondary considerations" bar entry of those refugees who might yet escape from the Nazis' control.
On the previous day, that same Garden rally was described in an exceptional half-page article, beginning with three paragraphs on Page 1 under the smallest of 11 front-page headlines:
SAVE DOOMED JEWS,
HUGE RALLY PLEADS
As never before or after, that day's coverage included long quotations from speeches and even the text of the rally's "resolution" calling for urgent measures to move Jews out of Hitler's grasp.
When more than a year later the editorial page returned to the subject and supported the idea of temporarily housing refugees in isolated American camps, it urged saving "innocent people" without ever using the word "Jew."
On its dense inside pages, however, The Times was much less hesitant about offering persuasive and gruesome details of the systematic murders of Jews. Hundreds of short items and scores of longer articles from different corners of Europe bore out the prophetic dispatch from the Berlin bureau that had appeared on Page 5 on Sept. 13, 1939, two weeks after Hitler invaded Poland:
NAZIS HINT PURGE
OF JEWS IN POLAND
"First intimations," it began, "that a solution of the 'Jewish problem' in Poland is on the German-Polish agenda are revealed in a 'special report' of the official German News Bureau." Given the report's claim that Polish Jewry "continually fortified and enlarged" Western Jewry, the Times correspondent added, it was hard to see how their "removal" would change things "without their extermination."
On March 1, 1942, just seven weeks after the notorious Wannsee Conference distributed orders about the mass-murder weapons to be used against Jews, an article on Page 28 bore this headline:
EXTINCTION FEARED
BY JEWS IN POLAND
Polish intellectuals and officials cited underground sources for the warning that 3.5 million Jews stood condemned "to cruel death -- to complete annihilation."
By June 13, the threat became official: "Nazis Blame Jews/For Big Bombings" read a headline on Page 7. The accompanying article quoted Joseph Goebbels as vowing that the Jews would pay for German suffering "with the extermination of their race in all Europe and perhaps even beyond Europe."
Two weeks later, two paragraphs appended to the end of a related article brought the news that "probably the greatest mass slaughter in history" had already claimed the lives of 700,000 Jews in Poland -- a slaughter employing "machine-gun bullets, hand grenades, gas chambers, concentration camps, whipping, torture instruments and starvation." By June 30, a brief item said the World Jewish Congress put the death toll at one million.
Still greater detail followed, on Page 6 of the July 2 issue, in a London report quoting the Polish government in exile. It cited the use of gas chambers to kill 1,000 Jews a day in different cities and the staging of a blood bath in the Warsaw ghetto. It said that "the criminal German government is fulfilling Hitler's threat that, whoever wins, all Jews will be murdered." Typically, the headline, "Allies Are Urged/To Execute Nazis," was no larger than that on a neighboring article about a Polish diplomat who died in a plunge on Riverside Drive.

Extermination Order on Page 10
On Nov. 25, a lengthy London dispatch on Page 10 cited roundups, gassings, cattle cars and the disappearance of 90 percent of Warsaw's ghetto population. It said Heinrich Himmler, the Gestapo head, had ordered the extermination of half of Poland's Jews before the end of 1942.
That same month, the State Department finally conceded that it had confirmed the extermination campaign but insisted that the Allies were helpless to prevent it. By Dec. 9, 1942, President Franklin D. Roosevelt was reported on Page 20 to have promised Jewish petitioners eventual punishment of the Nazi murderers. He was told that "the scientific and low-cost extermination" had claimed almost two million lives. There followed a rare front-page notice, on Dec. 18, under the smallest of a dozen headlines: "11 Allies Condemn/Nazi War on Jews." A brief editorial that day observed that this protest responded not just to the outcry of victims but to "officially established facts."
For once, The Times Magazine now felt free to offer a passionate plea for Europe's Jews. A brief essay by the novelist Sholem Asch on Feb. 7, 1943, recounted "the inhuman process of transportation in sealed, unventilated, limed freight cars, which are death traps."
"Those that survive," he wrote, "become as human waste to be thrown into mass-slaughter houses."
The magazine's next and last article on the subject, by Arthur Koestler on June 9, 1944, dealt mainly with the difficulty of comprehending "the greatest mass killing in recorded history."
Yet comparable emotion appeared in The Times only in a half dozen large advertisements pleading for "ACTION -- NOT PITY!" They were from groups urging the rescue of Jews or the formation of an avenging Jewish army in Palestine. Only passing notice recorded the mounting Jewish death toll: 3 million in August 1943, 4 million in July 1944, 5.5 million in November 1944.

Never the Lead Article of the Day
No article about the Jews' plight ever qualified as The Times's leading story of the day, or as a major event of a week or year. The ordinary reader of its pages could hardly be blamed for failing to comprehend the enormity of the Nazis' crime.
As Laurel Leff, an assistant professor at the Northeastern School of Journalism, has concluded, it was a tragic demonstration of how "the facts didn't speak for themselves." She has been the most diligent independent student of The Times's Holocaust coverage and deftly summarized her findings last year in The Harvard International Journal of Press/Politics.
"You could have read the front page of The New York Times in 1939 and 1940," she wrote, "without knowing that millions of Jews were being sent to Poland, imprisoned in ghettos, and dying of disease and starvation by the tens of thousands. You could have read the front page in 1941 without knowing that the Nazis were machine-gunning hundreds of thousands of Jews in the Soviet Union.
"You could have read the front page in 1942 and not have known, until the last month, that the Germans were carrying out a plan to annihilate European Jewry. In 1943, you would have been told once that Jews from France, Belgium and the Netherlands were being sent to slaughterhouses in Poland and that more than half of the Jews of Europe were dead, but only in the context of a single story on a rally by Jewish groups that devoted more space to who had spoken than to who had died.
"In 1944, you would have learned from the front page of the existence of horrible places such as Maidanek and Auschwitz, but only inside the paper could you find that the victims were Jews. In 1945, liberated Dachau and Buchenwald were on the front page, but the Jews were buried inside."
A story buried but not, over time, forgotten.
After the Nazis' slaughter of Jews was fully exposed at war's end, Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger, the influential daughter, wife and mother of Times publishers, changed her mind about the need for a Jewish state and helped her husband, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, accept the idea of Israel and befriend its leaders. Later, led by their son, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, and their grandson Arthur Sulzberger Jr., The Times shed its sensitivity about its Jewish roots, allowed Jews to ascend to the editor's chair and warmly supported Israel in many editorials.
And to this day the failure of America's media to fasten upon Hitler's mad atrocities stirs the conscience of succeeding generations of reporters and editors. It has made them acutely alert to ethnic barbarities in far-off places like Uganda, Rwanda, Bosnia and Kosovo. It leaves them obviously resolved that in the face of genocide, journalism shall not have failed in vain.

GRAPHIC: Photos: DEAD, AND BURIED: On April 20, 1943, a Page 1 article about a conference on the "refugee problem" said nothing about Jews and asserted, inside, that refugees were being considered part of "a broad group," regardless of their religion. The execution of two million Jews was reported in an appended article of five paragraphs. During the height of the war, photographs of the Nazi death camps were not widely available; the one at top accompanied an article published in 1989.

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section H; Column 1; Special Section; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 3738 words

HEADLINE: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; 
150 and Counting: The Story So Far

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. McFADDEN; Robert D. McFadden is a senior writer on the metropolitan staff of The Times.

 BODY:
BEGINNINGS are apt to be inauspicious, and so they were in 1851 with Henry Jarvis Raymond's little newspaper. But over the last 150 years, as the nation endured wars, depressions and often painful political, economic and cultural growth, that paper survived competitive challenges, even brushes with death, and prospered beyond its founders' wildest dreams.
 As it marks its sesquicentennial this week, The New York Times -- centerpiece of a $3.5 billion conglomerate of newspapers, magazines, radio and television stations and Internet sites -- is widely regarded as America's most influential newspaper. Its news-gathering operations employ 1,000 journalists in New York and in dozens of domestic and foreign bureaus. Nearly 1.2 million daily copies of the paper -- nearly 1.7 million on Sundays -- are distributed in 200 metropolitan areas across the nation, and the readers are among the best-educated, most affluent people in America. 
 Destiny? Surely not. The Times's evolution is a complex and paradoxical story, of steadfastness and willingness to change, of owners and their staffs espousing core values of fairness, accuracy and impartiality, while evolving their ideas of who the readers are and what they want and need, in adapting to new technologies and in redefining fundamental concepts of the news and how to present it. Indeed, The Times has redefined and reinvented itself many times. 
In recent years, Times readers have become accustomed to a supermarket of information in a big multisection paper packed with world, national, suburban and city news and a panoply of sports, business, arts, entertainment, science and other subjects. There is something for everyone, stylishly written. Page 1 is a sharp focus on a complicated world; it carries only six or seven articles, news and illuminating features, with color pictures and graphics, all placed and sized to show the weight accorded by editors to current events. Most readers of The Times, already aware of breaking news from broadcast and Internet sources, want and are given news in depth, often with analysis and interpretation.

Lots of Facts and Long Sentences
But for much of the 20th century, The Times rather aloofly regarded itself as America's paper of record and presented the news as if from on high. It was solidly reported and accurate, but was a daunting compendium of facts recited on pages of unrelieved seriousness. Coverage was heavy on government and world affairs, but short on analysis; the writing was ponderous, with long sentences and dangling phrases. Humor was rare, as if it lacked significance. Politics was written for politicians, not voters. A typical front page was a picket fence of narrow columns filled with 15 or 20 articles, often without pictures or other signs of life. Inside was another gray vault, often bearing lists: market prices, arriving ships, votes in Congress, new books, out-of-town buyers -- all useful, but in what way? That was left to the reader to decide.
Until the 1920's, reporters were paid for the number of words they got into print, an arrangement that spared them the task of digesting news, encouraged them to include every last detail and sometimes masked mental laziness in a guise of thoroughness. And for most of its 19th-century history, The Times was a primitive version of journalistic responsibility -- a prudent voice that gave news impartially and authoritatively, but cast it in florid phrases and stacked it, page after page, in long columns relieved only by label headlines: "Awful Event" (Abraham Lincoln's assassination), "The Secret Accounts" (Boss Tweed's skulduggery) or simply "The News From Europe."
Raymond's Times was apparently modeled on The Times of London, known then as a wellspring of integrity, and it embodied many of the qualities that would make it famous -- an unsensational view of the news, an avoidance of partisanship and bombast, a mannerly tone and thorough reporting. Raymond also pledged to avoid bitter personal feuds, which embroiled the city's other journals and obliged some editors to face off in duels or fistfights.
Seven previous papers called The Times had failed in New York between 1813 and Sept. 18, 1851, when the New-York Daily Times was founded. Raymond's version, for all its high-mindedness, faced daunting odds in a city of 500,000 (mostly living below 14th Street), which already had dozens of papers and teemed with businesses, crowded tenements, piers lined with ships and muddy streets awash with adventurers, greenhorns, whiskey-soaked toughs and thundering preachers. The new Times lacked the bite of James Gordon Bennett's raucous Herald and the zest of Horace Greeley's Tribune. But within 10 days, it claimed a circulation of 10,000, including "the most respectable families in town." And in a year circulation had doubled, to 20,000.
The Times's excellent coverage of the Civil War added greatly to its prestige in the 1860's. While he continued to edit The Times, Raymond became an important figure in Republican politics during the war, serving as party chairman, helping Andrew Johnson secure the vice presidency and winning a term in Congress. Editors now would see such activity as a clear conflict of interest.

The Fall of Lincoln, and of Tweed
The Times extensively reported the assassination of Lincoln in 1865, including a lead article by Edwin M. Stanton, the secretary of war. Allowing a government official to write a major news article seems ridiculous; even then the press saw itself as a watchdog, not a partner, of government, but there were often egregious lapses.
While The Times was generally not a crusading paper, it began an investigation in 1870 that exposed the multimillion-dollar schemes of William Marcy Tweed, boss of the Tammany Hall Democratic organization. Ignoring death threats, bribe offers and advertising boycotts, The Times -- by now without "Daily" in its name -- published accounts of fraudulent public works contracts and toppled Tweed and his ring. The exploit became a journalistic legend.
More typically, The Times chronicled the great changes in the city as the 19th century moved toward its close: the Dickensian gloom fading as arc lamps replaced gaslight on Broadway, a new elevated train rumbling up Third Avenue, the Brooklyn Bridge being constructed high over the East River and New York's population swelling with immigrants and a host of social and economic problems.
By 1893, a depression had settled over New York, and The Times began to lose its financial advertising, a chief source of revenue. By 1896 it was $300,000 in debt, circulation had plummeted to 9,000 and it was for sale. Its life hung in the balance. Adolph S. Ochs, a young newspaperman from Chattanooga, Tenn., saw it as an opportunity and bought a controlling interest for $75,000.
It was a bold idea. At the time, the claimed circulations of the major competitors were 400,000 for The Evening World; 300,000 for The Morning Journal; 200,000, The (Morning) World; 145,000, The News; 140,000, The Herald; 130,000, The Evening Journal; 70,000, The Morning Sun; 60,000, The Evening Sun; 19,000, The Post; 18,000, The Press; 16,000, The Tribune; and 12,000 The Advertiser.
To imagine that all these newspapers, excepting The Post (the present Daily News was begun in 1919), would be dead someday and The Times pre-eminent in the world would have been madness in 1896. But the Ochs purchase was the beginning of a family ownership that not only saw it all happen but also marked its own centennial at the head of the newspaper in 1996 and is now in its fifth generation. 
Though not a journalist himself, Ochs was a deft businessman and shared the values that had sustained The Times -- a belief that readers wanted straight news, thoroughly reported, reflecting all sides in a controversy and written without the biases that infected other papers.
The Times, Ochs said, would be "an independent newspaper, entirely fearless, devoted to the public welfare without regard to individual advantage or ambition, the claims of party politics or personal prejudice or predilection." To sum it up, he coined the Page 1 motto "All the News That's Fit to Print." And he dropped the hyphen in the Times logo.
Ochs greatly expanded business and financial news, printing market prices, news on ship movements and lists of arriving out-of-town buyers useful to wholesalers and manufacturers. He began publishing real estate transactions and news on education and books, as well as the routine affairs of commerce and government. He began a letters-to-the-editor column, a poets' corner, a Saturday literary supplement and a Sunday illustrated supplement, forerunners of the Book Review and the magazine section.

Catching Einstein in an Error
In 1904, in a step that would prove crucial, Ochs hired Carr Van Anda from The Sun as managing editor. Over the next 25 years, the Ochs-Van Anda team carried The Times to new heights of achievement. A man of wide learning, Van Anda once spotted an error in a calculation by Albert Einstein and detected a forgery in a hieroglyphic supposedly 4,000 years old.
As wireless communications revolutionized the accessibility and speed of news from faraway places, The Times leaped on the advantages. In 1904, it ran news of the first naval engagement of the Russian-Japanese War in a dispatch datelined, "Off Port Arthur, On Board The Times Steamship Haimun." With the opening of the Marconi Transatlantic Wireless Service in 1907, European news grew voluminous.
By 1912, with circulation at 200,000, The Times was becoming the most important newspaper in the country. Still conservative in appearance, it rarely published pictures or used banner headlines -- except when major news broke, as it did on April 16.
"Titanic Sinks Four Hours After Hitting Iceberg," the headline declared. The article's wording was typically convoluted. "The admission that the Titanic, the biggest steamship in the world, had been sunk by an iceberg and had gone to the bottom of the Atlantic, probably carrying more than 1,400 of her passengers and crew with her, was made at the White Star Line offices, 9 Broadway, at 8:20 o'clock last night." 
The newspaper's reputation for complete, accurate coverage was solidified in World War I. Disregarding the costs of cable and travel and other reportorial expenses, and led by Edwin L. James, its chief war correspondent, The Times detailed every thrust and parry, from the first shots in Sarajevo and the sinking of the Lusitania to America's plunge into the conflict and the Treaty of Versailles, whose full text it printed exclusively.
Sparing no expense and pouring the profits back into the paper became a hallmark of the Ochs stewardship. By 1920, after 24 years, profits had totaled more than $100 million; all but $4 million had been used by Ochs to expand and improve The Times.
The paper's reserved use of big headlines and picture layouts became a standard by which readers, and even other news media, judged the relative importance of events. While other journals numbed readers with hyperbole and inflated typographical splashes day after day, The Times's approach portrayed an orderly world encompassed by a historic framework.
While The Times usually saved its displays for extraordinary events -- war and peace, elections, deaths of popes and presidents, revolutions and historic scientific exploits -- there were occasional lapses in judgment, some almost incredible. For reasons hard to explain today, perhaps something to do with manhood in a sporting age of flappers, Prohibition and soaring stock markets after the Great War, Times editors in the 1920's demonstrated an astonishing fixation on heavyweight title prizefights.

A Broken Thumb in Big Type
On July 3, 1921, a Times banner -- three lines across the top of Page 1 -- proclaimed: "Dempsey Knocks Out Carpentier in the Fourth Round; Challenger Breaks His Thumb Against Champion's Jaw; Record Crowd of 90,000 Orderly and Well Handled." Eight articles on the fight -- on the blow to the jaw, the broken thumb, demands for Dempsey's arrest, even Dempsey's telegram to his mother -- filled six of the eight columns. These displays were repeated on Sept. 24, 1926, when Gene Tunney beat Jack Dempsey for the title, and on Sept. 23, 1927, when Tunney beat Dempsey in the rematch.
In the 1920's and 30's, The Times only occasionally identified its writers with bylines; in the first 50 years of the paper's life, signed articles were almost nonexistent. Thus the Russian revolution, the Civil War, the loss of the Titanic and much of World War I were reported anonymously.
The effect was to heighten a sense of awe and mystery about the newspaper, creating an illusion that the institution, not talented journalists, was responsible for its achievements. In the 40's most war correspondents were accorded bylines for outstanding work, but much of the paper -- except columnists and critics -- was still wreathed in gray, incognito prose. Since the 50's, The Times, its institutional name forever secure, has put bylines on most major news articles by staff members. The average reader pays little attention to bylines -- although those with specialized interests often look to specialists' bylines -- but reporters value them to enhance their own standing with news sources and, to a lesser extent, for peer recognition. Reporters in a more cynical age used to say that a byline and a dime would get you a cup of coffee.
In 1935, The Times added two important innovations to its coverage. One was wirephotos -- pictures transmitted over telephone lines. The first wirephoto, of survivors of a dirigible explosion off San Francisco, amazed readers and competitors, who wondered how The Times got the picture across the country in hours.
The second addition was a weekly section reviewing the news, which grew to become much more -- a section devoted to interpretation, analysis and commentary -- as the decades passed and a glut of information threatened to swamp readers.
After Ochs died in 1935, his son-in-law, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, became publisher. Over the next 26 years, he and his managing editors, Edwin L. James and Turner Catledge, continued traditions of thorough, impartial reporting -- on the Depression, World War II and the Korean War. But there were bad lapses.
Like most of America, The Times paid scant attention to reports that Hitler was annihilating European Jews. While much of the paper's reporting on the persecution of Jews was thorough, crucial Holocaust news was buried. On Nov. 25, 1942, for example, a small article on Page 10 reported that two million European Jews had been killed, and a July 1944 report that 400,000 Hungarian Jews had been deported to death camps ran at only four inches on Page 12. Many newspapers were skeptical of such reports, suspecting they were exaggerated by groups seeking relief funds. But critics said that if The Times, with its influence and capabilities, had acted differently, Americans would have awakened to the atrocities sooner.
A decade later, when Senators Joseph R. McCarthy and James O. Eastland were charging that Communists and their sympathizers had infiltrated the government, Hollywood, the news media and other American institutions, The Times and other newspapers, still trying to be objective, uncritically reported what proved to be largely fabricated allegations. Editorially, The Times later denounced both senators for demagoguery and for trying to intimidate a free press. The experience helped move The Times toward more interpretive news writing.
In 1961, Arthur Hays Sulzberger retired and was succeeded by his son-in-law Orvil E. Dryfoos, whose brief stewardship included The Times's coverage of the Cuban missile crisis. When Dryfoos died in 1963, the leadership of The Times passed to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the son of Arthur Hays Sulzberger. Over the next 29 years the paper underwent dramatic changes while covering major news of the century: the Vietnam War and the civil rights movement, the Pentagon Papers and the Watergate scandals, moon landings, the collapse of Soviet Communism and the end of the cold war.
Publication of the Pentagon Papers -- a 7,000-page secret government history of the Vietnam War showing that successive administrations had hidden the conflict's true causes and dimensions -- was a historic achievement for The Times. The Nixon administration tried to suppress the documents, but the Supreme Court, in a landmark case, upheld the primacy of the press against government attempts to halt publication.

Another Near-Death Experience
As a backdrop for these feats, The Times had its second brush with death, and was guided back to even greater prosperity through a minefield of labor strikes, technology that revolutionized production and communications, changing readership interests, a national transformation of the once-local advertising base and a metamorphosis that changed the paper's content and look while maintaining its essential character.
Strikes by printers, news and editorial staffs and other unionized workers in the 1960's sent several of New York's newspapers to the graveyard. By the end of the decade, even The Times stood on shaky ground. Its pages were old-fashioned, its news writing still ponderous. Revenues, heavily reliant on department-store advertising, were declining. Circulation was stagnant. Some studies said The Times might be doomed in the television age if it failed to control soaring production and labor costs.
But in 1974, the management negotiated contracts that provided lifetime jobs as well as buyouts for many blue-collar employees and gave the paper the right to automate much of its production, cutting labor expenses markedly. Soon, clanking typesetting machines were gone, along with metal type and the whole paper culture of the newsroom -- typewriters, copy paper, spindles, pencils, erasers and an elaborate system of pneumatic tubes to shoot capsules of edited copy to the composing room. Gone too was the newspaper's morgue -- a treasury of yellowed, flaking clippings, filed and cross-filed for ready reference.
In their place were computers to write, to edit, to set "cold" type, to transmit words and pictures around the world, to perform research and store the institutional memory, even to do the legwork for beat and investigative reporters.
Beginning in the 70's, The Times underwent a transformation that erased a stodgy image, improved readability and restored profits. Its sober pages were enlivened with brighter writing and layouts; news coverage was intensified, and specialists were hired to cover subjects like medicine, computer sciences, financial affairs, law and government, education and the fine and performing arts. The paper was expanded, with new weekday sections on sports, science, food, home furnishings and entertainment. At first, critics called these sections frivolous, but Times executives defended them as stylish and said they took no space from regular news. They proved highly popular with readers and advertisers.
The Times also began a Sunday guide for television listings and introduced suburban weekly sections for New Jersey, Westchester County, Connecticut and Long Island. It also brought out Sunday Magazine supplements that focused on subjects like education, fashion, health, leisure activities, travel and home entertainment and design.
Since 1980, when the paper first began publishing a national edition, The Times has widened its reach and circulation, enlarged its advertising base and established a network of printing plants and production-and-distribution partnerships with newspapers and delivery companies. One result has been the achievement of a longstanding goal: transformation of The New York Times into a truly national newspaper.
Today, pages are beamed by satellite from New York to printing centers nationwide to provide same-day delivery to readers in 200 metropolitan areas. Nearly half of its circulation -- almost 500,000 on weekdays and nearly 800,000 on Sundays -- lies outside the New York metropolitan area.
Advertising, the backbone of newspaper revenue, has also been transformed. Once reliant on New York City advertisers, and subject to the ups and downs of the local economy, The Times is increasingly a repository of national advertising by computer makers, financial concerns, airlines and other national companies. National ad revenue jumped to 82 percent last year from 31 percent in 1996, making the paper far less vulnerable to dips in particular sectors. (The average share of national advertising in American newspapers is 17 percent.)

A Little Rouge Amid the Gray
As anyone who has ever worked for or against The Times will tell you, the paper is universally and reverently known as the Gray Lady of 43rd Street. Her traditions -- seriousness, genteel taste, fairness, the chiaroscuro look -- account for the description.
But traditions aside, "Gray Lady" is no longer quite apt. In 1997, The Times introduced color to the daily pages, one of many innovations under Arthur Sulzberger Jr., who succeeded his father as publisher in 1992. The presses in The Times's building on 43rd Street, its headquarters since 1913, rolled for the last time in 1997. Automated plants in Edison, N.J., and College Point, Queens, have taken their place.
Redesigned sections -- Dining In/Dining Out, House & Home, Weekend, Circuits -- have been added. And The Times has deepened its involvement in the Internet, establishing Web sites under New York Times Digital. Continuous News made its debut last year, to supply Internet users with news from Times resources. Joint productions with television news organizations have taken The Times into additional ventures.
Last year, The Times announced that the architect Renzo Piano had been selected to design a new home for the newspaper -- a gossamer skyscraper of about 50 stories on Eighth Avenue between 40th and 41st Streets scheduled for completion in 2005.
Turning the pages of a coffee-table book of famous front pages of The New York Times, with their banner headlines, it is easy to be caught up in the sweep of history: war and peace, that atomic bomb, men on the moon. They are indeed the great stories of the age, reflecting momentous occasions and traditions that have brought The Times and members of its staff 81 Pulitzer Prizes.
But it is good to remember that, in the scramble against the deadline, it was all just news.

SUBJECT: WRITERS (78%); NEWS REPORTING (78%); JOURNALISM (78%); ANNIVERSARIES (77%); WEALTHY PEOPLE (71%); TELEVISION INDUSTRY (70%); AFFLUENT MARKET (68%); CITIES (68%)

PERSON: MCFADDEN, ROBERT D

PUB-DATE: November 14, 2001
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section H; Column 1; Special Section; Pg. 26

LENGTH: 1455 words

HEADLINE: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; 
Beyond (and Behind) the Stock Tables

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS AND CHRISTINE BOCKELMANN; Floyd Norris, the chief financial correspondent of The Times, and Christine Bockelmann edited "The New York Times Century of Business," published in 1999 by McGraw-Hill

 BODY:
WHEN the New-York Daily Times made its debut on Sept. 18, 1851, it provided what was deemed to be a requirement of a serious newspaper, even then: stock tables and an article on what had moved the market.
 Of course, the markets were a bit smaller then than they are now. There was one exchange, the New York Stock Exchange, and the newspaper's stock table listed just 60 securities, most of them bonds. The previous day's activities seem to have been pretty dull. 
 Other markets were also "Carefully Reported for The Daily Times," as the paper headed its daily report on what might now be called commodities. Prices for ashes were "extremely firm," but the wheat market was "somewhat depressed." 
There were few big businesses then, except the growing railroads. But coverage grew as business did, and as technology -- from electricity to telephones to automobiles to the Internet -- changed the world.
Today, business and financial news is everywhere. Coverage reflects the increasing sophistication of the reader as investor, consumer, employer, employee, homeowner and more. In the weeks that followed the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, the market reaction, and the disaster's effects on the economy, were major elements of the continuing story.
Rules requiring businesses to disclose far more about themselves have made it much easier for reporters to obtain information, analyze it and pass it along to readers. So has the advent of the Internet. The growing sense that business is a powerful factor in shaping ordinary lives has whetted readers' appetites to know more.
From the beginning, The Times has taken readers' interests to heart in its own distinctive ways. Determined not to be a scandal sheet, the paper has tended to cover financial crises with the aim of not making them worse. The 1929 stock market crash led the paper day after day, but each day's headline found at least one reassuring element even as the articles described the collapse of prices. Front-page coverage of the 1987 crash included an article dismissing the likelihood of another depression.

Muting the Alarms
The Times's approach to the first major financial crisis it covered, in 1857, set the tone. Only short articles inside the paper told of the great distress on Wall Street, and an editorial on Aug. 27 proclaimed that the panic "is not a serious interruption of the ordinary channel of prosperous enterprise, but a threatened stampede of terrified stockholders, operators and directors." It blamed alarmist reporting in the rival Tribune for helping to stir the panic.
To The Times, the day's major news was the progress in laying the first trans-Atlantic telegraph cable. "The establishment of an Electric Telegraph between the Old and the New Continents," read a front-page article, "is obviously an enterprise which has no precedent in the annals of mechanical engineering; the object proposed being nothing less than the commercial annihilation of distance in respect to one of the great Gulfs which have been placed between the East and the West -- the opposite halves of the habitable world."
Not that the early Times always played down financial crises. In 1869, when Jay Gould tried to corner the market in gold, the paper reported prominently and in great detail on the price movements -- and on the rumors of what was really behind them. By the panic of 1901, Wall Street's huge gyrations were major news, and The Times made no effort to minimize their severity. "Disaster and Ruin in Falling Market" was the lead headline on May 10. That panic arose over a battle for control of the Northern Pacific Railroad, with E. H. Harriman on one side and J. P. Morgan on the other.
In serving readers as investors and as consumers, newspapers now routinely report on profits and analyze corporate operations and balance sheets, but such articles were very unusual, in The Times and elsewhere, until the 1930's, when the federal government required companies to issue regular financial reports.
But another aspect of what is now expected in business pages -- scrutiny of top executives -- was a staple by the early 1900's, as giant trusts came to dominate many industries. There were calls for government action to break up the trusts, but there was also a fascination with the men who stood astride the world of finance, accumulating fortunes beyond most readers' imagining.
Thus on Dec. 20, 1912, when the lead article was about J. P. Morgan's testimony before a Congressional committee investigating what was called the "money trust," the front page also reported that John D. Rockefeller -- who did not need to be identified as the head of the giant Standard Oil Company -- had played a round of golf. "To-day he beat his record of 44 by one stroke, and he was as pleased over the feat as if he had made another million," the article reported. It did not mention how many holes were played -- nine, presumably.

Skewers and Bonbons
The Times, like much of America, was fascinated by business titans. In 1905, The Times printed excerpts of a book by Andrew Carnegie in three Sunday magazine sections. "The manual worker is as proud of his work, and rightly so, as men are in other vocations," wrote the steel magnate in one excerpt, "The Romance of Labor." He told the story of a maid who was thrilled "to have the honor" of shining a famous man's boots. "Happy girl in her work, knowing that all service is honorable."
But The Times could skewer business, too. In 1906, Upton Sinclair's novel "The Jungle" shocked America with its expos 1/8 of unsanitary conditions in the meatpacking industry and led to the first federal meat inspection law. It also inspired The Times Magazine to publish a satire, "Extracts From 'The Jungle' as the Packers Would Have Written It," signed only by "Y."
The essay told of an immigrant laborer who was hired in the Potted Ham Department at a meatpacking company. "Jurgis could hardly believe his ears. He, Jurgis Rawcuss, unskilled, uneducated, and but recently sterilized, was to help make the most carefully prepared, the purest, the most delicious food known to mankind!" So impressed was the immigrant by the cleanliness he saw, he almost immediately became a citizen and a patriotic American.
Innovations were often at the top of the news, although no paper could be sure which would become important. In 1946, for example, The Times gave front-page display to a report on "an amazing machine" known as "the electronic numerical integrator and computer" -- the pioneering Eniac. Two years later the invention of "a device called a transistor" merited four paragraphs on the radio page.
Radio had become the rage in the 1920's, and it was covered voluminously by The Times. It was viewed as a revolutionary technology with amazing potential, much as the Internet is viewed now. Like the Internet, it provoked a great era of speculation on Wall Street. In 1925 Alexander D. Noyes, the paper's best-known business writer, wrote of the "speculative mania" gripping the public, and forecast that prices would fall. The warning was four years premature.
When the crash came, The Times reported somberly on Oct. 30, 1929: "Wall Street was a street of vanished hopes, of curiously silent apprehension and of a sort of paralyzed hypnosis yesterday. Men and women crowded the brokerage offices, even those who have been long since wiped out, and followed the figures on the tape. Little groups gathered here and there to discuss the fall in prices in hushed and awed tones. They were participating in the making of financial history. It was the consensus of bankers and brokers alike that no such scenes ever again will be witnessed by this generation."
An editorial described the crash as an "inevitable sequel" to an "orgy of speculation." But it voiced confidence that the Federal Reserve Board would be able to ensure that Wall Street's woes would not spread to the rest of the economy.
Today, as in the early decades, The Times covers both the big financial crises and the trends that could change how people live. It has chronicled new technologies as diverse as air-conditioning, which transformed America by making large parts of the country comfortably habitable, and biotechnology, which has raised both life expectancy and the fears of experimenting with life.
What has changed is the quantity of business news, as investors choose among thousands of stocks and as corporations affect people around the globe. The Times began its Business Day section in 1978; by now there is more business coverage in a single day than there was in months of the paper's early decades. The goal, however, has never changed. It is to bring home to readers how the world of business and finance affects their lives.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Money Matters: Readers in the 1930's benefited from corporate disclosure laws that got behind the billboards (John Gutmann); COULD BE WORSE: Like much of The Times's coverage of financial crises over the decades, a 1929 headline sought to give the good news along with the bad. But there was no ignoring the effects of the Great Depression, like this bread line in Lower Manhattan in 1935.
