HEADLINE: 150th Anniversary: 1851-2001; 
When Newspapers Were Newsmakers

BYLINE:  By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD; John Noble Wilford is a senior science writer for The Times.

 BODY:
I MAKE news," boasted James Gordon Bennett Jr. He was full of himself, as usual. But make news he did, with deep pockets and commanding zeal. As owner of The New York Herald after the Civil War, Bennett would not wait for news to just happen. He dispatched reporters far and wide with orders to send back sensational copy of adventure and discovery, anything to capture the essence of a time of expanding horizons and, not incidentally, to win readers away from the competition.
 It was what editors did in the rough-and-tumble of journalism when The New-York Times was striving to secure a foothold: when they went out of their way to "make" news, the papers became participants in what they were reporting. The practice continues to this day, though rarely with the showmanship of a Bennett. 
 Only purists with blinkers would argue that journalists do not have an impact on the news they write about -- or that they could avoid it. A decision to cover one thing and not another makes news of one and non-news of the other. 
Over time, The Times found its own niche. It made news, but in a way that proved adaptable to the changes in exploration and adventure brought about by advances in science, aviation and technology.
No paper, of course, could have matched Bennett's first and greatest exploit. In 1869, a century before the moon landings, he summoned a reporter, Henry M. Stanley, and ordered him, "Find Livingstone." For three years, there had been no direct word from David Livingstone, the British missionary lost in deepest Africa.
Stanley, heading a search party, became the leading participant in the story. When he finally found his man in 1871, it was his own words -- not anything the missionary said -- that left an indelible mark: "Dr. Livingstone, I presume?"
Near the end of the 19th century, another titan of journalism, William Randolph Hearst, whipped up a frenzy of support for war with Spain over Cuba and deployed his crack correspondent, Richard Harding Davis, and the artist Frederic Remington to Havana to file on the first shots. But Washington and Madrid seemed less eager for combat than Hearst. After a long wait, Remington cabled: "There is no trouble here. There will be no war. Wish to return." To which the bellicose Hearst supposedly responded: "Please remain. You furnish the pictures and I'll furnish the war."
Whether or not Hearst actually used those words, they were in the spirit of the man and of journalism in those years. This may not be how journalists see themselves today, but that was not the last time they took an active role in the dialogue of war, politics or domestic security. Think of The Washington Post bringing down a president with its Watergate reporting, or The Times (followed by The Washington Post), in defiance of White House pressure, publishing the Pentagon Papers on the conduct of the war in Southeast Asia.
In the last decades of the 19th century, The Times remained for the most part on the sidelines as the more colorful press engaged in journalistic adventuring. The paper had emerged from the Civil War with a reputation for sober, thorough reporting. The paper's one serious foray into Bennett-style adventurism was a series of exclusive accounts by an Army explorer in Alaska in 1886, billed as "The Times' Alaska Expedition." But this paled in comparison with Bennett's three-year search about the same time for remnants of the ill-fated John Franklin expedition in northern Canada.
The appeal of the remote unexplored corners of the world eventually drew The Times into the game of expedition exclusives with increasing vigor and success. The man largely responsible was Carr Van Anda, the managing editor in the early 20th century and a gifted mathematician fascinated with science and exploration.
With the backing of his publisher, Adolph S. Ochs, Van Anda lined up, over 25 years, the polar explorers Robert E. Peary and Richard E. Byrd, as well as the aviator Charles A. Lindbergh. In the 1930's, editors signed up William Beebe for the report of his descent in a bathysphere to the seafloor, and Auguste Piccard for the account of his balloon ascent into the stratosphere.
The paper's practice was not to mount its own expeditions, but if someone had organized and secured substantial financing for a project, then The Times would invest modestly in return for exclusive rights to publish a first-person account. The paper was not so much making news as collaborating in spreading it.
In the first of these arrangements, Peary accepted the paper's offer of $4,000 for New York rights to an account of his 1909 expedition, trumpeted as the "discovery of the North Pole." His first message, triumphant if not necessarily quite accurate, was sent part of the way by wireless, itself a notable achievement.

The Flipper in the Loch
Aviation was the rage in the 20's, and Times reporters kept busy with accounts of record-setting flights and disastrous failures. Byrd's flight in 1926 with Floyd Bennett, to a point close to the North Pole if not actually over it, was described in another Times exclusive. When Lindbergh made his trans-Atlantic flight to Paris from Long Island, The Times had a $5,000 contract for his own detailed story.
The reporter as adventurer, in the Stanley mold, lives only in memory. The Spirit of St. Louis rests in the Smithsonian, and Paris is only a drink, meal and movie away on a jumbo jet. Scientists and reporters, even tourists, regularly fly in and out of Antarctica. A man in California recently paid for a trip to the International Space Station. Where are the sensations of yesteryear?
There is, of course, the occasional throwback. In 1976, an editor on the foreign desk of The Times read an article of mine about a picture purporting to show the flipper of a large creature in Loch Ness, Scotland. In an earlier time, the editor said, a newspaper would send an expedition to find Nessie. So began what became known as the New York Times Loch Ness Expedition.
Waste no time seeking parallels between this and Stanley's search for Livingstone. The pier from which we put out in boats to sweep the deep waters with sonar and the little house where we monitored video from submerged cameras were just down the road from a comfortable hotel with a well-stocked pub, where the Nessie legend was refueled nightly. Every few days I transmitted an article filled with the excitement of anticipated discovery, but Nessie was a no-show. Still, The Times and I had made news. Reporters descended on the lochside village, and where there is a critical mass of journalists, there is news.
On returning from Scotland, I covered the spacecraft landings on Mars, where Martian microbes proved as elusive as Nessie. Here was an example of the new exploration. Only governments can afford expeditions into space and investigations of cosmic origins, and all but a few ventures to the poles and the seafloor. These are national and international endeavors, driven by science and a perceived political and economic need to be at the front of modern technology.
In exploration today, no publication can buy exclusive rights to a government project. Yet reporters are still making news, though with a difference. For science journalists in particular, the difference is in bringing research from the lab and the field to the front page, rescuing it from obscurity in language accessible to the public.
This may not match finding Livingstone, but the implications can be greater. The Times has taken a leading role in this type of journalism, from the time of Van Anda through the introduction of the weekly Science Times in 1978. At Van Anda's instigation, the reporter Alva Johnston spent three days in 1922 at a wide-ranging science conference, listening to reports, interviewing scientists and writing a number of well-informed articles about research that probably would not otherwise have reached public attention. They were exclusives because no reporter had before deemed such science to be news. Johnston was the first science reporter to win a Pulitzer Prize.
In the late 30's, William L. Laurence, a Times science reporter, put two and two together and came so close to recognizing the possibilities of an atomic bomb that in the midst of World War II the government asked that he be detached from the newspaper for a secret assignment. Laurence was given the only inside story of the Manhattan Project, on the condition that nothing be published until the bomb had been dropped.
Walter Sullivan once wrote an article about the first detection of radiation from the birth of the universe in the Big Bang; the scientists themselves later said they had not fully appreciated the significance of their research until they read the report in The Times.
So it is today, with issues like cloning, genome mapping, clinical trials for drugs, global warming and prospects for biological warfare -- subjects already in the news but crying out for interpretation on a newsmaking scale. Every science reporter here fields calls from bewildered but pleased scientists whose research has been the subject of a Times article. They have been besieged for days with requests for other newspaper and magazine interviews, television appearances and sometimes book contracts. That's making news, reverberating news, today's way.

Laurence, a Times science reporter, nearly figured out the atomic bomb himself. (Arnold Newman); WILD GOOSE: A 1934 picture of something in Loch Ness, where a reporter sought a monster. HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Several agencies are trying a variety of methods to reflect the world after Sept. 11.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliot 

 BODY:
SEVERAL agencies are becoming known as specialists in a new kind of advertising, producing a variety of work seeking to reflect the changed national reality after Sept. 11.
 Some agencies are producing public service campaigns, some are producing campaigns for paying clients and some are commissioning surveys and studies to assess the changes in consumer attitudes and behavior since the terrorist attacks. Some of the work is serious, some is humorous; some of the ads speak like a cheerleader, others like a sage. 
 Executives of the agencies involved say they are aware of the fine line in circumstances like these between opportunity and opportunism, between rising to a challenge and leaping to cash in. They describe their efforts, which they compare to crisis communications for companies in distress, as necessary to serve marketers required suddenly to reassess all advertising messages. 
"It has to be done in a delicate way," said Philip B. Dusenberry, chairman for the North American operations of BBDO Worldwide in New York, part of the Omnicom Group. "You have to strike the right note, the right tone."
"It's important not to seem self-serving or self-aggrandizing," he added. "We're just there to help our clients."
BBDO has produced paid ads addressing the Sept. 11 aftermath for General Electric, the New York Stock Exchange and Visa, as well as a pro bono campaign on behalf of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani carrying the theme "The New York miracle. Be a part of it," to promote tourism during the holidays. That campaign, composed of six television commercials featuring quintessential New York personalities like Woody Allen and Yogi Berra engaged in unlikely pursuits, has been widely praised for its humor and special effects.
"Making an emotional connection with consumers is especially important now," said Steven Blamer, president and chief executive at the New York office of Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group. This week, his agency introduced a 60-second commercial for the Postal Service, that organization's first advertising since canceling all campaigns after the anthrax scare. The spot uses the Carly Simon song "Let the River Run" to portray postal workers in heroic fashion, i.e., doing their jobs.
"It shows our employees doing what they do every day, now in the face of adversity," said Larry Speakes, advertising manager at the Postal Service.
The commercial is the initial work by Grey after its parent, Grey Global, began posting last month on its Web site (www.grey.com) a series of "white papers" related to Sept. 11, and addressed to advertisers. The papers are written by executives from Grey Global agencies around the world that specialize in services like advertising, public relations and interactive marketing.
"This assignment for the Postal Service grew out of many things we talked about on the Web site," Mr. Blamer said, like advice from Steven Novick, vice chairman and chief creative officer at Grey Global, to not "make the product the hero" but rather focus on people; to "watch the flag-waving"; and to avoid giving worried, distracted consumers "an overproduced piece of advertising."
Simplicity and familiarity are the watchwords for campaigns from the New York and Toronto offices of the Wolf Group that encourage tourists to visit New York. The New York office's campaign is sponsored to the tune of $40 million by the Empire State Development Corporation and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The television spots reinterpret the development organization's famous "I Love New York" campaign; in one scene, Mr. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki urge visitors to "come see New York united in its finest hour."
The Toronto office's campaign, produced pro bono, also revisits the "I Love New York" theme, which becomes "Canada Loves New York" and encourages Canadians to visit the city en masse the weekend of Nov. 30-Dec. 2 by taking advantage of special lower prices on plane and bus tickets and hotel rooms.
A print ad, showing the Statue of Liberty clad in the Canadian flag, declares, "There will never be a more inexpensive time to visit New York." A commercial, shown on television and in movie theaters, features Canadian celebrities known to Americans -- like Dan Aykroyd, Kim Cattrall, Wayne Gretzky, Eric Lindros, Jason Priestley, William Shatner and Alex Trebek -- making remarks like "I'm Canadian and I love New York" and "J'adore New York"; the prime minister, Jean Chretien, even appears, saying, "Canada, show your support."
Large Canadian media companies including Bell GlobeMedia, CanWest Global Communications, Rogers Communications and the Torstar Media Group are donating an estimated 3 million to 5 million Canadian dollars worth of commercial time and ad space to run the campaign.
"The Canadian work was inspired by the New York work," said Larry Wolf, chairman and chief executive at Wolf Group, who is Canadian and based in Toronto. "What we tried to do is capture the spirit of 'I Love New York' from a Canadian perspective."
"It's important to get life back to what it was," he added, "or else the bad guys somehow win."
Another agency that has produced work related to the new reality is McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
One commercial by the agency's New York office, produced pro bono for the Advertising Council, features Laura Bush, the first lady, asking Americans to take time to talk to their children about the events of Sept. 11. That office also created a public service spot for a new organization named the Live Brave Coalition, in partnership with the council, urging Americans to "simply live" and resume normal activities.
Because one characteristic American activity is shopping, the McCann office in Troy, Mich., produced the "Keep America Rolling" campaign for the General Motors Corporation, promoting zero percent financing on cars and trucks. That campaign is being credited with helping stimulate vehicle sales despite fears that uncertainty about the economy would keep consumers from buying big-ticket items.
Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, part of the Publicis Groupe, has also been busy in this realm, producing pro bono print ads ranging from an appeal for donations to organizations like the American Red Cross and the Heart of America Foundation to an effort to waive the term-limits law that prevented Mr. Giuliani for running for a third term. The agency also distributed pins created by the foundation, being sold in Hallmark stores to raise money for a Family Relief Fund.
But Saatchi & Saatchi came in for considerable ribbing back in its original headquarters city, London, for an e-mail message sent by Kevin Roberts, chief executive, on Sept. 12. The message described the agency's employees as "passionate, competitive and restless" and as "ideas people" who had "much to contribute" after the attacks, and concluded "Nothing is impossible."

HEADLINE: Loss Reported By Interpublic 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Interpublic Group of Companies said yesterday that it had lost $478 million in the third quarter as sales fell 7.4 percent after businesses cut back spending on marketing campaigns and rivals snatched away some accounts. 
 The loss came to $1.29 a share and was in contrast to a profit of $90.8 million, or 24 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. 
Sales fell to $1.61 billion from $1.73 billion. 
 A slowing economy compounded by the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks reduced spending by Interpublic's customers, and it lost accounts like DaimlerChrysler, AT&T and PepsiCo Inc. The company, which is based in New York, expects fourth-quarter revenue to decline from year-earlier sales, although it was not more specific. 
Excluding restructuring and other costs, the company had profit of 15 cents a share. 
The loss of DaimlerChrysler cut $33.9 million from Interpublic's revenue, while the Sept. 11 attacks reduced sales by $35 million, the company said. 
So far this quarter, the company has gained new accounts including several additional assignments from Coca-Cola.

LENGTH: 1373 words

HEADLINE: After Hitler, Bin Laden Isn't So Scary; 
In Response to Terror, A New Generation Gap

BYLINE:  By JANE GROSS 

 BODY:
Jess Biblowitz remains calm in the face of menace, uneasy about the stock market and the possibility of a military draft but not given to apocalyptic visions. Roy Kean feels swells of patriotism that send him browsing the "help wanted" page on the C.I.A. Web site. David Diggs plans to leave New York City, join his girlfriend in the Middle West and find a secure job in what has become an insecure economy.
 Mr. Biblowitz is 81, a World War II veteran. He says that people his age have little to lose in the current crisis, not enough energy for panic and a high threshold for adversity. Mr. Kean, 53, avoided the Vietnam War with a favorable lottery number. He says that people in their 40's and 50's already had the scare of a lifetime during the Cuban missile crisis. Mr. Diggs is 28 and knows nothing of war but plenty about prosperity. He says that his age group is reeling, their blithe assumptions buried in the World Trade Center rubble. 
 Three generations. Three reactions to a world suddenly gone awry. Each response, predictable but telling, is determined by crises already endured. And each plays out in ways both emotional and practical. 
There are exceptions to the patterns that emerged in two dozen interviews. But, over all, it seems fair to say that experience is a shock absorber; that historical perspective steadies the elderly and middle-aged, while those at the heady beginning of adulthood are upended by the events of Sept. 11.
"Each shock takes place in a long line of intermittent shocks," said Todd Gitlin, a professor of sociology and journalism at New York University. Those who have "already had to manage dangers and disturbances and who have a life to fall back on" are more resilient, he said.
"If you have a history of circuit-jamming events, even if the shake-up is tremendous, the shock passes," Mr. Gitlin said. "Then you have the expectation, as we like to do in America, of moving on." 
Moving on is a comfortable concept for Mr. Biblowitz, who served in the Coast Guard in the North Atlantic, and his wife, Bunny, then a student at Brooklyn College, who sold war bonds, worked in the federal Office of Price Administration and bartered coupons for meat and nylon stockings. 
Both recall the ubiquity of the "war effort," a phrase on everyone's lips. "Doing without" was the norm, Mrs. Biblowitz said. Hailed as the greatest generation, men and women like the Biblowitzes went about their business in good times and bad. 
"Life went on," said Mrs. Biblowitz, 75. "Everybody coped with what had to be." 
Mr. Biblowitz concurred. "Death and tragedy become second nature," he said. "And at our age, we don't have as much to lose." Mr. Biblowitz said he had only two worries: his dwindling retirement reserves, given the state of the stock market, and his 17-year-old grandson, Eli, who is a year away from registering for the draft. 
At the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, several World War II veterans said they, too, had no fears for themselves but were uneasy for their children and grandchildren. Henry Lazar, 80, a mechanic in the Army Air Corps in England, is confident "life will go on and everyone will get over this." But Mr. Lazar, paralyzed on his left side from a stroke, wonders if his 22-year-old grandson, Jeremy, will face limited opportunities when he graduates from Fairleigh Dickinson University.
Isadore Haft, 94, agreed. "Nothing bothers me anymore," said Mr. Haft, who fought in the South Pacific and has a drawer full of photographs to show for it. But he fears the effect of a failing economy on his son-in-law, a vice president at Toys "R" Us. 
If the economy frightens the Vietnam-era generation, many with college tuitions to pay, it is not what dominates its conversation. Instead, reopening old rifts, they revisit their decisions about America's most unpopular war. They mull the meaning of flags flying from suburban homes, city high rises and S.U.V.'s. And they recall the civil defense drills and basement fallout shelters of the cold war and the memories of where they were when President John F. Kennedy, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert F. Kennedy were assassinated. 
Gerald Nagel, a public relations consultant, 57, said he was spared conscription by a "friendly draft board" and relieved of the scramble for deferments. Now, despite concerns about civil liberties and the protection of Israel, Mr. Nagel is gung-ho. 
He says that there is a "pent-up desire to be patriotic" in this age group, which has finally found its "enabling event, with the poles of good and evil clearly drawn." Being a patriot feels good, Mr. Nagel said, and is not diluted by fears of further terrorist attacks on American soil. 
He attributes this composure to the Cuban missile crisis, "the most scared I've been in my life or am likely to be." Mr. Nagel was a student at Bronx Community College in 1962 when Nikita Khruschev, the Soviet leader, pointed his bombs this way and young people were convinced "the world would come to an end by the end of the day." 
Then, as now, their elders seemed calmer. One student in Mr. Nagel's art appreciation class refused to complete an assignment, unwilling to waste his last hours on an unappealing task. The professor's blunt reply still echoes. "You may be right," Mr. Nagel recalls him saying. "But if Khrushchev and Kennedy work it out, the world will go on, the semester will continue and you will fail this course." 
For those who served in Vietnam, people like Mr. Nagel and Mr. Kean are "sunshine patriots, not winter soldiers." Rick Weidman, 55, the director of government relations for the Vietnam Veterans of America, says he is "ironically amused" to watch grown men, who know nothing of war, "reliving adolescent urges." 
Ron Powers, 63, who served in both Vietnam and Korea and now counsels veterans in Queens, is harsher. "I try to avoid them, grit my teeth and walk away," he said. "If I was 20 years younger, I'd punch them in the face." The day the towers fell, Mr. Powers -- whose son is a police officer raking the Fresh Kills landfill in Staten Island for human remains from the terror attack -- left his office shaking with rage and went home to watch John Wayne in the movie "The Searchers." If he were commander in chief, he said, "we'd have nuked them in hours, turned Afghanistan into a sand puddle." 
Memories of earlier calamities are what the people in their 20's are missing. While their personal lives were routinely disrupted by divorce, the world around them was a mostly placid place; war was a video game beamed into their living rooms from the Persian Gulf. And for those who graduated from college in the mid-1990's, jobs were there for the taking and six-figure salaries in certain professions the norm. 
"The sky was the limit," said Thomas Thibodeaux, 28, a trader. "There was always another job around the corner -- a bigger job, a better job, more money." 
No longer. Coreina Chan, 26, left an entry-level job in architecture to follow her boyfriend into stock trading. The goal was to make enough money to secure her future and her parents' and then return to the work she loved. "When we graduated," Ms. Chan said, "the biggest risk was to regret not living out your passion. Now it's not, 'Am I going to fulfill myself?' It's, 'How am I going to pay my bills?' " 
Looking our her window in Chinatown, which once framed a view of the World Trade Center, Ms. Chan inhales smoke. The neighborhood is still a tangle of police checkpoints and closed subway stations. She both lives and works downtown, as do many of her contemporaries. Even those who don't, come south to party. Or used to. 
It is no party these days in SoHo, where Katherine Rosman, 29, a freelance writer, picked at a muffin and spoke of her inability to absorb what has happened. "History is something you read about in books," she said. "It is not fun to be at the center of it."
Ms. Rosman is panicked in many ways: Struggling to focus on work, unable to tear herself from the television, reconsidering the safety of tall buildings. Her parents, like the president and the mayor, are begging her to get back to normal. 
"What's normal?" she asked. "Is the world ever going to be normal again? Is everything ever going to be O.K.?"

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT; 
Restoring the Heart ofFord

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
In 1992, when Nicholas V. Scheele took the reins of the Ford Motor Company's recently acquired Jaguar luxury division, J. D. Power ranked the Jaguar's quality one notch above that of a Yugo.
 That's right, Yugo. The rickety car from the Balkans whose value doubled when you filled it with gas, according to one joke from the Yugo humor canon. 
 "Two magnificent European imports," Mr. Scheele, 57, Ford's new chief operating officer and president of automotive operations, wryly remarked in a recent interview. 
By the time Mr. Scheele left Jaguar in 1999, the cars' quality had improved so much that the insides of its vehicles closely matched their sleek skin and its sales were on the rebound, gilding Mr. Scheele's reputation as Ford's Mr. Fix-it.
Mr. Scheele (pronounced SHAY-lah) now has a new and far more ambitious charge: to turn around Ford itself, the nation's second-largest automaker behind General Motors. Put in charge of Ford of Europe in 1999, Mr. Scheele is well regarded inside and outside the company, but he is unproved at this scale.
"He works every front," said Ronald Tadross, an analyst for Bank of America. But now, Mr. Tadross added, "he's got a much bigger fish to fry."
Most analysts were convinced that Ford's broad management shake-up two weeks ago, which swept Jacques A. Nasser out as chief executive, was inevitable after the decline over the last year and a half of the company's reputation and financial fortunes. Attention has focused on William Clay Ford, Jr., the 44-year-old chairman and great-grandson of Henry Ford, who took over as chief executive, putting a member of the Ford family in charge of the company for the first time in two decades.
But it is the experienced Mr. Scheele who will have to lead Ford's troops into battle. Tapped in August to run Ford's North American operations, he was immediately put in charge of preparing a recovery plan for its automaking heart.
Wall Street, grown skeptical of unfulfilled promises, now waits to see the plan, due in January. More important, most analysts remain unsure whether Mr. Ford and Mr. Scheele will be able to carry it out effectively.
At Ford of Europe, Mr. Scheele improved the European product lineup while cutting capital spending and supplier costs. He also trimmed the hourly work force, which is concentrated in Britain and Germany, in part by using more common parts and processes. But his new assignment is still a big step up from the European unit, which accounts for only about a quarter of the cars sold by Ford worldwide, to making substantial change at Ford's headquarters in Dearborn, Mich.
Mr. Scheele and Mr. Ford have preached a "back to basics" approach that hews to improving the business instead of redefining it, as Mr. Nasser originally sought. There have already been numerous cuts -- slashing the dividend in half, reducing the white-collar work force by 5,000 workers, cutting production and idling some plants -- yet more are clearly inevitable.
The fall of Ford came quickly. Only a year ago, Mr. Nasser was considered a hard-charging, innovative executive who styled himself after John F. Welch Jr., the recently retired chairman of General Electric. Then came the bruising dispute with Bridgestone/Firestone over what part tires played in fatal rollovers of the Ford Explorer. Dealers, meanwhile, rebelled at Mr. Nasser's plans to build dealerships directly and sell cars online. Managers chafed at a strict new grading system. And Ford fell behind G.M. and Chrysler in quality rankings.
"Go back to last year this time, Ford was the premium company out of the three," said Kevin Rendino, manager of the $8.6 billion Merrill Lynch Basic Value fund, which has reduced its holdings of Ford stock by 70 percent since the middle of 2000.
"Now," he said, "it's almost flip-flopped and Ford has the worst reputation."
Support from other professional investors has wavered as well. Invesco, the Denver fund group, held almost two million shares at the end of September, according to S.E.C. filings, but has since sold all of its shares, a spokeswoman said. Janus Capital, one of the nation's largest fund companies, sold all of its 8.1 million shares of Ford Motor in the second quarter.
Such is the climate Mr. Scheele faces. He joined the company in 1966 after his grades at Durham University in England were not high enough to get him into the British foreign service. He selected Ford over I.B.M. and other companies, he says, because he was low on money and Ford wanted him to start immediately.
"I didn't do any work in college," he said. "I played a lot of sports. I played a lot of cards. I drank a lot, basically, because I wasn't interested."
At Ford, he found a place where he was "actually doing something that contributed from Day 1; that was a huge motivator." 
Mr. Scheele came up through the purchasing department, an unusual path for a top executive, but one that gave him a feel for cost-cutting. But he had to do far more than hack at waste at Jaguar, which by the early 1990's was little more than a famed brand name with a waning reputation. Jaguar's sales were at a low and Toyota's Lexus group was stealing customers. Jaguar's sedan had been around since the early 80's and its sports car since the early 70's.
"They were old and tired and very expensive," Mr. Scheele said. "There was nothing in the pipeline."
Mr. Scheele first reassured wary dealers by flying them to England to show them his new product plans, and by introducing a more generous leasing deal. Then, he sought to invigorate the work force by assuring them that the company was not about to go under and by fostering an emotional connection between its customers and its workers, whose job it was to make cars that most of them could not afford.
Instead of cutting pay, as expected, he won concessions that stripped out two layers of bureaucracy and gave the company greater control over the selection of work-group leaders. But the most innovative action was to have some of Jaguar's hourly workers make phone calls to customers who reported problems.
"Bear in mind, these are line operators who would never have the economic capability of affording the cars," Mr. Scheele said. "They're now talking to customers that, in economic terms, are hugely differentiated.
"The power of using the line operator, the hourly guy, to talk to a customer, you cannot believe it," he said. "It provided a direct link, the communication was there, and they could see it through the customer's eyes."
Since Jaguar's financial results are not broken out in Ford Motor's financial statements, it is difficult to pinpoint its actual performance, except to say it was losing money when Mr. Scheele came in and making money when he left.
At Ford of Europe, he began extensive cost-cutting efforts, like using more common parts in making different cars like Jaguars or Lincolns, that analysts now expect will be brought to North America. Mr. Tadross, like many other analysts, says the company needs to cut North American costs by $5 billion over the next two to three years, about 5 percent of sales over that period. That will probably require closing up to five plants to reduce production, eliminating about 10,000 hourly workers out of 100,000 and cutting about 6,000 white-collar workers from a staff of 45,000.
Such turnaround plans come along every few years at one auto company or another. The Chrysler Group, a unit of DaimlerChrysler, unveiled its own turnaround effort in February. The challenge from Wall Street's perspective is actually getting the plan to work.
One of the biggest hurdles Ford must overcome is persuading the United Automobile Workers to agree to close plants, because Big Three labor contracts forbid closings without union consent.
The change of management may help. The knock against Mr. Nasser was not his ideas, many of which were considered innovative, but his approach. While top management and the public were consumed by the Firestone dispute, relations were fraying with dealers, suppliers, white-collar workers and the union. Mr. Scheele's skills in dealing with such constituencies are better regarded.
Indeed, Mr. Scheele says the most interesting part of the business to him is relationships. "Above all, the fascination is the people, be they employees, dealers, suppliers, whatever," he said. "Communications are absolutely critical. You've got to have a mutual understanding of what everybody's objectives are because life ain't a bed of roses and we should debate and discuss."
And that may be Mr. Scheele's greatest advantage in the months ahead. "He doesn't put on airs," said Jerry Reynolds, a Ford dealer in Garland, Tex. who is a former chairman of the Ford National Dealer Council. Mr. Reynolds recalled a dealer convention earlier this year where Mr. Nasser and Mr. Scheele appeared together. 
"Nasser came out in a $1,000 suit and tie and stood stiffly," he said. "I don't think he was ever comfortable with the dealers. Nick came out in a short-sleeve shirt, no tie, looked a little rumpled. He said, 'I want to tell you how sorry I am about the things we've done.' Talk about music to your ears."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
America West Seeks Loan In First Application to U.S.
America West Airlines applied for a federally guaranteed loan of $400 million, becoming the first airline to seek a part of the $10 billion in guarantees approved as part of an emergency rescue package for the airline industry.
 The rest of the industry will be watching closely to see how a body created by Congress to distribute the loan guarantees handles the first application. Page C8. 

Nasdaq Leads Broad Stock Rally
Stocks rallied, with the broad market hitting levels unseen since late August on expectations of a speedy conclusion to the war in Afghanistan. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 196.58 points, or 2.1 percent, to 9,750.95 -- its biggest percentage gain since Nov. 1. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 20.76 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,139.09. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 51.98 points, or 2.8 percent, to 1,892.11. C10.

Recession May Have Begun in March
The six economists who determine when recessions begin and end have publicly mentioned March for the first time as the month in which the longest economic expansion in American history "possibly" ended and the current recession "possibly" began. C2.

No Widespread Panic After Crash
A day after the American Airlines crash in New York, travel agents reported scattered cancellations of airline bookings and signs of procrastination as leisure travelers held out hope that desperate carriers would cut fares to lure holiday business. D9.

Instead of coverage of the crash of Flight 587, the CNN Airport Network showed a singing cowboy. Business Travel: Joe Sharkey. C9.

Talks Stalled on Stimulus Plan
Senate leaders and the Bush administration agreed to negotiations on an economic stimulus package, but House Republicans blocked any talks, at least for the moment. B7.

Morgan Stanley Shuts Japan Outlet
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter said that it would close its only retail brokerage outlet in Japan because there was little chance it would turn a profit. World Business, Section W.

A Symbol for Work and for Life
William F. Baker, the president and chief executive of Thirteen/WNET, the public television station in New York, said that 30 years ago, when he was working for the Scripps-Howard Broadcasting Company in Cleveland, he suggested that the company buy a lighthouse to use as an employees' retreat. But his boss didn't like the idea, so he started looking for another job. Many years later, he finally got his lighthouse, buying Henry Island in Nova Scotia. "So when I say during Thirteen's on-air membership drives that our public television station is like a lighthouse," he said, "I know what I'm talking about. After all, I am a real lighthouse-keeper." The Boss. C6.

Deadline Is Upheld in Credit Cases
Federal law gives people whose credit ratings have been damaged by a credit-reporting company's mistake only two years from the date of the mistake to file a lawsuit, even if the mistake does not come to light until later, the Supreme Court ruled. A20.

Vodafone Reports a Half-Year Loss
Vodafone said that write-downs of overvalued assets and other charges resulted in a net loss of $14.1 billion for the six months that ended Sept. 30. World Business, Section W.

Retailers Post Improved Results
Wal-Mart Stores and Home Depot posted gains in third-quarter profits, while J. C. Penney rebounded from a loss. C7.

HEADLINE: Russia Seeks Belated Peace Dividend 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
The people who run Russia's companies and oversee its economy did not draft a formal wish list of economic measures for President Vladimir V. Putin to raise with George Bush as they meet this week. That is because what they want from the United States can be boiled down to one point: stop treating Russia like an enemy economy. 
 As Russia moves to integrate its economy with the rest of the world's, business leaders and government officials here say that more support is needed from America to smooth the way. American officials say that they are doing what they can, but that they cannot move faster than Congress and other countries' governments will allow. 
 "Russia wants to become a part of the international community and global economy," said Alexei Mordashov, general director of Severstal, one of Russia's biggest steel plants. "It would be right for all Western countries -- the U.S. and Europe -- not to push us away, but to help us in this process."
In the tumult of the first decade after Communism, Russian economic relations with the West mainly took the form of emergency loans from the International Monetary Fund. Now that Russia's economy has three steady years of growth under its belt and investment is beginning to flow on a large scale, more normal relations are possible, and Russian companies are eager to gain greater access to Western markets.
But laws and regulations unchanged since cold war days stand in the way, officials and businesses here say, especially in the United States.
"There are some remnants, some heritage from the past that should be corrected," said Andrei Illarionov, Mr. Putin's economic adviser, in an interview last week. "Russia should be considered an equal partner. We cannot be equal by economic size, demographics, or geographical location. But in commercial relations, in all these rules of behavior, it should be very normal good relations among neighbors."
One problem area is Russia's status under American antidumping laws, which are meant to protect American industries from unfair competition. The laws penalize countries that are deemed to have tried to increase their market share in the United States by selling goods below the cost of production.
In antidumping suits, which hinge upon production costs, Russia is treated as a "nonmarket" economy. For purposes of calculating production costs, the law calls for a "surrogate" market-economy country to be used for comparisons with the United States. But such countries often have little in common with Russia, and as one Western embassy's trade issues specialist acknowledged, the practice is "usually disadvantageous to the party charged with dumping."
The Russian government has applied to the Commerce Department to change its status and begin using actual cost figures from Russia, rather than from any surrogate, in antidumping calculations.
Russia's steel industry has suffered since 1998, when the United States accused it of dumping hot- rolled steel, its main export. At the time, the Russian government agreed to accept quotas to avoid punitive duties. Since then, Severstal's exports to the United States have fallen by three-quarters. 
Another roadblock is the Jackson-Vanik Amendment, a 1974 sanction intended to press Communist-bloc nations to permit free emigration, particularly of Jews, from the Soviet Union.
The law has not been invoked against Russia in years, but the fact that it remains on the books would block Russia from obtaining trade privileges from the United States once Russia joins the World Trade Organization. Other former Soviet republics, like Georgia, which has already joined the trade organization, are similarly restricted by the law. 
The Bush administration has asked Congress to scrap the Jackson-Vanik law. When that might happen is unclear, but its repeal is not expected to be controversial.
Russia wants to join the World Trade Organization as soon as it can, both to gain easier access to foreign markets and to gain the tools to defend its manufactured products there. Half of Russia's exports today are basic commodities -- chiefly oil and gas -- that need no protection. But goods like steel and fertilizer now face restrictions on imports to the United States that Russians say are unfair; as long as Russia is outside the W.T.O., it has no avenue to appeal them.
Membership "is the most important issue for us," said Alexei Kudrin, Russia's finance minister, in an interview last month.
Even with American support, Russia still faces arduous negotiations over membership. China's recently completed membership talks started in the 1980's. But Washington can help grease the skids. 
Above all, Russia wants more private investment by American companies. A recent tax ruling opened the way for a consortium led by Exxon Mobil to start on a $12 billion oil and gas development in Russia's Far East. More such projects could bind Russia more closely to the United States, businesses argue.
"Russia can be a very useful part of the world, economically and politically," Mr. Mordashev said. "This is a chance for getting closer, for getting more Russian goods into the American market and more American goods into the Russian market. This is a chance for more integration."
And Russia is now a better place to invest than it was in the early 1990's, companies say.
"In 1991 there was nothing -- just euphoria," said Anatoly Karachinsky, founder and chief executive of IBS, a Russian computer services conglomerate. "When the East saw how the West lived, we thought that soon we would be able to live like that. But then it turned out we had to build an economy. And we have been building it. It wasn't all successes, but we've made the first steps -- the foundation."
Ultimately, investors will want to see more than warm words between governments before they open businesses here. A stable government, a reasonable tax system and a legal system that protects property rights are essential prerequisites, and Russia is still in the process of putting them in place.
"Our decisions about investing in Russia are made on the merits of how we see the market developing," said John Stevenson, president of Frito-Lay's operations in Central and Eastern Europe. Frito, a unit of PepsiCo, said last month that it would build a $40 million snack food factory in Russia. "There isn't very much of a connection between the events of September and the decision to invest."

HEADLINE: 10 Nations Look Like Prospects For Joining the European Union 

BYLINE:  By PETER S. GREEN 

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
The European Union announced today that as many as 10 countries from Southern and Central Europe may be allowed to join by 2004. 
 Across the region, post-Communist states welcomed what they saw as a vote of confidence from the European Commission, the union's administrative arm, and a sign that their painful economic reforms would soon bring them membership in the exclusive club of Europe's richest nations. 
 Reports issued today on membership negotiations with candidates praised eight Central European and Baltic countries -- the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia -- as well as Malta and Cyprus. All got high marks for economic and democratic reforms. 
Gunther Verheugen, the union's commissioner for enlargement, said the first new members could join the 15-member body before elections to the European Parliament in June 2004. "It is not a utopian dream," Mr. Verheugen said today in a speech to the European Parliament in Strasbourg. "It is a realistic and feasible challenge."
The commission's president, Romano Prodi, said that after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States, the European Union must expand its "area of stability and prosperity." 
"A historic moment really is just around the corner if we are able to keep up the pace," of reform in the candidate countries, Mr. Prodi said.
The reports issued today still had harsh words for many candidates. They warned that candidate countries must tackle corruption, bureaucracy and a lingering reluctance by parliaments and administrations to put into operation the laws and rules already in place inside the European Union. 
Trafficking in women and children and the treatment of Gypsies were also singled out as problems that should be addressed by the applicant countries.
Turkey, criticized over economic problems and human rights abuses, lashed out at the reports.
"It has become clearer that concepts and status constantly invented for Turkey are nothing but delaying tactics," said Deputy Prime Minister Devlet Bahceli. He said the European Union's attitude toward Turkey was "biased and ill-intentioned."
Bulgaria and Romania were given failing marks by the European Union, which said they had yet to develop functioning market economies.
Several politically sensitive issues still have to be resolved, including whether there will be free movement of workers from the new countries in the existing member states, how European Union subsidies would be extended to new members and plans for agricultural reform in the poorer candidate countries.

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the European Union's expansion plans misstated the given name of its commissioner for enlargement. He is Gunter Verheugen, not Gunther.

HEADLINE: German Leader Calls Vote of Confidence on Role in Afghanistan 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
Putting severe pressure on his junior coalition partner, the Greens, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder today called a parliamentary vote of confidence over his decision to deploy up to 3,900 troops to support the war in Afghanistan.
 The vote, called for Friday, could result in a new ruling coalition in Germany or even new elections, a year before they are scheduled. Whatever happens, the politically adroit Mr. Schroder is likely to remain chancellor. 
 Mr. Schroder has made much of solidarity with the United States since Sept. 11, and what he terms the historic move to deploy German troops outside Europe for the first time since 1945. He told members of his Social Democratic Party that he intended the vote to force the Greens, who have their roots in pacifism and opposition to the Vietnam War, to renew their commitment to the coalition and the requirements of power. 
Late this afternoon Mr. Schroder spoke directly to Green lawmakers to make his case.
Tonight, in a brief statement televised live, he said that he would win the vote, but that more work was required. "It will require more discussion and more convincing, but I think that everyone knows the special significance of what is at stake here," he said. 
Mr. Schroder has staked his reputation on shaping a Germany that will take its proper place, militarily as well as economically, in Europe and the Atlantic alliance.
But the Greens are ambivalent at best. Seven Green legislators -- and some members of Mr. Schroder's own Social Democratic Party -- have said they will vote against the deployment, arguing that the war in Afghanistan is not the way to defeat terrorism and is causing too much harm to civilians.
Parliament must ratify any deployment of German troops outside Germany. That vote will now be considered a vote of confidence and should take place on Friday, said Peter Struck, the Social Democrats' leader in Parliament.
Mr. Schroder has the support of his Green foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, and most other Green party leaders. But ordinary Greens are unhappy with the compromises the party has made to retain power.
If he loses Friday's vote, Mr. Schroder could form a new coalition with the liberal Free Democrats, add them to the current coalition or even try to form a broader unity government with the conservative Christian Democrats. Or he could seek new elections.
With the economy in recession and unemployment rising toward 4 million -- Mr. Schroder had promised to get it under 3.5 million -- early elections that focus on Germany's role in the world, and not domestic doldrums, could be a way for Mr. Schroder to secure a new mandate and remake the government.
"Schroder is linking the vote of confidence to the vote on the military because if he lets the disagreement within the coalition pass, he will have to worry about this happening again," said Oskar Niedermayer, a professor of politics at the Free University, Berlin. "He must ensure that he can trust in his coalition."
Laurenz Meyer, of the opposition Christian Democrats, expects the coalition to survive. "The Greens are glued to their jobs," he said sarcastically. "They would rather drive the tanks themselves than give up their ministry posts."
New elections would not favor the conservatives. They are in the middle of a leadership battle, with the party chairwoman, Angela Merkel, considered a sure loser in any election against Mr. Schroder.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Other People's Money

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
You may have seen the story about the businessman who allegedly used the attack on the World Trade Center to make off with other people's money. According to his accusers, Andrei Koudachev stole $105 million that had been invested with his firm, falsely asserting that the sum had been lost in the collapse of the towers. It's not entirely clear whether he is accused of stealing the money before Sept. 11, then using the disaster to cover his tracks, or of taking the money after the fact; maybe both.
 It's too bad that so many of our leaders are trying to pull the same trick. 
 Just before Sept. 11, political debate was dominated by the growing evidence that last spring's tax cut was not, in fact, consistent with George W. Bush's pledge not to raid the projected $2.7 trillion Social Security surplus. After the attack, everyone dropped the subject. At this point, it seems that nobody will complain as long as the budget as a whole doesn't go into persistent deficit.
But two months into the war on terrorism, we're starting to get a sense of how little this war will actually cost. And it's time to start asking some hard questions.
At the beginning of the week we learned that the war is currently costing around $1 billion per month. Oddly, this was reported as if it were a lot of money. But it's only about half of 1 percent of the federal budget. In monetary terms, not only doesn't this look like World War II, it looks trivial compared with the gulf war. No mystery there; how hard is it for a superpower to tip the balance in the civil war of a small, poor nation? At this rate, even five years of war on terrorism would cost only $60 billion.
True, the terrorist attack has also forced increased spending at home. But Mr. Bush has threatened to veto any spending on domestic security beyond the $40 billion already agreed. And even that sum is in doubt. Half of the $40 billion was money promised to New York; last week New York's Congressional delegation, Republicans and Democrats alike, demanded that Mr. Bush disburse the full sum, openly voicing doubt about whether he would honor his promise.
So the budgetary cost of the war on terrorism, abroad and at home, looks like fairly small change. Even counting the measures that are likely to pass despite Mr. Bush's threat, I have a hard time coming up with a total cost that exceeds $200 billion. Compare that with the $2.7 trillion Social Security surplus. What will happen to the remaining $2.5 trillion?
Again, no mystery: much of the money was actually gone before Sept. 11, swallowed by last spring's tax cut, which will in the end reduce revenue by around $1 trillion more than the numbers you usually hear. And the administration's allies in Congress are striving energetically to give away the rest in tax breaks for big corporations and wealthy individuals.
The new round of tax cuts is supposedly intended as post-terror economic stimulus. But recent remarks by Dick Armey give the game away. Defending the bill he and Tom DeLay rammed through the House -- the one that gives huge retroactive tax cuts to big corporations -- he asserted that it would create 170,000 jobs next year. That would add a whopping 0.13 percent to employment in this country. So thanks to Mr. Armey's efforts next year's unemployment rate might be 6.4 percent instead of 6.5. Aren't you thrilled? 
Let's do the math here. This bill has a $100 billion price tag in its first year, more than $200 billion over three years. So even on Mr. Armey's self-justifying estimate, we're talking about giving at least $600,000 in corporate tax breaks for every job created. That's trickle-down economics without the trickle-down. 
Ten weeks ago this bill, or the equally bad bill proposed by Senate Republicans, wouldn't have stood a chance. But now people who want to give the Social Security surplus to campaign donors think they can get away with it, because they can blame Osama bin Laden for future budget shortfalls.
They say every cloud has a silver lining. The dust cloud that rose when the towers fell has certainly helped politicians who don't want you to see what they're up to.

HEADLINE: Bush Orders Oil Reserve Filled to Maximum 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
President Bush ordered the Energy Department today to increase the United States' emergency supply of oil, the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, to its capacity over the next few years, the first time it will be full.
 Filling the oil reserve to capacity "will strengthen the long-term energy security of the United States," Mr. Bush said in a statement. 
 Analysts have said that strengthening the United States' insurance against a break in the flow of oil from the Persian Gulf region gained urgency when the strikes on Afghanistan began. But Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham denied that the president's decision was influenced by the heightened tension. 
Created in 1975, the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, a network of underground caverns in Louisiana and Texas, was intended to smooth out, in the short run, the price spikes and possible shortages that could be caused by a disruption in supplies. It has a capacity of 700 million barrels of oil and now contains about 545 million barrels, which at the country's current rate of imports would last 53 days if foreign supplies were halted. The most the oil reserve has ever contained was about 590 million barrels in the early 1990's, which at the time would have been enough for 82 days if there were no imports. 
The United States imports a smaller percentage of its oil from the Middle East than it did 30 years ago, and would not be paralyzed by oil shortages if supplies from the region fell considerably. But the broad economy, and the individual consumer, would encounter sharply higher prices as supplies dwindled. Despite the reduced reliance on oil from the Persian Gulf, the country consumes and imports far more oil over all than it did a decade ago, exacerbating the vulnerability of the economy to a precipitous drop in supplies. 
The White House announcement comes on the eve of a meeting by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries here on Wednesday. OPEC, facing falling prices, is expected to reduce output by a million to 1.5 million barrels a day. 
Analysts in Vienna, Washington and New York were divided over whether the White House's announcement was meant to sway OPEC's decision.
Some said the timing was a coincidence. But others thought that the White House might want OPEC to factor into its forecasts that filling the Strategic Petroleum Reserve would require, on average, an extra 100,000 barrels of oil a day for about two years. The move might also be viewed by OPEC, some experts said, as an effort by the White House to help stabilize oil markets by bolstering demand, if only by a relatively small part of worldwide use -- now estimated a little above 76 million barrels a day.
"It goes to underscore the notion that there are common interests between the United States and a country like Saudi Arabia on oil prices," said Jan Stuart, head of research on global energy futures at ABN Amro. "They don't want prices too high or too low. Very low prices would hurt the oil industry in the United States, an important industry here, and it would be damaging to parts of the world we care about like Venezuela, the Middle East and Indonesia."
Crude oil prices rose on the announcement. In New York, crude oil for December delivery climbed 44 cents, or 2.1 percent, to $21.67 a barrel. Brent crude oil for December delivery also rose 2.1 percent in London.
Mr. Bush has been considering ways to fill the strategic reserve for at least three weeks, industry experts said. The reserve could have been filled rapidly if the White House had asked Congress to appropriate money to buy oil on the open market. But with many industries and constituencies competing for federal money, the chances of an appropriation were considered slim.
Instead, the Energy Department will take oil rather than cash royalty payments from companies that lease federal lands for drilling. The quantities will be small at first, the Interior Department said, because there are still contracts in force between the government and the companies for cash payments. But once many of those contracts expire in late March, the in-kind oil payments should start in greater amounts.
The plan will add 108 million barrels of oil to the reserve on top of an increase of 48 million barrels already expected by 2003, much of it as the payment for a deal last year under which oil companies received crude oil from the government to be refined into heating fuel. At current prices, the 108 million barrels would be valued around $2.3 billion.
Lawrence J. Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, referring to the time needed to fill the reserve through the in-kind payment plan, said: "It will take two and a half years or more to get a job done that should have been done in the next six months. But to avoid an appropriations battle, the White House took the line of least political resistance."
The Bush administration's move comes as the Saudi Arabian oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, the de facto leader of OPEC, completed a quick tour of major non-OPEC exporters, including Russia and Norway, to coax them to hold output at current levels or decrease it in an effort to shore up prices.
So far, he has had little success. Russia agreed to reduce exports by only 30,000 barrels a day, at a time when its exports would have declined slightly anyway because of increased heating oil use at home. Norway rebuffed Mr. Naimi's entreaties. Oman, a small producer, has said that it will decrease exports. And it is uncertain what Mexico, a principal exporter to the United States, will do. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: An aerial view from the United States Energy Department's Internet site of the Bryan Mound oil storage installation, southwest of Houston, one of four Strategic Petroleum Reserve sites in the country. HEADLINE: Start of Recession Thought to Be in March 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The six economists who determine when recessions officially begin and end have publicly mentioned March for the first time as the month in which the longest economic expansion in American history "possibly" ended and the current recession "possibly" began.
 March 2001 appeared yesterday in a memo signed by the six economists and posted on the Web site of the National Bureau of Economic Research, a nonprofit research organization in Cambridge, Mass., that has gained over the years the final say in dating business cycles. 
 "I would not be surprised to see March chosen as the peak month of the last expansion and thus that makes March the first month of the ongoing recession," said Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist and a member of the Bureau's Business Cycle Dating Committee.
Until now, the committee had not publicly mentioned a possible starting date for the recession. 
The decision will probably come very soon, Mr. Gordon added in a telephone interview, either at a formal committee meeting, the traditional method, or through e-mail exchanges. A formal meeting has not been scheduled, but e-mail messages are going back and forth at a considerable pace.
Mr. Gordon and Robert Hall, a Stanford University economist and the committee chairman, were described by another committee member as the most convinced that March was the turning point. They are the senior members and their view carries a lot of weight. Some other members, however, are less certain. Ben Bernanke, a Princeton University economist, is one.
"It is a very difficult call," Mr. Bernanke said, "because the indicators are not as synchronized as they usually are."
The popular definition of a recession is two consecutive quarters of contraction in the gross domestic product, a proxy for the entire economy. The committee, however, tracks more detailed measures and sometimes waits a year or more beyond what seems to be the turning point in the business cycle to be sure that an expansion or a contraction does not peter out.
This time, the terrorist attacks strengthened the view that March was the start of the 10th recession since World War II. "We are now about two months after Sept. 11," Mr. Gordon said, "and I do not think that we would be talking so soon about dating the start of a recession if it had not been for the extra downward push to the economy from Sept. 11."
If last March becomes the official date, then the expansion that started in March 1991 will have ended on its 10th birthday. The average length of the nine previous recessions since World War II was 11 months. If the current downturn is of average length, it would end in February. The two longest recessions -- in the mid-1970's and early 1980's -- each lasted 16 months.
The Business Cycle Dating Committee takes the gross domestic product into account, but since G.D.P. is continually revised, often decades later, the committee relies much more on four other national gauges: industrial production, employment, inflation-adjusted personal income and wholesale-retail trade.
Three of the four indicators have behaved in the last few months as they behaved in the early months of previous recessions, the committee said in its latest monthly progress report, which was posted on the Internet yesterday. The fourth, personal income, had not peaked in September, although it probably has now, Mr. Gordon said.
The starting date is a hard call this time. Usually, the committee's favored indicators turn down together, but this time industrial production peaked in September of last year, wholesale and retail trade during the winter, employment last March and personal income probably in October. The March date represents a blending, according to committee members.
"We could end up deciding tentatively among ourselves on the date for the peak," said Jeffrey Frankel, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, "and yet wait six months to officially announce it."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: NORTHERN ALLIANCE; 
Despite Flowers and Festivities, Alliance Finds an Uneasy Capital

BYLINE:  By DAVID ROHDE 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
On trucks, tanks and armored troop carriers, Northern Alliance forces poured into this battered capital today, greeted initially by flowers and festivities but confronting a situation of explosive uncertainty. 
 Defying American requests that they stay out of Kabul, alliance units occupied the city and tacked their green, white and black flags to ministry gates. Music played and men shaved beards in celebration of release from the Taliban's rule. 
 One man, standing outside an abandoned office of the Taliban religious police, held up one of the whips used to strike women who did not wear veils. He led the crowd in a chant of "Death to Mullah Omar!" -- a reference to the reclusive Taliban leader. 
But an uneasy mood gripped Kabul as nightfall came and even this morning, the potential for chaos was clear.
After alliance soldiers killed six Arabs and Pakistanis who tried to ambush them, including two who fired from a tree, dozens of residents set upon the bodies, bludgeoning them with stones and spitting on them. 
One young man repeatedly stabbed a corpse in the chest with a knife and then jammed it into the dead man's eye. The International Committee of the Red Cross removed the bodies before nightfall. 
To many Afghans, foreign fighters like these Arabs and Pakistanis are particularly hated symbols of the Taliban and the radical brand of Islam they imposed on Afghanistan after taking power five years ago. 
Taliban forces retreated to positions south of Kabul near the town of Chahar Asiab, pursued by Northern Alliance soldiers and the American warplanes that have pummeled them over the past six weeks. Mullah Mohammad Omar, the Taliban leader whose whereabouts are now unknown, urged his scattered troops to fight on.
"Any person who goes hither and thither is like a slaughtered chicken that falls and dies," Mullah Omar said in a radio address. "You should regroup yourselves, resist and fight." He did not refer to his guest, the accused terrorist Osama bin Laden, whose whereabouts remain unclear. 
In the north, cornered in the city of Kunduz, the Taliban did resist today, repulsing a Northern Alliance attack. In the south, where the Taliban stronghold is the city of Kandahar, there were reports of moderate forces abandoning the hard-line faction of Mullah Omar, but these reports could not be confirmed. 
At a press conference tonight, Abdullah Abdullah, the designated foreign minister of the Northern Alliance, said there was an uprising against the Taliban in the eastern city of Jalalabad, on the main road from here to the Pakistani border. It was impossible to confirm this claim. 
He also defended the alliance's decision to take Kabul, saying that the departure of the Taliban left a vacuum that had to be filled. "There were security problems for the people of Kabul to which the alliance had to respond," he said.
That the Taliban fled Kabul in haste seemed clear. A machine gun and three mortar rounds that had been set up to defend the presidency building were still in place today.
Whether the Taliban is now capable of regrouping and forming an effective guerrilla force was one of many unanswered questions provoked by the abrupt -- and apparently unscripted -- transformation today of this American-led war.
Another central question was glaringly apparent in this city as anxiety grew during the day: how will the mainly ethnic Pashtun population be treated by alliance forces composed mostly of Tajiks, Uzbeks and Hazaras from the north? 
The potential for violence seemed great, despite urgent American pleas for restraint. Across town, groups of young men with stolen guns and crude muskets declared themselves policeman and occupied the presidency building.
They set upon one boy accused of stealing, shoving and slapping him. As dozens of people watched this morning, they dragged him into a guard shed. Hafizullah, a banker who was in the crowd, pleaded for order.
"There is a vacuum of power," he said. "My message to the United States and the United Nations is that they must decide about the security of Kabul very soon. All of the people are afraid of this situation."
The United States, and its main regional ally in the war, Pakistan, had warned that the Northern Alliance should remain outside the city. But they never clarified how they proposed to restrain a victorious, advancing northern army, and in the end momentum mattered more than any pleas to halt.
Pakistan, with a large Pashtun population and a rival, India, to the east, is determined to prevent a hostile Northern Alliance government from taking power in Kabul.
But the situation on the ground has run far ahead of the political planning, with proposals for some sort of temporary United Nations administration buttressed by an international force still vague. In this vacuum, mayhem appears to be a likely outcome. 
Capt. Muhammad Akbar and his 10 men from the Northern Alliance tried today to reassure people. They stood around a bustling traffic circle here tonight and attempted to demonstrate that law and order would prevail.
Hours after crowds showered them with flowers and money as they entered the city, the officer and his soldiers began operating a checkpoint to look for goods and weapons stolen from Taliban bases.
While some Kabul residents greeted the captain and his men with open arms, other barely spoke to them. 
The captain and all of his men are ethnic Tajiks, while the majority of the people in Afghanistan are ethnic Pashtuns, with clear memories of the corruption, chaos and civil war that engulfed the city when the alliance leaders last tried to run it six years ago. 
Murad Mohd, an unemployed 36-year-old man, echoed other exhausted city residents when asked what the city needed most. "First, the security is most important," he said. "After that, they should improve the situation in Afghanistan. Many of the people are poor."
Asked which leader could best achieve those goals, he returned again to security. "We just need the one who wants peace and stability in the country," he said. "We just want that one."
As many as 6,000 alliance troops entered the city this morning, but most of them continued southward in pursuit of the Taliban, leaving special police units at checkpoints and crucial positions in this city where perhaps one million people still eke out a living. As the day wore on, these police units established order, searching cars and patrolling the streets.
Several people took out cassette recorders and played music for the first time in years. Barbers did a brisk business shaving beards. "Now, I have permission to control my beard," said Abdel Rahman, a clean-shaven 20-year-old who said he shaved his beard off today. 
Asked if women liked his new look, he grinned and said "Yes, they like it."
Residents generally expressed warmth, not hostility, toward the United States. When an American warplane flew overhead, a boy said he did not fear it. "They are chasing them now," he said, referring to Taliban who fled southward from the city.
Women did not remove the long, all-concealing robes known as burkas -- they are the traditional attire of Afghanistan -- but a few did briefly expose their faces, an act that risked a public whipping under Taliban rule. 
Food appeared plentiful. A central market that lines the road leading into the city had large amounts of fresh meat for sale, fruit juices from Iran and even Coca-Cola, a testament to the strength of smuggling networks in the area.
As night fell, lights came on in the city for the first time in weeks. Under Taliban orders, the lights had been extinguished to protect Kabul from American bombing.
That bombing appears, in general, to have hit its targets -- military bases and government complexes within walled compounds. There was little visible evidence today on city streets of buildings damaged by American bombing.
