HEADLINE: Nations Back Freer Trade, Hoping to Aid Global Growth 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: DOHA, Qatar, Nov. 14 

 BODY:
Reaching a consensus that they hope will rejuvenate the world's economy, trade ministers from more than 140 nations agreed today on an agenda to topple tariffs and liberalize trade on everything from wheat to insurance policies.
 In six days of nearly round-the-clock meetings in this Persian Gulf emirate, the members of the World Trade Organization sought to balance their national interests against the urgent need to shore up the world's battered economy. Their success helped to dispel some of the psychological damage inflicted by the collapse of similar talks in Seattle two years ago. 
 With trade growing at the slowest rate since the early 1980's and the world economy on the brink of recession, negotiators were under intense pressure to act together to stimulate growth. The World Bank estimates that the outline agreed upon today could help add $2.8 trillion to global economic activity by 2015. 
"This agreement sent a powerful signal to the world that we have removed the stain of Seattle," Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, told delegates as the meeting concluded. "We will continue to build a common trading system based on common rules."
Developing nations made out well because the agreement was likely to open markets in industrial countries to their leading exports. It will also open doors for multinational corporations, especially those that provide financial and environmental services, and for agriculture exports.
But if the full extent of the accord is realized in forthcoming negotiations, it could hurt special interest groups around the world that have long enjoyed direct government support for the ability to use domestic rules to limit imports. 
Among the biggest are American textiles, steel and semiconductor companies, as well as small European and Japanese farmers. Longstanding demands by organized labor to have worker rights addressed in trade talks were largely ignored.
Many ministers said the agreement was designed mainly to benefit developing countries, which have complained bitterly that trade rules favor the rich but have begun to hold huge sway within the trade group. 
Among their major gains was an understanding that would help poor countries gain access to less-expensive generic drugs to treat AIDS, malaria, tuberculosis and other diseases, even at the risk of breaking patents held by major drug companies. This understanding was reached on Monday, after the United States and several African nations declared that patents would not stand in the way of public health.
Speaking of the overall outcome of the talks, Nigeria's commerce minister, Mustafa Bello, said, "This has not been an easy negotiation, but Africa wishes to put on the record that it is satisfied and it approves this declaration."
The W.T.O. also passed a significant milestone when it admitted China and Taiwan as its 143rd and 144th members, meaning that its membership now covers all the major industrial and developing countries with the exception of Russia.
Removing barriers to farm trade was arguably the most significant and certainly the hardest-fought element of the agreement. The United States, Australia, Brazil and many poor countries who feel they have a comparative advantage in farm exports have lobbied for years to cut tariffs and trade-distorting payments for farmers.
Their targets have for years been the European Union, Japan and South Korea, which rigorously shield farmers from foreign competition. Japan reluctantly committed to negotiating reductions in its sky-high tariffs during the latest talks, but Europe refused to eliminate some $4 billion in annual payments it makes to farmers to promote exports.
The pending presidential elections in France, where the farm lobby is strong and farm policies are equated with the French way of life, made the negotiations especially sensitive.
Though the French threatened to make the issue a "deal breaker," France and the European Union agreed to "phasing out" the subsidies. But Europeans added a bit of diplomatic double-speak, suggesting that the goals should not "prejudice the outcome" of negotiations.
There are several degrees of separation between these proposals and action that could affect the price of goods that people buy, meaning that ministers are doing no more than commissioning study groups that could theoretically mandate new trade rules years later. 
But developing countries resisted fiercely, fearing that the negotiations would eventually force them to change their laws and even cede sovereignty. Many countries also tried to prevent Europe from using environmental rules to protect farmers, particularly by refusing to import genetically modified foods.
Even after the success here, doubts remained about the effectiveness of the World Trade Organization. It operates by consensus, meaning individual members can hold the group hostage. The negotiating program had to be watered down so much to obtain agreement that one Japanese trade official called the delicately constructed declaration "a perfect balance of unhappiness."
But there is no doubt that the fate of the trade group would have fared worse had the talks failed. Michael Moore, the organization's director general, thanked delegates tonight for "saving the W.T.O."
Although trade negotiators entered the talks vowing to fight terrorism with commercial solidarity, ministers repeatedly flirted with failure. Rich and poor nations engaged in heated ideological skirmishing even as they battled to defend narrow vested interests, with Ecuadorean bananas and Thai tuna among issues that at times blocked consensus. 
In the end, it took six days of nonstop haggling in a compound hermetically sealed by security guards against a feared terrorist attack to bridge all the gaps.
Mr. Zoellick helped hold the meeting together by making concessions to break deadlocks. He retreated from the American position on medical patent rules to defuse a damaging split between North and South countries, while allowing negotiations on antidumping despite strong opposition from the steel and semiconductor industries.
The apparent flexibility of the Bush administration's position contrasts with the firm stances it took on global warming, germ warfare and other agreements, suggesting that President Bush's international focus since the Sept. 11 attacks has affected the administration's approach to economic matters as well.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
A small dose of common sense would help Congress break the gridlock over airport security.

BYLINE:  By Alan B. Krueger; Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. E-mail: akrueger@princeton.edu.

 BODY:
"WHEREFORE, security being the true design and end of government," Thomas Paine advised in 1776, "it unanswerably follows that whatever form thereof appears most likely to ensure it to us, with the least expense and greatest benefit, is preferable to all others." Such common sense is needed in Congress on aviation security.
 Everyone agrees that the current system, in which barely profitable airlines contract with private companies, provides inadequate incentives for security. Airlines seek the lowest-cost providers. Federal standards are lax and poorly enforced, so security companies provide the bare minimum -- and sometimes less. 
 The main disagreement is whether screening should be contracted out by airports to companies working under federal oversight or whether screeners should be federal employees -- or whether the president should have the flexibility to choose between these models.
Economic logic says you usually get what you pay for. Airline security is no exception. 
Low pay is particularly problematic. Screeners and other security workers are paid the minimum wage or slightly more. Not surprisingly, companies can recruit only minimally skilled workers.
Better security will require employees with enough common sense to search luggage thoroughly if they discover passengers with knives in their pockets, regardless of what federal standards require. Every contingency can never be spelled out.
Low pay also causes high turnover. The General Accounting Office found that annual turnover for screeners varied from 37 percent in Honolulu to 416 percent in St. Louis. The average was 126 percent at the 19 largest airports. 
High turnover has a potentially pernicious effect because it makes it easier for terrorists to get airport jobs. High turnover also raises training costs and reduces the incentive to provide training in the first place.
A new study directed by Michael Reich of the University of California at Berkeley examines the effect of an initiative at San Francisco International Airport that established recruitment, compensation, training and performance standards for all workers in security areas or engaged in security tasks in April 2000. 
Starting pay for screeners rose from $5.91 an hour to $10 plus health benefits. Turnover fell from 95 to 19 percent. Employers reported that morale, skills and performance improved, while absences and grievances fell.
Looking across 19 airports, Professor Reich also found that lower turnover was associated with a greater likelihood of detecting security breaches.
Both the House and Senate bills would raise pay, but the Senate bill -- which federalizes workers -- would raise it more. The House only vaguely authorizes the Transportation Department to set "minimum compensation levels, when appropriate." 
Federal workers would be more likely to unionize, although the Service Employees International Union has made inroads with security workers. It is disingenuous, however, to say unions and Democrats favor federalizing security to increase membership. The service employees' union opposes federalizing the work force (because it would lose members), while the largest government union supports it. If all 28,000 screeners were unionized, membership would increase by only one-tenth of a percent.
Anyway, a more heavily unionized work force would not jeopardize security. Ever since the seminal study by the economists Charles Brown and James Medoff, most studies have found that unions raise productivity, even in the public sector. Unions raise wages and reduce turnover, so it is not surprising they lead to higher productivity, although at higher cost.
European airports, which commonly contract with the private sector for security, provide only limited guidance on the advantages of public versus private employees. First, firing for cause is about as easy in the private sector in Europe as in the public sector here. Second, pay and benefits for low-level workers in Europe are much higher.
The main potential advantage from private contractors stems from their incentive to use resources efficiently. Most important, competition among private companies may result in security innovations.
And the option of contracting to private providers shields government should a terrorist attack occur; government could quickly replace the contractor, giving the appearance (and possibly reality) of improving security. 
The main risk of using private contractors is that they could marshal their resources to influence regulators. Indeed, the Aviation Security Association, a group representing security firms that was formed two days after Sept. 11, is lobbying for bigger budgets and higher pay. Could it be that cost-plus contracts, which lead to increased profit when costs rise, have something to do with their sudden interest in worker pay?
Contracts must be written with safety in mind. The House bill simply leaves this up to the Transportation Department. Companies should be penalized if they fail undercover tests. Profits should not be just a mark-up over cost.
Another risk is a shortage of federal employees to perform the crucial supervision, background checks, training and certification. Federal employment is down 10 percent since 1966.
And will private workers have access to C.I.A., F.B.I. and I.N.S. data networks?
Regardless of who employs the screeners, security issues still remain. "It takes a village to turn around a 747," said Julie Neff, who just retired after 30 years as a flight attendant because her relatives were concerned for her safety. Caterers, cleaners and others have access to planes. "What is missing from both bills but in the San Francisco plan," Professor Reich said, "is the inclusion of higher standards for the other workers who have access to the planes."
President Bush is said to be readying an executive order in case the House and Senate remain gridlocked. So here's a Brandeisian proposal: direct the Transportation Department to contract out screening in some airports and use federal workers in others. Then have the Federal Aviation Administration conduct random undercover tests to see which system is working best.
As Thomas Paine argued, "The representative system of government is calculated to produce the wisest laws, by collecting wisdom where it can be found."

HEADLINE: University of California Moves To Widen Admissions Criteria 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 

 BODY:
Six years after it eliminated affirmative action based on race and sex in its admissions process, the University of California Board of Regents moved today toward adopting a new policy that would broaden the factors considered in selecting students.
 Among the new factors would be a student's success in overcoming economic and educational disadvantages. The policy was accepted by the Regents' Education Policy Committee on 13-to-2 vote, and it is expected to be approved by the full board on Thursday. 
 The policy, known as comprehensive review, has been criticized as a covert way of reviving race as a factor in admissions, which is banned by state law. But supporters maintain that the new policy looks at how all students, not just poor ones, met challenges and therefore is race neutral.
After race was barred as a consideration in admissions, the university system experienced a sharp decline in the number of minority students, and officials have grappled with how to balance educational excellence with access to the system.
Most recently, they have relied on a two-tiered system. The first tier, which accounted for 50 percent to 75 percent of the students admitted, relies strictly on grade-point averages and test scores. The second tier takes into account factors like the number of advanced courses available at the school attended, extracurricular activities and leadership skills.
The new measure, which would do away with the two-tiered system, was supported by Ward Connerly, a board member who championed the elimination of admissions based on race and sex as well as Proposition 209, which prohibits the use of race and sex in state hiring. Although Mr. Connerly had expressed concern that the change would allow race "to be used through the backdoor," he endorsed the measure after wording was added stipulating that no race preferences of any kind could be applied.
"I think it's incumbent on higher education to look at ways of extending opportunities to those of low and moderate income without regard of their race," Mr. Connerly said. "I think we nudged one step closer to that today."
But those who opposed the measure expressed concern about the system's ability to maintain academic excellence while relying less on academics for admission.
"I do worry about not having a percentage of admissions absolutely required on academic merit alone," said S. Sue Johnson, chairwoman of the Board of Regents.
Michael Reese, the university system's assistant vice president for strategic communication, said changes in the admissions policy were an effort to address the vast disparities among California's schools.

HEADLINE: Demand at Food Pantries Rises, but Donations Drop 

BYLINE:  By ALAN FEUER 

 BODY:
The slow economy and the loss of thousands of jobs after the World Trade Center attack have heightened demand at food pantries, but the supply of donations is decreasing, according to a study released yesterday by the city's largest food bank.
 The food bank, Food for Survival, took a survey of the soup kitchens they serve in the days after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack and found that 64 percent of the people receiving free food in New York were taking donations for the first time. Most of these first-time clients were single mothers who needed emergency food because they had lost their jobs in the attack, said Lucy Cabrera, the president of the food bank. 
 Even before Sept. 11, Dr. Cabrera said, reliance on food donations was greater than last year's. More than 1.5 million New Yorkers, including 510,000 children, relied on soup kitchens, food pantries and shelters to avoid going hungry, Dr. Cabrera said. In 1997, by comparison, about 450,000 people received emergency food donations, she said.
Last month, Food for Survival distributed 28 percent more food to about 1,200 food pantries, homeless shelters and soup kitchens around New York than in October 2000, Dr. Cabrera said at a news conference at the Hunts Point produce market in the Bronx. At the same time, donations from individual contributors decreased by about 30 percent in October compared with the same month last year, she said.
Dr. Cabrera attributed the drop in donations to the fact that regular donors had already given money to charities to help with the fallout from the terrorist attack and could not afford to give much more. 
Even with the decrease in donations, however, Food for Survival has not had to decrease food deliveries, Dr. Cabrera said. Indeed, the food bank sent huge amounts of food to ground zero after the attack.
"We saved up funds because we always knew that a rainy day would come," she explained. "Well, that rainy day came on Sept. 11."
The study, called "Hunger in America 2001: The New York City Report," surveyed 632 emergency food providers in New York and 376 low-income clients.

HEADLINE: Growth in Albany Spending Is Double Rate of Inflation 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 14 

 BODY:
State spending will grow by more than twice the rate of inflation this fiscal year, at a time when the government already faces a shortfall of at least $1.6 billion after the Sept. 11 attacks, budget officials said today.
 The growth in spending has happened even though the government limped along for four months on emergency spending measures and then, in August, the State Legislature passed what lawmakers called a bare-bones budget. 
 Both the emergency appropriations over the summer and the August budget were intended to keep spending at last year's levels until a final budget agreement could be worked out. That final agreement did not come until late October, after the terrorist attack dealt a huge blow to the state's economy. The Legislature added about $168 million in spending this fiscal year, which was paid for with some new revenues, like money from a multistate lottery, and by moving money from other programs. 
But spending still grew. Budget officials estimated today that the part of the budget paid for solely with state taxes -- the general fund -- will total $41.9 billion, about 5.8 percent above last year's figure. 
The entire budget, including federal grants and state revenues earmarked for particular purposes, will grow to $84.3 billion, or 5.7 percent over last year, compared with the 2.2 percent increase in the cost of living for the first six months of this fiscal year, April through September.
"The fact remains that this so-called bare-bones budget isn't bare at all," said Brian Backstrom, an analyst with Change-NY, a conservative group advocating fiscal restraint. "It spends at twice the rate of inflation."
Budget officials for Gov. George E. Pataki say the Legislature is partly to blame for the rise in spending because lawmakers did not approve cuts he requested. For instance, the Assembly and the Senate ultimately rejected plans to cut Medicaid reimbursements to nursing homes by about $138 million and subsidies to buy drugs for the elderly by about $41 million. "The Legislature didn't do the cost containment," said Kevin Quinn, a spokesman for the state budget director, Carole E. Stone. 
At the same time, the state was hit with some new expenses, budget officials said. The faltering stock market meant the state had to make a $44 million contribution to the state pension fund. An unexpected growth in the number of children receiving welfare cost the state $60 million. Several lawsuits cost it $55 million.
Legislative leaders say their rejection of the governor's proposed cutbacks cannot account for the entire growth in the spending this year. "We didn't add any more spending," said John McArdle, a spokesman for the Republican Senate majority. "We just didn't do his cuts."
Dean Fuleihan, the secretary of the Ways and Means Committee in the Democrat-controlled Assembly, said, "It's inconceivable to me that our inaction on their cost-containment measures could possibly get us to that kind of growth."
Budget officials acknowledge that the five emergency spending measures passed over the summer did not, in fact, limit spending to last year's levels, but allowed for increases the governor had built into his January budget proposal. That budget provided for a 3.6 percent increase in general-fund spending. 
Some expenses, like Medicaid and school aid, were driven by last year's formulas and continued to grow faster than inflation over the summer, officials said. In addition, the administration did not spend $300 million budgeted for the last fiscal year until after April 1, adding to this fiscal year's expenses.
The rise in spending could not come at a worse time. Mr. Pataki is predicting that the dropoff in tax revenues because of the devastation in Lower Manhattan could be as much as $3 billion this fiscal year and $6 billion next. He has promised to cut $3 billion over the next 18 months, but has yet to lay out how, beyond a hiring freeze and early retirements.

HEADLINE: N.J. Transit in 'Financial Morass,' Study Says 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 14 

 BODY:
New Jersey Transit is facing a financial crisis caused in part by its use of state and federal funds intended for long-term projects and maintenance to pay its day-to-day operating costs, an independent study warned today.
 The report, by the Alan M. Voorhees Transportation Center at Rutgers University, says the public transit agency, the nation's third largest, is in a "financial morass," saddled with a growing operating deficit that threatens its ability to meet future needs -- particularly as ridership soars in the aftermath of the terror attacks. 
 The underlying cause of the problem, the study says, is the failure of the State Legislature and several governors to provide adequate operating aid each year, and the state's failure to allow modest fare increases over the last 11 years. As a result, the report says, the agency has diverted about 70 percent of its state and federal capital-improvement funds to short-term expenses. 
But the report went on to blame the agency for spending the remaining 30 percent on new, politically popular projects that are being pursued rapidly and often without strategic planning, adding to the operating deficit. That deficit is now $569 million, about half the size of the current budget.
Among the study's recommendations is a moratorium on new rail projects until elected officials and the agency address the basic problems: chronic underfinancing and diversion of capital funds.
"This is not a simple financial rut from which N.J. Transit can escape with ease," the report said. "With the funding made available to it, N.J. Transit has been directed to overextend itself; use capital to pay operating maintenance expenses, incur too much debt service and use other preservation capital to construct and then operate too many new rail projects."
Jeffrey Warsh, the executive director of the transit agency, which operates the state's heavy commuter rail, light rail and bus lines as well as the Newark subway system, agreed in many ways with the report's assessment. In fact, a similar critique was made by the agency itself in a report released Sept. 10 but was largely ignored outside transit advocacy circles.
Mr. Warsh disagreed, however, with the criticism that the agency had moved too quickly on costly new systems and rail lines. Without the rapid construction on the Hudson Bergen Light Rail system and the near-completion of the Secaucus interchange, he said, the agency will not be ready to handle the sudden increases in ridership in the wake of traffic snares since the trade center attack and the loss of the major PATH station beneath the towers.
"We are seeing a 45 percent increase in ridership that we weren't supposed to see for a decade," Mr. Warsh said. "Yes, we have moved fast, but without that, we would be in bigger trouble than we are after Sept. 11."
Martin E. Robins, the principal author of the report said that with its diversion of capital funds and growing operating deficits, the agency is "operating on two of its six cylinders." 
He said that roughly $236 million in capital funds is being diverted each year to daily operations that ought to be devoted to meeting future needs. New Jersey Transit has been able to dodge the immediate problem of inadequate state operating assistance through changes in laws that have given it more flexibility in how it spends federal capital funds. The State Legislature has also relaxed its rules on how the agency can use Transportation Trust Fund money normally earmarked for long-term investments.
"Some of this gap could be addressed through fare increases," Mr. Robins said in the study, "but the lion's share of responsibility rests with appropriations from the next gubernatorial administration and the State Legislature."
Because each 5 percent fare increase would net only $25 million, Mr. Robins said that even a 10 percent increase would not come close to meeting the agency's needs.
The board of New Jersey Transit approved a $1.14 billion budget for its commuter rail and bus lines for 2002 this past July, up $138 million from last year. The amount reflected state assistance to the agency, which was only one-third of the increased aid it had sought. This capped years in which federal operating assistance was virtually eliminated and state assistance was cut as well.
Kristen Fountain, spokeswoman for the Tristate Transportation Campaign, a regional mass transit advocacy group, said that there had been a "disconnect" between the long-term planning on mass transit needs and providing the operating money needed each year.
New Jersey transportation officials, she said, had embarked on ever-more ambitious plans, with the hope from year to year that their operating budgets would be increased to keep up with the pace.
"We need leaders who can bring the two processes together," she said of the long-term planning and the annual budget cycle. "It is one of the main things that the administration of Governor-elect James McGreevey ought to be focusing on, and maybe this study will help."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Commuters await trains at a station in Hoboken. New Jersey Transit has been using federal and state funds for day-to-day operating costs that were intended for long-term projects and maintenance, a study says. (Richard Perry/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE RED CROSS; 
Red Cross Pledges Entire Terror Fund To Sept. 11 Victims

BYLINE:  By DIANA B. HENRIQUES and DAVID BARSTOW 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 

 BODY:
The American Red Cross, humbled by weeks of scathing criticism, announced today that it would use its $543 million Liberty Disaster Fund only to assist the people affected by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, a decision that guarantees families hundreds of millions of dollars in additional charitable aid.
 The announcement is a sharp departure from the organization's original plans to steer more than $200 million of the Liberty fund donations into a reserve fund for potential future terrorist attacks and to use millions more for programs aimed at improving its own readiness for such attacks. 
 The reserve fund had provoked intense criticism from victim families and lawmakers, who accused the agency of misleading many of its donors about how their money would be spent. Only last weekend, the agency offered refunds to any disgruntled donors. 
But today, it went even further, promising not to use any of the Liberty fund for things like a $50 million blood reserve program and community outreach efforts. Instead, it vowed to spend at least half the fund, or $275 million, on cash grants and services to affected families by Dec. 31, and to announce its plans for the rest of the money in January.
"The people of this country have given the Red Cross their hard-earned dollars, their trust and very clear direction for our Sept. 11 relief efforts," said David T. McLaughlin, chairman of the agency's board of governors, at a news conference. "Regrettably, it took us too long to hear their message. Now we must change course to restore the faith of our donors and the trust of Americans."
As part of the changes announced today, the Red Cross will now cover a full year's worth of living expenses for the affected families -- from the four terrorist-led airplane crashes at the World Trade Center, at the Pentagon and in western Pennsylvania -- through its "family gift" cash-grant program, which was originally limited to three months of aid. That program, which has already distributed more than $47 million, will deliver an additional $111 million in cash gifts to families by January, the agency said.
The Red Cross also said that it will use some of the Liberty donations to hire more than 200 case workers to help families navigate the maze of charities that are trying to assist victims.
And finally, the agency said that it will use the interest earned on the Liberty fund to cover as many of the administrative expenses as possible. Agency officials estimated that fewer than 10 cents of every donated dollar will be spent on overhead.
"We deeply regret that our activities over the past eight weeks have not been as sharply focused as America wants, nor as focused as the victims of this tragedy deserve," said Harold Decker, who replaced Dr. Bernadine Healy two weeks ago as the chief executive of the disaster relief agency.
Mr. Decker also ended more than six weeks of confusion by committing the agency to cooperate with efforts to build a database of victims who have received charitable help, first proposed 10 days after the attacks by New York Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer, with the backing of most of the major charities responding to the terrorist attacks.
When the database was first announced, Dr. Healy rejected it as an invasion of privacy. Mr. Decker said he thought the database would help coordinate long-term help for families. Dr. Healy did not respond to a telephone message left at her office today.
Mr. Spitzer called today's announcement "a monumental step forward."
Mr. Spitzer, whose office regulates charities in the state, said he had been pressuring the Red Cross for weeks to change its plans for the Liberty fund. But at first, he said officials seemed impervious to his argument that the agency was effectively defying the wishes of donors.
He eventually told the relief agency that he was prepared to take legal action against it over its plans for the Liberty fund, Mr. Spitzer said. "What had been a misstep of some magnitude has now been corrected," he added.
The Liberty fund's new direction was also greeted enthusiastically by members of Congress, some of whom have been critical of the agency's previous plans.
Only last week, senior Red Cross officials were criticized by members of Congress and legislators in New York who accused the agency of cynically using the Sept. 11 tragedies to address long-term fund-raising goals and of siphoning tens of millions of dollars from widows and children.
But today, some of the same lawmakers who criticized the Red Cross last week attended the agency's news conference to express their support for the new deployment of the Liberty fund.
Representative Charles Bass, a Republican from New Hampshire and a longtime Red Cross supporter, called last week's hearings painful and commended the agency for moving "to respond to, clearly, what was the American will."
Families of those killed on Sept. 11 approved of today's announcement, too. "Now at least we know we're O.K. for a year," said Liz McLaughlin, a widow from Pelham, N.Y., who had offered emotional testimony on the subject before Congress last week.
As the Liberty fund's work moves from emergency relief to more long-term assistance, Mr. Decker said that his legal staff will be working closely with other charities and with Congress to clarify the Internal Revenue Service rules that apply to tax-exempt agencies to ensure that the relief effort is not impeded.
Under I.R.S. rules, tax-exempt charities are required to base their distributions on financial need, which in the past has been defined as an inability to afford the basic necessities of life.
Although Mr. Decker said that several hundred families who were offered help by the Red Cross have declined, because their own resources are adequate, many of the other families who have received aid are more affluent than the traditional I.R.S. definition seems to envision. This has stymied some richly endowed charities that planned to make large cash grants, across the board, to the families of firefighters and other uniformed personnel who died in the trade center twin towers' collapse.
The emergency assistance that is the traditional focus of the Red Cross is generally exempt from the neediness standards of the I.R.S., which noted that even affluent families may be left temporarily needy by floods, fires or other disasters. And the Red Cross hoped that by using case workers trained in assessing family needs, it can satisfy the I.R.S. standards going forward, said A. Frank Donoghue, the chief executive of the Red Cross's southeastern Pennsylvania chapter in Philadelphia.
Last week, as part of legislation to stimulate the economy, the Senate Finance Committee adopted a measure that would expand how charities could define financial need. The point, said a Republican staff member on the committee, was to avoid criticizing charities for not distributing donations to the victims of Sept. 11 while also tying their hands with the red tape of I.R.S. regulations.
"We're not going to put them in a hard spot," the staff member said.

Nations Back Freer Trade, Hoping to Aid Global Growth
Trade ministers from more than 140 nations meeting in Doha, Qatar, agreed on an agenda to topple tariffs and liberalize trade on everything from wheat to insurance.
 The members of the World Trade Organization sought to balance their national interests against the urgent need to shore up the world's battered economy. Page A12. 

Many American companies endorsed the new rules for negotiating a trade agreement. C3.

Terry Semel, the longtime co-head of the Warner Brothers studio who was named chief executive of Yahoo seven months ago, will convene a meeting with investors today at which analysts hope he will assure them he can reverse the company's sharp decline in revenue and find a steady path to growth in the harsh Internet environment. Market Place. C6.

Henry Blodget, 35, the stock analyst who became a symbol of the Internet mania that enriched some investors but ultimately cost many others dearly, is leaving Merrill Lynch, officials of the firm said. A1.

Enron Plans to Sell Some Assets

Eastman Kodak, contending with precipitous drops in revenue and profit, said that it was realigning its businesses along product lines rather than geographic ones. C3.

The Senate killed a $73 billion Democratic economic stimulus plan and accelerated talks about alternatives. B9.

Stocks rose on a 7.1 percent surge in retail sales. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 72.66 points, or 0.8 percent, to 9,823.61. A drug developed by CV Therapeutics, a California biotechnology company, could become the first new type of treatment for the chest pain of angina in more than two decades, doctors said. The company said it would file its application seeking government approval for the drug, ranolazine, in the second half of next year. Shares of CV Therapeutics rose $9.96, or 26 percent, to $48.35. C6.

Signs of Downturn Seen in Europe
Some of Europe's biggest corporations provided a spate of evidence that a real economic downturn may be coming sooner rather than later. World Business, Section W.

Newmont Pursues Two Acquisitions
Newmont Mining unveiled a plan to become the world's biggest gold company, with agreements to take over Normandy Mining, Australia's leading producer, and Franco-Nevada Mining of Toronto for a total of $4.4 billion in stock and cash. World Business, Section W.

Finding the Best Security Solution
To determine the most effective way to improve aviation security, the government could contract out screening in some airports and use federal workers in others. Then the Federal Aviation Administration could conduct undercover tests to see which system works best. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: BOLDFACE NAMES 

BYLINE:  By James Barron 

 BODY:
Moving Fast, With Anchor
DAN RATHER says a Philadelphia taxi driver who handled the wheel "like a Nascar driver" rushed him from the airport to the train station when his New York-bound flight was rerouted after the crash of American Airlines Flight 587 on Monday.
 Mr. Rather was on an American Airlines flight from Austin, Tex., that landed in Philadelphia around noon. The taxi driver made the seven-mile trip to the train station "in a flat 14 minutes," Mr. Rather said. "All I'm going to say is I put him on the incentive system." He would not say how much he had paid the driver, adding that he did not know the man's name. 
 Mr. Rather said he learned of the crash in New York from an inside source -- the pilot of his plane, who sent him a note before making an announcement on the public address system. "The note said, 'I'm not authorized to tell everybody this at this moment, but as a courtesy I want you to know,' " Mr. Rather said. "The flight attendant who handed it to me said, 'If you can keep this to yourself at this moment, we'd appreciate it.' I did. I didn't even call my office immediately." The pilot "laid out the facts" of the crash on the public address system a short time later, Mr. Rather said. Later the pilot said the plane would go to Nashville, then Baltimore, then Philadelphia.
Mr. Rather had arranged for a reservation on the train, and after dashing through the airport, he climbed into the cab, telling the driver there was not a moment to waste. "He took off very quickly, sort of jerked my head back," Mr. Rather recalled. "He said, 'Don't you worry, Mr. Rather.' I was in the chair" -- at CBS News in Manhattan -- "shortly after 2 p.m."

A News Star May Dim
The public-television types have the tin cup out, as they so often do. This time it is DALJIT DHALIWAL who will get the hook unless someone puts something in the cup, and more than pennies. WNET-TV says that for lack of $300,000 or so, it is dropping Ms. Dhaliwal, the British anchor whose fans range from DAVID LETTERMAN to autograph-seeking waiters at the Four Seasons restaurant.
WNET, which has distributed her nightly program since October 1998, has told 60 stations around the country that carry her "ITN World News" that it will stop supplying the program at the end of the year. Unless, of course, some money turns up.
WARD CHAMBERLAIN, a vice president of WNET, said that the program's principal underwriter, Virgin Atlantic Airways, had cut back on its contribution. "We're $300,000 or $400,000 short," he said.
JOHN C. RIORDAN, a vice president of Virgin Atlantic, said the airline had always expected WNET to find a second underwriter. He said he was disappointed that it had not done so, adding, "Airline economics have changed."

Interested in Fashion? Sure
"I've never been to a lingerie fashion show," SIGOURNEY WEAVER said on her way to her seat in a tent in Bryant Park, where Victoria's Secret models were about to show off the company's merchandise. "I think it will be great theater, especially for my husband," she added, flashing a glance at her husband, JIM SIMPSON. Joining them in the crowd were MACAULAY CULKIN, ALAN CUMMING, RUSSELL SIMMONS, MARK WAHLBERG and REGIS and JOY PHILBIN.
"This is a special favor for Regis," Mrs. Philbin said. "He very rarely really, really wants to go to something. But he really wanted to go to this. So I figured he must be shopping for me for Christmas."

HEADLINE: Sales Tax, Key to Budget, Plunges in Nassau 

BYLINE:  By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Nov. 14 

 BODY:
As Nassau County's top officials prepare to meet Thursday to try to patch together a budget that could avoid a state takeover, they are facing a major hurdle: the county's biggest revenue source is its sales tax, and no one is sure how badly it has eroded or when it might recover.
 The latest tax collections showed a scary plunge. Receipts for September skidded 16.9 percent compared with the prior year's figure, according to the State Department of Taxation and Finance. And in October, receipts were still down 8.8 percent from a year earlier. 
 "The sales tax is key to the budget, and these last two months were certainly the steepest declines seen in recent memory," said Dr. Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist for the Long Island Association, a group of business, labor and civic leaders. "The direction is certainly down, and down significantly." Nassau was especially affected by terrorist attacks in New York City because it is an adjoining county with many commuters who work in Manhattan and at the airports in Queens and in related businesses, Dr. Kamer said.
In the latest draft of the county's $2.2 billion budget for next year, the sales tax is projected to yield $851 million, nearly 40 percent of the total. It dwarfs any other revenue, including the property tax, fees and state and federal aid. But now no one knows for sure what the county sales tax, which is 4.5 percent, will actually produce.
The calculations are complicated by the effects of the World Trade Center calamity, the anthrax attacks, the plane crash on Monday, stock market gyrations, growing unemployment and the threat of regional, national and global recessions.
"Consumer psychology is hard to predict, and we have more uncertainties than before, a number of imponderables," Dr. Kamer said. "There's a lot of downside risk to any forecast today." Her projection is that sales will recover modestly, especially in the second half of next year, reaching an overall annual average of a 2.5 to 3 percent increase.
A deadline of Nov. 28 looms for the county to close what state monitors say are gaps of up to $45 million in the budget originally proposed by the retiring county executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, and revised by the County Legislature.
The opening talks on Thursday will bring the Legislature's majority and minority leaders and Mr. Gulotta together with the head of the state-appointed oversight board, Frank G. Zarb, chairman of the Nassau County Interim Finance Authority.
"What's happening with the sales tax is one thing we'll be talking about, what we can or can't assume for next year," said the Legislature's presiding officer, Judith A. Jacobs, a Democrat.
Her party is pushing for some combination of spending cuts and revenue increases above the 5 percent property tax increase already built into the budget.
But Mr. Gulotta, a Republican, has resisted tax increases in the past, and the Republican minority in the Legislature also favors spending cuts over more taxes.
Robert W. Lazaro, a spokesman for the minority leader, Peter Schmitt, has called on Mr. Gulotta to save money by wringing concessions from the county labor unions, to avoid a state takeover of the county's finances. "You can't tax your way out of this problem," Mr. Lazaro said. He also warned against "fudging the sales tax numbers." Critics have said that Mr. Gulotta's optimistic sales tax projections in the past were a prime cause of the big deficits that ultimately required a state bailout and the special oversight board.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: SECURITY COSTS; 
Additional Budget Cuts As States and Cities Address Safety Issues

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: DENVER, Nov. 14 

 BODY:
The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks are leaving a hefty financial bill with state and local governments, forcing them to pay for immediate security needs that were once only vaguely contemplated.
 From small towns like Red Wing, Minn., which is sharing weekly costs of $160 for a full-time guard at the local nuclear plant, to cities like Baltimore, where new security costs have reached $3.97 million since the attacks, government officials are taking a hard look at their budgets to figure out how to pay for efforts now deemed essential to homeland defense without layoffs and program cuts. 
 The National Governors' Association estimates that over the next six months, the post-Sept. 11 expenses could total as much as $10 billion in the 50 states. This is in addition to earlier projections of budget shortfalls totaling $15 billion due to the flagging economy and rising Medicaid costs. 
The total impact represents as much as 3 percent of a given state budget. 
"This makes a very bad situation catastrophic," Raymond C. Scheppach, executive director of the governors association, said of costs related to homeland security. "Most states have already done two to three rounds of budget cuts. Now they're preparing to do more and praying that the economy turns around."
For more than two months now, states and local governments have taken on the additional responsibilities to guard important buildings, improve airport security, protect water supplies, test for anthrax and pay the soaring overtime costs of police, firefighters and other emergency workers. 
"So far as I can see, everybody is reprioritizing and refocusing," said Larry Kallenberger, executive director of Colorado Counties Inc., a public policy group.
No state has been immune to new security needs since the attacks. Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift of Massachusetts authorized spending $26 million for terrorism-related efforts, including overtime for state police. The Ohio State Highway Patrol needs $800,000 over the next six months for increased security and inspections. Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has approved spending $12 million for personnel and programs to handle biological and chemical attacks.
In Missouri, Gov. Bob Holden protected education and law enforcement programs when he cut $400 million from the budget earlier this year. Now, costs related to the terrorist attacks have raised the possibility of more cuts, "and in the next round," said Mr. Holden's spokesman, Jerry Nachtigal, "those areas may not escape unscathed."
While New York City, in particular, faces costs in the billions of dollars, other cities and counties, whose fire and police departments and emergency medical personnel are often the first line of defense, have their own problems.
A recent survey by the National League of Cities found that the impact of the attacks on local employment and tourism could lead to a 4 percent decline in revenues for cities, the equivalent loss of $11.4 billion. More than half the 214 cities surveyed in late October said they increased spending on security after Sept. 11 and they would offset the spending by dipping into surpluses and cutting other programs.
"We are hurting," said Mayor Marc Morial of New Orleans, president of the United States Conference of Mayors. "Against the backdrop of seven to eight years of prosperity, low crime rates and low unemployment, all of a sudden -- bam -- Sept. 11 hits, and our revenues have been affected."
In New Orleans, Mayor Morial said, sales tax revenues plummeted 11 percent in September, which has forced a hiring freeze in city government and cutbacks in a variety of programs. Security costs for the city and the New Orleans airport, he said, have dug a $10 million budget gap.
In Baltimore, Mayor Martin O'Malley said city budget officials estimated that security costs could reach $15.8 million for the fiscal year.
"I've told all my agencies to sharpen their pencils and make recommendations of how to close the gap," Mayor O'Malley said. "But we could still face layoffs in January unless the economy turns around and the federal government acts quickly to help us."
Security costs in Dallas have passed $2 million and could reach $6 million by the end of the year, said Lois Finkelman, a City Council member. City officials have already begun inspecting budgets and searching for security companies to help ease police overtime costs. 
Other big cities have similar concerns, but most cities have a wide enough tax base to provide local leaders with room to spread the budget-cutting pain. That is not necessarily the case in rural areas, where many of the emergency services are performed by volunteers and where local leaders have to find clever ways to meet security needs.
In Red Wing, a town 50 miles south of Minneapolis, the need to post a guard at the road leading to the Prairie Island nuclear plant was solved by the plant management company assuming most of the costs, leaving the remainder to the city and to Goodhue County.
The solution -- city and county each contributing $80 a week -- seems reasonable, but the need to post a guard occupies one of Sheriff Dean Albers's 42 deputies for half a day, every day, at a time when the department has been told to step up its vigilance by "watching for suspicious low-flying planes and strange-looking people in the wrong place," as Sheriff Albers said.
"The whole thing adds more and more to our daily workload," he said. "Now, if we get a call that someone's mailbox has been damaged by vandals, it's not going to get handled."
The governors association and the mayors conference have lobbied Washington for help, asking for immediate reimbursements as well as access to long-term assistance through federal grants. At least one version of the economic stimulus package that Congress is now debating, a proposal from Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, would provide $6.3 billion for state and local efforts. 
But some places are not waiting for the federal government to act. Colorado and Illinois are debating the idea of using revenue from the state lottery to offset defense costs. And as a sign that virtually no area has escaped the impact of the terrorist attacks, officials in Catron County, N.M., who normally provide annual flu shots for local senior citizens at no cost, have been told that the sudden demand for flu shots amid the anthrax scare around the country means that the county will now have to pay $8.95 a shot.
With at least 150 people in need of the shots, said Jan Porter, the county treasurer, the cost could approach $1,500. But rather than use county money, Ms. Porter said, local residents are prepared act on their own.
"We hold a lot of fund-raisers when we have to," she said. "I suppose this time, we'll raise the money with an arts and crafts fair or maybe a bake sale."

GRAPHIC: Photos: In Red Wing, Minn., Officer Jon Beckman, above, was assigned yesterday to guard the Prairie Island nuclear plant. Members of the Massachusetts National Guard were en route to training for security missions around the country. (Associated Press); (Eric Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: AVIATION SECURITY; 
Security Firms Ever Mindful To Cut Costs

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL MOSS and LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
International Total Services Inc. had been faltering for years. The company, which screens passengers at major airports nationwide, was running out of money. 
 I.T.S., as it is known, paid so little that it could scarcely hire enough workers, and those it did hire quickly left. At one airport, when its army of 90 screeners had slipped to 60, the company had raised salaries by more than a third to attract workers. But then it started losing $80,000 a month on that one job alone. 
 After slashing costs, dumping contracts, and borrowing all the money he could, the company's president, Mark D. Thompson, was in the Midtown Manhattan offices of his lawyer preparing to file for bankruptcy on the morning of Sept. 11. 
With Congress locked in yet another round of debates over airport security in the wake of the terrorist attacks, the fortunes of I.T.S., one of the largest companies in the industry, illustrate how difficult it will be to reinvent a system that has long treated airline security as an amenity rather than a necessity.
When passenger screening began in earnest in 1973, the government left security in the hands of the airlines. But the carriers saw it as a money-losing proposition and turned the chore over to private companies. Since then, in the brutal economics of airline deregulation, the airlines have sought to cut the cost of security by giving contracts to the lowest bidders, even if those companies have minimal or spotty records. 
Cost cutting was so deeply ingrained that even as the government scrambled to tighten security after Sept. 11, some airlines called on their screening companies to slash costs by 15 percent, according to Kenneth P. Quinn, a former chief counsel of the Federal Aviation Administration who now lobbies for security firms.
For their part, the companies have often accepted money-losing screening contracts in hopes of winning more lucrative airport work, such as baggage handling. Many then cut corners in hiring and training their screeners, paying them minimal wages that led to high turnover and low morale, industry experts say.
This economic conundrum is at the center of the debate in Washington about overhauling air security, with the House and Senate at odds over whether federal workers or private companies should perform the bulk of the screening work. But the record of airline security makes clear that, whoever is doing the screening, important questions remain. 
Even with the higher pay that Congress is now considering, the industry will need to attract, train and hold onto people who can effectively perform the vital, if monotonous, task of looking for weapons that are almost never there.
And the government will have to do something it has never managed to do before: maintain a focus on security even after the crisis has passed. 
"There is enough guilt to go all around on this," said Douglas R. Laird, former director of security for Northwest Airlines and now an aviation security consultant. "Everybody has some of it on their shoes."

Shifting Safety Concerns
When Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded off Long Island in 1996, a commission headed by Vice President Al Gore rushed to overhaul airline security, fearing the jet had been blown apart by a bomb. 
But when evidence pointed to a faulty fuel system, the government's focus shifted to aircraft safety improvements, and the passenger-screening changes lost momentum.
Five years later, the F.A.A. was just getting around to adopting one of the panel's key recommendations -- that the agency assume direct oversight of the security firms -- when the Sept. 11 attacks occurred. 
"We had planned an announcement the next week," said Rebecca Trexler, an agency spokeswoman. "I had posters, pictures, a press release."
From the first, airport security has been an on-again, off-again imperative.
Screening began after a rash of hijackings in the late 1960's and early 70's. First federal marshals screened passengers, but only those who fit hijacker profiles. In 1973, screening began full force as every passenger was required to pass through a metal detector and place carry-on baggage on an X-ray machine.
The airlines insisted on controlling the process -- whether they were doing the screening themselves or hiring others -- and the federal government did not question the arrangement.
One former F.A.A. security chief, Billie H. Vincent, said the system appeared to work fairly well until 1982, when a bomb exploded aboard a Pan Am flight from Tokyo to Honolulu, killing one person. Security concerns increased, he said, but even so, through the early 1980's some airlines balked when he called to recommend security precautions in response to intelligence about specific terrorist threats.
"I would issue emergency orders the next day," he recalled. 
After the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988, a safety panel recommended that all screening employees be checked for criminal records. But at a time before computerized fingerprint analysis, the airlines successfully fought the move, arguing that the checks would take too long and cost too much.
To plead their case before Congress, the airlines hired William H. Webster, the former head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who called the background checks "a feckless gesture." 
While it is not known if such checks would have prevented the events of Sept. 11, Mr. Webster said recently, "We may have to go beyond what seemed reasonable at the time."
At the F.A.A., Ms. Trexler said her agency had been actively pursuing a number of security initiatives in the wake of Flight 800. Among them is a program to test the ability of screeners to detect weapons concealed in luggage. 
"It's the nature of the government that we can't do things suddenly," she said. "It's a long, deliberative process." 

Fierce Lobbying for Jobs
One of the early leaders in passenger screening was Wackenhut, the Florida-based security giant that guards nuclear power plants, prisoners, corporate executives and much more. Until the early 1990's, the company also had contracts at about 70 airports, but then smaller companies began edging it out of the business.
"The airlines kept lowering their prices and in most cases taking the low bidder, and we started losing contracts, one after another," said Patrick Cannan, a company spokesman.
Lobbying for the contracts became fierce. Michael B. Cantor, a consultant who worked in the mid-1990's for Argenbright, at the time a small but growing security firm, described how the company once courted United Airlines in Chicago. "We had dinner at a steakhouse, and there were maybe 20 or 30 guys," he recalled. "I looked at all the beefsteak on the table and thought, 'All the cows that gave their lives for this one contract is incredible.' "
Frank A. Argenbright Jr., the company founder, strove to distinguish his company in a highly competitive market in which the product all looked the same, Mr. Cantor said. When the Super Bowl came to Atlanta, where the company was based, "Frank had someone go out on the street and buy tickets at any price, for the airline guys," Mr. Cantor said.
In successfully vying for United's security work, Mr. Argenbright considered another approach, Mr. Cantor said. "He wanted to send them a check for $100,000 and say, 'If we do a bad job, you can cash this as part of the money for a transition to another company.' I said don't do it. It's nothing illegal but it would make everybody uncomfortable."
A spokeswoman for Mr. Argenbright said he had considered that plan but never carried it out.
Often, companies did not see the passenger screening contract as the prize. It was just a way to get their foot in the door for other airport work. Sky cap, or wheel chair handling contracts typically paid more.
Mr. Laird, the security consultant, described a chain of events he said became common. "If it takes 100 screeners to do a job, you'd bid it as if you were providing 97," he said. "Then you'd really staff it at 93 and hope you didn't get caught. That was the game played."
When security companies asked to get paid more, Mr. Laird said, "the airlines would never budge on the money and the product kept going down, down, down."
The F.A.A. uncovered thousands of breaches in security during the 1990's and issued millions of dollars in fines to the airlines. But industry officials say those fines were often greatly reduced through negotiation, if they were collected at all.
Last year, the F.A.A. fined T.W.A. $126,750 when its security firm allegedly failed to check the backgrounds of several dozen workers. But then T.W.A. went bankrupt. "We're still owed," said Ms. Trexler, the F.A.A. spokeswoman.
This should be a great time for International Total Services, which counts LaGuardia Airport among the major airports it serves. Of the four largest security companies, I.T.S. was the only one not involved in screening any of the Sept. 11 hijackers in Boston, Newark or Washington. It is also the only one that is still United States-owned, a potential advantage at a time of concern over national security.
But I.T.S. filed for bankruptcy reorganization on Sept. 13, driven to the brink of collapse not by terrorism but by the precarious economics of the airport security industry.
The company was founded in Cleveland 1978 by a group including Robert A. Weitzel, an aviation security specialist who in 1987 became the company's president.
Its explosive growth began in 1997 when the company sold stock to the public, raising $27 million. I.T.S. planned to buy mom-and-pop security and aviation-service companies across the country.
Such consolidations were a fad on Wall Street at the time and this one seemed to make sense. Airlines were increasingly contracting out everything from security screening to Skycaps and cabin cleaning, and they preferred to deal with a few big suppliers rather than many small ones.

A Company in Turmoil
But there were risks. The company had lost money as recently as 1994, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Passenger screening, in particular, was a low-profit business -- there was not much money left over after paying workers and buying equipment and uniforms. Employee turnover was about 100 percent.
Nevertheless, I.T.S. was a hit on Wall Street, where its share price soon doubled. The company spent almost $40 million (much of it borrowed from banks) in 21 months to buy the assets of 19 companies.
But most of what it bought were contracts, some of which were unprofitable and all of which could be canceled on short notice. Many of them were. Ultimately, the company wrote off $29 million of the acquisitions as worthless.
Like its competitors, I.T.S. found itself squashed between the demands for cost-cutting by airlines and the pressures of an economy with very low unemployment. "From an operational standpoint, we are all in the same leaky rowboat," said Michael F. Sosh, the company's chief financial officer. "We have the same employee pool, the same wage scale."
For example, in August 1999, I.T.S. was only able to hire 60 of the 90 people it needed at one airport, where it was offering just 10 percent above minimum wage, according to testimony it submitted to the Department of Transportation.
Worried that it would get in trouble with the F.A.A., I.T.S. raised the pay rate by 36 percent. Hiring increased, turnover plunged, screening improved. But the company began losing $80,000 a month on that contract.
As the company's finances worsened, accounting problems led Nasdaq to delist its stock in 1999. Almost a year later, when it finally reported its financial results to the S.E.C., they were terrible. Company officials had told shareholders that it had earned $1 million in fiscal 1999. In fact, the company had actually lost $7.3 million.
In a lawsuit filed Sept. 18, the company put the blame for its troubles squarely on Mr. Weitzel, who had retired in late 1999. As far back as 1995, the company alleges, Mr. Weitzel underpaid workers compensation premiums by $2.6 million, made accounting errors, and interfered with the company's efforts to sell itself.
Mr. Weitzel denies the allegations. As far as the accounting goes, "His response is that he used the correct standards, and the professional people he hired used them," said his lawyer, Jonathon M. Yarger.
Meanwhile, I.T.S.'s main business suddenly has prospects of making money, said John W. Demell, who runs the company's aviation operations. After Sept. 11, he said, "There's a different attitude about what customers are willing to spend for security."
As Congress continues to debate air travel security, there is still trouble at the gates.
Although airport managers typically play no role in picking security firms, after Sept. 11, David Krietor, who runs Sky Harbor International Airport in Phoenix, felt he had to take drastic action.
On the day air travel resumed after the attacks, a flight crew was allowed through security with a knife and a corkscrew. Then federal prosecutors alleged that Argenbright, which ran the Sky Harbor checkpoint, had hired workers around the country, including some in Phoenix, without checking for criminal records.
The airlines refused Mr. Krietor's request to switch security firms. So on Oct. 12 he took the unusual step of revoking the security company's permit to work at the airport.
Even that didn't work. The airlines have pleaded for more time. Argenbright, which says it has made numerous improvements nationwide, is still screening passengers in Phoenix. And three more security breaches have forced Mr. Krietor to empty entire terminal concourses so every last person -- most already jittery about flying -- could pass through metal detectors again.
"It's immensely frustrating," Mr. Krietor said. "I have virtually no control."
The question of who will control airport security is at the center of the agenda in Washington.
The authors of a bill passed unanimously by the Senate, including Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, the chairman of the Commerce Committee, and Senator John McCain of Arizona, the ranking Republican on the panel, argued that passengers would only feel safe on airplanes again if security was handled by law enforcement officers employed by the Justice Department. They argue that federal employees would be better paid than private workers and less likely to leave the job after a short time.
But House Republicans, led by Representatives Tom DeLay, the majority whip, and Dick Armey, the majority leader, say that increasing the federal work force by 28,000 -- the anticipated number of passenger screeners -- is unnecessary.
The House plan calls for the Department of Transportation to set strict standards, supervise and train the screeners, who would be privately employed. Civil service laws, House Republicans say, are to cumbersome and inflexible to get the job done. They also point out that in Europe, frequently, these same private security companies do a much better job because they are strictly regulated by the government.
Regardless of what shape the new system takes, finding the right people to do the job will remain the biggest challenge. Rising unemployment may help. But Amie Powell, for one, won't be signing up.
Ms. Powell liked her stint at an Argenbright checkpoint at Denver International Airport several years ago. But then she left it for a job as a waitress at the Chuckwagon Cafe.
Now she's back in the market for a new job, but she hasn't given a second thought to Argenbright's help wanted ads. Even with the prospect of better pay, she now has new concerns. "With all of the terrorism going on," she said, "it would be just too stressful."

HEADLINE: U.S. Companies Largely Back Trade Decisions 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
With some notable caveats, many American companies yesterday endorsed the World Trade Organization's new rules for negotiating a trade agreement, arguing that the potential for increased exports outweighs the damage a few industries might suffer.
 "We view the new round of negotiations authorized at the W.T.O. meeting as a hunting license for bringing down tariffs," said Franklin J. Vargo, an international trade expert with the National Association of Manufacturers. 
 The agreement reached yesterday by more than 140 trade ministers gathered in Doha, Qatar, sets the rules for a new round of tariff-lowering trade negotiations. 
There were dangers for some industries. Pharmaceutical companies objected to provisions that might weaken patent protection for drugs. Steel producers saw a risk that America's antidumping laws could be diluted. The textile industry worried that too much ground might have been given to foreign competitors.
Tariffs worldwide average 12 percent, down from 15 percent as a result of the Uruguay trade agreement in 1994. And now there is the promise of fresh tariff reductions.
"We will seek free trade in everything from digital cameras to black-and-white film," the Eastman Kodak Company said, "with the aim of cutting our tariff costs of nearly $200 million a year."

HEADLINE: U.S. Companies Largely Back Trade Decisions; 
Agreement on Medicines

BYLINE:  By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
The agreement on medicines brokered in Qatar makes it clear that poor countries can make generic versions of expensive brand name drugs for the treatment of AIDS and other serious epidemics -- a situation that the big drug companies have long sought to avoid.
 Some analysts and activists say that the new trade declaration could apply to almost any medicine that a country needs, including those that treat diseases like asthma, diabetes, cancer and heart disease. 
 But yesterday, the drug companies played down the significance of the declaration, which is intended to clarify an existing global agreement on patents. Gwen Fisher, a spokeswoman for Merck, said, "This does not change the way we sell our medicines." 
Alan F. Holmer, president of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, the brand name industry's Washington trade group, said: "We do not believe that our intellectual property rights are in any way diminished. We're satisfied with the language." He said he believed that the agreement applied only to highly contagious and devastating diseases and not to chronic illnesses.
Earlier, however, on Monday, Mr. Holmer had sent a letter to Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, warning that any compromise should not weaken the drug industry's patent rights.
James Love, the director of the Consumer Project on Technology, an organization that works to improve access to medicines, argued that the new declaration could be used to help lower the price of drugs and other health care products in all countries.
"This goes beyond AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis," Mr. Love said. "Any health care item could be included. We want to use this in the United States, in Germany and in Switzerland." 
Even before the declaration, poor countries had the right to make copycat versions of a brand name medicine in the event of a health emergency by issuing what is called a compulsory license. But no country has done so, in part because of fears about trade sanctions. Yesterday's declaration makes it clear that each country has a right to grant compulsory licenses and to determine what constitutes a health emergency.
Richard T. Evans, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein, said that the declaration would help to legitimize the business of making copycat versions of brand name drugs in many developing countries, and some companies will probably never be able to make money in those countries. "We can write off the developing countries," he said, "as a long-term source of profits." MELODY PETERSEN

HEADLINE: U.S. Companies Largely Back Trade Decisions; 
Agricultural Trade

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
American agriculture officials said they were pleased with the outcome of W.T.O. meetings because it meant members of the group were prepared to move toward reductions of tariffs and other barriers to agricultural trade.
 The United States, the largest exporter of agricultural goods, has long been frustrated by high tariffs and other trade barriers in Europe, the Pacific Rim and elsewhere. 
While American farmers are highly subsidized for production at home, they get less export assistance than farmers in many other countries and the United States does not impose high duties on agricultural imports. 
 "This will give American farmers greater access to world markets," said Tim Hume, head of the National Corn Growers Association. "It's important because agriculture products face an average of 60 percent tariffs abroad."
The talks in Qatar do not signal a clear victory for United States agriculture because they are only the beginning of a process. They do, however, indicate that member countries would like to move toward a more liberal and open marketplace for food. Some companies are likely to be particularly big beneficiaries of trade liberalization in agriculture: Cargill and Archer Daniels Midland, the grain exporters, and Tyson Foods and Smithfield Foods, meat producers and processors. And farmers could see some higher prices. DAVID BARBOZA

HEADLINE: More Signs Of Downturn For Europe 

BYLINE:  ByEDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Nov. 14 

 BODY:
They are not using the word recession yet, but some of Europe's biggest corporations provided new evidence today that a real downturn may come sooner rather than later.
 Siemens, the electronics conglomerate, reported today that it lost nearly $1 billion in the most recent quarter. Lufthansa, in many respects the strongest airline in Europe, said that air travel had been down about 22 percent since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 and that it might well finish the year with a loss. And Allianz, the German insurance conglomerate, raised its estimate on the terrorist-related claims it will have to pay to 1.5 billion euros ($1.3 billion) from 1 billion euros. 
 As recently as last spring, many European companies thought they could dodge the economic downturn in the United States with only minor damage. That comfort had already largely evaporated by Sept. 11, but the anxiety unleashed by the terrorist attacks and the subsequent war in Afghanistan has had an impact on almost every sector.
In Germany, five economic institutes that advise the government released their most pessimistic forecasts yet for the nation, Europe's biggest economy, in the coming year. German growth, nearly nonexistent in recent months, will remain well below 1 percent next year as well.
Unemployment is rising across the Continent, while investment has declined sharply and consumer spending is anemic. Export growth has ground to a halt, even though the euro remains cheap compared with the dollar.
Siemens, with products as diverse as household appliances and nuclear power turbines, is suffering from steep declines in the demand for wireless telephones and networking systems. And because it still owns 51 percent of Infineon Technologies, its former chip-making subsidiary, the company has been badly hurt by plunging sales of memory chips for personal computers.
Siemens has announced plans to eliminate as many as 15,000 jobs worldwide. Infineon, where sales have fallen by nearly half in the last 12 months, is eliminating another 5,000 jobs. Rivals like Alcatel of France and Ericsson of Sweden are also cutting jobs by the thousands.
Heinrich von Pierer, the chief executive of Siemens, has already ordered a broad revamping of its businesses in telecommunication networks and mobile telephones. Siemens took write-offs and restructuring charges totaling 1 billion euros ($881 million) for the two units.
Investors greeted the Siemens report with relief, because most of the bad news was already known and Mr. von Pierer provided no new shocks. Siemens's stock climbed 7.6 percent, to 62.19 euros ($54.80).
But most European companies say it is still impossible to predict whether a real recovery will occur next year. Chemical producers like BASF have been hurt badly by plunging demand for chemicals used to make plastics. Vendors of luxury goods and high-fashion clothing have been hurt by consumer anxiety, particularly in the United States. Bulgari, the Italian manufacturer of luxury watches, suffered a 60 percent decline in its third-quarter profits and said sales had dropped significantly after Sept. 11.
Airlines and tourism companies are dealing with widespread fear of flying as well. Iberia, the Spanish airline, announced plans today to eliminate 2,500 jobs. That comes after the bankruptcies of Swissair and Sabena, and the growing threat that airlines from Ireland to Italy may collapse as well.
"Sept. 11 has changed the world," said Jurgen Weber, chief executive of Lufthansa, as he reported that profits had evaporated since then. "It has changed international air traffic more profoundly than any crisis before."
Lufthansa's profit in the nine months ended Sept. 30 were 290 million euros ($256 million), down 65 percent from the period a year earlier. Mr. Weber predicted that air traffic would remain depressed by about 22 percent at least through December, and analysts assume that the once-lucrative trans-Atlantic routes will be among the hardest hit.
For companies that already had problems of their own making, the situation is worse. Bayer, the chemical and pharmaceutical conglomerate, reported today that it lost 183 million euros ($161 million) in the third quarter; for the period a year earlier it reported a profit of 534 million euros.
Bayer was hurt by plunging demand and prices for basic chemicals, but its drug business has suffered even more, chiefly because Bayer was forced to withdraw an anti-cholesterol drug after it was implicated in more than 50 deaths.
Bayer was one of the few companies to get something of a lift from recent events, because it makes Cipro for treating anthrax. But Cipro sales will provide only modest profits, because the United States government forced the company to sell it bulk supplies at less than one-quarter of the normal price.
