HEADLINE: Retail Sales Increase 7.1%, Mostly From Car Incentives 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 

 BODY:
Retail sales surged 7.1 percent in October, almost three times analysts' expectations, as consumers spent money at auto dealers, department and discount stores and building supply outlets.
 The increase, reported by the Commerce Department, followed a 2.2 percent decline in September. The report also showed that sales excluding a record increase in purchases at car dealerships rose only 1 percent, after falling 1.5 percent in September. The increase in vehicle sales was a result of no-interest financing offered by manufacturers. 
 Some economists, noting the incentives-driven increase in auto sales, said that the unemployment rate, now up to 5.4 percent, would restrain spending in the coming months. "A weak labor market and a need to repair balance sheets is going to weigh on the consumer for some time," said Joshua Shapiro, chief United States economist at Maria Fiorini Ramirez in New York.
Analysts had expected retail sales to increase 2.5 percent and sales excluding cars to rise 0.3 percent.
October's total increase was the largest since 1992, the earliest that figures are available under the Commerce Department's most recent method of tabulating sales. It switched to a new method of computing retail sales figures this year and revised the data back to February 1992. Using previous accounting methods, the October rise was the biggest since 1968.
Sales of cars, trucks and parts increased by a record 26.4 percent last month after falling 4.5 percent in September. As General Motors, Ford and other manufacturers drew buyers into showrooms with interest-free loans, sales jumped in October to a record 21.3 million units at an annual pace, exceeding the 21.2 million pace set in September 1986, industry figures showed.
The report "demonstrates the power of economic incentives," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y. He added, "People told consumer surveys they were miserable, but they were willing to borrow money to pursue a bargain."
Sales at department and discount stores increased 0.7 percent after falling 0.5 percent in September. Those at clothing and accessory shops rose 6.9 percent last month after a 5.9 percent decrease in September.
Consumers patronized discounters last month in an effort to stretch their buying power. Sales at stores open at least a year were 6.7 percent higher in October than in the month a year earlier.
Sales of building material rose 2.8 percent in October, the biggest increase since April. Sales at stores offering sporting goods, books, music, electronics and appliances also rose.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
ALegal Eagle (His Ad Claims)

BYLINE:  By CRYSTAL NIX HINES 

 BODY:
In an increasingly competitive economic environment, a growing number of law firms are trying to create brand images that will set them apart from their competitors. To do so, they are developing sophisticated marketing campaigns complete with print, radio and television advertisements, even relying at times on kitschy slogans once commonly used to sell consumer goods.
 For example, Hale & Dorr, based in Boston, uses ads with fluorescent colors and the slogan, "When Success Matters." The ads proclaim the firm as counsel to innovators, visionaries and change agents. 
 In San Francisco, the law firm Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe has built a campaign around the letter "O." An advertisement for its intellectual property litigation displays a green life raft in an O shape and tells clients to "grab hold of Orrick." Another, a globe with a cut-out circle, declares that "the global economy is an Orrick business." 
And in Winston-Salem, N.C., the firm Womble, Carlyle, Sandridge & Rice illustrates its slogan, "Our lawyers mean business," with a bulldog. The mascot, named Winston, has appeared on airport billboards, coffee cups, T-shirts and mouse pads. "Is it serious?" said Pressly M. Millen, a partner and the chairman of the client development committee at Womble Carlyle. "Of course not. But if the idea is to be noticed and get name recognition, it's certainly done that for us."
Law firms have wrestled with the ethical question of whether and how to advertise since the Supreme Court lifted the prohibition in 1977. For years, most of the advertising was sedate and passive, often confined to small notices in trade publications. But as competition for clients increased, some firms began to look for a new and more effective ways to attract clients. 
"I find some of the ads revolting in terms of taste and content," said William B. Dunn, a partner at the law firm Clark Hill in Detroit and special adviser to the American Bar Association's Standing Committee on Ethics and Responsibility. "It's a shame if people are persuaded by some of those ads." He said that aside from some general prohibitions against false and misleading ads, there were few restrictions that state bar associations could place on advertising.
Although many firms have had marketing programs for years, only recently have some started to apply the techniques used by corporations and financial service firms to buff their images.
"Law firm advertising has really broken free," said Burkey Belser, president of Greenfield/Belser, a design firm in Washington that has helped more than 200 firms with advertising campaigns. "Law firms have gotten over the hurdle of whether it feels comfortable to advertise at all, and then once over that hurdle, are doing very creative advertising."
David R. Brink, a retired lawyer in Minneapolis and a past president of the American Bar Association, said that "as long as the ads are demonstrably true, they are probably all right from an ethical point of view."
"But from the point of view of taste," Mr. Brink said, "that's something else." He said that while the theory of advertising is sound, some lawyers "might regret the loss of more tasteful and seemingly genteel ways of yesteryear."
Experts say sophisticated advertisements, client forums and other marketing efforts are crucial in an environment in which firms must find ways to separate themselves from the competition.
"There might be 50 or 100 great firms," said Sylvia L. Coulter, marketing director at Hale & Dorr and president of the Legal Marketing Association, which has 1,500 members. "How do you tell which one to go to?"
For many firms, the answer, increasingly, is branding, with some firms trying to push the envelope to attract attention. A survey by the Legal Marketing Association found that half of all firms have recently conducted a branding campaign although most were relatively modest.
Womble, Carlyle was one of the first large firms to place billboards in airport kiosks, Mr. Millen said, and it took its bulldog campaign to the radio a few weeks ago.
Brobeck, Phleger & Harrison in San Francisco shocked the legal world this year by becoming the first nationwide firm to advertise on television, a forum traditionally reserved for personal injury lawyers. The firm's $3.5 million campaign included four 30-second commercials on the CNN cable network, with the computer graphics designed by the same company, Digital Domain, that produced them for the movies, "Titanic," "The Matrix" and "The Terminator," the law firm's marketing director, David Geyer, said.
"We think the early-mover advantage brings us this perception of being out front," Mr. Geyer said, "and it's my experience that clients want to work with firms that are out front on issues." 
On one of its television spots, an airplane stalls and descends toward the ocean. Then an oversized hand lifts it safely back toward the sky. On another, a train is speeding over a mountain pass and the giant hand reaches down to straighten the curves out of the track. Each spot ends with the firm's tagline, "Brobeck: When Your Future Is At Stake." The airplane ad was temporarily withdrawn after Sept. 11 and also after the jetliner crash in New York on Monday.
Mr. Geyer said that the advertisements "leave no impression we are chasing ambulances." He noted that when Andersen Consulting (now Accenture) became the first consulting agency tied to an accounting firm to advertise on television in the late 1980's, it was the fifth largest, while PriceWaterhouse was the leader. "Ten years later," he said, "their positions have reversed."
Mr. Geyer attributes part of the firm's growth to marketing efforts built around a strategy of "awareness, contact and closure."
According to The American Lawyer magazine, the firm has risen to the 14th largest in the nation -- with revenue last year of $476 million, a 52 percent increase over the previous year -- from the 33th largest in 1997, with $250 million in revenue. 
But others are skeptical that law firms will be able to create an effective brand image that will distinguish one from another.
"Marketing professionals in law firms have been led to believe that for a very modest investment, they can achieve the kind of 'brand' that is being achieved by the big accounting firms and other professional services firms," said Mark T. Greene, managing director of FGI Research, a marketing research company. "That's simply not going to happen for anything close to the marketing expenditures law firms have been making."
Mr. Greene noted that large corporations normally spend $100 million to $200 million on a marketing campaign for a product. Law firms generally spend about 2 percent of their gross revenues, and the average expenditure is about $136,000, according to the association's survey. Marketing costs for accounting firms average about 7 percent to 10 percent of gross revenue.
But Norm Rubenstein, chief marketing officer at Orrick, said that law firms could still achieve name recognition over time, despite modest budgets, by aiming at a smaller audience.
"Individuals who hire law firms are a less expansive universe than the entire buying public," Mr. Rubenstein said, "and the investment is different than it is for selling soap or Coca-Cola to every consumer in America."
Another obstacle, experts say, is the insistence of many firms on marketing themselves as "full-service law firms," rather than as leaders in particular fields.
"Law firms always want to be branded as a big firm with great lawyers and great work, but that doesn't get you anywhere," Mr. Greene said. "They haven't had the courage to say, 'Here's how we are different,' because doing that is in part saying what you are not. If you say you have the best intellectual property practice, the real estate lawyers are going to be upset."
Julie A. Eichorn, president of Paragon, a consulting firm for professional organizations in Austin, Tex., questioned whether clients are really looking for "one-stop shopping," and said firms needed to do a better job of identifying their expertise and "deciding which piece of the market they want."
Beyond expanding their marketing efforts, law firms have elevated the status of marketing directors, with some being called chief marketing officers and paid partner-level salaries. Many have been lured from consumer products companies and consulting, advertising and accounting firms. 
Mr. Geyer of Brobeck, who says he is in the middle range on the partner pay scale, had 15 years of advertising experience at J. Walter Thompson, as well as six years in Pricewaterhouse's marketing department.
Frederick J. Morsches, director of marketing at Foley, Hoag & Eliot in Boston, which has 240 lawyers, came from the card company Hallmark and the consulting firm of McKinsey & Company. Ms. Coulter of Hale & Dorr had nine years of sales experience at Wang Laboratories.
Although law firms are using differing strategies to emerge from the pack, the key, marketing directors and lawyers agree, is creativity.
"Our guiding principle was to try not to look like traditional law firm advertising -- which distinguishes itself in how boring it is," Mr. Millen said. "Firms can really overdo the stuffiness. The block-letter ads you see printed one after another in legal trade publications are a recipe for being ignored."

HEADLINE: New Horizons for CanWest 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: WINNIPEG, Manitoba 

 BODY:
You don't have to go far in Winnipeg to encounter the Aspers.
 The University of Manitoba has the I. H. Asper School of Business with its Asper Commemorative Room. The Asper Jewish Community Campus is home to a popular athletic club, two schools, a museum and a Holocaust center. The family has financed the Lyric Theater in a park adjoining the Assiniboine River, and the Manitoba Theater for Young People. Winnipeg's new ballpark is named for the Aspers' media company, the CanWest Global Communications Corporation. The Asper Foundation's offices are in the same downtown building as CanWest's headquarters. 
 The family's reach is becoming just as noticeable across the country, through the rapid growth of CanWest, which has shot up the rankings to become Canada's largest media company. In just the last two years, a spree of acquisitions has transformed what was once the smallest of the three national television networks into a sprawling empire of 16 television stations, 7 specialty channels, 26 daily newspapers and 120 community papers.
In the United States, CanWest has a partnership with the Tribune Company's Tribune Entertainment unit to produce and distribute television shows like "Mutant X" and "Andromeda." In Australia, CanWest controls Network Ten, one of the country's three privately owned networks, as well as its biggest billboard company. CanWest also has majority stakes in the No. 2 television station in Northern Ireland and in New Zealand's biggest radio network.
The company's revenues have more than doubled in two years, and its work force has grown tenfold, to 9,000 workers.
 The company reported on Wednesday that revenue reached 576 million Canadian dollars ($361.4 million) in the latest quarter, which ended Aug. 31. Operating income has grown rapidly as well, fueled by new acquisitions, but because of the cost of servicing debts taken on to make the acquisitions, the company said it had lost 37 million Canadian dollars ($23.2 million) for the quarter. 
Canada has a history of having international media barons emerge from the hinterlands. Lord Beaverbrook, who rose to own The Daily Express of Britain, grew up in New Brunswick. Lord Thomson of Fleet, the onetime proprietor of The Times of London, began at a radio station in North Bay, Ontario. More recently, Conrad Black, whose interests include the Telegraph group of Britain, The Chicago Sun-Times and The Jerusalem Post, started with a paper in rural Quebec.
The Aspers' horizons are no less ambitious. "Our objective is to create a lasting and unassailable worldwide media business," Leonard Asper, CanWest's chief executive, said in an interview.
Though its stock trades in New York and Toronto, CanWest remains a family business dominated by Israel H. Asper, Leonard's father and CanWest's chairman. The family controls 45 percent of CanWest's stock, and David Asper, Leonard's older brother, is also a senior executive. Their sister, Gail, is corporate secretary and runs the Asper Foundation. 
Israel Asper, known as Izzy, passed the chief executive title to Leonard two years ago. He has said he will give up his remaining official duties and his CanWest office next August when he turns 70, but few would be surprised if he continued to call the shots for years to come. "You have a certain moral authority when you're the founder," Leonard Asper, 37, said. 
Israel Asper, the son of Russia immigrants who operated a movie theater in tiny Minnedosa, Manitoba, built his career and his company in somewhat un-Canadian ways. Trained as a tax lawyer, he was frustrated in a political career after being elected to the provincial parliament. He started in the media business in 1975 by buying a small television station in Pembina, N.D., with three partners and moving it north to Winnipeg.
Now, in a country where the publicly financed Canadian Broadcasting Corporation is a dominant force, CanWest's Global TV network has carved out a profitable niche attracting advertisers to popular American-made programs. "They were great in assessing the hot new show," said Gordon Pitts, a Toronto journalist who is writing a book on Canada's media barons.
Too great, sometimes, for the liking of homegrown film producers, who have long complained of the difficulty of competing with Hollywood. When one called Mr. Asper and other private broadcasters "nothing but toll collectors between Canadians and their access to popular American shows," Mr. Asper sued, charging defamation; the case is pending.
CanWest bought more stations in British Columbia, Alberta and Ontario last year, making it a national network. A few months later it snapped up the Southam chain of newspapers from Mr. Black's Hollinger group for $2.2 billion, including a half-interest in The National Post, a paper begun by Mr. Black in 1998 to challenge The Globe and Mail. CanWest took full control of The National Post earlier this year.
Naming Viacom and the Tribune Company as models, Leonard Asper said that having a spectrum of properties under one roof had advantages. "You can go to advertisers with a deeper and richer tapestry of information of how they can reach their customers," he said. There are also economies of scale, like a companywide call center in Winnipeg.
And the Aspers are not done acquiring: radio stations and a billboard operation in Canada are high on CanWest's shopping list. "We've decided to fortify home base," Israel Asper said, adding that once the Canadian portfolio was complete, "we'll return to the international arena."
Leonard Asper said expansion in the United States was "a logical progression," but the company views the American market with caution. "You have to be both well capitalized and have very strong partners to play in the U.S. sandbox," he said. "A bad deal can ruin the company."
Britain is also a potential target. CanWest submitted the highest bid for Britain's Channel 5 television network in 1995, but regulators rejected it because they were unhappy with the company's programming plans. 
Analysts have expressed growing concern that the Aspers have already bitten off more than they can easily chew. Because of last year's acquisitions, CanWest's debt was $3.02 billion on Aug. 31, compared with $367 million in August 1999. About one-fifth of that debt is in high-yield notes at 10.63 percent interest.
"Our No. 1 corporate priority is to reduce debt," Leonard Asper said. CanWest Global has suspended dividends to conserve cash, and it has eliminated 130 jobs at the money-losing National Post.
Robert Bek, a media analyst at CIBC World Markets in Toronto, describes CanWest's debt as "a nagging thing" but "very manageable" in relation to other media groups.
The Aspers' ambitions may be tempered by their deep roots in the Canadian prairies. Although Israel Asper owns an apartment in New York, he and his two sons and their families live within five doors of one another on Winnipeg's stately Wellington Crescent.

HEADLINE: Toys 'R' Us Thinks Big in Less Playful Time 

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
With the economic downturn, the decline in tourism and forecasts of a dismal holiday season for retailers, it may be a risky moment to open a $35 million store, especially in a neighborhood that depends on out-of-towners for much of its foot traffic. But this Saturday, the giant retailer Toys "R" Us is planning to open what it calls the largest toy store in the world in Times Square.
 Once considered an ordeal for parents, with its unimaginative displays, crammed aisles and unhelpful salespeople, Toys "R" Us has been working hard in the last two years under its new chief executive to overhaul its image. 
 Starting Saturday, that effort will be put to its biggest test, as the company opens an airy new store in Times Square. At 110,000 square feet, it is big enough to accommodate a 60-foot-high Ferris wheel that children can actually ride, a five-ton dinosaur inspired by Jurassic Park and a 25-foot-tall replica of the Empire State Building, complete with King Kong. 
The new four-level store is on Broadway between 44th and 45th Streets, on the site of the Criterion movie theaters and Roundabout Theater. Once a seedy entertainment area, Times Square is now home to several prime office buildings, but it has only a handful of major retailers. A Warner Brothers studio store at 1 Times Square closed last month.
The opening comes at a time when the toy industry has been trying to cope with children's changing tastes and the difficulty in keeping up with demand for the most popular products. Manufacturers have also suffered from something that Chris Byrne, an independent toy consultant, describes as "age compression." These days, Mr. Byrne said, many children stop playing with toys when they turn 8, and many girls have outgrown Barbie dolls by 6.
Some retail experts, however, have predicted that toys will do well this season, because parents will want to indulge their children in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks.
Many toy retailers do half their business during the Christmas holidays, which leads K. B. Toys, a mass retailer more commonly found in suburban malls, to open temporary K. B. Toys Express stores in vacant Manhattan space. This year K.B. is quietly slipping into half a dozen locations, including the former site of a Wolf Camera store on 86th Street near Lexington Avenue.
At Toys "R" Us, John H. Eyler, the chairman and chief executive, said he expected his new store, which will employ 700 people, to have a successful Christmas, with families from across the region taking the place of tourists. It is being marketed as the chain's flagship and as a kind of indoor theme park.
As a flagship, the new store will have a role beyond generating sales, said Sally H. Wallick, an analyst with Legg Mason Wood Walker. "It's also there as a place to showcase new products and showcase the company in a new way," she said. Yesterday, even before the store had opened, Microsoft used it as a setting to introduce its new XBox video game system.
Formerly the nation's leading toy retailer, Toys "R" Us dropped into second place, behind Wal-Mart Stores, before Mr. Eyler was lured away from F.A.O. Schwarz. Since his arrival in January 2000, the company has spent $500 million to revamp 433 of its 1,583 stores, including its only other Manhattan store, at Union Square. A poorly performing Toys "R" Us at Herald Center on 34th Street closed in May.
The new store will epitomize the changes at the chain, Mr. Eyler said. "This is part of the long-term brand-building of our company," he said.
There will also be plenty of other brand-consciousness at the store, including the Pepsi Cafe. Each of the 14 cars on the Ferris wheel will promote a different toy or character, from Barbie to a Tonka Truck. Customers will also be bombarded by commercials from 45 video monitors throughout the store. 
In an arrangement that is commonplace in the cosmetics industry but is new in the toy business, some 25 manufacturers are sharing in the cost of displays like the two-story Barbie-doll town house.
Some toy industry experts expect the new Times Square store to steal some thunder from F.A.O. Schwarz's flagship Fifth Avenue store, which is half its size and is aimed at less cost-conscious tourists. Vendex, the company that owns F.A.O. Schwarz, recently announced that it was putting the toy retailer up for sale. 
But Mr. Byrne said there was no reason New York could not have both. "There's room for 'The Producers' and '42nd Street,' " he said. "Toys 'R' Us will not supplant the iconic role of F.A.O. Schwarz. It's a different experience."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY IN ART; 
Filmmakers Send a Message With Lego as the Medium

BYLINE:  By SARA IVRY 

 BODY:
LIKE many filmmakers, Rob Weychert has his ambitions. He used Stravinsky's "Rite of Spring" in one film and he makes allusions to "Brave New World" in another. He adores the films of Todd Solondz, whom he calls "the modern master of black comedy." 
 "I don't know anybody else making films now that makes me simultaneously want to vomit and laugh hysterically," Mr. Weychert said of Mr. Solondz. "It would be neat to try with Lego." 
 That's right: Lego. The brightly colored plastic blocks that snap together to create all manner of shapes have inspired a niche world of filmmaking called brick films. Lego directors like Mr. Weychert use the traditional technique of stop-motion animation, shooting the film frame-by-frame and moving the figures between shots to create the illusion of motion. Some of their efforts are viewable online at brickfilms.com and in a special section of ifilm.com. 
Most works are from one to five minutes, enough time to satirize just about anything, and parodies of "Star Wars" and "2001: A Space Odyssey" are a staple of brick films. But there is a small group of auteurs, like Mr. Weychert, whose film work suggests a movement away from a fascination with novelty toward headier terrain. 
Jason Rowoldt, a computer consultant in Washington and the founder of brickfilms .com, acknowledged that, among the 40 or so filmmakers whose work is online, some do stand out. "Along with every 10 really juvenile directors," he said, "you get someone who really does a good job and wants to tackle things." 
Russ Jensen, a 21-year-old art student in central Michigan, addressed racism in his short "Black vs. Yellow." Two minifigs (Lego-speak for minifigure) declare their mutual unjustified hatred. A third comes along, chops them up in pieces and then reassembles them so that the two figures are now, in the Lego sense, biracial. 
Mr. Jensen said he used yellow, rather than white, because of its dominance in the Lego palette. "The way I portrayed it is kind of silly, but I don't think it's any more or less silly than it is in real life," he said. 
The films of Mr. Weychert, a graphic designer who lives near Philadelphia, are far less earnest, mixing social commentary with a slacker spirit. In "Twelve Bucks," an unemployed minifig gets a job but fails to realize that the cereal factory where he goes to work is really a missile plant. 
"I knew that I wanted the story to tell itself without the characters necessarily knowing what was really going on," Mr. Weychert said. The film, which can be seen at brickfilms.com or at bredstik.com, traveled briefly around the country as part of an independent film festival. 
Mr. Weychert's first film, "Siege on the Corporate Identity Plant," ridiculed corporate culture. "Heat, Part Two" (there is no "Part One") is a fantasy about accelerated global warming over New Jersey. He has started another project, "As Good as Soma," an anti-consumerist sendup whose title is derived from a reference Huxley makes to a drug in "Brave New World." 
"One of the challenges I'm looking forward to overcoming is making something that can actually be moving or gut-wrenching," Mr. Weychert said. 
The Lego company is aware of brick films and last year released an elementary filmmaking kit called the Lego & Steven Spielberg MovieMaker Set. But Lego officials may not have foreseen the circumstances their minifigs would find themselves in.
Q. Allan Brocka, a brick filmmaker based in Los Angeles, made an eight-part, sexually explicit series called "Rick & Steve: The Happiest Gay Couple in All the World." It has been screened at many film festivals, including Sundance. "Girl," a short by a filmmaker in Bangor, Maine, whose professional name is Ben B., includes an alarming sequence in which the Lego child's mother snorts a line of cocaine.
"That's not in line with our brand values and not something intended with our MovieMaker or our products in general," said Mike McNally, a Lego spokesman, referring to the cocaine sequence. But he said that Lego had no plans to take any action against brick filmmakers, who generally derive no money from their work.
Mr. Weychert joked: "It's the big thing right now, you know. Survivor and Lego animation."

HEADLINE: Measuring Success: At Least the Talks Didn't Collapse 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 

 BODY:
For the Bush administration and other proponents of increasing commerce across borders, the biggest success of the trade talks that ended today in Qatar was that they did not fail.
 Buried in the complexity of the agreement worked out among the representatives of 144 nations are all kinds of provisions that could ultimately have a profound effect on governments and economies, on particular companies and industries, on workers and even on ways of life. 
 But as important as those details are, they were secondary over the last six days of negotiations to finding some way, through painful compromises and artful fudges, of building a consensus among the members of the World Trade Organization that liberalizing international trade was a priority worth sacrificing for.
The goal in Doha was quite limited: not to agree on dropping particular trade barriers or ending competition-stifling subsidies, but simply to agree on what issues should be put on the agenda for negotiations. 
Still, failure was a real possibility. The last attempt to begin a new round of trade liberalization talks melted down amid recriminations among governments and violence in the streets of Seattle in 1999. 
The trade ministers who gathered this time around were laboring not just under the shadow of Seattle, but also in a weakened global economy in which nations are under intense pressure to sacrifice the long-term economic potential of trade to the immediate political imperative of protecting domestic constituencies.
"Getting out of Doha with an agreement to launch a round was very important," said Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., president of the Economic Strategy Institute, a research organization in Washington. "Had they not done that, the W.T.O. would have been seriously wounded. And you would have had a serious negative psychological impact on global markets that are already struggling, and backward movement on trade barriers and protectionism."
It may have been too much to say, as did Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, that "the stain of Seattle" has been removed. Seattle, and subsequent protests at other international gatherings, have shown the potency and the breadth of opposition to free trade and the concept of globalization. 
That these talks succeeded -- under heavy security, in a location inaccessible to most protesters, at a time when vigorous dissent risked seeming out of step with the campaign against terrorism -- did not by any means prove that the protesters had lost.
It was a clear signal, though, that the nations assembled in Qatar did not want to repeat the mistake of 70 years ago, when the United States and other nations deepened the Depression by resorting to protectionism when confronted with economic trouble at home.
It was also a victory for the administration in the sense of assembling another international coalition, however reluctant and tenuous, on an issue that it had explicitly cast as part of its effort to combat terror.
Today's deal, President Bush said, "sends a powerful signal that the world's trading nations support peaceful and open exchange and reject the forces of fear and protectionism."
In cobbling together language that allowed each country to claim to have avoided making any concessions that would bring objections at home, the Doha negotiations put off resolving the really difficult issues. 
The European Union still has not given up its insistence that it should be able to subsidize its farmers. India did not drop its position that the entire thrust of trade policy was unfair to the developing world.
Mr. Zoellick gave ground in a real way on some issues. He signaled that the United States was willing to tilt the balance between the pharmaceutical industry's right to patent protection and the developing world's need for drugs to fight scourges like AIDS in poor countries.
But he agreed to put other issues on the negotiating agenda without conceding that the United States had any intention of giving ground. Many nations think the United States is far too quick to protect industries like steel from foreign competition by invoking antidumping laws, which are intended to bar imports that are sold below cost.
But even before the Doha agreement was complete, Donald L. Evans, the commerce secretary, said in an interview that the administration was only interested in clearing up confusion about how the United States and its trading partners could use such laws, not in restricting Washington's freedom to use them.
"It's not a matter of us saying we're not going to have the ability to use our anti-dumping laws," Mr. Evans said. "All we want to do is strengthen them."

HEADLINE: City Braces For Gridlock, Holding Line On Road Jobs 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
New street construction projects will be suspended from Monday until the new year as part of the city's plan to ward off traffic congestion during the holidays, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.
 "We're going to try to cut out all nonessential construction work during this period except for emergency work," work related to ground zero in Manhattan or to the site of the plane crash on Monday in the Rockaways, the mayor said. 
 The street construction embargo will apply to public and private projects not already under way, officials said, and the city will issue construction permits only in essential cases. Iris Weinshall, the city's transportation commissioner, offered as an example a request by Con Edison to add service to a particular area. "We would say, 'Unless it's an emergency we'd rather you put it off till Jan. 2.' " 
Despite the drop in tourism, officials have identified 10 "gridlock alert" days, the first being tomorrow, when they expect the number of vehicles in Manhattan to exceed one million. The city plans to strictly enforce "Don't Block the Box" regulations, aimed at drivers whose vehicles obstruct intersections after the light has changed, and extra police officers will be on the streets citywide, officials said. 
The city also plans to modify the timing of traffic signals on crosstown streets to speed the flow and use signs with variable messages to alert drivers to street closings or other conditions. Ms. Weinshall said drivers should look for information on the signs or on the Department of Transportation's Web site (www.nyc.gov/calldot).
Although tourism is down over all since the terrorist attack, Mr. Giuliani said, and there are fewer international visitors, domestic tourism does not appear to have been affected, and might even be up a little. Referring to the number of event tickets sold and hotel rooms booked, the mayor said, "The sheer numbers now would have been a good year, like, two or three years ago."
With the holiday season approaching, the mayor said, he expected people to start complaining about traffic.
"You should count your blessings," Mr. Giuliani said. "The more the city has traffic problems, the better the economy of the city is doing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said holiday traffic congestion could also be viewed as a sign of economic health. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE INTERVIEWS; 
Prosecutors Begin Effort to Interview 5,000, but Basic Questions Remain

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

 BODY:
The interviews will take place in homes, not police stations. Miranda rights need not be read, though lawyers are welcome to sit in. Interpreters should be provided. Do not ask about religion. Do ask about violence and terrorism. Feel free to mention reward money.
 Those are among the guidelines for law enforcement officials now scrambling to interview more than 5,000 young men who have come to the United States from countries with suspected terrorist links on student, tourist or business visas within the last two years. In a Nov. 9 memorandum to federal prosecutors and antiterrorism task forces, Attorney General John Ashcroft asked that the interviews be completed within 30 days, a schedule he acknowledged was ambitious. 
 The memorandum includes a list of set questions -- about the interviewees' activities in the United States, familiarity with terrorist groups and experience with weapons -- and requests written reports on each conversation.
As the nation's 94 United States attorneys began doling out lists of names and addresses to local and state investigators yesterday, several officials expected to carry out the sweeping task said that Washington did not explain how the list was compiled and that they remained confused about how to proceed. One investigator who spoke on the condition of anonymity said the vast exercise "puts a tremendous strain on agencies" and raises "all sorts of civil liberties issues."
Arab and Muslims in the United States said they had already suffered weeks of ethnic profiling and discrimination from neighbors and strangers and now feel the government is supporting suspicion based on background, not behavior.
"I know it's an emergency, but we've got to be smart enough to watch that we don't throw away the freedoms of what America is all about," said Ismael Ahmed, director of the Arab Community Center for Economic and Social Services in Dearborn, Mich., home to the nation's largest concentration of people from the Middle East. "It could be students now, green card holders next, citizens after that. We've got to be careful."
In his memorandum, Mr. Ashcroft emphasized that "these individuals were not selected in order to single out a particular ethnic or religious group," and that they should not be treated as criminal suspects. 
"The list was generated by taking a population of individuals and applying to that population a set of generic parameters," the memorandum says. "These individuals were selected for interviews because they fit the criteria of persons who might have knowledge of foreign-based terrorists."
Those on the list are men ages 18 to 33; officials declined to specify the countries where their visas were issued. The United States attorney in Vermont, Peter W. Hall, said those on his district's short list were not from the Middle East. But officials said that most of the 5,000 names had Middle Eastern connections. In Los Angeles, an official said the 100 people on his list were mainly Arabs who share characteristics with the hijackers, such as being enrolled in flight training schools or scheduled to attend community colleges.
Many officials across the country said they had yet to start the interviews and refused to discuss it. "We are following the guidelines," said Fred Alverson of the United States attorney's office in Ohio. "I can't give any more specifics."
Mindy Tucker, a spokeswoman for the Justice Department, compared the interview project to a neighborhood canvass after a murder.
"This is a preventative effort, focused on information gathering," Ms. Tucker said. "The instructions are clear. These are voluntary interviews, and anyone who doesn't want to answer questions doesn't have to."
Some civil liberties experts said such broad questioning of a group of foreigners was highly unusual, if not unprecedented.
"The legal dividing line between what's O.K. and what's not depends on exactly what they do, and with what tone," said Susan Herman, a professor at Brooklyn Law School. "Law enforcement people can always ask questions, and you don't have to answer. But people do have a tendency to think that if they're being asked questions, they should answer. Immigrants may be especially intimidated and feel they have to answer questions."
Among the concerns of Arab leaders and civil liberties advocates was what would happen if people's visas are found to be expired. 
In a companion memorandum to officials, also dated Nov. 9, the deputy attorney general says that "while the primary purpose of these interviews is not to ascertain the legality of the individuals' immigration status, the federal responsibility to enforce the immigration laws" is important. Interviewees suspected of being here illegally are to be reported to the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the memorandum says. 
The newly announced interviews come after hundreds of foreign students have already been questioned by law enforcement officers in recent weeks. Raheem Yaseer, deputy director of the Center for Afghanistan Studies at the University of Nebraska in Omaha, said F.B.I. agents have been polite, but left the students feeling uncomfortable nonetheless.
"They think it is a kind of discrimination, because they are not picked out randomly," Mr. Yaseer said. "There are lots of Latinos and there are lots of other people here, people from India -- they are not questioned."
In Pullman, Wash., at Washington State University, which has courted students from wealthy Persian Gulf states, an administrator said he did not know how his school and other universities would be affected, but that he would comply with "whatever the government mandates." 
"I personally wouldn't have any problem in helping to do what's necessary," said David Guzman, the school's registrar.
In Southern California, along a strip of Palestinian coffee shops not far from Disneyland known as Little Gaza, the sight of F.B.I. agents trolling for tips among store owners has become commonplace. Mazen Almoukdad, manager of a cellphone store, said business was off 40 percent because college students from Qatar, the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait are afraid to stroll the streets.
There was a mix of apprehension and acceptance among those who might just be on the Justice Department's list.
Mahmoud Khatid, a 36-year-old Palestinian who said he spent three years in the custody of the immigration service, said that despite his experience the questioning of Middle Eastern men about their knowledge of terrorist cells was understandable, under the circumstances of the Sept. 11 attacks.
"Any country would do these procedures," Mr. Khatid said. "There is nothing to worry about. A questioning is a questioning."
But Arsalan Iftikhar, a law student at Washington University in St. Louis and a spokesman for the Council on American-Islamic Relations, was one of many people who compared the situation to "The Siege," a movie in which hundreds of Arabs are rounded up after a terrorist attack.
"We want to see the perpetrators brought to justice, but this sort of sweeping investigation really carries with it the potential of marginalizing an entire demographic," Mr. Iftikhar said. "We never thought they would go for people who are here lawfully. How do we know the next step is not going for citizens of Middle Eastern descent also? Where do we draw that line?"

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: FEDERAL AID; 
Panel Defeats Effort to Give Billions More To New York

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 

 BODY:
A measure that would have provided billions of dollars to help New York recover from the Sept. 11 terrorist attack was narrowly defeated tonight by a House committee after the White House applied pressure on lawmakers to oppose it.
 The measure was advanced by a bipartisan coalition of New York lawmakers in the House who defied a veto threat from President Bush. 
 The vote against the measure by the House Appropriations Committee makes it doubtful that New York will get any additional federal aid this year beyond what the White House and Congress have agreed to provide.
The vote was 33 to 31. Thirty-two Republicans and one independent voted against the measure. The two New York Republicans on the committee joined 29 Democrats in supporting it. One Republican abstained. 
"It was really disappointing that my colleagues from across the aisle and from other states failed to support New York tonight," said Representative Nita M. Lowey, a Democrat from Westchester.
The vote came after a day of furious back-room negotiations and maneuvering. Vice President Dick Cheney even summoned several New York House members to the White House and urged them to abandon their plans and avoid a showdown, according to the lawmakers and their aides.
New York Democrats and Republicans had made the spending measure a top priority, hoping to test Mr. Bush's pledge to help New York in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center.
More than that, Democrats saw the vote as an opportunity to highlight the difference between their priorities and those of the Bush White House and its Republican allies on Capitol Hill.
"It's like rubbing salt on New York's wound," said David Sirota, a spokesman for Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the ranking Democrat on the committee.
The standoff arose out of the president's promise to provide New York with $20 billion in aid in the days after the terrorist attack. Since then, the administration has sought to deliver the money piecemeal.
That approach has drawn criticism from New York Democrats in the House, who have questioned whether the White House and Republican leaders in Congress could be trusted to fulfill the president's promise without public pressure.
The dispute reached a new level when House Democrats from New York managed to win the support of the two New York Republicans on the Appropriations Committee: Representatives James T. Walsh and John E. Sweeney, both from upstate.
Mr. Walsh and Mr. Sweeney joined New York Democrats in pushing a measure to provide $9.73 billion in additional aid for New York. The New York Democrats on the committee are Jose E. Serrano of the Bronx, Maurice D. Hinchey of Saugerties in the Hudson Valley, and Mrs. Lowey. 
Throughout the day, New York lawmakers worked furiously to win the support of their colleagues on the committee, where Republicans outnumber Democrats, 35 to 29.
But even before the vote was taken, it became increasingly apparent that the New Yorkers would probably fall a few votes short of victory. 
Earlier in the day, Mrs. Lowey emerged from her meeting with Mr. Cheney in the Roosevelt Room of the White House saying that the vice president had sought to reassure her that the administration had every intention of fulfilling the president's commitment in due time.
But she said she was not swayed by his arguments.
To date, the White House and Congress have moved to give New York about $9.2 billion of the $20 billion that President Bush promised. But New York lawmakers are worried that the White House and Congress will stall on the rest, particularly because Washington suddenly has to pay for antiterrorism measures and a war in Afghanistan as the national economy slumps.
The money that has been set aside came out of a $40 billion package that the president and Congress had approved to help pay for disaster relief, military actions and counterterrorism measures. President Bush has threatened to veto any bill adding money to that amount. 
New York's entire $20 billion was supposed to come out of that package. New York lawmakers said they decided to force the issue when they realized that the state would receive only about $9.2 billion of that $40 billion. The White House insists that the rest will come as New York needs it, presumably from some future appropriation.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED; 
Democrats' Stimulus Plan For Economy Dies in Senate

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 

 BODY:
Senate Republicans used procedural votes today to kill a $73 billion Democratic economic stimulus plan. After a party line vote failed to advance the measure, talks about alternatives accelerated. 
 Moderates offered proposals that they said would form appealing compromises between the Democratic bill, which emphasized aid to the unemployed, and Republican ones, which relied heavily on tax cuts. 
 Senate leaders sought support instead for immediate bipartisan negotiations with the House, which passed a $109 billion measure dominated by tax cuts on Oct. 24. And John Feehery, the spokesman for Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, expressed guarded interest in the idea after rejecting it on Tuesday. Any bill to come out of such negotiations would then be voted on by both houses. 
A 51-to-47 majority of the Senate actually voted in support of the Senate Democratic bill today, but that fell short of the 60 votes required to overcome two points of order, asserting that the bill violated Senate procedures. The first objection was that $15 billion for homeland defense did not constitute an "emergency" under the budget act, which in past years has allowed extra spending for hiring census takers. 
The Bush administration opposed that spending as unnecessary and beyond limits agreed on in early October. But Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who is chairman of the Appropriations Committee, argued: "We are now faced with security threats that were not foreseen last month -- the stuff of nightmares. Anthrax appeared like a vampire in the night, sapping us of our customary optimism. The threat of smallpox may face us for the first time in over 20 years." 
The second point of order was that the bill exceeded provisions for tax cuts and spending in this year's budget resolution. No one argued that it did not, but Democrats went through the ritual of moving to waive that provision and lost again by the same margin. All 50 Democrats and Senator James M. Jeffords, the Vermont independent, backed the bill. Forty-seven Republicans opposed it, and two did not vote.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader who argued intensely for the bill, had said repeatedly that he did not want to compromise once with Senate Republicans and again with House Republicans. Mr. Daschle has said negotiations should involve both parties, both houses and the Bush administration. The Republican leader, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, agreed.

HEADLINE: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK; 
Out at the Ranch, Guests From Russia

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: CRAWFORD, Tex., Nov. 14 

 BODY:
Vladimir V. Putin may have looked relaxed out here on the Texas prairie this afternoon, riding shotgun as he bounced along in President Bush's gleaming pickup. 
 But he still hasn't agreed to amend or walk away from an arms control treaty that prohibits the kind of antimissile system that Mr. Bush wants to test. Even Mr. Bush's pledge on Tuesday to cut America's nuclear arsenal by two-thirds did not succeed at that. So tonight, at the rambling stone house that the Bushes have just completed on the prairies and in the canyons that cut through central Texas, the president shifted to Plan B. 
 It involved plying the Russian president and his wife, Lyudmilia, with mesquite-smoked beef tenderloin, southern fried catfish, grilled sourdough bread and pecan pie, all washed down by a Texas hill country wine (really) and consumed to the country-and-western music of an Austin band, the Ranchhands.
No one knows whether this approach will work, especially as it was dampened by a thunderstorm that swept across the 1,600-acre ranch just as the festivities were supposed to get under way. 
But Mr. Bush's aides conceded that some unexpected obstacles had emerged to separate them from the grand bargain that they had envisioned here, including a Russian insistence that Mr. Bush's word to cut nuclear arms, however good, needs to be backed up by treaties. 
Still, Mr. Bush's aides insisted that they were not disappointed by the first day of talks in Washington. And they said that the meeting in this town of 631, a one-stoplight crossroads that this morning was dotted with handwritten greetings like, "Texas Says 'Howdy,' Russian President Putin," was just part of a complex process that will go on for months. 
But it was hard to hide the truth. Mr. Bush desperately wants a deal that would make it unnecessary for him to withdraw from the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972, a move that would tear at the antiterrorism coalition that he has painstakingly built. He wants the deal struck here, where it could be called the Crawford accord.

Business Casual, Haltingly
Mr. Putin arrived here well briefed, and almost properly attired. By the time his helicopter touched down at the new helipad 500 yards or so from the Bushes' house, he was wearing black slacks, a black short-sleeve golf shirt and a wide belt. But at a moment when he desperately needed cowboy boots -- it's muddy on the ranch, especially today -- he was left with loafers, the surest giveaway in Crawford of a city slicker.
It wasn't Mr. Putin's first stop in Texas. He spent the morning with another Bush -- George H. W., the president's father -- at Rice University, where he addressed a concert hall filled with students, business leaders and members of the Texas political gentry. Lloyd M. Bentsen, the former senator and treasury secretary, watched in a wheelchair from the side of the hall, as Mr. Putin strode into the room accompanied by former President Bush and his former secretary of state, James A. Baker III. 
The oddity of the moment was striking. Critics of the elder Mr. Bush and Mr. Baker say the relationship now blossoming between the United States and Russia should have blossomed a decade ago. 
Mr. Putin recalled that when he first met Mr. Baker, he himself was a "modest city bureaucrat and Mr. Baker was a big boss." He briefly made the case that Russia needed a bigger voice in NATO -- membership and a vote would be nice, he seemed to suggest. But he sensed, correctly, that the invited crowd wanted to talk business, not politics. 
So he quickly turned to comparisons between Russia and Texas, focusing, naturally, on oil. "I'd like to say that in the Russian market, your risks are much lower than a few years ago," he said. 
Things would have been fine if he had stuck to the economic comparisons. But then he wound into a joke about cowboys in both countries that his translator mangled badly, and that left the audience entirely confused. "It sounded," an administration official said, "a little like our ABM negotiations."

New to the Prairie
Mr. Putin is the first foreign leader to visit Mr. Bush at what he calls his true home, and clearly Mr. Bush was itching to get back to the place he loves.
"We haven't been back since the war began," he said on Tuesday night. This morning, he was up at dawn running the trails down to the river and, then, after convening his daily national security meeting by videoconference, he was outside again, Reagan-like, clearing brush.
But he returned to a place that, like the rest of the country, has been changed by the attacks on Sept. 11. 
Farmers around here were cautioned that there was only one place for their crop dusters this week -- on the ground.
Fighter jets were constantly flying overhead. When Mohammad al-Alami, a reporter from Al Jazeera, the Arab satellite television network, arrived at the Waco airport, he was temporarily detained because his company credit card was found to be "linked to Afghanistan," he reported. 
The Federal Bureau of Investigation confirmed the detention, but said the reporter was released when it was clear that al Al Jazeera and Al Qaeda, the terrorist network, were very different. "I gave them my passport and my professional accreditation," he said, "but the people I've spoken to haven't heard of Jazeera." 
Meanwhile, back at the ranch, the talk was all about dinner carefully planned for weeks by Laura Bush. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell flew in, along with Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans, who recently took an American business group to Moscow. 
The triumverate of Mr. Bush's closest advisers was there as well, the chief of staff, Andrew H. Card, along with the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, and Karen Hughes, Mr. Bush's counselor. (Karl Rove, the president's top political adviser, stayed away.)
Then there were the local celebrities -- Ben Crenshaw, the golfer, and Van Cliburn, the pianist, who lives in Fort Worth. A few of Mr. Bush's friends arrived, too, like Tony Garza, probably the first Texas railroad commissioner present at a United States-Russia summit meeting. 
They ate, the White House said, in a breezeway that connects the main house from the guest quarters. There were toasts, and a celebration of the release this evening of the eight humanitarian workers held hostage by the Taliban. Then Mr. Bush brought out a birthday cake for Ms. Rice, who turned 47 today. She and several other guests danced to Texas country tunes.

HEADLINE: Powell Poised To Announce New Strategy In Middle East 

BYLINE:  By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell is poised to unveil a new American strategy to end the violence between Israelis and Palestinians and restart talks aimed at creating a Palestinian state, senior administration officials said today.
 In a long-awaited speech that could be delivered as early as Monday during a scheduled visit to the University of Louisville in Kentucky, Secretary Powell will signal that the Bush administration will take a more active diplomatic role in bringing peace to the region, the officials said. 
 Still, these officials said, the speech will be directed as an emotional appeal to both sides to take concrete steps toward peace, not as a blueprint that somehow breaks from previous American positions.
They said a draft of the speech would urge Israel to halt the construction of any new settlements in Palestinian areas after a cease-fire is put in place and negotiations are resumed. 
It will also repeat calls to the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, to both end the violence and the incitement to violence and arrest those who are wanted for their suspected involvement in terrorist attacks.
"He always says he is doing that, that he is making the maximum effort," Secretary Powell said in an interview with The New York Times this week. "We think he can do more and I say that to him." 
Secretary Powell said that in his meeting with Mr. Arafat on Sunday, he told the Palestinian leader to "bring under control all of those elements under your control" and "use your moral authority as leader of the Palestinian people and not only end the violence but also end the incitement to violence." When that has been effort has been shown, Secretary Powell added, even if the results are less than 100 percent, "it gives us a lot more to work with." 
Officials said Secretary Powell would not incorporate President Clinton's outline that provides for Jerusalem to be open and undivided, the recognized capital of two states, Israel and Palestine. Instead, he would announce that the thorny issue should be left to the final stage of peace negotiations.
Secretary Powell said in the interview that the speech would be "a comprehensive statement of what the United States stands for," adding that it would build on President Bush's address to the General Assembly on Saturday, in which he said clearly that the state of Palestine should be created. 
But despite the fact that the Middle East speech has been in the works for months, a final draft has yet to be agreed on and the White House has not given final approval, a senior administration official said. 
Mr. Bush came into office determined not to take the same active role that President Clinton had, which comes with the risk of failure. During the October 2000 presidential debate, for example, Mr. Bush said that "it can't be the United States timetable as to how discussions take place," a criticism of Mr. Clinton's failure to broker a peace agreement at Camp David last year. 
Asked whether Mr. Bush would assume a larger peace-making role, Secretary Powell said that the United States needed to "build slowly and carefully" and that when there is progress Mr. Bush will become "more engaged than he is now."
Until the Sept. 11 attacks, there was considerable resistance inside the administration to a Powell speech that would commit the United States to take a more hands-on role. 
But perhaps more than other senior official, Secretary Powell has recognized the deep resentment and anger in the Arab and Muslim world toward the United States because of the Palestinian crisis. Asked by the Jazeera television network six days after the attacks why America is hated in the Muslim world, Secretary Powell acknowledged that violence in the Middle East had created a "sense of hopelessness" and that terrorism is fueled by these "grievances."
In the interview, Secretary Powell stressed that it was "essential to move quickly in order to jump-start the Palestinian economy again, let people get to work and remove the level of humiliation that exists in the region." That reality "adds to the anxiety and the aggressive activity and behavior on the part of so many people," he said.
One element inhibiting a more concrete American plan is that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, who is now scheduled to visit Washington the first week in December, and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres of Israel themselves have still not forged a common strategy.
Secretary Powell was to have announced his Middle East strategy in a speech to the General Assembly in September, which was delayed because of the terrorist attacks. In the interview, Secretary Powell joked that his was "the most famous non-speech ever given this year."

HEADLINE: Despite Woes, Indonesia Economy Grew in 3rd Quarter 

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
Indonesia's currency is sliding, inflation is rising and government finances are a mess. But its economy still managed to grow faster than expected in the third quarter, demonstrating what the World Bank calls the country's ability to muddle through the global slowdown and its own political confusion.
 Indonesia's Central Bureau of Statistics said today that the economy grew 3.5 percent in the third quarter, compared with the third quarter of 2000, largely on the strength of low-end manufactured exports and domestic consumption. Exports, though slowing, were up 6.6 percent in the third quarter; domestic spending rose 7.1 percent. 
 At the same time, the government appears headed for a fiscal breakdown unless it can somehow push through long-delayed asset sales by the end of the year. Publicly, officials express optimism, but finance ministry officials said they were holding meetings to decide which government programs -- from public housing and rural finance to education and disaster relief -- would be cut back to close a probable budget deficit of at least 30 trillion rupiah ($2.8 billion).
While the rest of the world assesses how much has changed since the terror attacks of Sept. 11, in Indonesia the atmosphere is very much one of business as usual, or rather turmoil as usual. Though the country has made significant progress under a $5 billion rescue program from the International Monetary Fund, it has yet to recover from the currency and financial crises that swept Asia in 1997 and 1998. In the three and one-half years since the fall of Suharto, three successive presidents have failed to overcome parliamentary bickering and push through controversial reform measures, rein in corruption or restore investor confidence. 
"The problem is politics," said Steven Hess at Moody's Investors Service in New York. "That's the price of converting form 32 years of one-man rule to democracy. It's messy."
Indonesia is both large enough -- its population of 204 million is No. 4 in the world after China, India and the United States -- and poor enough that domestic spending on even basic consumer necessities can yield economic growth. Indonesians manage to save a fairly high proportion of their annual income, which averages $600 a person, allowing them to keep spending even in difficult times. And in contrast to wealthier neighbors like Singapore and Malaysia, Indonesia does not depend on high-technology exports and has not been hit hard by the slowdown in that sector.
The problem is that economic growth has not been fast enough to generate the millions of new jobs the country needs to keep ahead of population growth and keep more citizens from slipping into poverty.
Economists say Indonesia must find a way to attract much more foreign investment, which fell 50 percent in the first nine months of 2001, to $6.05 billion. 
Beyond regional unrest and political uncertainty, investors are disappointed by the government's failure to keep promises to privatize its business holdings. A planned sale of the state's 51 percent stake in Bank Central Asia, which may raise 5 trillion rupiah ($470 million) or more, is now unlikely to happen before year-end, officials acknowledge. A deal to sell the country's largest cement company, Semen Gresik, to Cemex of Mexico for another 5 trillion rupiah has foundered over local opposition to foreign ownership. 
As a result, Indonesia's currency has fallen more than 10 percent this year, pushing up prices for imported goods and leading the central bank to raise interest rates while most of the world's main central banks were cutting them. Higher rates raised the cost of servicing the government's debt, now equivalent to more than 90 percent of Indonesia's gross domestic product, and left the Jakarta government unable to use either of the traditional tools for stimulating the economy -- added public spending and looser monetary policy.
"Everything at the end of the day centers on the rupiah," said Heriyanto Irawan, head of research at Merrill Lynch in Jakarta. "And the direction of the rupiah depends on the level of confidence in the government."
Along with foreign aid, asset sales are supposed to plug Indonesia's budget deficit, but the government is 13 trillion rupiah ($1.2 billion) short of its sales target for the year. And failure to live up to past commitments to international aid agencies, including the World Bank, has denied Indonesia roughly $1.7 billion in new foreign loans. The agencies say continued failures may deny Indonesia another $1.3 billion next year.
But Indonesia's economy will muddle through anyway, the World Bank said in its report. Illustrating how, the country's automotive industry reported today that car sales rose 2.2 percent in the first 10 months of the year, while sales of motorbikes more than doubled.

HEADLINE: Brazil Welcomes Global Move on Drug Patents 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER L. RICH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
The Brazilian government, which has challenged the giant drug companies' patent defenses perhaps more aggressively than any other country, hailed the World Trade Organization's declaration on drug patents as an important victory for the developing world's fight against health scourges like AIDS.
 The decision also promises to open the way for Brazil to realize a long-held ambition: to export its low-cost versions of AIDS drugs to countries without the resources to produce their own. 
 Such exports have frequently been blocked by confusion surrounding international patent rules and by pressure from multinational pharmaceutical companies, which scared off many countries that might have been buyers. 
In Brazil's view, the text of the agreement reached at Doha, Qatar, gives each of the organization's 144 members discretion to set its own rules for issuing "compulsory licenses," which force patent holders to allow rivals to manufacture patented drugs. And each country is free under the agreement to set its own criteria for what constitutes a national public health emergency, the justification for compulsory licenses. 
Before the Doha conference, the question of compulsory licenses had been left unclear in the organization's 1994 treaty on intellectual property rights. 
Brazil has been on the forefront of attacking AIDS in the developing world since 1998, when it began copying and producing some of the antiretroviral drugs used in "cocktails" to treat AIDS. The Health Ministry provides the cocktails free to patients, and turned to making them domestically when the cost of importing brand name drugs threatened to bankrupt the program. Brazilian patent law protects drugs only if they were commercialized after 1997.
Unlike India, where private companies do most of the copycat drug making, Brazil has made patent breaking a direct activity of the government. Seven state-owned laboratories now produce generic copies of 8 of the 12 drugs used in the AIDS cocktail, at a tiny fraction of the prices charged by multinational pharmaceutical giants like Merck and Roche.
Under pressure from the drug companies, the United States government threatened to bring a complaint against Brazil at the World Trade Organization, accusing it of violating the 1994 treaty. The complaint was dropped after a sustained public outcry, and Brazil reached accommodations with some of the giant drug makers.
Now, the Brazilian government says, the Doha declaration means that it no longer has anything to fear from such complaints.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
After Sept. 11, value and price become the themes for promoting holiday shopping.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
AS retailers face their most challenging holiday shopping season in decades, they are striving to entice consumers into stores with campaigns playing up value without hurting their brand images by running schlocky ads that scream "Sale!"
 The struggle by retail chains simultaneously to meet short-term goals like salvaging the fourth quarter and long-term goals like reinforcing relationships with customers is evident in watching how holiday campaigns, now beginning to run, veer from brand-burnishing to a hard sell and back again; some companies, like Sears, Roebuck are trying to do both. 
 Getting consumers in a spending mood "is going to be tough," said Walter Levy, managing director for retail trends and positioning at Kurt Salmon Associates in New York. "Anybody who thinks otherwise is a fool."
"If I were a retailer today, I would look at my pricing instead of waiting for something not to sell," he added, "because some people, stuck with inventory, will go down and dirty right away to move the goods." 
Complicating the process is a need to make pitches more reflective of life after Sept. 11 by giving more prominence to emotional appeals centered on family, friendship, comfort and tradition. That can be difficult when an ad also has to promote sale prices on boom boxes, sweaters or power tools.
"You want to slam them over the head, but do it in a way that feels good," said David McLean, creative director at Banana Republic in San Francisco, a chain owned by Gap Inc. that is proceeding with plans for a low-key print and outdoor campaign, created by an in-house team, "with a good familiarity that feels appropriate right now."
While "at holiday we become a little more pointed about calling out certain products and product categories" like sweaters and scarves, Mr. McLean said, "we're walking a fine line to convey a product message while keeping our messages focused on relationships and warmth as appropriate to the season."
The compromise adopted by many retailers and agencies is to run ads shining a spotlight on particular merchandise, especially gift fodder, without including prices -- reserving offers, coupons and deals for brochures, catalogs, direct mail and fliers.
"I think it's going to be a tough holiday," said Michael James Leedy, chief marketing officer at American Eagle Outfitters in Warrendale, Pa., which specializes in casual apparel for teenagers and 20-somethings, "but it will depend on where you're positioned as a brand."
"Our main strength is image; that's what we're about," he added. "If you're approachable, affordable, attainable, you'll do fine." American Eagle is moving ahead with a brand-building television and print campaign created by an in-house team before Sept. 11, which carries the cozy theme "Get together"; at the same time, Mr. Leedy said, mailed ads are "focusing on driving traffic with offers tailored to different customers "
American Eagle's main competitor, Abercrombie & Fitch, scrapped its centerpiece holiday promotion, the winter edition of its quarterly "magalog," citing the inappropriateness of the racy content in these uncertain times. Instead, the company will decorate stores with brand-polishing posters and send out 750,000 copies of a catalog mixing price-and-item information with lifestyle photographs.
"We anticipate intense promotional pricing, earlier discounts and couponing, and price wars in the discount sector," said David Selby, senior vice president for marketing at Sears in Hoffman Estates, Ill. "We want to play to our strengths in driving profitable growth."
So starting Wednesday, Sears will run a humorous campaign mixing brand and price messages on TV and online and in magazines and movie theaters, which "balances our desire to position Sears as a retailer who understands your life," Mr. Selby said, "and one that has extraordinary value."
Work by one agency, the Chicago office of Young & Rubicam Advertising, part of the Young & Rubicam division of the WPP Group, is more image-oriented, while work by another agency, the Chicago office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, also owned by WPP, specifies that products like JVC camcorders will be on sale at half their regular prices.
"We don't scream the price and item," said Joe Sciarrotta, co-managing director and executive creative director at Ogilvy Chicago. "They're loud because the creative stops you" with surprising juxtapositions like showing a dog devouring a guest's coat at a party, which is followed by the words "Men's and women's leather outerwear, 50 percent off."
His counterpart at Y.& R. Chicago, Mark Figliulo, managing partner and chief creative officer, said: "It has to connect, it has to mean more than a price point, because there are a lot of price-point ads out there. How would you differentiate yourself in that sea of offerings?"
Another Gap Inc. division, Gap, hopes to make a connection with a simple campaign, focused on sweaters, created by Modernista in Boston and carrying the theme "Give your gift." Gap will make donations to charities on behalf of the celebrities appearing in the commercials and print ads, who include the singers Sheryl Crow and Alanis Morissette and the cast of "The Producers."
To help make the campaign less ethereal, the one publication chosen to carry the most print ads, 29 pages, is the December issue of Lucky, the new magazine devoted to shopping from the Conde Nast Publications division of Advance Publications.
"Gap chose to run a major image campaign in a shopping environment," said Alexandra W. Golinkin, publisher at Lucky. "No matter what page you pick, there is shopping."
One retailer embracing price-oriented ads is the Kmart Corporation. Kmart is running a campaign by the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/ Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group, depicting sales on specific products like Samsung DVD players and Sony PlayStation 2 video game systems; the lowered prices "are our gift to you," the commercials proclaim.
"It's not a pure branding campaign because it's not the right time right now for that," said Steven P. Feuling, senior vice president for marketing at Kmart in Troy, Mich.
"Before Sept. 11, we saw this was going to be a value Christmas because of issues with the economy," he added. "Now it's going to be an even bigger value Christmas for us."
What is in store from Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's largest retailer? Brand-building commercials to be introduced next week will present customers and employees "sharing their holiday stories" that are "reflective of what's going on with people right now," said Alicia Kriese, senior vice president and group account director at a Wal-Mart agency, GSD&M in Austin, Tex., part of Omnicom.
"Our insight is that our customers want even more of what Wal-Mart is in their lives in these uncertain times," she added.
The varied approaches make sense to Cary Silvers, vice president at Roper ASW in New York, the research company that is part of the NOP division of United Business Media, based on the results of consumer surveys.
"A lot of consumers are sitting on the fence in terms of confidence," Mr. Silvers said, "so the messaging is critical right now because you don't want to give consumers a reason not to come into the stores."
"In an economic downturn, brands that deliver on promises of quality and image should sustain themselves," he added, "but the ones that don't are in jeopardy."
