HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Blue Chips Up, but Cut in Economic Forecast Limits Gains

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Confident of an economic turnaround in 2002, investors bid blue-chip shares higher yesterday. But a scaled-down outlook for the nation's economy limited the advance, and profit taking caused a slight dip in technology stocks.
 Yesterday's mixture of modest gains and slim losses was understandable, given how Wall Street has been rallying for weeks. 
 Investors have been growing more optimistic that the economy will recover next year and are encouraged by signs that the United States has been successful in its retaliation in Afghanistan for the Sept. 11 attacks. But analysts have said the market's rallies are vulnerable until the turnaround becomes more apparent.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 48.78 points, or 0.5 percent, at 9,872.39. The Dow has gained 318 points in its three-day advance and is approaching 10,000, a level that has eluded it since Sept. 5, when it closed at 10,033.27.
The broader market closed fairly flat after advancing earlier. The Nasdaq composite index fell 2.62 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,900.57, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 1.03 points, or 0.1 percent, to 1,142.24. 
Analysts have been expecting investors to curtail their buying or to secure recent profits, particularly when reminded of the weak economy; that was the case yesterday when the International Monetary Fund downgraded its outlook for the nation's growth.
Updating its economic forecast to reflect the business fallout resulting from the terrorist attacks, the I.M.F. cut its estimate of United States growth in 2002 to 0.7 percent. That would be the weakest performance since the end of the last recession in 1991. Just a month ago, the I.M.F. forecast a 2.2 percent rate.
Analysts were not bothered by the I.M.F. downgrade.
"They are probably lagging in their process," A. C. Moore, chief investment strategist for Dunvegan Associates in Santa Barbara, Calif., said. "The market looks ahead, and I think those were thoughts that reflect the past and current situations as opposed to the future." 
Mr. Moore said the market had risen on indications, like stronger retail sales, that business was improving. The Commerce Department reported Wednesday that retail sales rose 7.1 percent in October, the biggest monthly increase on record, a sharp contrast to the 2.2 percent decline in sales in September.
Wall Street's winners came from a variety of areas yesterday. American Express rose 96 cents, to $34.39; McDonald's gained 82 cents, to $28.36; and Wal-Mart Stores advanced 72 cents, to $56.
Other companies rose on better-than-anticipated earnings results. Children's Place, a retailer, rose nearly 16 percent, or $4.33, to $32.14, after beating profit expectations by 6 cents a share.
Analysts said the possibility of lower oil prices was another positive for the economy, and it helped the market yesterday.
OPEC's most powerful member, Saudi Arabia, said the oil cartel would let crude prices fall if necessary as a way of pressing outside producers into cooperating with its plan to cut output. --------------------

Treasury Prices Tumble
(By Reuters)
Treasury bond prices plunged yesterday as flickerings of life in the economy dimmed hopes for more rate cuts from the Federal Reserve.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 2 points, to a price of 101 22/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.78 percent from 4.53 percent on Wednesday. 
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 3 10/32, to 102 2/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.24 percent from 5.02 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Environmentalists Concerned About State Plan for Borrowing 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
The Pataki administration is considering borrowing money to pay for some environmental programs that are usually financed through a special $150 million fund, stirring fears among environmentalists that the governor intends to raid the fund to help balance next year's budget.
 The Environmental Protection Fund was the only pot of money entirely left out of the final supplemental budget deal that legislative leaders and Gov. George E. Pataki hammered out last month. Established in 1993, the fund is paid for by a special tax on real estate transfers. By law, it can only be used for the purchase of parkland and other environmental programs. 
 But this year legislative leaders never reached agreement with the governor over how to spend the money, so the Assembly and Senate never voted to appropriate the money. After the September terrorist attack wreaked havoc on state revenues, leaders in both houses said the governor made it clear in private talks that he did not want to spend the fund this fiscal year.
Last Thursday, a senior aide to Mr. Pataki told a delegation of environmentalists that the administration had no intention of spending the $150 million this fiscal year, which ends on March 31. 
Instead, the aide, John Cahill, a former environmental commissioner, told the environmentalists that the administration might borrow about $60 million to pay for some of the fund's programs. That would leave most of the $150 million sitting in a bank account. Some environmentalists said they saw the proposal as a prelude to Mr. Pataki's asking the Legislature to let him use the fund to plug holes in next year's budget.
"We left the meeting feeling discouraged, to say the least," said Val Washington, the executive director of Environmental Advocates. "We don't want this year's Environmental Protection Fund raided, and that's what we are fighting for."
Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, the environmental committee chairman who sponsored the law setting up the fund, said Mr. Pataki had tarnished his record on the environment. "When I offered the law, it was to make sure the environment never played second fiddle as it had in the past," he said. "This is about the governor insisting the environment play second fiddle."
In an interview this week, Mr. Cahill said the governor had not yet decided whether to use the borrowing plan to finance the acquisition of parkland and other fund programs. Among other purposes, the grants would be used for spurring recycling, creating town parks, revitalizing waterfronts and studying pollutants in the Hudson River.
Mr. Cahill also said it was too early to say if the governor would seek legislative approval to use the fund to avert cuts to other parts of the state budget. Neither had the governor ruled the idea out, he said.
"There is no plan, but this is a fluid process," Mr. Cahill said. "There is no program in the state that will not be touched by the enormous problem the state faces in light of the aftermath of the World Trade Center attacks. We are looking at all our options." 
Budget officials say the state will lose as much as $9 billion in revenues over the next 18 months because of the terrorist attack's devastating effect on the state's economy.
Governor Pataki, who often cites Theodore Roosevelt as his hero, has earned very high marks, even from his critics, for his record on protecting wilderness and expanding parks, adding more than 300,000 acres during his time as governor. Under his tenure, the Environmental Protection Fund grew to $150 million from $25 million.
But his refusal to spend the money set aside this year has drawn fire not only from his Democratic opponents, like State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, but also from some of his staunchest friends among conservationists.
"This would represent a 180-degree turn from his past performance," said John F. Sheehan of the Adirondack Council. "That's troublesome for everyone."
Aides to the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican, said he would withhold judgment on using the fund for other purposes until it becomes clearer how far revenues will fall off. But the Democratic Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, said he still hoped to reach an agreement with the governor to spend the money in this fiscal year. "It is our intention to use it for what it was intended," he said.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Drop for Third Consecutive Week 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
The number of workers filing initial claims for state unemployment benefits dropped to the lowest level since mid-September, the government reported today, signaling that the job cuts after the terrorist attacks are abating.
 New jobless claims fell to 444,000 in the week that ended Saturday, the Labor Department said. It was the third consecutive weekly decline, the first time that has happened since July. 
 A separate report showed business inventories fell for an eighth consecutive month in September, the longest string since August 1982 to March 1983, when the economy was emerging from recession.
The reports, combined with a strong retail sales report on Wednesday, suggest that the economic slowdown may be nearing an end.
"Businesses keep cutting stocks, and there are fewer people lining up for unemployment benefits," said Chris Rupkey, senior financial economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi in New York. "Combine this with the huge rise in October sales and you have to believe that the worst may be over for the economy."
Still, while the pace of jobless claims is slowing, companies are not hiring. Total jobless benefit rolls rose to an 18-year high of 3.826 million in the week ended Nov. 3 as laid-off workers found that there were few new jobs available.
"If you're out of work, you're not finding a new job," even though "the pace of layoffs has clearly slowed after the tidal wave that Sept. 11 caused," said Steven Wood, chief economist with FinancialOxygen Inc. in Walnut Creek, Calif.
And while companies kept reducing stockpiles in September, sales plunged 2.8 percent. That pushed up the inventory-to-sales ratio, a measure of the time goods sit on shelves, to 1.45 months in September.
That is the highest ratio since September 1998 and follows a reading of 1.42 months in August.
Businesses have been cutting inventories all year. Stockpiles fell at an annual rate of $50.4 billion in the third quarter after declining $38.3 billion in the second quarter and $27.1 billion in the first three months of this year.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Dell Rebounds After a 2nd-Quarter Loss

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

 BODY:
Rebounding from a loss in the July quarter, the Dell Computer Corporation reported a third-quarter profit of $429 million yesterday. Its earnings fell by a third from the period a year ago but edged past Wall Street's estimates.
 Dell, the world's leading vendor of personal computers, which account for about half its business, continued to drive down its selling prices and take market share from competitors. Dell was the only major PC vendor to grow in the quarter that ended Sept. 30, analysts said. 
 But the company, based in Austin, Tex., is still fighting for a growing piece of a shrinking market. Dell predicted that it would sell about 5 percent more computers in the current quarter than in the last, outpacing the rest of the industry. But Dell said that revenue would improve only slightly over its third quarter, which ended Nov. 2, and that earnings would be flat, at 16 cents.
For the third quarter of its 2002 fiscal year, Dell posted net income of $429 million, or 16 cents a share, beating analysts' consensus estimates by a penny a share. Earnings declined 36 percent from the period a year ago, when Dell earned $674 million, or 25 cents a share.
Revenue of $7.47 billion surpassed consensus expectations by $150 million, declining 10 percent from the third quarter a year ago.
"We were the only major systems company to grow units year-on-year and sequentially in every product category," said James M. Schneider, Dell's chief financial officer. "Once again, we have demonstrated that Dell's business model is potent in all economic cycles."
Dell released its earnings after the markets closed. In regular trading, shares of Dell rose 23 cents, to $27.69. In after-hours trading, shares fell to $27.30.
Many analysts have predicted that uncertainty surrounding the proposed merger of Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer would drive customers to competitors like Dell, especially if their efforts to overcome Wall Street's skepticism distracted them from their day-to-day business.
Hewlett-Packard diffused some of the criticism Wednesday when it announced better-than-expected earnings, and revenue that exceeded most analysts' projections by about $1 billion. Hardware and software sales fell sharply, and its PC division continued to lose money despite improving sales of PC's for the home, but cost-saving programs helped earnings more than anticipated. 
Still, Dell executives said they had sold systems to customers fleeing those companies. Kevin B. Rollins, the president and chief operating officer, said in a conference call with reporters that his competitors were "a bit more entangled" in their internal operations. 
"Customers in that environment are a little nervous and, more often than not, going with Dell," Mr. Rollins said. 
Dell was coming off a difficult second quarter, when it posted a loss of $101 million, or 4 cents a share, largely because of charges related to job cuts, asset write-downs and factory closings. 
Despite slowing demand for PC's, Dell has steadily gained market share since the beginning of this year, rising to 26 percent of the United States market, from 20 percent. In preliminary figures released last month, the International Data Corporation, a market research firm, said worldwide PC sales in the third quarter declined 14 percent over the same period last year and 1 percent from the second quarter, in stark contrast to the 15 percent growth typically seen from the second quarter to the third. 
Sales of Dell's servers, storage systems and workstations, all high-powered corporate computers, rose 20 percent over the previous year, the company said.
Michael S. Dell, the chief executive, said Pentium 4 chips from Intel, the Windows XP operating system from Microsoft and new wireless networking products from several vendors would lead the industry to its next upgrade cycle beginning next spring or summer. 
By the end of the quarter, Windows XP was shipping in 46 percent of consumer PC's. Sixty-two percent of desktop computers were sold with Pentium 4 chips.
Mr. Dell estimated that 164 million PC's worldwide were more than three years old, and 450 million PC's contain chips running at less than 700 megahertz, about a third the speed of the fastest processors on the market today.
"We would expect that in the spring and in the summer, there is going to be a lot of upgrade activity going on among corporations," he said. "Certainly factors like the economic stimulus being debated right now would have some impact on that."
James D. Ragan, a senior equity analyst with Crowell, Weedon & Company, a Los Angeles brokerage firm, said Dell's aggressive price cuts, which drove average system prices last quarter down $50, to $1,800, were inflicting pain upon its competitors. He said Dell should reap the benefits in the future.
"If you believe we're going to get a meaningful recovery, that's certainly good news for Dell shareholders," Mr. Ragan said.

HEADLINE: Boon for U.S. in Cheaper Energy; 
OPEC Disunity May Prop Up Hard-Pressed Businesses

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
OPEC's problems could translate into substantial benefits for American business and consumers.
 With oil prices falling as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries fails to reach agreement with Russia and other oil producers outside the cartel, the United States is poised to receive a much needed lift from lower energy costs, analysts said. That relief, together with lower interest rates, is expected to improve the odds that the economy will emerge from its downturn sooner rather than later. 
 "The U.S. economy runs well on cheap oil and cheap money, and right now they're both cheap," said Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI/WEFA, an economic consulting firm. "So we can look at the economy improving next year." 
Oil prices, which were hovering at $30 a barrel as recently as early September, fell to $17.45 yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, raising the prospect of cheaper gas at the fuel pump and lower energy costs for a wide range of industries -- from struggling airlines and automakers to fertilizer producers and electric power generators.
No one is sure how long oil prices will remain this low or to what degree lower fuel prices will bolster the $10 trillion United States economy. But even though oil and gas drillers in the Southwest and Rocky Mountain states will take a hit, the overall effect on the United States economy should be positive, economists said.
Some of the effects may already be noticeable. The price of natural gas, which is used to heat homes and factories and to power manufacturing, has plummeted to about $2.30 per million British thermal units from about $10 a year ago, sharply reducing the cost of energy.
The sharp drop in oil prices in recent weeks, if it lasts, could generate an even greater benefit for consumers. Some economic models show that for every $1 decrease in the cost of a barrel of oil, American consumers gain about $5 billion in spending power. A drop from about $30 a barrel last year to about $20 a barrel over the next year would translate into about $50 billion in consumer spending power.
"That's roughly the size of the tax rebate, so that's a significant savings," said Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Economy.com, based in West Chester, Pa. "And that's just consumers; businesses could also save billions of dollars."
Since automobiles and light trucks consume nearly half of the oil sold in the United States, the biggest savings are expected to go to consumers, giving their pocketbooks a much needed injection of cash just in time for the holiday shopping season, economists said.
That would be a sharp turnaround after a year in which prices at the gas pump rose to $2.25 a gallon in some places. Rising diesel and jet fuel prices also hurt the airline industry even before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and forced several big package delivery companies, like FedEx and United Parcel Service, to impose fuel surcharges of 1 to 4 percent.
Only a few years ago, U.P.S. was spending about $700 million a year on fuel. Last year, the company's fuel costs climbed to about $930 million, according to Steve Holmes, a spokesman for the company in Atlanta.
In recent weeks, the price of gasoline in much of the country has fallen below $1.20 a gallon -- and it could be headed lower, oil industry experts say.
Paying less for gasoline or home heating fuel could aid consumer spending, economists say.
"That means we have more money to spend on other things, like going to movies, going out to restaurants and going shopping," said Ms. Latta of DRI/WEFA. "And if you can keep the consumer spending you can mitigate the effects of the slowing economy."
Among those companies that would benefit from lower oil prices are the airlines and trucking concerns, as well as chemical, metal and paper producers.
Some economists warn, though, that lower oil prices could eventually come back to bite the American economy because of weakening demand for United States products abroad.
"I think initially it's good for the U.S. economy, but it's not that clear over time," said James E. Glassman, a senior economist at J. P. Morgan. "It creates dislocation in emerging markets like Russia and the Middle East. When their oil revenues go down, their buying power goes down."
Some companies would suffer in the short run, including Exxon Mobil, Kerr-McGee, ChevronTexaco and other big oil companies. Some of the bigger diversified ones, which also refine and have chemical and other operations, are somewhat insulated, but just about every oil company should have a drop in earnings growth after two years of heavy consolidation and spectacular profit growth.
"The party is over," said Eugene Nowak, an oil industry analyst at ABN-Amro. "The companies have had some good times, but the third quarter started showing some weakness. Earnings will be down considerably in the fourth quarter."
Several oil analysts, however, said the industry never expected prices to stay above $25 a barrel for long. The companies knew these were extraordinarily good times, and many were careful not to overextend themselves, the analysts said. 
The oil companies have been trimming back their costs, analysts said, in anticipation of a slowdown. There will still be profits in the next few quarters, but they will not be as fat.
"Are we looking at an industry in trouble? Absolutely not," said Mark Flannery, an oil analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston. "We're looking at an industry that's going to earn a lot less money, but the last two years we've had a bonanza."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES; 
OIL PRICES TUMBLE TO A 2-YEAR LOW

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE with NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
Oil prices went into free fall today as Russia, the world's biggest oil exporter after Saudi Arabia, rejected a challenge from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries to stabilize prices by sharply cutting production.
 Prices in New York dropped 11.6 percent, to $17.45 a barrel, their lowest level in more than two years. Crude oil prices have fallen 21 percent this week. 
 Analysts said the recession-bound economy of the United States would receive a much-needed lift from plummeting energy costs, with consumers freed to spend more on holiday purchases and with beleaguered airlines and cargo haulers bearing one less burden. Page C1. 
Experts added that Russia's stance reflected both the government's limited control over Russian oil companies and Moscow's post-Sept. 11 collaboration with the West. Russia and the United States, they added, share OPEC's concerns that prices might fall too far and shake regimes whose stability is especially critical to the war on terrorism.
OPEC leaders acknowledged that their unexpected decision on Wednesday not to reduce oil production unless other major exporters did the same amounted to the declaration of a price war.
The cartel's gamble is that falling oil prices will persuade its competitors to blink and join in production cuts. OPEC said it expected Norway and Mexico, the second- and third-largest producers outside the group, to come around.
But Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov of Russia said today during an official visit to Spain that his country would resist "any big reductions" beyond the token reduction of 30,000 barrels a day that it promised earlier in the week.
In a telephone interview from Spain, Aleksei Volin, the deputy head of the Russian government's administration, explained that deeper cuts could endanger Russia's obligations to its customers in Europe, where it sends most of its oil exports. 
OPEC leaders acknowledge that Russia has become the market's linchpin. "We cannot have cuts without Russia," Adil Khalid al-Subih, Kuwait's oil minister, said in an interview in Vienna. "We will not support any cuts without a significant contribution from non-OPEC nations. They know exactly what they are doing. It is not a matter of convincing them."
The question that will loom larger each day, OPEC officials and industry experts said, is who will surrender first, as prices enter a tailspin and ravage economies highly dependent on oil revenues. 
"It's a game of chicken," said Roger Diwan, managing director at the Petroleum Finance Company, a consulting group in Washington. "OPEC wants to scare Russia and the Russian oil companies. They want to show that with low oil prices, everybody will hurt."
To bolster oil prices in a slowing global economy, OPEC has pared its daily output three times this year for a total of 3.5 million barrels, or 13 percent. But the cartel's rivals have responded by increasing their production, grabbing market share and cashing in on prices that have averaged more than $25 a barrel.
OPEC's 10 voting members have said that they will no longer tolerate that situation. They proposed on Wednesday that OPEC would reduce output by a further 1.5 million barrels a day as of Jan. 1, if non-OPEC producers cut by a total of 500,000 barrels a day. 
For Russia, the decision to defy OPEC may be less a national energy strategy and more an effort to avoid confrontation with the country's powerful oil companies. Under Russian law, the government has some control over oil exports. But unlike the situations in Mexico and Norway, in Russia most of the industry is in private hands and the government has been hesitant to force companies to cut.
Some Russian companies that have worked the hardest to increase production and restore an industry that had collapsed with the fall of the Soviet Union are adamantly opposed to cuts. They would force layoffs, executives argue, and waste expensive new technology bought over the last three years.
"If they say we have to cut, we will cut, but I'll do everything I can to show it is unreasonable," Mikhail Khodorkovsky, chief executive of Yukos, Russia's second-largest oil producer, said today at a news conference in Moscow.
Still, Russia's warming relations with the United States since Sept. 11 may also be playing a role in its oil policy. President Vladimir V. Putin reiterated last month that Russia could serve the West as an alternative source of energy to a destabilized Middle East. 
Mr. Khodorkovsky echoed that theme today. "We can propose a real partnership with the West in creating a stable market for oil," he said. "That window of opportunity is today."
Other Russian oil companies indicated, however, that there was room for compromise with OPEC, in part because a further slide in oil prices -- to $15 a barrel or less -- would force the layoffs or cutbacks in exploration and production that they are trying to avoid.
Lukoil, its biggest producer, said the Russian oil industry could withstand a cut of 200,000 to 300,000 barrels a day. The third-largest producer, Tyumen Oil, said it would begin trimming its investment program if prices fell below $17 a barrel.
One high-level OPEC official said today that the United States government would be concerned, too, if prices fell below about $15 a barrel. The Americans, he said, understand that as Persian Gulf nations lose oil revenue, the welfare states they support come under stress. That, he said, could pose more of a threat to their stability than bombing raids in Afghanistan that are unpopular among many Arab citizens. 
Dr. Subih, the Kuwait oil minister, told reporters in Vienna that prices could fall to $10 a barrel -- a level not flirted with since late 1998 -- if non-OPEC producers did not join the cartel in cutting production. A price war, he acknowledged, could be damaging to OPEC members, whose economies are lopsidedly reliant on oil revenue. 
But the cartel is betting that Russia, too, will feel the pain. Oil is at the heart of Russia's economy; together with natural gas, it makes up half of the country's earnings from exports. The Moscow government's federal budget is balanced delicately on an oil price of about $20. This year's budget surplus provides a cushion, but a long period of low prices could mean difficult spending cuts in 2003, when foreign debt payments of about $19 billion come due.
"For the next year their position is secure; the question is the year 2003," said Aleksei Zabotkine, chief economist at the United Financial Group, an investment bank based in Moscow. "If the oil price doesn't reverse itself, then we will see a rather unpleasant situation."
Even so, Russia has never followed through on past promises to cut oil exports, and most analysts here do not expect this time to be different.
"Russia wants to appease OPEC, but it will not do anything concrete," said Dmitri Avdeev, an oil analyst at United Financial. "Exports might fall because of seasonal factors, but production will continue to rise."

HEADLINE: Deal Brings Indian Casino in the Catskills Closer to Reality 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
Gambling in the Catskills moved a step closer to reality yesterday, as the St. Regis Mohawk Indian tribe signed an agreement with the world's largest gambling company to build and run a casino at the venerable Kutsher's Country Club in Monticello.
 Progress toward a Mohawk casino has accelerated greatly, after moving in fits and starts since the mid-1990's. Last month, the State Legislature approved up to six Indian casinos in New York, including three in the Catskills and three in western New York. 
 Those projects still face expected legal challenges from casino opponents that could delay work for years, but most parties were treating yesterday's development as a milestone. 
Other important steps remain, including federal approval of the agreement and the location, a compact between the Mohawks and Gov. George E. Pataki and approval from the National Indian Gaming Commission, an arm of the Department of the Interior.
But people involved in those processes say that they expect them to go fairly smoothly, and that the only significant obstacles left are the legal challenges. "We're pretty optimistic that if the timetable goes reasonably as we expect, we should be able to break ground next year," said Thomas E. Gallagher, chairman and chief executive of Park Place Entertainment, the Mohawks' partner. "We expect to be open sometime in 2004."
The $500 million project, including a 750-room hotel, would represent a dramatic turnabout in the region's long-sagging economic fortunes.
The Pataki administration wants the state to receive up to 25 percent of gross profits from slot machines, the largest source of profits in a casino. The Mohawks and Park Place have already agreed to pay $15 million a year to Sullivan County.
The deal signed yesterday provides that after those payments, 70 percent of casino profits would go to the tribe and 30 percent to Park Place. 
The governor's office is trying to negotiate compacts simultaneously with the Mohawks and the Seneca Nation of Indians.
A framework agreement reached earlier this year with the Senecas, and the bill approved by the Legislature, call for the Senecas to have a casino in Niagara Falls, one in Buffalo and one at an undetermined location in western New York.
But the Seneca compact is not as far along as the Mohawks', and has been complicated by tribal politics. The Senecas have not chosen a developer or specific sites, and they have been reluctant about a compact provision making it easy for casino workers to unionize, a condition imposed by the state.
Some Seneca factions oppose gambling, while others say the leaders are not driving a hard enough bargain with the state. The deal is subject to a tribal referendum.
A 1988 federal law allows states and tribes to enter into gambling compacts. Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo negotiated two such compacts, for the Mohawks' casino in Hogansburg, in northern New York, on the Akwesasne reservation near the Canadian border; and for the Oneida Nation's Turning Stone Casino on its reservation in central New York, near Utica. The state receives no revenue from them.
Federal law also allows for Indian casinos situated away from reservations, on land held "in trust" for the tribe. That provision has been used successfully just once, in Wisconsin, and the Mohawks and Senecas are attempting to use it again.
A state court ruled early this year that an off-reservation casino required the Legislature's approval. The Department of the Interior must give special clearance for a casino away from tribal lands, but indications are that that will not be a serious obstacle.
